fields.headline: Barnsley 2 - 4 Ipswich
fields.trailText: Barnsley: Miller, Curtis, Morgan, Chettle, Brown, Barnard, Tinkler, Hignett, Appleby, Dyer, Shipperley. Subs: Sheron, Hristov, Jones, Eaden, Thomas.
fields.body:
Barnsley: Miller, Curtis, Morgan, Chettle, Brown, Barnard, Tinkler, Hignett, Appleby, Dyer, Shipperley. Subs: Sheron, Hristov, Jones, Eaden, Thomas.

Ipswich: R. Wright, Croft, McGreal, Mowbray, Venus, Clapham, Holland, Magilton, J. Wright, Johnson, Stewart. Subs: Wilnis, Naylor, Brown, Reuser, Branagan.

Referee: T Heilbron (Newton Aycliffe)

1 minute: Ipswich kick-off the last play-off final under the Twin Towers. Immediately they pump the ball forward and Johnson goes in heavily on Barnsley keeper, Miller fouling him in the process. Johnson falls hard but he looks OK.

3 Ipswich are pressing Barnsley back. By contrast Barnsley look nervous and Miller kicks a goal kick straight into touch.

5 GOAL! Hignett drifts into space and lets fly with an absolute screamer from 32 yards. The ball crashes against the bar, hits Wright's arm and goes in. Wright is slightly off his line but he has no chance with the goal.

8 Barnsley look full of confidence now. Hignett is finding space and Tinkler is winning the tackles in midfield.

9 Ipswich have their first chance of the match. The ball drops to Venus 20 yards out but he pulls his shot wide of the post.

12 Ipswich seem to have recovered from their shaky spell after the goal. Croft tackles Hignett at half-way and storms down the line. But his cross is headed clear.

14 Dyer is looking dangerous every time he gets the ball. The ball drops to Shipperley about 30 yards out. Nobody tackles him and he fires in a low shot just inside the post which Wright comfortably saves.

16 Now it's Ipswich's turn to attack. Twice they play lovely passing moves only for the final ball into the box to let them down. The game is already looking like it could be another classic play-off final.

18 Tinkler is tackled by J. Wright and goes down with a toe problem. He needs treatment. Chettle also injured after a clash of heads but after a quick dab of the sponge he looks OK.

20 Play restarts. Tinkler is back on. The action is now end to end. Miller plucks a difficult cross out of thin air, and immediately releases the ball. It's quickly played through to Dyer, who looks like he could be in until he's tackled at the last second.

22 Johnson is substituted for Ipswich with a calf injury. He obviously hasn't recovered from his silly challenge on Miller in the first minute. Naylor replaces him.

25 A great passage of Barnsley passing play stretches Ipswich and when ball is played through to Hignett about 25 yards out nobody is near him. He has time to look up before trying a curler which is only narrowly wide of the post - with Wright beaten.

27 The ball drops to Holland 20 yards out. His fierce shot is blocked by Chettle. Ipswich get a corner.

28 GOAL! From the corner the ball is played to Magilton. He crosses it in to the back post where it is headed powerfully home by 36-year-old Tony Mowbray in his first appearance at Wembley. Miller gets a hand on it but he can't keep it out.

31 Ipswich have the initiative and get their third corner in three minutes. The ball drops to Magilton but his cross is blocked. Ipswich get another corner.

33 Ipswich storm forward. The ball is played via Naylor to Holland and he's clean through in a central position about 20 yards out. But his shot is straight at the keeper and Brown desperately clears.

35 It's all Ipswich at the moment. They are playing all the football and doing all the attacking. Barnsley are encamped in their half. Is a second goal imminent?

37 Naylor, who has looked sharp since he's come on, runs down the left and fires a low cross which is well taken by Miller.

39 Ipswich get yet another corner when Naylor's shot is blocked by Appleby. But Magilton's kick is easily cleared and Barnsley play the ball back to Miller to get a rest.

41 Barnsley at last venture into Ipswich's half and earn a free-kick on the on touchline about 35 yards out when Dyer is fouled. But Barnard's cross is well taken by Wright.

44 Magilton again finds space and glides a cross onto the head of Holland. But is header is tame and goes well wide.

45 PENALTY!!! Wright brings Hignett down. It's a needless challenge - Hignett is going to get the ball but it's to the side and there's no real danger. Darren Barnard steps up to take it....

45 AND IT'S SAVED!!! Bernard fires the shot to Wright's right, but it's too close to the keeper and Wright pushes it away.

HALF TIME

48 After a scrappy opening couple of minutes, Dyer is released out wide by Barnard. He holds the ball up well and tries to return the pass but the ball is intercepted.

49 The game erupts into life again. First Holland shoots wide after Magilton's cross is headed down by Naylor. Then Barnsley break, and Dyer and Hignett exchange a one-two. But Dyer can only dribble a shot from Hignett's well judged dink straight into Wright's arms.

51 GOAL! Ipswich are ahead. A long ball is flicked on by Stewart straight into Naylor's path. He waits for Miller to come before deftly flicking it past him from 15 yards.

52 Naylor takes his top off in celebration and is booked.

55 Ipswich are now completely dominant. Once again the ball breaks to the substitute Naylor, who is having a storming game. He scampers down the line and fires in a low cross. For some reason Brown makes a pigs ear of clearing it, but J.Wright hits his shot wide.

57GOAL!!! Ipswich are 3-1 ahead. Great work again from Naylor, who lays it out wide. Clapham immediately whips in a pin-point cross to Stewart who gets ahead of two defenders to smash an unstoppable header home from 8 yards.

59 Barnsley almost pull one back when a long ball is pumped through to Dyer. But his overhead kick flashes just wide.

60 Barnsley substitution: Thomas replaces the ineffectual Tinkler.

62 Ipswich almost score again when another Magilton corner is met by Mowbray. But his header - from only just outside the six-yard box - goes narrowly wide. Could they rue all these missed chances?

64 Barnsley substitution: Hristov replaces Dyer, who can consider himself slightly unlucky. He's tried hard and worked his socks off.

66 Hristov almost makes an immediate impact, breaking into the penalty area and getting set to release a shot. But Mowbray makes a superb tackle.

69 Barnard drifts into space about 30 yards out and gets the ball played through. He looks up and fizzes in a smart left-footed shot which goes just wide. It's the first sign of attacking life for the South Yorkshire team for the past ten minutes.

71 Barnsley subsititution: Eaden replaces Curtis.

72 Magilton is fouled just outside the box. It's about 22 yards out and slightly right of the goal. But Venus's low shot crashes off the wall and Barnsley clear.

74 Ipswich nearly go 4-1 ahead when Mowbray's long ball finds Naylor completely clear. He controls it awkwardly and tries to loop it over Miller - but only succeeds in scooping it straight into his hands.

77 A superb four pass move opens up the Ipswich defence and Shipperley has a great shooting chance about 20 yards out. But his snap shot is too close to Wright.

77 ANOTHER BARNSLEY PENALTY! The ball is played long to Thomas. But as the former Palace man tries to scoop it over Mowbray's head, he is caught by the Ipswich defender's trailing leg. Hignett runs up to take it...

78 AND HE SCORES!!! Hignett dispatches his shot right into the top corner, to set up an enthralling last 12 minutes! Barnsley are back in it!

80 Ipswich, who have looked so confident for the entire second half are now looking decidedly edgy. And Barnsley are throwing everybody forward. Hignett has a shot blocked but Dave Bassett's men are now encamped in the Ipswich half - and are unlucky not to score when Nicky Eaden's cross flashes across the six yard box but nobody can get a foot onto it.

83 Ipswich substitution: Reuser replaces Stewart

84 What a save!!! Richard Wright stops Hristov's point-blank header to keep Barnsley out. Hristov was only about eight yards out, in a central position, but he aimed his header much too close to Wright.

86 Barnsley get a free kick on the angle of the box. The ball is played in by Barnard and it pinballs around for about ten seconds before Wright manages to catch it. Ipswich look on the ropes - but do Barnsley have enought time to take advantage?

88 Ipswich have a penalty appeal turned down when Reuser falls down in the box.

89 Ipswich substitution: There's a delay in the play when Jermaine Wright goes down injured. The Barnsley fans are booing - they think it's time wasting, but Wright is replaced by Wilnis.

90 IPSWICH ARE 4-2 AHEAD!!! Barnsley are throwing everybody forward but when they lose it midfield, the ball is passed through to Reuser. He runs for about 50 yards, out-pacing the despairing Brown before drilling it high into the top corner. Ipswich must be in the Premiership now!

95 FULL TIME - Ipswich are in the Premiership after yet another superb Wembley play-off final.

fields.headline: The Music Programme
fields.standfirst:
*
Linbury Studio, London
fields.trailText: The contest for the worst new opera I had ever seen was a close-run thing until now: there was a handful of contenders and it was difficult to choose between them. But Roxanna Panufnik's The Music Programme, receiving its British premiere in the Covent Garden Festival, takes the title by a mile.
fields.body:
The contest for the worst new opera I had ever seen was a close-run thing until now: there was a handful of contenders and it was difficult to choose between them. But Roxanna Panufnik's The Music Programme, receiving its British premiere in the Covent Garden Festival, takes the title by a mile.

It is hard to know where to begin with this farrago. Perhaps with the libretto, compiled by Paul Micou from his (reportedly rather good) novel of the same name, which makes incomprehensible what seems on paper a straightforward scenario. It concerns a UN-funded music camp in a fictional African country that is being investigated by a US envoy. The characters are paper-thin, most of them scarcely credible and their motivations obscure; the words are leaden. The staging, by Krzysztof Warlikowski for Teatr Wielki of the Polish National Opera, which gave the world premiere, doesn't help, and neither does the Anglo-Polish cast, which fails to get even a quarter of the words across - a fatal flaw in what purports to be a comic opera.

Then there's the score, most of it reliant upon other composers, such as Bach, Mozart, Ligeti, Sondheim and Maxwell Davies (the borrowing from Eight Songs for a Mad King is gobsmackingly brazen). I doubt, however, that anyone would want to lay claim to the badly stressed vocal lines, winsome dance music and stretches of scruffy ostinato, all orchestrated in a lumpish way.

It lasts 75 minutes, and seems longer than Parsifal (which is a lot funnier). There are interminable stretches of orchestral tuning and taped dolphin sounds (don't ask me why), and some irritating byplay between the orchestra and the conductor, Wojciech Michniewski, who is required to wear a silly hat for most of the performance. "What's the point of The Music Programme?" asks a gushing article about Panufnik in the "souvenir" programme. Quite.

fields.headline: Vurt: the Remix
fields.standfirst:
***
Contact, Manchester
fields.trailText:
***
Contact, Manchester
fields.body:
Jeff Noon's stage adaptation of his award-winning sci-fi novel is not always coherent, is not helped by the fact that it is often inaudible, and, at almost three hours, is a little self-indulgent. But it is also a stylish and very watchable slice of youth culture theatre that has all the dry ice, bright lights, big sounds and clubbing atmosphere you associate with this kind of theatre, plus a strong narrative and characters with real inner lives.

In a Manchester of the future where pure humans live uneasily side by side with dog people and half-human, half-robot types, the Stash riders are a group of friends, led by the manipulative, dishonest, bullying Beetle, whose idea of a good time is to get "all feathered up". One lick of a feather, some of which are so dangerous they have been made illegal, and you are transported to another consciousness, a dreamworld known at its most extreme as the Vurt, where the Gamecat rules and the game can be a peach or turn really nasty. Des, sister and more to the fragile, damaged Scribble, took a curious yellow feather and never came back, trapped forever in her dreams in the Vurt. The friends, meanwhile, are left with an alien thing in her place, a Vurt creature that they lug about with them.

Scribble's attempts to retrieve Des from the Vurt form the backbone of a story that has an edgy, wired feel, and that succeeds in creating a tangible sense of real and alternate worlds, both equally weird. The whole piece is also touched by an ineffable sadness, a feeling of innocence lost.

Noon's play captures all the shimmery, shivery excitement of drugs and altered states, but also the undercurrent of violence, and points up the emptiness of a life lived constantly somewhere else. Liam Steele's production is at times more show than substance, but it never fails to provide that adrenalin rush of excitement.

 To June 17. Box office: 0161 274 0600.

fields.headline: Norma
fields.standfirst:
***
Royal Opera House, London
fields.trailText:
***
Royal Opera House, London
fields.body:
Opera demands movement as well as music, and concert performances of operatic works, bereft of the drama that inspired the composer, can be a lame affair. The Royal Opera's concert performance of Bellini's Norma grew in confidence as the evening wore on, and by the end there was a sense that the performers to whom the audience were listening were perhaps worth watching as well.

For this concert the orchestra was in the pit, leaving the singers with a vast stage to fill. The chorus filed on and off for their numbers; the principals (a band of druids and Romans in evening gowns and white tie), sang without scores and acted, for the most part modestly, in character. Drawings of mysterious forest and cave settings (sketches for scenery used for a previous production by Pier Luigi Pizzi) were projected on to a screen by way of backdrop.

Performances like this, with no expensive sets or costumes, are much cheaper to present than staged opera; there were odd moments that suggested rehearsal time might have been sacrificed as well. Some of the sudden dynamic changes in the overture surprised the orchestra more than the audience, and while the chorus sang vigorously, there were some scrappy entries.

The principals, as one would expect, were more polished. Suzanne Mentzer was a rich, expressive Adalgisa; Franco Farina a robust, full-toned Pollione. His delivery was disciplined rather than showy, making no exaggerated attempts to hog the limelight - not that there was much left up for grabs once the Romanian-born Nelly Miricioiu swept onto the stage. The grande dame's performance began rather inauspiciously. Her initial, angry declamations had a harsh percussive start to each note; during her aria Casta Diva there appeared to be no communication between her and the rest of the ensemble, despite the best efforts of conductor Paul Wynne Griffiths, whose beat was left floundering whenever Miricioiu decided to linger on a particular phrase.

But, as we heard to better advantage in later scenes, Miricioiu possesses a voice that can travel effortlessly to all corners of the theatre, even in a beautifully soft pianissimo. She also has the bearing of a star, ensuring that the final curtain was followed by scenes of unashamed diva-worship.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 'Thursday evening is always the best night of the week," says Katie Nesling, a picture researcher at Eaglemoss Publications, a company that specialises in producing "partworks", or serialised magazines. "The picture meeting on Thursday afternoon is the deadline for each issue - by then I must have a choice of photos for each part of the magazine - and once the decision has been made on which photos are the best, I can relax until it all starts again the following week."
fields.body:
'Thursday evening is always the best night of the week," says Katie Nesling, a picture researcher at Eaglemoss Publications, a company that specialises in producing "partworks", or serialised magazines. "The picture meeting on Thursday afternoon is the deadline for each issue - by then I must have a choice of photos for each part of the magazine - and once the decision has been made on which photos are the best, I can relax until it all starts again the following week."

Most partworks published by Eaglemoss are weekly titles, such as Techno Quest or Good Cooking with Gary Rhodes, which means that Nesling works on more than one issue at once. "Every Monday there is a picture planning meeting, where we sit down with the editors and artwork designers and work out what pictures are needed for the issue. That meeting usually refers to the issue due to be published in four weeks' time, so we generally have a month to sort out the pictures."

Sometimes finding the right images is very straightforward. "You come away from the meeting with a list of pictures you require and it can be as simple as sending that list on to a library which will come back to you with the photos."

At other times, things can become more complicated. "If you're working on a specialist title such as Techno Quest, which is about science and technology for children, it can be harder to track down pictures. Often you end up dealing with specialist associations or organisations which don't charge for the pictures but which may not be so reliable."

"I think it's important to have a structured way of working, particularly because I am dealing with four titles at once," she says. "I tend to make all my phone calls in a block, usually between 11 and 12 in the morning, when I'm fairly sure people will be at their desks. Chasing people can be tiresome but it's also important - it's easy to call up several different picture libraries or associations and then assume the photos will appear, but that's not always the case. You have to keep tabs on what's going on. If you're two weeks into researching for an issue and you have no pictures, the pressure starts to mount."

"The worst thing you can do in this situation is keep quiet and hope someone comes back with the goods. I will go and talk to the person writing the article or column and discuss what other ideas might work. You know where you are, and what date things have to be ready by. My deadline is Thursday afternoon and I try to ensure everything is tied up with that particular issue at least two days earlier. If you're constantly dealing with deadlines, the only way not to get stressed is to stay one step ahead of the game."

fields.headline: He shoots, he doesn't score
fields.trailText: Frank Skinner last night made his first television appearance since quitting the BBC and joining ITV in a multi-million pound deal. There was only one way to describe it: a shambles.
fields.body:
Frank Skinner last night made his first television appearance since quitting the BBC and joining ITV in a multi-million pound deal. There was only one way to describe it: a shambles.

A year ago Skinner was one of the jewels in the BBC's crown. His late-night chat show was attracting 10m viewers and endless free publicity, particularly after a shambolic appearance by "It girl" Tara Palmer-Tomkinson.

Then money got in the way. Skinner's manager allegedly demanded £20m for a five-year deal, the BBC rejected this as "ridiculous" and Skinner signed to ITV for a seven-figure sum. His departure, shortly after Des Lynam's defection, was seen as another example of the BBC's inability to hold on to talent.

Last night was Skinner's first TV appearance since, a chance to remind us what a coup ITV had pulled off.

Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned was an attempt to recreate the crowd-pleasing formula that Skinner and David Baddiel had perfected in Fantasy Football League: two blokes on a sofa, shooting the breeze. The twist was that this time soccer would be out of bounds, and the audience would choose the subjects for discussion. This would be the chat show equivalent of a comedy improvisation night.

It should have worked: the duo tested the formula successfully on stage at last year's Edinburgh festival. Yet on TV they never got into their stride, with one limp anecdote and off-colour interruption following another, punctuated by self-conscious remarks like "I thought it would be funnier than this" and, contrary to all the promises, several references to football. For the first time, these two TV naturals seemed terrified by the cameras.

The audience seemed just as uninspired; the whole thing recalled An Audience With... , but without any of the stars, on or off stage.

The show would have been a total disaster if yesterday had not been Baddiel's birthday, which gave Skinner a chance to present him with a card inscribed "If you're reading this out on air, we must be getting desperate" (all too true).

The present, a gold-plated plaster cast supposedly of Robert DeNiro's genitals, let them fill a few minutes telling the story of how it had been obtained and commenting on the size of the scrotum. This may not have been rehearsed, but it was hardly the "high-risk, challenging, genre-creating television" that we'd been promised.

fields.headline: Working and watching hard
fields.standfirst:
The British work record hours, but still find time to be couch potatoes, says Bill Saunders
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is a source of slightly masochistic national pride that the British, so we are told, work the longest hours in Europe. So it may come as a surprise to learn that Britain has almost as many couch potatoes as it does workaholics.
fields.body:
It is a source of slightly masochistic national pride that the British, so we are told, work the longest hours in Europe. The Germans may think of themselves as models of quiet efficiency, but while the Spanish and Italians are tucking into bread and olives, then retiring for a couple of hours' siesta, we Brits like to think we are the only nation to scoff a sandwich at our desks, tethered to the computer keyboard.

So it may come as a surprise to learn that Britain has almost as many couch potatoes as it does workaholics. A third of the population, according to a new survey, spend more than 36 hours a week at work, but almost as many admitted to spending the same amount of time slumped in front of the telly. National stereotypes can be misleading, and in Britain, it would appear, Jim Royle and his telly-addict family are more common than we might like to think.

The notion of Britain as a nation of dedicated workers is just one of the well-established workplace assumptions given a good shake by the survey, conducted on behalf of the Alliance & Leicester. Take the much-trumpeted feminisation of the workplace, for example. Certainly women are working longer hours and at higher levels than ever before. But men are still putting in the longest hours: more than half of working men say they put in more than 36 hours a week, compared to only a fifth of all women.

And what about the concept of the "work-rich/time-poor"? Received wisdom holds that it is City high-flyers for whom long hours are a sign of dedication and an almost competitive office status symbol. Consequently it is assumed to be those on low incomes who are spending their days in front of the telly. But this stereotype proves equally misleading. On average it is members of social stratum C2, semi-skilled and clerical workers, who work the longest hours.

The Alliance and Leicester aimed to measure how much time people spend sorting out their finances. It worked out at a respectable two hours per week going to the bank or making investment decisions. The company, unsurprisingly, would prefer that we took a bit longer paying the bills and rather less watching EastEnders, and declared the figures on TV watching "alarming".

But it is hardly surprising if we slump in front of the box when we finally get home, considering the amount of time we spend getting there. Of those in full-time work, more than a third estimate they spend at least 26 hours a week travelling to work. Britain's most travelled workers, unsurprisingly, are to be found in the south east commuter belt. In comparison, the lucky residents of rural East Anglia spend very little time getting to and from work.

One of the most surprising findings of the survey related to internet usage. We may think Britain is now a nation of internet junkies, but the study found that use of the net is actually very low: only 14% say they spend an hour or more online each week. But the tide on remote working does seem to be turning. One in eight full-time workers say they spend no time at all on the daily commute, suggesting that a sizeable proportion are now teleworking from home. Let's hope they are not watching Richard and Judy instead.

fields.headline: T-Online may make Freeserve bid
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Freeserve, Britain's leading internet service provider (ISP), are likely to regain lost ground tomorrow amid speculation that Germany's T-Online is preparing a bid for the business.
fields.body:
Shares in Freeserve, Britain's leading internet service provider (ISP), are likely to regain lost ground tomorrow amid speculation that Germany's T-Online is preparing a bid for the business.

T-Online, the ISP spun off from Deutsche Telekom last month, is reported to be preparing a £6bn offer. It hopes to pre-empt any rival bids from the likes of cable companies NTL and Telewest, which have been cited as potential buyers.

Interest was ignited after Dixons, the high street electrical chain which founded Freeserve less than two years ago, appointed investment bank Goldman Sachs to review its holding in Freeserve, a move widely interpreted as signalling a sell-off.

Dixons is able to sell half its 80% stake in Freeserve from June 27 when the company presents its annual results.

Freeserve's management is said to be resistant to a sale to T-Online, fearing the company would be subsumed within the larger group. T-Online, which is believed to have first ap proached Dixons earlier this year, has 4.9m subscribers. Freeserve has just under 2m.

It is suggested that T-Online would be prepared to offer 600p to 650p a share, representing a large premium on Friday's closing price of 392p.

Freeserve shares reached a high of 920p in March but tumbled after a clutch of rivals announced the launch of unmetered internet access. It has also been affected by the sell-off of hi-tech stocks.

A deal between T-Online and Freeserve would be the latest in a rapidly consolidating internet industry. Earlier this month Spain's Terra Networks agreed to pay $12.5bn (£8.4) for US portal Lycos.

 Nina Brink, the founder and former chairwoman of the pan-European ISP World Online, said she was not warned by her advisers, ABN Amro and Goldman Sachs, that selling her World Online shares just before a stock market launch would send a negative message to investors.

webTitle: Commerzbank rushes to fill Jupiter void

fields.headline: Commerzbank rushes to fill Jupiter void
fields.standfirst:
Departures force second charm offensive

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Commerzbank was last night putting together a hastily arranged executive committee to run Jupiter, one of Britain's most successful fund management companies, after the sudden departure of a number of top executives.
fields.body:
Commerzbank was last night putting together a hastily arranged executive committee to run Jupiter, one of Britain's most successful fund management companies, after the sudden departure of a number of top executives.

In an attempt to prevent the loss of crucial fund management business, the German bank is thought to have worked on a contingency plan which would spread management control of the business among a wider range of employees, while also allowing Frankfurt to exercise additional influence.

Among those reported to have left Jupiter, bought by the German bank five years ago, is John Duffield, the chairman and founder of the group, which manages funds worth approximately £14bn.

Until reports of their sudden departures this weekend, Jupiter - which has a number of high-profile City figures on its payroll, including Edward Bonham-Carter, the brother of actress Helena Bonham-Carter - was regarded as one of the best examples of how to manage a takeover of a fund management operation.

This comes at a time when Perpetual, its closest rival, has been forced to admit it has received takeover approaches, a sales process which might be derailed by the apparent strife within Jupiter.

The unconfirmed departures follow the apparent break down on Friday of intense discussions between the senior staff at Jupiter and Commerzbank, which took full control of the fund management group at the start of the year.

Until then Commerzbank, itself under pressure in Germany from shareholders, had owned 75% of the business with the remainder being held by the fund management team.

Negotiations over a new pay and bonus structure for the fund managers had been taking place between multi-millionaire Mr Duffield and Commerzbank since the start of the year, when the bank took full control and reported to have paid out £500m to the fund managers.

Mr Duffield is said to have received £175m for his stake, which was based on a performance-related deal.

The German bank is expected to try to move quickly to reassure investors in its individual savings accounts and personal equity plans, as well as major institutional investors, for fear of losing business from them. It will be the second charm offensive by the group this year after the decision by star fund manager William Littlewood to leave his job for health reasons.

Industry sources suggested last night that in addition to trying to promote an impression of stability at the fund management group, Commerzbank would also be concerned about any move by Mr Duffield, one of the best-known fund managers in the City, to set up a rival operation.

The shake-out at Jupiter, which according to one report involved the departure of eight of its top nine directors, comes at a difficult time for Commerzbank, which is under pressure in its domestic market where speculation about takeovers and mergers is rife following the sudden collapse of the marriage between Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank last month.

Mr Duffield could not be contacted last night, while officials for Jupiter and Commerzbank did not return telephone calls.

fields.headline: We will survive
fields.standfirst:
Public Enemy
New Trinity, Bristol
****
fields.trailText:
Public Enemy
New Trinity, Bristol
****
fields.body:
Though they no longer dominate hip-hop as they did 10 years ago, it's worth remembering that, before Public Enemy, rap was not an instinctively political medium. And after much internal strife and external adversity, they survive, to remind young upstarts who the original perpetrators were and, more importantly, provide an outlet for the genre's most eloquent voice.

For many, Chuck D's stentorian tones are hip-hop, and songs like Rebel Without A Pause the standard against which all efforts are measured. That these songs still sound as vital testifies to the continued efficacy of PE's analysis and the mesmeric wordplay of Chuck and his comic foil Flavor Flav, whose presence leavens the polemics, not least when he announces how great it always is "to play Brooklyn".

Their latest album might be patchy, and these days Chuck busies himself with the mechanics of the music industry, but live, Public Enemy remain untouchable. Though they do acknowledge the efforts of later rappers (the Security Of The First World perform some samurai moves in a nod to the Wu-Tang Clan) their essence is what it has always been: an onslaught of noise, beats and lyrical virtuosity. Time and familiarity haven't diminished the potency of such battle hymns as Fight The Power, and Chuck renders these well-worn truths with the conviction of a true street orator.

Public Enemy's presence still provokes the local paper to run a scare story. "Controversial?" smiles Chuck, holding up the article. "We don't intend to be controversial - we just have a point of view." They may not be fashionable, but their relevance is beyond doubt.

fields.headline: Philharmonia/ Richard Hickox
fields.standfirst:
***
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText: Richard Hickox's brief Britten series with the Philharmonia kicked off with a performance of the War Requiem that left a certain amount to be desired. The work is arguably both Britten's finest score and music's greatest pacifist statement, but it needs careful handling if its shattering impact is fully to be felt. The balance of elements is tricky. Public grief, private protest and images of mangled innocence are suggested by Britten's interweaving of tripartite forces: soprano, chorus and the main orchestra; two male soloists and a separate chamber ensemble; boys' chorus and organ. Hickox sharply differentiated the role of each group with results that were often impressive, though the whole didn't always cohere.
fields.body:
Richard Hickox's brief Britten series with the Philharmonia kicked off with a performance of the War Requiem that left a certain amount to be desired. The work is arguably both Britten's finest score and music's greatest pacifist statement, but it needs careful handling if its shattering impact is fully to be felt. The balance of elements is tricky. Public grief, private protest and images of mangled innocence are suggested by Britten's interweaving of tripartite forces: soprano, chorus and the main orchestra; two male soloists and a separate chamber ensemble; boys' chorus and organ. Hickox sharply differentiated the role of each group with results that were often impressive, though the whole didn't always cohere.

The formal lament, with the soprano as its high priestess, proceeded with a measured solemnity that didn't always suggest the necessary sense of collective pain. On the other hand, strategic placing of the choruses on the platform led to some startling antiphonal effects which seemed to ricochet across vast spaces. This, above all, was a requiem taking place in a void. The boys' voices, meanwhile, echoed like lost souls from a vast distance.

Hickox is stronger when it comes to the two men and the chamber ensemble, sharply pointing up the ironic cross-referencing of thematic material between them and the remaining performers. But his approach needs more viscerality throughout. Only when he gets to the Libera Me does Hickox really let the emotions rip with results that are overpowering.

The soloists were variable. The Latvian soprano Liubov Chuchrova has a metallic voice, reminiscent of the great Galina Vishnevskaya, for whom the work was written. However, she lacks Vishnevskaya's subtlety. Anthony Rolfe Johnson and Roderick Williams were the tenor and baritone, with Rolfe Johnson's declamatory anguish sharply contrasting with Williams's elegiac lyricism - though Williams hasn't quite got the requisite fullness in his lower registers for this music. The choral singing - combining the Philharmonia Chorus with the BBC National Chorus of Wales - was unfailingly beautiful, if a shade cool. The Choristers of St Paul's Cathedral were exemplary throughout.

But his approach needs more viscerality throughout. Only when he gets to the Libera Me does Hickox really let the emotions rip with results that are overpowering. The soloists were variable. The Latvian soprano Liubov Chuchrova has a metallic voice, reminiscent of the great Galina Vishnevskaya, for whom the work was written. However, she lacks Vishnevskaya's subtlety. Anthony Rolfe Johnson and Roderick Williams were the tenor and baritone, with Rolfe Johnson's declamatory anguish sharply contrasting with Williams's elegiac lyricism - though Williams hasn't quite got the requisite fullness in his lower registers for this music. The choral singing - combining the Philharmonia Chorus with the BBC National Chorus of Wales - was unfailingly beautiful, if a shade cool. The Choristers of St Paul's Cathedral were exemplary throughout.

fields.headline: The game of the Dame
fields.standfirst:
Elizabeth Taylor - A Musical Celebration
Royal Albert Hall
**
fields.trailText:
Elizabeth Taylor - A Musical Celebration
Royal Albert Hall
**
fields.body:
The sanctification of Elizabeth Taylor is a peculiar phenomenon of the kind which occasionally grips the British public, and highlights our pitiful wannabe status compared to Americans. Here we were celebrating her elevation to Dameship as if she were familiar in our local public life, whereas she does little but breathe the priceless air of international hyper-celebrity fundraisers. She is as American as the Hollywood sign.

Keen to demonstrate that we British yield nothing to the Americans when it comes to showbiz, the organisers had assembled a smorgasbord of talent which must have left the guest thanking her lucky stars that she upped sticks to California years ago. Over there she would probably have had Julia Roberts, Tom Cruise and the Pope. Here, she was confronted with the ever-grinning Marti Pellow, Jamiroquai's Jay Kay wearing a dinner suit, Martine McCutcheon in a ballgown and some Euroschlock from Bocelli. David Frost, co-compering with Stephen Fry, has the instinctive comic timing of a European committee on tax harmonisation.

Not that there wasn't some solid-gold talent on offer. Tony Bennett slid smoothly through a couple of numbers with the Ralph Sharon Trio, while John Barry appeared late to prod the band through a selection of his greatest movie soundtracks. Reba McEntire sang My Secret Love (cunning choice, given that this was a benefit for Liz's Aids foundation) with style, radically different from the sentimentality of her own concerts.

Rumours of a performance by Michael Jackson were unfounded, but, looking like a transsexual geisha, he stood onstage with her after she'd delivered her closing plea for better, cheaper healthcare for Aids victims. A disorientatingly bizarre occasion.

fields.headline: Grand Union
fields.standfirst:
***
Sadler's Wells, London
fields.trailText:
***
Sadler's Wells, London
fields.body:
Bandleader Tony Haynes has a mission to bring the peoples of the world together, and there were times during Where The Rivers Meet when it looked as if they were all trying to squeeze into Sadler's Wells in person. This cross-cultural spectacular involves the big band-sized Grand Union Orchestra, plus singers and players from China, Bangladesh, Turkey and Chile, a choir, children playing steel-pans, student jazzers and more.

It's the kind of thing that sounds fantastic on paper. It often looks and sounds pretty good on stage too, though with some longueurs and structural incoherence. Over three decades, Haynes has been a tireless worker for community music, and he has used Grand Union and its predecessor Red Brass as the jazzy professional core of many bold projects involving youth bands, amateurs, and folkloric groups of all kinds.

But the snag he still wrestles with is that the concept sometimes outpaces the music for substance, vision and surprise. Where the Rivers Meet embraces themes ranging from western exploitation of Africa to traditional songs of Asian fishermen and Chilean exile laments. The jazz musicians supply rich orchestral support, and the soloists interject an invigorating energy, trumpeter Claude Deppa and saxophonist Tony Kofi particularly. When the chemistry ignites - like singer Brenda Rattray's majestic voyage over a slow funk groove, or the orchestra sounding as plaintively sonorous as a brass band behind resonating Turkish melodies - it lights a flare over the project's potential.

But the eloquence of music springs from inside, not from an imposed programme. Maybe Haynes, an inspired enabler, might now go the extra mile to draw a wider spread of composers into this big picture. Then the musical impact might more closely match the glowing ambitions of the founding idea.

webTitle: Go to war with a workmate

fields.headline: Go to war with a workmate
fields.standfirst:
Don't be shocked if your company leaves you in a muddy field with nothing but a map, a bag of clues and some colleagues. Dolly Dhingra on the trend for adventurous team-building
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Don't be shocked if your company leaves you in a muddy field with nothing but a map, a bag of clues and some colleagues. Dolly Dhingra on the trend for adventurous team-building.
fields.body:
Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to retrieve the top-secret plans before your enemy beats you to it. It is a task requiring cunning, ingenuity and courage. You don't know who you can trust, and must be sure not to misinterpret your cryptic clues. Oh, and watch out for the masked gunmen.

For most office support staff, Mission Impossible means trying to locate the maintenance contract for the photocopier. But for those companies with a more adventurous bent, training staff in problem-solving and teamwork means arranging something a little more taxing. And we're not talking a day trip to the local go-karting circuit.

Take the James Bond event organised by Red Letter Day, one of the UK's leading corporate "experience" companies. You will be trained, says the company, in "the tricks that kept Bond alive" - abseiling, hostage- taking, unarmed combat skills and and how to fire a gun in a suave manner. "We provide the Bond girl - you don't have to bring your own - and you get a vodka and Martini at the end of the day," says Lesley Moran, the company's operational manager.

Companies can take staff white-water rafting, parachuting or mud-busting (driving round in tanks and military vehicles). Or what about the "land, sea and air treasure-hunt challenge"? Each of the teams taking part is issued with a luxury powerboat, two 4x4 vehicles and a Jet Ranger helicopter.

The market for corporate adventure days is booming, and the more adventurous the better. "I think everyone's done paintballing and go-karting and they are looking for something different," says Moran. And it's no surprise, she adds, that the growing demand for corporate team-building activities has coincided with increased reliance on technology. The more we use the internet and email, the less we meet colleagues face-to-face. It is probably telling that companies need to abandon their staff in a muddy field with nothing more than a map and a bag of clues in order to encourage them to work with each other.

"Companies come to us for all sorts of reasons," says Moran. "It could be that they want some team-building exercises, but quite often they come after a merger with another company. They usually feel that it's important to take staff for an experience outside the office."

One of the main benefits of these extracurricular activities is that once staff have donned waterproofs and got stuck into the task in hand, job titles are irrelevant. "It's good for employees to do something completely unrelated to work because it is one of the few times the hierarchy of the office disappears and the power structures fall away," says Moran. This can be particularly beneficial to those in traditional office support roles. "A secretary could be brighter and more equipped to deal with certain tasks than her boss. Since it's a team-building exercise, the talents of the team are beneficial to all - it is a non-threatening environment in which an individual's talents can shine."

"Team-building exercises can be of great help to workers," says Andrew Forrest, learning and development director of the Industrial Society, "but everyone involved has to be very clear about the objectives if it's not to become just a fun day out. The style of the event, especially if it is outdoors, needs to be thought through and in no way should participants be humiliated. If a company has certain values that it adheres to in the workplace, they should adhere to those outside the office."

Forrest offers employers tailor-made courses. "We don't use the term 'corporate bonding' because it sounds like the Moonies or some weird cult. We call it 'team building'. One feature we would always include in the activity, whether it is mountain climbing or jumping through bogs, is the need for a long debriefing session in order to see what each of the participants feel they have learnt."

Sometimes, says Forrest, the team dynamic can be all wrong. "There are different ways to get to the same objective and it is important to look at the team and wonder why it is not working properly. If it includes a couple of introverted people who are not participating fully, physical activities might not be the best thing. You've got to think about them as individuals. Some people are more sedentary, and there's no real need to put everyone through the same sadistic cruel horror."

The Outward Bound Trust, based in Eskdale, Cumbria, specialises in adult team work - around 70% of its work is commercial and development work, and 200 employers, including Unilever, Transco and John Laing, regularly send staff on courses. Outward Bound has been taking in apprentices since the 1940s when it was discovered that older seamen tended to survive war experiences over their younger counterparts, largely because of mental fortitude. By forcing apprentices through new and challenging experiences, went the logic, they would become stronger and more developed in character.

"At its most basic, people become more self-aware through any of our programmes," says Phil Dale, general manager of the Eskdale centre. "We deal with all sorts of groups, either new teams of employees who have to work together, or teams who need to change the way they behave. We'll assess what the problem is in the work environment and then give them parallel tasks to do in the field."

But not all team-building activities need to take place in a gale-force wind on top of a remote mountain. Feedback, based in north London, has been running courses for more than 16 years. Theirs is a calmer affair and activities are largely based indoors. "We specialise in negotiating skills and strategies for commercial negotiating and industrial relations," explains consultant Eddie Fin.

Whatever the immediate sur roundings, says Dale, the experience of getting together with colleagues outside work to solve a particular task should always result in similar challenges and benefits. "With any problem, whether in the office or outdoors, the principal questions people need to address are: What is the problem? What resources have I got? How best can I solve it? And lastly, how can I check that I have solved it? Quite a lot of it involves problem-solving skills, which they will take back into the workplace." Learning to drive a tank may be more useful than you thought.

fields.headline: Six for Wasim turns tables
fields.trailText: Wasim Akram made light of being implicated in the match-fixing scandal by the Qayyum Report when he took five wickets in the space of 22 balls for one run on the third day of the deciding third Test against West Indies.
fields.byline: Craig Cozier in St John's, Antigua
fields.body:
Wasim Akram made light of being implicated in the match-fixing scandal by the Qayyum Report when he took five wickets in the space of 22 balls for one run on the third day of the deciding third Test against West Indies.

Pakistan's left-arm quick bowler shattered West Indies' hopes of a substantial first- innings lead as he reduced them from 214 for three overnight to 273 all out, a lead of just four runs. West Indies soon took wickets in Pakistan's second innings but the tourists recovered from 3 for two to lead by 134 with an hour to play, with six wickets in hand.

Wasim, who will be 34 in a week, took six for 61, his twenty-third Test haul of five or more wickets. He bowled unchanged from the Viv Richards Pavilion end throughout the morning session, his spell of 11 overs costing just 18 runs.

It was his long-time partner, Waqar Younis, who made the breakthrough, removing West Indies captain Jimmy Adams on his overnight score of 60. Adams and Shivnarine Chanderpaul had built a solid platform for West Indian ascendancy on day two. Their fourth-wicket stand was worth 134 when Adams was leg before.

Wasim then took over as he swung the second new ball both ways. Teenager Ramnaresh Sarwan had made 10 when he fell in similar fashion to his skipper, caught in front playing back to an inswinger. In Wasim's next over, wicketkeeper Ridley Jacobs continued his lean run, adjudged leg before to a yorker for a duck.

Chanderpaul advanced his overnight 68 to 89 before, in sight of his third Test century, he too was undone by Wasim, bowled an inswinging full toss. Next, Wasim removed fast bowlers Franklyn Rose and Curtly Ambrose to give Pakistan the chance of a slender lead. Rose slogged his way to 15 with two fours before he top-edged a hook to fine leg, while Ambrose sliced a drive to cover point. Last-wicket pair Reon King and Courtney Walsh managed to secure the lead, but it had been Pakistan's morning with six West Indian wickets falling for the addition of only 58 runs.

Wasim then wrapped up the West Indies innings when he bowled King with his second ball after lunch.

West Indies hit back with quick wickets at the start of the Pakistan second innings, Walsh and Ambrose reducing the visitors to three for two. The series is level, 0-0.

fields.headline: Puzzle for the lateral thinkers
fields.trailText: Inside Edge Norman Harris looks at the lighter side of the game.
fields.body:
Grounds such as Bristol, Northampton and Cardiff attracted few paying spectators last week. The skies, and the forecasts, made sure of that. But, even when the sun is out, county cricket takes hardly any money at the gate, with stewards having little to do except check members' badges. It has the uncomfortable feel of bad business, especially where a handful of paying spectators rattle around in a cavernous space like The Oval. On that ground, gate takings on an average championship day amount to £1,500 at most, while the cost of collecting that money is between £2,000 and £3,000.

So why not let the public in free, save on stewarding and boost the crowd? Surrey's chief executive Paul Sheldon says: 'It's sad, but crowds for four-day cricket just aren't going to go up. The fact is that we give away a lot of free tickets to schools and very often the take-up is only 30 to 40 per cent - and that's for one-day games.' And then there's the argument that members would be unhappy if non-members had free entry, and would be wanting a refund. A challenge, surely, for one of the lateral-thinking marketing men in professional cricket's bright new world?

 By the looks of it, Shane Warne has reached new heights: not only one of Wisden's five players of the century, but also immortalised on Aussie postage stamps.... In fact, the leg-spinner's appearance at the Stamp Exhibition at Earl's Court last week was to promote a scheme in which Australian stamps could be used in conjunction with a personalised label. The 45c stamp is regulation issue, but the supplementary label has no postal validity.

Says stamp designer Mel Brown, a cricket specialist: 'It's what the trade calls a Cinderella issue. That is to say, it is dressing up as something it isn't.' A bit like a googly, one might say. Shane must wait longer to actually feature on a regulation Australian stamp - as Sir Donald Bradman and Victor Trumper have done. In the UK, where stamps rarely honour the living, only WG Grace has made it.

 It's all very well the laws of cricket stating that 'each captain shall nominate his players in writing to one of the umpires....' It just doesn't work like that at grassroots level. Typically, the game starts with some players still on their way or being phoned up. It even happened the other day in the Surrey and Berkshire zone of the Wadsworth 6X Village Cup.

The visitors, Littlewick Green, had only eight players when they won the toss and bravely elected to field. Two of the missing three subsequently joined in. The home side, Whiteley Village, posted 200 for four against the Littlewick 10. In reply the visitors reached 191 for nine - whereupon Whiteley walked off, assuming victory. Not so. Littlewick's eleventh man had arrived much earlier but, seeking to protect a shoulder that is awaiting an operation, didn't field. Now he emerged to bat, and helped add the 10 runs needed for victory.

The home side didn't accept the result, claiming a breach of a competition rule about 'observing the best traditions and dignity of the game'. The competition organisers were happy to let the result stand. How could they have done otherwise?

It was a village cricket classic.

fields.headline: Rational fear of shoot-out
fields.trailText: Vic Marks At Cardiff, no play was possible until 4pm yesterday. If rain prevents sufficient play to produce a result in these matches, it goes down to a bowl-out. Failing that, it's sudden death.
fields.body:
So many counties championed the return of the Benson and Hedges Cup; they must wonder whether this was worthwhile. This 'summer's' rains have coincided precisely with the advent of a B&H match. At Cardiff, where no play was possible until 4pm yesterday, Glamorgan and Surrey will try to continue today. Meanwhile over the bridge at Bristol in the other semi-final Gloucestershire and Lancashire attempt to dodge the showers today and Monday.

When finally play began in a howling gale Glamorgan opted to bat but encountered early problems. Robert Croft,timidly for a pinch-hitter, gave a simple return catch to Alex Tudor, while Matthew Elliott dragged a ball from Martin Bicknall on to his stumps. All the while the clouds were banking up in the background. This is not Mastermind . They may have started but there is no guarantee they will finish.

Amid the storms the coaches must decide whether to adopt the Hoddle policy of not practising shoot-outs or to instruct their bowlers to take to the indoor school and aim for those three stumps. If rain prevents sufficient play to produce a result in these matches, the five chosen bowlers have two attempts to hit the stumps in the bowl-out. If the scores are equal after the 10 mandatory deliveries, it's sudden death.

The obvious solution was close to hand at Cardiff, namely to pop over the road to the Millennium Stadium and play under a roof. Unfortunately it was already occupied since Wales were playing the French Barbarians (at rugby). Cricket, rather than rugby, needs a roof. I wonder what they're doing there today.

If they are able to conduct a bowl-out outside at Sophia Gardens, it could produce a high scoring contest since the ball rarely bounces above stump high here. This is partly because for a month last October the square was covered by a gigantic marquee, which was used for providing hospitality during the Rugby World Cup. As a consequence the grass died. This spring the square has usually been covered up as well - by tarpaulins laid out to stop the pitch becoming a muddy swamp.

If proper play is possible Glamorgan's best chance of success lies in their knowledge of how to play on a low-bouncing surface. Surrey have nine players with international experience in their team and in normal circumstances would be regarded as the firm favourites. But they are conditioned by the generous bounce that is usually evident at The Oval.

However Glamorgan, as they proved in their emphatic quarter-final victory over Hampshire, know how to play at Sophia Gardens: not to be too greedy with the bat (200 can be a good score here) and then to bowl unerringly straight without worrying too much about the pursuit of pace and swing. The Welsh bowlers, led by the devoted Steve Watkin can do that. The support of Owen Parkin, Adam Dale and Alex Wharf does not comprise a fearsome quartet, but they can be effective when the ball doesn't bounce.

The visitors at Bristol - Lancashire - are also the favourites. Their one-day record in the Nineties is awesome, which is highlighted by the fact that Neil Fairbrother is on the verge of his eleventh appearance in a Lord's final. Gloucestershire can, however, boast two Lord's victories last season in the bogus Super Cup and the NatWest Trophy.

Gloucestershire's side is geared to one-day cricket. Their overseas player is a specialist, Ian Harvey, who contributed little in last year's Championship, but who is a master at the one day game - either bowling at the death or biffing in the middle order. In the field their strategy is based upon the excellence of Jack Russell, still probably the best keeper in the country.

Russell is capable of standing up to the wicket to all the Gloucestershire bowlers if necessary and his aggressive presence there makes a huge difference in one-day cricket. The batsmen are shackled, fearful of leaving the crease in case they are stumped; the dropped single is also denied them and what's more his constant banter can get up their noses. Other keepers are now trying to ape Russell in one-day cricket, so that this form of the game is rejuvenating one of the old arts. As with Godfrey Evans and co a bowler now has to bowl fast or be excessively unreliable to drive the keeper back.

All four sides will be desperate to play over the next day or two. They dislike the prospect of a shoot-out as much as the footballers. The final is on 10 June and you don't need a John Kettley to tell you that there will be rain about over that weekend.

fields.headline: O'Neill in talks with Celtic
fields.trailText: Celtic have opened negotiations with Martin O'Neill over their vacant managerial post. The Leicester City manager has held initial talks with the Glasgow club, who see the former Northern Ireland international as the man to lead them out of the shadow of Rangers.
fields.body:
Celtic have opened negotiations with Martin O'Neill over their vacant managerial post. The Leicester City manager has held initial talks with the Glasgow club, who see the former Northern Ireland international as the man to lead them out of the shadow of Rangers.

But sources close to Filbert Street were last night stressing that contract talks were at an early stage.

O'Neill has been sounding out his closest confidants in the game as he ponders whether to end his successful four-and-a-half-year reign at Leicester. He has ambitions to manage a big club but is deliberating over whether or not Celtic would be the right move. O'Neill already has Uefa Cup football to look forward to next season with Leicester as a result of their Worthington Cup win in February.

Leicester players including Neil Lennon have already indicated that it would be a disaster if O'Neill ended his association with the club.

fields.headline: Young England crash to Italy
fields.standfirst: Comandini 24, Pirlo 45(pen)
fields.trailText: England's dreams of European Under-21 Championship glory lay in tatters last night after they crashed to only their third defeat in four years.
fields.byline: Martin Shaw at Tehelne Pole, Bratislava
fields.body:
England's dreams of European Under-21 Championship glory lay in tatters last night after they crashed to only their third defeat in four years.

Coach Howard Wilkinson's young lions now look set to scrap it out for the minor places at this year's tournament in Slovakia after a devastating loss to Italy. With only the winners of the two four-team divisions going through to next Sunday's final - Holland, Spain, Croatia and the Czech Republic comprising the other group - England's chances of overall success appear bleak. England, who last won the tournament in 1982, looked the more lively and sharper, but favourites Italy were much more ruthless when it mattered and they were two goals to the good by the break.

Manchester City goalkeeper Nicky Weaver had enjoyed a quiet game until pulling off a stunning fingertip save to deny former Inter striker Nicola Ventola in the 22nd minute. But less than two minutes later, Weaver could only help Gianni Comandini's header into the net.

Left-winger Francesco Coco picked out the Vicenza forward, who beat Weaver with a powerful header from eight yards. It was a goal England did not deserve to concede, although their best chance came from a dead-ball situation.

After former Rangers midfielder Gennaro Gattuso, now with Serie A giants AC Milan, had been booked for encroachment at a Frank Lampard free-kick, the England skipper tried his luck again. This time AC Milan keeper Christian Abbiati pulled off the first of three fine saves in the half, turning aside the West Ham star's 25-yard right-foot curler.

Abbiati also denied Aston Villa midfielder Lee Hendrie and Everton's Francis Jeffers within five minutes.

Then with the last kick of the first half, Andre Pirlo slotted home a penalty after Liverpool's Jamie Carragher made a high challenge on Ventola.

Jeffers should have pulled England back into the game but with only Abbiati to beat after a free-kick from David Dunn - a half-time substitute for Hendrie - he fluffed his opportunity. With England lacking spark up front, Wimbledon's Carl Cort was replaced by Matt Jansen, joining Blackburn team-mate Dunn on the pitch.

England U21 : Weaver, Mills, Carragher, King, Thompson, Lampard, Hendrie, Murphy, Johnson, Cort, Jeffers. Subs: Robinson, Young, Gardner, Jansen, Carrick, Harley, Chadwick, Campbell, Dunn.

fields.headline: Time Shearer acted his age
fields.trailText: Simon Kuper England have two main weapons: the deadball game and a new discovery, that of Shearer as provider for Owen.
fields.body:
On the evidence of yesterday, England might be all right at Euro 2000. True, no danger at all comes from their left flank. True, none of their defenders can play a one-touch pass, or even trap the ball first time. True, Gary Neville's chief offensive contribution is his throw-in.

But there is one thing England can do better than any other team in football: hit free-kicks from flanks and head them in. Without working out any particular ploys, they have become a dead-ball team.

The sequence usually runs as follows: Alan Shearer, shielding the ball, is fouled from behind. (When Steve McManaman returns to the side and starts running with the ball, it will be another source of free-kicks.)

The free-kick is then taken by David Beckham. At this level he operates like a specialist kicker in American football. The game goes too quickly for him to take much part but he is produced to kick dead balls.

He swings the ball into the box, where Shearer, Scholes, Campbell and almost all the other England players out-jump their opponents. Foreigners cannot head the ball. As one of them once said: 'If that was the point, the game would have been called headball.'

Sometimes the England man heads the ball in, as Scholes has done on various recent occasions and Keown and Shearer almost did yesterday. Or there is chaos, and the ball falls to Michael Owen, which is no bad thing either. After 24 minutes, he almost wriggled a corner into the net after a jumping Paul Ince had pushed over a defender. The goal after 39 minutes came from a variant of this method. Shearer won a throw-in on the right, flattening two Brazilians in the process. The throw was headed on by Beckham to Shearer, who reached Owen, who scored.

The goal exemplified England's other weapon, this one a new discovery: Shearer as provider for Owen. For most of the first half, the England captain played about 10 yards behind the Liverpool man, as Teddy Sheringham had played behind Shearer at Euro 96.

The new combination works. Like Laurel and Hardy, Shearer and Owen have complementary physiques. Shearer can win and shield the ball in midfield, while Owen has the pace to beat the last defender.

England were at their best with Shearer behind Owen. 'They did very, very well,' said Kevin Keegan. The problem is that Shearer still covets a fantasy of himself as the front man. Before the game he noted that both he and Owen liked playing on the 'defender's shoulder', and hinted that he would rather play with Emile Heskey.

Shearer is too slow nowadays to play up front. However he is the team captain, and so still seems to have some power to demand of Keegan as he did of Glenn Hoddle that he gets his turns at the front.

This happened in the game in Saint Etienne against Argentina at the World Cup, where David Beckham's red card was not England's only disability in the second half. The other was that Shearer apparently insisted on play ing up front, forcing Owen, of whom the Argentine defence lived in terror, to retreat into midfield from where he posed no danger.

It was similar at Wembley yesterday. One reason why England lost their threat in the second half was that Shearer began creeping in front of Owen. This didn't work. It was dysfunctional, like Hardy and Laurel: Owen lacks the brawn to shield the ball in midfield, and Shearer is too slow to do damage up front.

England can perform reasonably well at Euro 2000 if Shearer fully accepts that his job is to feed Owen. He will still be allowed to appear in the penalty area for free-kicks.

And he must also accept that all free-kicks belong to Beckham, even if there is a chance of a shot at goal. Just because Shearer is the team captain doesn't make him the team dictator.
fields.bodyText: On the evidence of yesterday, England might be all right at Euro 2000. True, no danger at all comes from their left flank. True, none of their defenders can play a one-touch pass, or even trap the ball first time. True, Gary Neville's chief offensive contribution is his throw-in. But there is one thing England can do better than any other team in football: hit free-kicks from flanks and head them in. Without working out any particular ploys, they have become a dead-ball team. The sequence usually runs as follows: Alan Shearer, shielding the ball, is fouled from behind. (When Steve McManaman returns to the side and starts running with the ball, it will be another source of free-kicks.) The free-kick is then taken by David Beckham. At this level he operates like a specialist kicker in American football. The game goes too quickly for him to take much part but he is produced to kick dead balls. He swings the ball into the box, where Shearer, Scholes, Campbell and almost all the other England players out-jump their opponents. Foreigners cannot head the ball. As one of them once said: 'If that was the point, the game would have been called headball.' Sometimes the England man heads the ball in, as Scholes has done on various recent occasions and Keown and Shearer almost did yesterday. fields.headline: Full-on Brazilian charm offensive
fields.standfirst: An open game and Michael Owen goal make the day at Wembley and give England hope for Euro 2000
fields.trailText: There is something about being around the Brazilians that stimulates even the most jaded footballing palate. Thank God for them yesterday. Because there is something about being around England games at Wembley that can make you want to weep.
fields.body:
There is something about being around the Brazilians that stimulates even the most jaded footballing palate. Off the pitch, it is the sight of all-singing, all-dancing fans to whom tribal violence is something inflicted by outsiders on the inhabitants of their rain forests. On the pitch, that all-swaying, all-swerving yellow and green inspires a million misty-eyed memories.

Thank God for them yesterday. Because there is something about being around England games at Wembley that can make you want to weep. It is not just the maddeningly orchestrated enthusiasm of a rabble-rousing public-address announcer that makes you feel like you are in the audience for a game show, it is the cloying traffic and public transport system that turns enjoyment into endurance.

Due to tube delays, the match kicked off half an hour late. Never, in covering six major championships and countless international matches in between, can this correspondent remember encountering a delayed kick-off abroad. Hooliganism, a creaking infrastructure; England seems determined to sabotage its own World Cup bid, with the decision on the venue for 2006 just over a month away.

At least the team provided a shaft of optimism with a goal as the sun came out after a rainstorm - proving that if you don't like the weather in this country, hang around and it will change - by Michael Owen at his predatory best. The weary thought did occur, though, that it may have been England's first mistake. Duly on the stroke of half-time came a goal by Franca, who could well be, in the absence of Ronaldo, the NBT (next big thing) of the world game.

Kevin Keegan billed the game as a contrast in styles. 'We've got Land Of Hope And Glory . They've got the samba,' he said. Actually, down the years - Bobby Moore's 1970 apart - it has been more the crass Vindaloo, noisily re-inflicted yesterday, against the silky Girl From Ipanema . The varying approaches showed up even in the pre-match warm-up. Each Brazilian had a ball to go through intricate dribbling drills. England ran and drilled long balls.

Sadly it looked that way for much of the first half. Too often England expected a bombardment of David Beckham curlers to do the trick, if not directly then certainly from the second-ball fall-out.Too often, too, they surrendered the ball as if meekly accepting that if they couldn't pass the ball as well as the Brazilians then they might as well not even try. Gary Neville was once guilty, then when England won it back, he lumped it forward where Alan Shearer could only head on to a defender.

It was sad because there is passing ability in the side. The reassuring presence of Paul Ince - though the comparison with the holding midfield player on the other side, Cesar Sampaio, illustrated his waning mobility - instigated one movement carried on by Paul Scholes and ending with Dennis Wise, doing some sterling work out of position on the left, seeing his low shot saved. The fitfully lively Scholes also flicked on neatly for Shearer's low shot, also saved by Dida.

Then came the goal which fuelled England hopes that Shearer and Owen can be a successful partnership. The captain is still a talismanic leader of a line and powerful attacker of a cross. Owen pro vides sharpness and trickery around the penalty area. Shearer's lay-off seemed, encouragingly, to show that he is ready to play to the prodigy's strengths rather than remain the single-minded striker of yore looking mainly to score himself.

England looked far less convincing at the back. Thankfully for them Martin Keown was in solid form, relishing this chance against Brazil after breaking a shoulder against them in Le Tournoi three years ago. Thankfully, too, because Sol Campbell was a mess alongside him, the questionable positioning that he so often compensates for in the Premiership with pace and power exposed by the Brazilians' movement. When Tony Adams returns, left-back might be Campbell's best hope.

It was Campbell who missed Rivaldo's corner for Franca to head home at the far post, an ironically English goal. There was still much to admire in open play, however, and it was heartening to hear Wembley respectfully appreciative. Brazil, of course, are everyone's second team. It is hard to recall another national anthem being applauded here.

The Brazilians have been staying in the same hotel as Barnsley, here for the play-off final against Ipswich tomorrow. Perhaps the First Division team watched them in training, singing: 'It's just like watching Barnsley.'

They have not always been as revered in their homeland, of course. Carlos Alberto Parreira's World Cup winners of 1994 were criticised for their defensiveness. 'Fifa should change the rules to let us have five teams in the World Cup,' he lamented. 'One defensive, one creative, one attacking, one fantasy and one competitive. Then we might have a chance of one team that might please half the people in Brazil.'

And England think they have it bad. They should think about the rest of us, in car and on tube.

fields.headline: Century up for Rangers
fields.standfirst:
Aberdeen lose Leighton after only two minutes and are finished off by a three-goal second-half burst by Albertz-inspired champions
Van Bronckhorst 35, Vidmar 47, Dodds 49, Albertz 50
fields.trailText: It is not often that a Scottish Cup final that goes precisely with the form can be said to be extraordinary, but this 2000 renewal of the oldest fixture in the calendar had more to it than an uncomplicated, wide-margin victory for the long odds-on favourites.
fields.body:
It is not often that a Scottish Cup final that goes precisely with the form can be said to be extraordinary, but this 2000 renewal of the oldest fixture in the calendar had more to it than an uncomplicated, wide-margin victory for the long odds-on favourites.

Even more than the goals that Rangers racked up with killing rapidity at the start of the second half - or the individual performance of the towering Jorg Albertz in the winners' midfield - the final is likely to be remembered for the fearsome injury that forced the veteran Aberdeen goalkeeper, Jim Leighton, to depart after only two minutes. But it should not be allowed to detract from Rangers' authority in winning the 100th trophy in their history.

Leighton's accident and the removal of the injured defender Russell Anderson were made worse by the fact that the injured players' replacements were not positional equivalents.

Striker Robbie Winters had to take over in goal (with only three substitutes allowed in the cup, neither side had nominated another goalkeeper), while the right full-back, Anderson, was replaced by the Moroccan midfielder, Rachid Belabed, after 31 minutes. Belabed occupied his normal territory, but David Rowson had to be brought back into the defence.

Approaching his 42nd birthday, Leighton's departure with a broken jaw and damaged teeth brought an early end to the last match in his 22-year-long playing career. His injury came when he collided with the trailing left knee of Rod Wallace.

For a considerable period though, the crispness of the Pittodrie players' tackling and passing kept them in the game. Indeed, when Rangers took the lead through Giovanni van Bronckhorst, neither side had really done enough to deserve the lead. Albertz moved to chip a free-kick forward from the left, van Bronckhorst began a run which covered 30 yards and by the time the ball arrived at the Dutchman's feet, he had been totally untracked and sent a left-foot shot from 12 yards over the line off the leg of Winters.

The league champions had lacked their normal ebullience early in the game, but they recovered their old ruthlessness so completely after half-time that they had quadrupled their lead within six minutes of the re-start.

Once again, though, they were helped by statuesque defending from the Pittodrie side. Albertz made the first two with corner kicks and scored the third himself. The German's first corner should have been cleared, but a weak header allowed Kanchelskis to hook the ball back into the area, where it fell to Tony Vidmar, who chested it down and drop volleyed high past Winters. The next corner from the left was speared straight to the unmarked Billy Dodds, who bulleted a header into the net.

The fourth goal was an Albertz speciality, a fierce drive from 25 yards against the underside of the bar, the ball dropping at least a foot over the line before bouncing out.

Aberdeen: Leighton (Winters 2); Whyte, Solberg, Anderson (Belabed 31), McAllister, Bernard, Jess, Rowson, Guntveit, Stavrum, Dow. Subs not used: Zerouali.

Rangers: Klos; Reyna, Moore (Porrini 71), Vidmar, Numan, Kanchelskis, Ferguson, Albertz, van Bronckhorst, Wallace (McCann 67), Dodds. Subs not used: Tugay.

Referee: Jim McCluskey (Scotland)
