fields.headline: Cricket's deluded fools
fields.trailText: Will Buckley The code of omerta has been smashed, the crims have fallen out, everyone is talking. The Qayyum report signified this. The fact that the Chandrachud report's credibility is in tatters reiterates it.
fields.body:
Howzat for a U-turn. Not so long ago, anyone suggesting that cricket was bent was lampooned as a crazed conspiracy theorist and chastised for failing to understand the game's complexities and traditions. Now, anyone who suggests the game is clean is condemned as a deluded fool.

On Friday, Ian Botham, after moaning that the game was rotten to the core, suggested that an American judge who knew absolutely nothing about cricket should be charged with working out what the hell has been going on. Nice call. For centuries the English legal system has been based on exactly such a legal precept. When it comes to appointing judges it is understood that any knowledge might be a dangerous thing.

The most important manifestation of this sea change in perception has come from the evidence given by cricketers to recent inquiries. In 1997, following allegations by Manoj Prabhakar in the Indian magazine Outlook , Justice Chandrachud investigated match fixing. It was held in private and Justice Chandrachud's report was not made public. More than two years later, after Cronje and in the face of much pressure, it was eventually released. It is remarkable for the manner in which the great and good of Indian cricket all speak with one voice.

Sachin Tendulkar : 'I do not believe that the matches are fixed or can be fixed.'

Mohammed Azharuddin: 'I do not think that any match can be fixed.'

Nayan Mongia: 'Matches are not fixed at all. '

Sunil Gavaskar : 'I think that it is impossible to fix a match.'

Kapil Dev: 'In my experience no match was fixed.'

And so on. The only slight variation on the theme came from Ajay Jadeja who argued that 'fixing a match requires a great amount of homogeneity which is not to be found in a pronounced manner in our team. The team is composed of players from different parts of India and they have not much in common between them.'

Interesting argument and one that suggests the real reason why England haven't being dragged into the present hubbub. The bookies didn't approach them not because, as previously believed, they thought they were crap, but because they knew they couldn't stand each other and that if you bribed one to throw a match it would only inspire the others to try that little bit harder just to spite him.

Given the evidence, it is not surprising that Justice Chandrachud in his windy and unconvincing judgment should pronounce the game as clean as an umpire's coat. At the end, he praised the players who came forward for having 'one common objective, namely to save the fair name of the game called cricket. I accept without hesitation the statements of Mohammed Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja, Kapil Dev and Ajit Wadekar.'

'Without hesitation' - oh dear. If Justice Chandrachud had hesitated until yesterday's revelations in Delhi he might have saved himself some embarrassment.

It is now clear that many of the great and good of Indian cricket were lying their heads off to Justice Chandrachud. Azharuddin has to account for £2.5 million pounds of extra income. It looks bleak for Kapil Dev and Ajay Jadeja. And Ajit Wadekar admits deception, shrugging off his lies with a 'Who reads the report anyway?' Quite a few people now, one might think, and most will conclude that there has been a cover-up.

Compare and contrast with the Qayyum report. Whereas the Indian cricketers had lined up to proclaim the game pure, the Pakistanis, perhaps in an effort to distinguish themselves from their neighbours, well and truly dished the dirt. The only constant in the Pakistani players' evidence is the name of Wasim Akram, censured in the report while escaping the life bans meted out to former Test players Salim Malik and Ata-ur-Rehman. Among the players' depositions to Qayyum, the following allegations are made:

Javed Miandad: 'In 1992-93 when I was captain, I was subsequently informed by Idrees, brother of Hanif Kentbury [a bookmaker] that he had bought three of my players, Wasim Akram...'

Aamir Sohail: 'When we were fielding, Akram went away for a while and being vice-captain, I took over. The wicket was taking turn. I employed fielders around the batsmen and succeeded in getting two wickets. When Akram came back, he was very angry and asked me what the hell are you doing.'

'The match was against England. There came a time when we were in a winning position. Strangely enough, instead of Moin Khan and Azhar Mahmood who were in good form, Akram promoted himself in the batting order. He scored four runs from 19 deliveries. Pakistan lost the match by eight runs.'

Imran Khan: 'Ata-ur-Rehman told me that he was paid money by Akram to bowl badly.'

Rashid Latif: 'In my view no-balls and wide balls were deliberately bowled by Akram. Two of his deliveries were so wide that I could not pick them up, resulting in fours off byes. Three players had mobile phones, Malik, Akram and Waqar.'

Aaqib Javed: 'Generally the players about whom it is stated they are involved in match-fixing and betting are Malik and Akram.'

Now it must be remem bered that Wasim has not at any time volunteered his own version of events, nor has he answered any of these allegations or have a lawyer cross-examine the witnesses. It is not known whether the allegations are motivated by malice or a desire for the truth to come out. None the less, it is certain that Wasim faces a tricky few months as his accounts are investigated and he is kept under surveillance.

Not least because of the change in attitude signalled by the differences in the evidence presented to Chandrachud and Qayyum. The code of omerta has been smashed, the crims have fallen out, everyone is talking. The Qayyum report signified this. The fact that the Chandrachud report's credibility is in tatters reiterates it.

Players will come forward with tales of match-fixing and will be believed. It is those who claim there is no match-rigging in international cricket who will never again be believed.

Tomorrow Outlook publishes an article by Surjit S. Bhalla entitled 'What is an Honest Bookie to do?' It is an intriguing attempt to pin-point the matches fixed by the use of a mathematical model. Of course, it has the whiff of the post-facto about it, but the findings are fascinating.

Australian involvement in dodgy matches is high in 1996, peaks in 1997 and then, coincidentally, as the Warne and Waugh affair is made public, plummets.

During the Chandrachud inquiry India are involved in no dodgy matches. After everyone is cleared, their MFPs (match-fixing points) soar.

Pakistan: very high MFPs between 1995 and 1997, but since Qayyum started investigating in 1998 nothing.

South Africa: no MFPs until 2000. But under Cronje, one of the highest rankings recorded.

Bhalla concludes his article: 'The Asia Cup starts at the end of May. Enjoy this affair, for it will be the first clean tournament in quite some time. It will be notable for the telling absence of mobile phones from the dressing room.' Straight cricket. Now there's a change.

Now it must be remem bered that Wasim has not at any time volunteered his own version of events, nor has he answered any of these allegations or have a lawyer cross-examine the witnesses. It is not known whether the allegations are motivated by malice or a desire for the truth to come out. None the less, it is certain that Wasim faces a tricky few months as his accounts are investigated and he is kept under surveillance. Not least because of the change in attitude signalled by the differences in the evidence presented to Chandrachud and Qayyum. The code of omerta has been smashed, the crims have fallen out, everyone is talking. The Qayyum report signified this. The fact that the Chandrachud report's credibility is in tatters reiterates it. Players will come forward with tales of match-fixing and will be believed. It is those who claim there is no match-rigging in international cricket who will never again be believed. Tomorrow Outlook publishes an article by Surjit S. Bhalla entitled 'What is an Honest Bookie to do?' It is an intriguing attempt to pin-point the matches fixed by the use of a mathematical model. Of course, it has the whiff of the post-facto about it, but the findings are fascinating. Australian involvement in dodgy matches is high in 1996, peaks in 1997 and then, coincidentally, as the Warne and Waugh affair is made public, plummets. During the Chandrachud inquiry India are involved in no dodgy matches. After everyone is cleared, their MFPs (match-fixing points) soar. Pakistan: very high MFPs between 1995 and 1997, but since Qayyum started investigating in 1998 nothing. South Africa: no MFPs until 2000. But under Cronje, one of the highest rankings recorded. Bhalla concludes his article: 'The Asia Cup starts at the end of May. Enjoy this affair, for it will be the first clean tournament in quite some time. It will be notable for the telling absence of mobile phones from the dressing room.' Straight cricket. Now there's a change.

fields.headline: Danger in Rebrov's sneak preview
fields.trailText: Wednesday's game against Ukraine at Wembley will provide Spurs fans with a first glimpse of their new signing Sergei Rebrov. More than likely they will be impressed.
fields.body:
Wednesday's game against Ukraine at Wembley will provide Spurs fans with a first glimpse of their new signing Sergei Rebrov. More than likely they will be impressed.

A few days short of his twenty-sixth birthday, Rebrov possesses boundless energy which compensates for his lack of stature. When Andrei Schevchenko was still playing for Dynamo Kiev he and Rebrov formed one of the most feared strike partnerships in Europe. But when the lanky Schevchenko was lured away to Milan last year it was only a matter of time before his partner followed him out of Kiev.

He is more Beardsley than Shearer. His ability to dive into spaces and create diversions set up countless chances for the prolific Shevchenko. If defences concentrated too hard on stopping his partner then Rebrov would revel in the opportunities that opened up for him.

The Kiev and Ukraine coach, Valery Lobanovsky, has been extremely astute in devising tactics that extract the best from Rebrov's stamina, quick eye and passing ability. George Graham would be wise to see how the wily Lobanovsky utilises Rebrov if Spurs are to get the best out of him.

Should Rebrov turn out to be a hit at White Hart Lane then there is every possibil ity that a flood of Eastern European players will head for the Premiership. Managers looking for attractively priced talent would be well advised to start their search in Ukraine, many of whose players will be hoping to impress club scouts on Wednesday night.

This may be the first time that England have played the former Soviet republic but we should be aware of their pedigree. Although he played his international football for Russia Andrei Kanchelskis started his career at Shakhtyor Donetsk in the Ukraine, the same club that gave the young Rebrov his break. Donetsk is one of the few clubs to have threat ened the dominance of the all-powerful Dynamo Kiev.

Dynamo traditionally provided the core of the Soviet teams from the death of Stalin to glasnost. Oleg Blokhin was the star of the Seventies and more recently Ukrainian names like Mikhailichenko, Rats, Litovchenko, Belanov and Protasov have embarrassed England whilst playing in Soviet red.

Lobanovsky's team on Wednesday will provide Kevin Keegan with as stiff a test as can be found in Europe. They will certainly play to win. If Sergei Rebrov shines at Wembley then an English defeat will not be mourned too much in one corner of North London.

webTitle: Ipswich v Barnsley: a form guide

fields.headline: Ipswich v Barnsley: a form guide
fields.trailText: Division One, Monday 3pm
fields.body:
Division One, Monday 3pm

Ipswich Town v Barnsley

In the league: Ipswich 6 Barnsley 0; Barnsley 1 Ipswich 2

Ipswich Town
Local verdict: Tony Garnett , East Anglian Daily Times.
Ipswich start favourites to overcome Barnsley but the bookmakers announced their odds before they knew that target man James Scowcroft was likely to miss out with hamstring trouble. Scowcroft has been voted player of the season by supporters and fellow players alike - a vital cog in the Ipswich wheel operating just behind the strike force of David Johnson and £2.5 million Marcus Stewart.

Martijn Reuser the Dutch international on loan from Vitesse Arnhem, is the likely deputy and his skills could blossom on Wembley's wide open spaces.

Ipswich are a passing side and Jim Magilton is the key man. They build from the back and hope that John McGreal might return after an ankle injury to help provide the right balance. Goalkeeper Richard Wright needs a commanding performance to clinch a place in England's Euro 2000 squad.

Final League position: 3

Play-off pedigree: 1987: Ipswich 0 Charlton 0; Charlton 2 Ipswich 1; 1997: Sheffield Utd 1 Ipswich 1; Ipswich 2 Sheffield Utd 2. 1998: Ipswich 0 Charlton 1; Charlton 1 Ipswich 0. 1999: Bolton 1 Ipswich 0; Ipswich 4 Bolton 3. 2000: Bolton 2 Ipswich 2; Ipswich 5 Bolton 3 (aet)

Odds to win today's play-off: 8-13

Odds to win First Division last August: 10-1; to win promotion 5-2

Barnsley Local verdict: Keith Lodge, Barnsley Chronicle
Barnsley have played 55 games in all competitions so far this season and they have produced a remarkable 190 goals. The fact that the goal difference is so close at 106-84 tells the story. The Reds are a superb attacking side but their defending has left a great deal to be desired, despite the heroics of player-of-the-year defender Chris Morgan who has been checked by several top clubs already. This season Ipswich have put eight past Barnsley, so much depends on how Morgan and Co get their act together at the back. Craig Hignett is the potential match-winner, always capable of turning a game either by setting up chances for others or by scoring himself. He leads the hitmen with 20 goals with Neil Shipperley (15); Darren Barnard (15) and Mike Sheron (11) the other double-figure marksmen.

Final League position: 4

Play-off pedigree: 2000: Birmingham 0 Barnsley 4; Barnsley 1 Birmingham 2

Odds to win today's play-off: 6-5

Odds to win First Division last August: 25-1; to win promotion 6-1

Key man: Martijn Reuser (Ipswich)

Two months ago Dutch international Martijn Reuser flew into Ipswich to score the winning goal against Fulham in his 15-minute debut. Since then the loan-signing supersub from Vitesse Arnhem has added power and creativity to midfield and scored some important goals in the anxious last weeks of the battle for promotion. He would love to complete the mission at Wembley.

'Things can go quickly,'says Reuser, a 25-year-old attacking midfielder. In those two months Reuser is transformed from a depressed player in an Amsterdam dressing room to a confident Wembley finalist. 'It feels good to be appreciated again.' Although even this year he played and scored for Ajax in the Uefa Cup, he had walked into a dead-end street under new manager Jan Wouters. Reuser had certainly seen better times. After years in the Dutch Under-21 side he earned himself a chance in Frank Rijkaard's full squad in a friendly against Ghana in 1998. But these past few weeks he has vigorously fought for Ipswich's Premiership dreams. Born and raised in Amsterdam, Reuser entered the Ajax youth training program and was signed by the club in 1993 at the age of 18. He played a small part Ajax's victorious Champions League campaign in 1995, but after that he was a regular for Louis van Gaal's side. Midway through 97/98 he went to Vitesse Arnhem. As the ambitious club rose into the top three in the Dutch league for the first time in the club's history, Reuser had his best two seasons so far. Then he returned to the struggling Ajax side at the beginning of this season, with high hopes of earning a spot in the first eleven after Jari Litmanen left for Barcelona. But Reuser did not fit the plans of manager Wouters and was on the bench for most of the winter.

'This season I felt I deserved more than that. Wouters had promised me a proper chance,' says the ambitious player, 'but when I had performed well, I was on the bench the next and sometimes when I had played crap I was back in. I did not see the logic in that.

'I'd like to stay in England. The football here suits me and I am playing better each week. The game against Barnsley is therefore as important for the club as it is for me personally. If we win, Ipswich will probably want to buy me, if we lose they won't. I hope to play from the start at Wembley - if not, I'll try to make a difference from the bench as I have done before.'

webTitle: England: how they rated, man by man

fields.headline: England: how they rated, man by man
fields.standfirst: Owen strihe cheers Keegan
fields.trailText: David Seaman 7
fields.body:
David Seaman 7

Not overworked, mainly because Brazil couldn't quite get hold of their free kicks, and there was little he could do to prevent the goal.

Gary Neville 5

Lucky that his friendship with Becks is recognised as a factor that might help on the international stage. Scores well on the effort stakes, but worryingly error prone.

Sol Campbell 6

One of his most loose performances for England, he lost his man for Franca's goal.

Martin Keown 8

Committed and composed, he read the game well and reacted accordingly. A defender Keegan clearly likes held the England rearguard together.

Phil Neville 6

Has to make the best of a bum deal on the left. To his credit he tries to keep it simple and just about manages.

David Beckham 7

Probably the only England player with the technique to play for Brazil. Still not at his most influential, he faded when he moved into the middle.

Paul Ince 8

Dominant as a one man protective barrier keeping watch in front of the defence.

Paul Scholes 7

Playing a little too deep to launch any of the hand grenades Keegan expects of him.

Dennis Wise 7

If it's down to him and McManaman on the left, he'll probably miss out on creativity alone. But he stuck to the task diligently. More influential when he drifted in.

Alan Shearer 8

A gritty performance - Brazil couldn't live with his aerial prowess - and after all the snide remarks he linked well with Owen.

Michael Owen 9

England's ray of sunshine: explosive, exuberant, confident, crafty and above all clinical. He deserved his intelligently struck goal.

Substitutes

Ray Parlour (5): Had half an hour on the right when Beckham moved into the centre. No substitute for the real thing. Robbie Fowler (6): Precious few minutes to prove his fitness and prowess. Kevin Phillips (6): No time to make an impact since England's offensive instincts had fizzled out by the time he came on. Nick Barmby (6): A few seconds claimed him a cap but no touch of the ball.

webTitle: Gills edge out Wigan in a Wembley classic

fields.headline: Gills edge out Wigan in a Wembley classic
fields.standfirst: Wigan 2 - 3 Gillingham AET
fields.trailText: Wigan 2 - 3 Gillingham
fields.body:
Gillingham gained promotion to the First Division for the first time in their 107-year history after a sensational comeback against Wigan at Wembley today.

The Gills were staring at a second successive defeat in the Second Division play-off final with just seven minutes of extra time remaining against the 10-man Latics.

But substitutes Steve Butler and Andy Thomson grabbed vital goals after Stuart Barlow's penalty had put the Lancashire side 2-1 ahead after the game had ended 1-1 after 90 minutes.

The result more than made up for the Kent club's agonising penalty shoot-out defeat against Manchester City last season.

The dramatic finale had come after Simon Haworth had equalised for Wigan, following Pat McGibbon's first-half own goal.

When Kevin Sharp was sent off for a second bookable offence close to the end of normal time Wigan looked out of contention, but they took an incredible extra-time lead through Barlow after Darren Sheridan was upended by Barry Ashby.

Trailing 2-1 with just seven minutes to go, the Gills seemed to have blown their promotion chance for the second successive year but Junior Lewis crossed for Butler, whose bullet header gave Latics keeper Derek Stillie no chance.

And with the dreaded spot-kick shoot-out looming, Peter Taylor's side snatched victory - and promotion - when Thomson latched onto Ty Gooden's centre and guided his header into the far corner.

Wigan had started brightly and created the first chance of note after three minutes when Andy Liddell's cross found Simon Haworth on the six-yard box but he could only direct his header straight at Gillingham goalkeeper Vince Bartram.

With Darren Sheridan pulling the midfield strings for Wigan and linking up well with Liddell, Peter Taylor's side were being forced to work hard for the ball.

Liddell was again at the heart of the action in the 26th minute when he beat Gills' former Arsenal keeper with a wonderful 25-yard effort which clipped the top of the crossbar and bounced away to safety.

The near-miss spurred the Kent side into action with midfield general Andy Hessenthaler inspiring his side to break the deadlock.

He found Asaba on the right and the striker's teasing cross was met by Onuora, who tangled with McGibbon and forced the Northern Ireland international into deflecting the ball into his own goal.

Arjan De Zeeuw attempted to clear the shot off the line but referee Rob Styles was satisfied that the ball had crossed the line after receiving indication from his assistant. But Wigan fought back and drew level in the 51st minute through a wonderful piece of opportunism from Haworth.

After Adrian Pennock had blocked the striker's original attempt, the ball broke to Neil Redfearn on the left and his cross was flicked in the air by Haworth at the near post, before the club's record signing looped a delightful volley into the far corner from the tightest of angles.

The game burst into life with both sides keen to grab a potential winning goal and De Zeeuw saw his header cleared off the line by Nicky Southall, who seemed to be standing inside the goal.

With Gillingham on top in the latter stages, Latics manager John Benson threw on striker Barlow in place of Redfearn but his plans were radically altered by Sharp's 86th-minute dismissal.

And in the end it was the Gills who had the last say and can now look forward to playing in the First Division next season.

fields.headline: Where history never died
fields.standfirst: Selina Mills finds Poland's tragic city a visual and cultural treat
fields.trailText: Every hour on the hour in Krakow, a small brass horn appears from a window at the city's striking Mariacki (St Mary's) Church and sounds a call that stops abruptly in mid-note. Legend has it that during one of the thirteenth-century Tartar raids on Krakow, a watchman took up his horn to warn of an invasion, only to be caught by an arrow in his throat as he blew.
fields.body:
Every hour on the hour in Krakow, a small brass horn appears from a window at the city's striking Mariacki (St Mary's) Church and sounds a call that stops abruptly in mid-note. Legend has it that during one of the thirteenth-century Tartar raids on Krakow, a watchman took up his horn to warn of an invasion, only to be caught by an arrow in his throat as he blew.

The Tartars put off their battle for another day and the bravery of the watchman has been honoured ever since. Krakovians take their clarion timekeeper for granted, rarely looking up as they rush across the Rynek, the city's vast medieval marketplace. But for visitors, long used to bells and alarm clocks, it gives Krakow a haunted, mystical quality that defines the city from the start.

Situated in the south of Poland, by the Tatra mountains, on the River Wistla, Krakow might come as a surprise to generations brought up on bleak images of the country during the Cold War. Once the ancient capital of Poland and home to one of oldest Jewish ghettos in Europe, Krakow bulges with exquisite architecture and art and has a culture embedded in legend, history and national pride.

Many visitors choose to start their tour of the city from the heights of Wawel, an acropolis overlooking the main town, which was the seat of Polish kings for 500 years. Housing a magnificent castle, cathedral, old hospital and variety of bell towers, it is also the burial site of all but four of the nation's kings. I got up early my first morning to beat the crowds (Poles flock here in pilgrimage every weekend) and met an another early bird, a jolly nun, Sister Anna, who decided it was her duty to show me around the cathedral and its 18 chapels.

My new friend's enthusiasm for the cathedral, once the seat of Archbishop Karol Wojtyla, now Pope John Paul II, was well founded. As you enter a cool dark Gothic nave cluttered with altars and sarcophagi, you fall into a river of national history - a flow of brave knights, poets, saints, freedom fighters and kings with wonderful names (Boleslaus the Curly, Mieszko the Stumbling, Ladislaus the Elbow High) - and rejoice in a festival of architecture which includes almost every style since 1300. If you can imagine Gothic architraves, Renaissance pillars and Baroque arches, along with Art Deco interiors, in the space of a town church, you can just about imagine Wawel cathedral.

'Krakovians are obsessed with history,' said Sister Anna as we peered at the Sigismund Chapel's striking marble carvings, dedicated to King Sigismund the Old. 'It's an essential part of Krakow life.'

As I wandered around the rest of the castle, leaving Sister Anna to embrace another visitor, I began to understand her need to share her city's past. Every brick, cobble, and flagstone is a testament to how Krakow has survived the turbulent centuries. Despite occupations, invasions and partitions, most recently by Nazis and Communists, Krakow has hung on to a cultural independence that has been fiercely protected by its inhabitants.

Some locals say national pride has resulted in a conservatism that prevents the city from moving on and embracing new ideas. But given that Krakow was the only Polish city that physically survived World War II (85 per cent damage was inflicted on Warsaw and Gdansk), for many others including Sister Anna its fairytale towers and cobbled streets provide a historical continuity that is a nec essary part of the Polish identity. While Wawel castle is a national focal point for history, much of the city's cultural life centres on the largest medieval market square in Europe, the Rynek.

In the middle of the piazza, surrounded by stately fin-de-siècle town houses, stands the Sukiennice - a cloth hall dominated by arcades and sixteenth-century gargoyles, with an interior market selling amber, crystal and local handi crafts. There is also a vibrant café culture on a par with that of Vienna or Prague. You can sit for hours watching old men play chess and listen to local musicians and the hourly trumpet call. Yet what separates Krakow from her central European cousins is that she has not totally given in to commercialism and gloss. While there is an abundance of hamburger joints and Internet cafés displaying the influence of the West, there is still just enough dust, just enough dirt and just enough lack of English spoken, to feel you are in an authentic city.

Everything in Krakow is half an hour's walk from the Rynek, so if you have the time it is well worth exploring the narrow streets and quiet courtyards full of secret little shops and restaurants. I was taken to what seemed to be an anonymous entrance on nearby Stasi Street but was instead an echo of times past: a workers' café, serving the most amazing selection of perogi (dumplings) and borscht (beetroot soup) for around £3. A discreet sign on the kitchen door warned customers: 'Open from 12.30pm till all the lunches run out.'

At night I investigated Krakow's cellars, where there are many restaurants serving international food. But as I wanted to try Polish food, locals suggested Pod Aniolami (Under the Angels) on Grodzka Street where I dined on heavy, classic country fare such as venison, pork and barley soup.

Close to the Rynek are many quiet and uncrowded museums which house gems you would queue for hours to see in London or Paris. There is something mesmerising about spending a whole morning uninterrupted with Leonardo Da Vinci, so it was well worth finding the discreet entrance to the Czartoryski Palace in Jana Street to see The Lady with an Ermine and Rembrandt's breathtaking Landscape with the Good Samaritan .

On the other side of the square is the city's Jagiellonian University, one of the oldest in Europe, where you can see the instruments used by Corpernicus to determine that the world was round (for which he was excommunicated) standing next to the recent Oscar won by Andrzej Wajda, a native of Krakow, for his lifetime devotion to film.

In 1495, however, King Olbracht moved an already large Jewish community from the university district to Kazimierz and it became one of the largest ghettos in Poland.

No one can visit this community, with its beautiful Renaissance synagogues and carved Yiddish shop signs, without sensing the events up to and after 1939, when Krakow's Jewish community was destroyed in nearby Auschwitz. Though there are still quite a few houses boarded up and desolate, the area is reviving, with new hotels and shops opening each month. In Szeroka Square, the main focus of the district, with its striking Old Synagogue, and a range of merchant houses, there is a lively atmosphere, especially in the evenings, where bands play live Klezmer music and restaurants offer traditional Jewish fare. In the summer, a Jewish Festival has a devoted following.

There is still a long way to go in reviving Kazimierz. But increased interest in the history of Krakow's Jews (due in part to Steven Spielberg's Schindler's List , which was filmed here - there is a plethora of framed napkins signed by him in the cafés) and an influx of visitors mean life and trade are slowly beginning regenerate. As in so much of this cosmopolitan city, the past is entwined very visibly with the present. Krakow is also a visual and poetic treat which, like the sound of the city's trumpet, resonates inside you long after you leave.

webTitle: In search of the Swiss secret

fields.headline: In search of the Swiss secret
fields.standfirst: We all know about the clock, but  Vanessa Thorpe finds out what else makes the country tick
fields.trailText: Harry Lime's over-familiar verdict on the Swiss, delivered on top of that ferris wheel in The Third Man, needs updating. The inconsequential cuckoo clock may still head the list of artifacts Switzerland has given the world, but there are now a number of impressive entries below it (and not just those nice, bright Swatch designs, either).
fields.body:
Harry Lime's over-familiar verdict on the Swiss, delivered on top of that ferris wheel in The Third Man, needs updating. The inconsequential cuckoo clock may still head the list of artifacts Switzerland has given the world, but there are now a number of impressive entries below it (and not just those nice, bright Swatch designs, either).

The Swiss gave us, for example, London's Tate Modern, delivered on time to widespread acclaim by the cutting-edge architects Herzog and de Meuron. And on 14 June the Sadler's Wells Theatre in London will be visited for the first time by Zurich Ballet, under the innovative artistic directorship of Heinz Spoerli.

It is not a coincidence. Britain is in the middle of a cultural exchange with Switzerland. So far this month the 22-year-old pianist Antoine Rebstein and the conductor Matthias Bamert have both visited the South Bank. So, if the Swiss are offering us all this, what are they keeping back for themselves - apart from a lot of decidedly superior chocolate? It takes less than two hours to fly to Zurich and find out how the city entertains the wealthy international bankers and business people who have chosen to live or work there for persuasive financial reasons.

The city is spread out around one end of a beautiful lake - yes, Lake Zurich - which promptly turns into a river and runs through the smart, old town. There are no skyscrapers in view and it's hard, as a tourist, to convince yourself that the place really is the global hub of everything financially hub-like.

Certainly, everything is indecently organised and clean - I even saw a man on a ladder polishing the inside of a street lamp - but it is a much more relaxed country than the Swiss generally let on. Take a boat out on Lake Zurich and you will see that the city is bordered by rolling hills and some of the most deluxe, Heidi-style chalets imaginable. These wooden homes are usually flanked by several little versions of themselves, all laid out around the grounds: a summer house, say, or a boat house, or a swimming pool changing-room.

This makes for idle and pleasant 'lives of the rich and famous' style sightseeing. In fact, the chalet turns out to be the key to understanding why Switzerland has become a kind of well-to-do rest home for the stressed-out of Europe. In English the word 'chalet' is now synonymous with holiday home and that's because Switzerland is where the idea of enjoying a sedentary, scenic holiday originated. Wealthy foreigners would stop off during a tour of the cultural heritage of Europe to unwind and take the waters and enjoy the beneficial air.

This is also why the best hotel schools are still in Switzerland and why the Swiss take service and efficiency so seriously. They quickly learnt that it paid off. Before I arrived in Zurich I was told the inhabitants would have used the bank holiday weekend to escape the city. It was hard to see why: there was nothing to escape, just the odd reckless pedalo zooming towards you on the lake, or perhaps rollerbladers careering down the tram tracks.

So, as a spurious way to test Swiss punctuality rather than because I needed to get out of town, I took the train to Lucerne to hear an evening concert. I left shortly after a matinee of Zurich Ballet's inventive production of Prokoviev's Cinderella and, not an hour later, pulled into Lucerne, next to an astonishingly modern concert hall.

After listening to Beethoven, I sauntered to a rustic-looking restaurant and ordered a local delicacy - a meat and potato-filled vol-au-vent that appeared to have taken a course of steroids. This weighty meal brought home the point that almost everything on the menu in Switzerland involves both meat and potatoes. After a few days, a walk in the mountains becomes essential.

From Zurich you can travel to the stunning Jungfrau, or, if you are a fan of Arthur Conan Doyle, take a day trip out to the Reichenbach Falls, down which Sherlock and Moriarty notoriously plunged.

I decided to follow in Mark Twain's footsteps and set out instead for the summit of Mount Rigi, overlooking Lake Lucerne. But while Twain took three days to climb through the all the cows and daisies to get to the snow and blooming edelweiss of the upper slopes, I took it easy inside the carriage of a cog wheel train. Naturally though, I thought better of it when it came to the return trip. Pulling on my anorak, lacing up my boots, I opted for the even more commodious cable car ride down to Weggis.

fields.headline: Unionists turn back at brink
fields.standfirst:
Ulster to govern itself again after Taylor's last-minute
                                                  support sways vote
fields.trailText:
David Trimble rescued the Northern Ireland peace process from
                                                  the brink of disaster yesterday. He pulled off an historic political
                                                  coup by persuading the Ulster Unionist Party to return to the
                                                  power-sharing Executive.
fields.body:
David Trimble rescued the Northern Ireland peace process from the brink of disaster yesterday. He pulled off an historic political coup by persuading the Ulster Unionist Party to return to the power-sharing Executive.

A week after Trimble's attempts to get his party to back the new peace deal appeared doomed to failure, the Unionist leader just managed to persuade enough members of the party's ruling council to back the deal to save the Good Friday Agreement.

But tensions immediately emerged following a day of high drama.

In a controversial statement, he said he believed Sinn Fein members still needed to be 'house-trained' before they could become bona fide democrats.

This remark is likely to cause widespread anger throughout the republican movement. Asked by reporters if his term 'housetrained' compared Sinn Fein to dogs, Trimble retorted: 'That's your language, not mine.'

After the highly charged meeting yesterday morning, the council eventually voted by 459 votes to 403 to accept the deal.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, who had personally staked his reputation on the resumption of the Northern Ireland Assembly, immediately signed papers to allow the Executive, including two Sinn Fein Ministers, to meet again on Tuesday.

The whole assembly will meet for the first time since it was suspended by Mandelson in January.

'No one who has witnessed the last week will underestimate the effort and commitment David Trimble has shown,' Mandelson said.

'At the same time I want to recognise how difficult many Unionists will have found it coming to this decision.'

Bertie Ahern, the Irish Prime Minister, welcomed the deal but said that the closeness of the result - 53 per cent to 47 per cent - was a concern.

'Of course, there is a lot of concern,' Ahern admitted. 'It would be far nicer if the 47 per cent was instead 7 per cent. 'It is now time for everyone definitively to seize this opportunity for a shared future of peace, partnership and prosperity. 'I believe that this time the Assembly is back for good. That is certainly what we want to see.'

Ahern said the IRA must now stick to its agreement from earlier this month to put its guns 'beyond use'. 'I hope they will implement it as quickly as possible, within a matter of weeks, as they agreed,' he said.

Shortly after the result was announced, Trimble issued a warning that his party could walk out of the Executive if the IRA failed to deliver on its promises to open arms dumps for inspection and put their weapons of war beyond use.

The jaded-looking UUP leader acknowledged that the vote had been extremely close and that the party had stretched itself to breaking point.

'There is a limit to how far we can stretch ourselves without an adequate response being made by the IRA,' he said.

'The republican movement has promised to put a confi dence building measure in place within a matter of weeks.

'Two weeks have already gone since that promise was made, I expect that promise to be delivered fairly soon now. If there is any foot-dragging, there will be difficulties.'

On 6 May the IRA broke the deadlock in the peace process by offering to put its arms beyond use and open up its weapons dumps for full inspection by independent observers from South Africa and Finland.

Flanked by his wife Daphne and the UUP president Josias Cunningham, Trimble thanked his deputy, John Taylor, for his eleventh-hour support which had been 'enormously helpful'.

The deputy leader weighed in to support Trimble yester day morning following his return from a week-long tour of the Far East. Taylor had initially said he could not support the deal.

Despite the knife-edge narrowness of the result, opponents of the Good Friday Agreement appeared to be deeply shaken by their last-minute defeat.

The UUP anti-Agreement faction had fought a sophisticated campaign over the last fortnight to persuade delegates to reject re-entering a coalition with Sinn Fein.

Speaking after the meeting while extremist loyalist protesters hurled abuse at Trimble and his entourage, Roy Beggs Jnr, the Assembly member for East Antrim, said he was still deeply sceptical.

'They say there is no alternative to this deal. Does that mean that if the deal is not accepted, the IRA will go back to war again? That's blackmail and I cannot support it,' he said.

fields.headline: Perfectly supernatural
fields.trailText: Philip French: This is a constantly surprising and frightening picture. But what makes it a little special is the way Koepp roots the story in a convincingly etched blue-collar community and has the protagonist and his wife engaged in a real marriage.
fields.body:
Occasionally good films come from out of the blue or, to use a livelier American term, from left field. Such a picture is David Koepp's uninvitingly titled Stir of Echoes. Koepp scripted Jurassic Park and Mission: Impossible; his 1996 directorial debut, Trigger Effect, went straight to video here without creating a ripple; and all I'd heard of his second feature film was that it resembled The Sixth Sense.

Well, it is a little like The Sixth Sense, and also a little like The Shining. But it's based on a novel by Richard Matheson, published in the Fifties when Stephen King was still in primary school and years before M. Night Shyamalan was born. A specialist in horror, SF and the occult, Matheson wrote the best of Roger Corman's Poe movies, contributed to Twilight Zone and Star Trek, and turned his own books into such classics as The Incredible Shrinking Man (the paperback of which a babysitter reads in Stir of Echoes) and Spielberg's Duel .

The movie takes place in a working-class Polish-American suburb of Chicago where electricity repairman Tom Witzky (Kevin Bacon) and his wife Maggie (Kathryn Erbe) live in a rented house with Jake (Zachary David Cope), their five-year-old son. Jake talks to what initially seems to be an imaginary friend called Samantha, but it transpires that he's a 'receiver', a person with X-ray vision in touch with strange forces.

His father develops similar, though more intermittent, powers when at the end of a party he drunkenly agrees to be hypnotised by his aggressive sister-in-law Lisa (Illeana Douglas), partly as a way of showing up her New Age mysticism. In this bravura sequence we are grasped with a steely grip that doesn't let up for the next 90 minutes. Lisa tells Tom to shut his eyes and imagine he's in an old picture palace. It's painted black. He's on his own. His seat starts floating towards the screen that has one word on it that he can't make out - until he's almost up against it. The word is SLEEP. This is our own dream experience of being at the movies.

Under hypnosis, Tom sees strange, violent images concerning a woman and his house, and when he awakes he continues to be haunted, first seeing a ghost, then experiencing premonitions. Is he in touch with something in his past, or have he and his son been brought into dangerous communion with a recent local tragedy? I will say no more.

This is a constantly surprising and frightening picture. But what makes it a little special is the way Koepp roots the story in a convincingly etched blue-collar community and has the protagonist and his wife engaged in a real marriage. Unlike the family in The Shining, this couple really care for each other and their child, and unlike Nicholson's madness in Kubrick's picture, Bacon's is induced by a sense of unidentifiable moral responsibility. When her husband becomes steadily unhinged, we understand Maggie's pain and sense of helplessness. All the performances are of a high order, and only very occasionally does Koepp strike a false note.

Jake talks to what initially seems to be an imaginary friend called Samantha, but it transpires that he's a 'receiver', a person with X-ray vision in touch with strange forces. His father develops similar, though more intermittent, powers when at the end of a party he drunkenly agrees to be hypnotised by his aggressive sister-in-law Lisa (Illeana Douglas), partly as a way of showing up her New Age mysticism. In this bravura sequence we are grasped with a steely grip that doesn't let up for the next 90 minutes. Lisa tells Tom to shut his eyes and imagine he's in an old picture palace. It's painted black. He's on his own. His seat starts floating towards the screen that has one word on it that he can't make out - until he's almost up against it. The word is SLEEP. This is our own dream experience of being at the movies. Under hypnosis, Tom sees strange, violent images concerning a woman and his house, and when he awakes he continues to be haunted, first seeing a ghost, then experiencing premonitions. Is he in touch with something in his past, or have he and his son been brought into dangerous communion with a recent local tragedy? I will say no more. This is a constantly surprising and frightening picture. But what makes it a little special is the way Koepp roots the story in a convincingly etched blue-collar community and has the protagonist and his wife engaged in a real marriage. Unlike the family in The Shining, this couple really care for each other and their child, and unlike Nicholson's madness in Kubrick's picture, Bacon's is induced by a sense of unidentifiable moral responsibility. When her husband becomes steadily unhinged, we understand Maggie's pain and sense of helplessness. All the performances are of a high order, and only very occasionally does Koepp strike a false note.

fields.headline: Thandie Newton's action heroine
fields.trailText: Thandie Newton is on the brink of international stardom, again. But this time it shouldn't elude her. This summer she stars in Mission: Impossible 2 the 'action love story' and sequel to 1996's convoluted thriller. She begins as Tom Cruise's partner in espionage and, well, you can guess how the relationship grows.
fields.body:
Thandie Newton is on the brink of international stardom, again. But this time it shouldn't elude her. This summer she stars in Mission: Impossible 2 the 'action love story' and sequel to 1996's convoluted thriller. She begins as Tom Cruise's partner in espionage and, well, you can guess how the relationship grows.

Her role in the putative blockbuster has left US critics heaping superlatives on her beauty and sly performance. The British actress had looked like the real thing when she upstaged Nicole Kidman as a worldly schoolgirl in Flirting a decade ago. It was Kidman, though, who took the red carpet route to Hollywood. Instead, Newton has often starred in prestige flops ( Jefferson in Paris ) and soon-forgotten, low-budget efforts ( The Leading Man ).

A couple of years ago she nearly made it playing the tricky part of an insatiable girl-child in Jonathan Demme's much-touted Beloved, shrieking and whimpering, and dividing critics as much as Björk's screen debut. The film flopped.

Mission: Impossible 2 is a bit more than the average summer crash-bang bonanza. It's directed by Hong Kong action stylist John Woo, scripted by Robert Towne ( Chinatown ) and unlike its predecessor boasts a reasonably coherent plot. Newton was impressed by Woo's determination to create a resourceful female lead to rival Cruise's square-jawed Action Man.

She wrote pages of backstory for her character, then junked it when the script changed during filming. 'I threw away all the notes and stopped trying to build the arc of the character,' she says. 'Really there wasn't a whole lot I could do, other than be open to change and be at the mercy of the story.'

Apparently race was never a casting issue. When Newton asked Woo how he saw the character, he replied cryptically: 'She's a butterfly.' But her career has been characterised, to a degree, by her colour. She has played a slave girl three times - Beloved , Jefferson in Paris and Interview with the Vampire - though Newton's response is direct. 'Get over it. Just look at the films they're completely different.'

Since her screen debut in Flirting at 16, Newton has averaged just over a film a year. After the success of her debut she precociously headed for Los Angeles, acquired an agent but had few offers due to her English accent. So she decided to get a 'proper education', winning a place to read anthropology at Cambridge University. She spent her summer holidays making films with stars such as Brad Pitt and Nick Nolte.

Her best films have tended towards a European sensibility. She was praised as the African refugee who is the subject of David Thewlis's ardour in Bernardo Bertolucci's underrated Besieged . But given her poise and knowing on screen, it's surprising that Mission: Impossible 2 is the 27-year-old's first stab at the smart, beautiful female in a major film. After all, if Catherine Zeta Jones can do it, why can't she?

Five things you should know about Thandie Newton

1 Her father is British and her mother a Zimbabwean princess of the Shona tribe.

2 She spent her early years in Zambia until political upheaval sent the family back to live in Cornwall.

3 She is pregnant and her baby is due in September. Her husband is screenwriter Oliver Parker.

4 She had to perform a stunt cliff fall in Beloved.

5 As a teenager she studied modern dance at London's Arts Educational School before an injury ended her fledgling career.

fields.headline: Saddle sore
fields.standfirst: Now it's Shergar the movie... and it's a donkey
fields.trailText: Now it's Shergar the movie... and it's a donkey
fields.body:
The tragic life of racehorse Shergar was stranger than fiction. In 1981 The Aga Khan's star won the Epsom Derby by 10 lengths. Then the horse valued at £10 million was kidnapped by the IRA and killed after a ransom demand failed. It was, by anyone's standards, quite a story.

Now the racehorse's short and eventful life has inspired a film that blends fact and schmaltz. The result is a Black Beauty fantasy about one boy and his thoroughbred.

In Shergar Mickey Rourke (remember him?) heads a splinter group of IRA terrorists who steal Ireland's most famous racehorse. So far, so faithful. However, the film heads into faction with the introduction of a heroic character, an orphaned teenage runaway charged with looking after the horse. The youngster, played by Tom Walsh, overhears their execution plans and decides to flee with his new four-legged friend.

The pair embark on a haphazard journey across rural Ireland meeting, among others, Ian Holm's itinerant poet and his beautiful granddaughter (Laura Murphy). His idyllic interlude is temporary as the desperate terrorists remain in hot pursuit.

Director Denis Lewiston has no qualms about his narrative sleight of hand. 'Having done a lot of research into Shergar's disappearance, I then let my imagination take over,' he explained. 'Shergar has become a legend, a mythical figure. In the film, he inspires the young boy who saves him to look forward to the future.' Oops, that's the preposterous ending given away then.

Actually, Shergar is hardly new stuff. The film was completed at the end of 1998 and debuted at the Cannes Film Festival last spring. However, securing distribution has been a struggle. The combination of Mickey Rourke and a reincarnated horse holds little appeal, it seems.

The actor's recent career has been so woeful his guild membership should be revoked to save him further embarrassment. The omens look bad for this one too, which is out next month. It's looking more than likely that Shergar , unlike its equine inspiration, will be nobody's favourite.

fields.headline: You're so vain...
fields.standfirst: John Travolta's vanity project  Battlefield Earth has taken 10 years to make and is set to be the turkey of the year. But, as  Mark Morris explains, he's not the first star whose labour of love has resulted in risible self-indulgence
fields.trailText: John Travolta's vanity project Battlefield Earth has taken 10 years to make and is set to be the turkey of the year. But, as Mark Morris explains, he's not the first star whose labour of love has resulted in risible self-indulgence
fields.body:
There's nothing like a real Hollywood flop. Not an average bad movie doing averagely badly, but a complete wreck of a film that makes you wonder what the hell anyone was thinking of when they decided to make it and how the hell anyone had the guts to release it.

There's no doubt that this year that film is Battlefield Earth . It's not just that the reviews were beyond brutal (' Battlefield Earth may well turn out to be the worst movie of this century,' suggested the New York Times ), or the fact that the box-office figures have been pitiful for a $70 million movie. It's more precise than that: the statistics showed that the audience crumbled between its first Saturday on release and the Sunday. In other words, people were calling their friends and strongly advising them not to see this film.

But that's barely the start of the Battlefield Earth catastrophe. Because the film isn't just any old lame sci-fi movie about a race of evil aliens who have conquered the earth. This is the film John Travolta has been struggling to make for at least a decade, his true labour of love. Yet even with Travolta's name behind it, no one was dumb enough to stump up the cash until hustling producer Elie Samaha started sucking up to big stars at a time when the studios were starting to worry that they were a waste of cash. Orig inally, Travolta was going to play the hero of Battlefield Earth , Johnny Goodboy Tyler. But the years drifted by and he grew too old for the part, and had to settle instead for playing the 10-foot, dreadlocked alien leader with the bizarre (British?) accent. Travolta wanted Brad Pitt to play Tyler, but had to settle for the little-known Barry Pepper.

'It will be like Star Wars, only better,' Travolta used to say. Well, in a word, no. In two ghastly weeks, Travolta's reputation has dived back to where it was before Pulp Fiction . So why did he do it? Simple: the novel Battlefield Earth was written by L. Ron Hubbard, who apart from being a master of immense, turgid sci-fi epics, was the founder of the Church Of Scientology. And Travolta is one of Hollywood's many devoted followers of Hubbard's weird self-help creed.

In fact, before Battlefield Earth was released, a few over-anxious cult watchers had warned about either overt, or subliminal, propaganda for scientology being pushed by the film. As it is, the film has done scientology more damage than anything its opponents could ever have contrived.

But let's say Travolta wasn't just obsessed by the book because he is a scientologist. It might just be his favourite novel. That's even sadder. Film stars' long-nurtured pet projects usually have an element of tragic over-ambition to them, a yearning to do something that's either more personal or breaks them out of the restrictions of their star persona.

Like Steve McQueen, frustrated with all those years as a taciturn cool guy in cool movies, growing a big bushy beard and donning glasses to star in an Arthur Miller adaptation of Ibsen's An Enemy Of The People . That's Miller and Ibsen . You can imagine how proud McQueen - the executive producer - was to be given the chance to elevate the minds of his audience. And you can imagine how horrified his agent was. It took a couple of years of sitting on a shelf for the film to make it into the cinemas, and then it only had a very short run. And 20 years after McQueen's death, it's clear he's still remembered as that silent guy in the Mustang or on the bike.

At least An Enemy Of The People saw the light of day. No such luck for Jerry Lewis's The Day The Clown Cried . In the 1972 film, which Lewis directed and wrote, he played a clown in a concentration camp who is used to lure the children into the gas chambers. Lewis lost 40lbs to play the role, which was designed to transform the reputation of the star of The Nutty Professor forever. But it was never released, for legal reasons rather than seemingly more pressing matters of taste. Mind you, after Life Is Beautiful and Jakob The Liar, The Day The Clown Cried suddenly doesn't seem such an outlandish idea.

Its fate was almost mirrored by The Brave, Johnny Depp's directorial debut about an illiterate man who sells himself to a producer of snuff movies. Depp talked his friend Marlon Brando into co-starring, and Iggy Pop into writing the soundtrack. The film was shown at the 1997 Cannes festival, to an astonishingly hostile reception. It was never released in the UK or the US.

Even when a star's baby gets merely mediocre reviews and revenues, it can still backfire. Girl, Interrupted appealed to Winona Ryder because of her own history of psychiatric trouble. So naturally, she took the central role as the author/narrator, even though she was a good 10 years too old for the part. She was promptly blown off the screen by the Oscar-nabbing Angelina Jolie.

Worthy intentions can't save you either: Bruce Willis used his own money to get Breakfast Of Champions made, ignoring the conventional wisdom that Kurt Vonnegut's work doesn't translate to film. The film was released last year in the US to utter indifference from the critics and the public.

Which is why even the biggest stars can find it impossible to get their pet projects made. As one old studio hand warned: 'The problem is that you're dealing with people who are so obsessed with a project that they've lost all objectivity.'

At the height of his identification with Native Americans, Marlon Brando tried to get Martin Scorsese to direct The Battle Of Wounded Knee . Scorsese wasn't biting. Brando then spent years cooking up projects with wayward genius Donald Cammell, the co-director of Performance . Unsurprisingly, they never got anywhere.

But the real heartbreaker is Sylvester Stallone's Edgar Allan Poe movie. Stallone started the script in 1970, long before he had found stardom, and plugged away at it throughout the Rocky and Rambo years. Yet even when he was the world's biggest film star, money for him to play Poe was never laid on the table. He was still tinkering with the idea in the 1990s, but as the years passed it began to sound like his heart had gone out of it. 'As I get older, Poe gets older,' he said at one point. No longer, presumably: Stallone has now lived 14 years longer than the opium-eating poet and writer.

Then there's Meg Ryan, who has hauled her Sylvia Plath script from studio to studio for the best part of a decade. It's easy enough to see why they all passed, even before you hear Ryan's reasons for wanting to make the film. 'I am totally fascinated by that woman. I think Sylvia Plath speaks to women forever, but especially now, because more than ever we are these multi-tasking people with a lot to accomplish - and on top of everything else, she was a mother. To be an artist and a mother - those are two very difficult things to reconcile.' And there you were thinking the Plath myth was all about the intensity of the poetry and her tortured relationship with Ted Hughes.

Just occasionally, stars get away with it. Burt Lancaster's The Swimmer was received almost as badly as Battlefield Earth when it was released in 1968, but these days it is largely viewed as a pretty interesting film. In case Travolta tries to take any comfort from the story, he should be reminded that as Lancaster's source material was John Cheever rather than L. Ron Hubbard, respectability was always nearer at hand.

And while in 1984 it seemed truly barmy that Bill Murray was writing and starring in an adaptation of Somerset Maugham's The Razor's Edge , his reputation has grown so much since that it seems like an interesting curiosity rather than an act of stupidity. And there was widespread scepticism when Gary Oldman, at a time when he was Hollywood's evil mastermind of choice, kept insisting he was about to make an autobiographical film in south London. But the sneering stopped after Nil By Mouth . It helped, of course, that Oldman stayed behind the camera and that he wanted to make a realist European film.

There is one star who shows that you can make Hollywood fulfil your dreams, no matter how crazy they are. And they don't come much more deranged than taking a minor Isaac Bashevis Singer short story and blowing it up into a two hour 13 minute musical with 12 songs. Then, casting a 40-year-old woman as a 20-year-old who could pass for a man. Truly, the fact that Barbra Streisand was not only allowed to produce, direct and star in Yentl , but wasn't chased out of town by a lynch mob when the film came out shows that she exists on a different planet from the rest of us. No matter how misguided Battlefield Earth might be, when it comes to untethered self-indulgence, Travolta is strictly a beginner.

Battlefield Earth is released on 2 June

webTitle: Once again, the jury is guilty

fields.headline: Once again, the jury is guilty
fields.standfirst: Last year's decisions were absurd. This year's choice of Björk and Lars von Trier defies belief
fields.trailText: Last year's decisions were absurd. This year's choice of Björk and Lars von Trier defies belief
fields.body:
I woke up last Monday morning wondering whether I had dreamt, or had actually heard on my bedside radio, that Lars von Trier's Dancer in the Dark had won the Palme d'Or at Cannes, and that the Swedish Academy had convened an emergency session to confer a posthumous Nobel Prize for Literature on Barbara Cartland.

On checking the morning papers, I discovered that the least likely of the two was in fact true, thus fulfilling my ironic prediction in last week's Observer that Dancer in the Dark could be the sort of kitsch that Luc Besson, president of the 53rd Cannes jury, might go for.

So if the organisers thought that a jury which included the actors Kristin Scott Thomas, Barbara Sukowa and Jeremy Irons, and the novelists Patrick Modiano and Arundhati Roy, would correct the absurdity of last year's principal prizes, they were mistaken. Von Trier's inept musical, starring Björk as a Czech immigrant factory worker condemned to death in Sixties America for a murder she didn't commit, does very badly what Dennis Potter's Pennies From Heaven did supremely well. Its arrogant hit-and-miss director, a weird mixture of the naive and the sophisticated, brings to mind a remark of Isaiah Berlin's about a flamboyant literary intellectual: 'He's an example of that rare phenomenon, the authentic charlatan.'

As for Björk, honoured above Lena Endre (Liv Ullmann's Faithless) Emmanuelle Béart (Olivier Assayas's Les Destinées Sentimentales) and Juliette Binoche (Michael Haneke's Code Inconnu) as the festival's best actress, I can only say that although a lifelong opponent of capital punishment, I couldn't wait for the hangman to pull the lever on the trapdoor. But we had to watch as she sang her way down death row to the gallows, dropping in to raise the spirits of assorted male inmates, and then warbled another dirge with the noose around her neck.

Of course Dancer in the Dark might turn out to be a hit - though given the choice between this and Springtime for Hitler, Max Bialystock of The Producers might well have had second thoughts. If you want to see an off-beat musical, look out for Stephen Daldry's attractive directorial debut, Dancer, shown in the Directors Fortnight and set in Durham during the 1984 miners' strike. This is Stepping Out meets Kes, a sentimental, crowd-pleasing tale of an 11-year-old Geordie lad (Jamie Bell), reared in the macho world of coal miners, but discovering his vocation as a ballet dancer with the encouragement of teacher Julie Walters. It got the warmest reception I heard in Cannes this year.

The choice of the Chinese anti-war comedy, Devils on the Doorstep (of which I wrote last week), for the Grand Prix du Jury was misguided, but not contemptible. The general critical consensus, though, was that if the prize was to go to a lengthy Asian picture the proper choice would have been Edward Yang's admirable Yi Yi (which won the Best Director prize) or Shinji Aoyoma's 317-minute Eureka about the healing of three people who survive a bus hi-jack massacre. Tony Leung's best actor in Wong Kar-Wai's In the Mood for Love, a Hong Kong variation on Brief Encounter shown as the final competitive film (and not finally edited until the previous night), was well deserved. So was the Jury Prize that I hopefully predicted last week would go to Samira Makhmalbaf's Blackboards. She shared it with Songs From the Second Floor, a quirky Swedish comedy set in a decaying modern city in a state of post-millennial freefall and shot in a series of deep-focus tableaux with no cuts or camera movements within each sequence.

Songs From the Second Floor is the first full-length feature for 25 years by Roy Andersson, a director of TV commercials (and no kin to Benny Andersson of Abba who wrote the film's score). It is a technical tour-de-force, heavily influenced by Ionesco and Buñuel, with the final scene seeing an entrepreneur throwing a load of unsold crucifixes onto a rubbish dump. Unwisely, Andersson takes the smiles off our faces half-way through by introducing the ghost of a Holocaust survivor whom we see hanged alongside his sister by the SS in Poland. After that I remained numb.

The festival saw the end of the dogma of the Dogme 95 group with the departure from its self-denying tenets by Lars von Trier, its leading light. But we did see in the Un Certain Regard section the fifth Dogme movie, The King is Alive, written and directed by Kristian Levring, one of the four signatories of the original 1995 manifesto. Made in English, it centres on a party of European tourists stranded in the Namibian desert when their bus driver loses his way and performing King Lear (or as much of it as an ex-actor played by David Bradley can remember) to keep up their spirits and retain their sanity. Janet McTeer, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Lia Williams and David Calder co-star, and it's gripping, gruelling stuff.

The festival also saw the exhaustion of that over-worked form, the 'mockumentary' with Griffin Dunne's Famous (shown in Un Certain Regard) and Denys Arcand's Stardom (screened out of competition as the closing film). The low-budge Famous is a jokey vérité portrait of a fictitious New York actress eager for success; the expensive Stardom follows the rise of a small-town Canadian girl to super-model status, told through fake documentary footage, newsreels, talk shows, TV commercials. Both pictures feature lots of actors in self-indulgent mood - Charlie Sheen, Mira Sorvino, Buck Henry, Sandra Bullock, Spike Lee as themselves in Famous; Dan Aykroyd, Charles Berling, Robert LePage, Frank Langella doing turns in Stardom. A moratorium is called for here.

What was the worst movie in competition? The once respected Ruy Guerra, one of the founders of the Brazilian Cinema Novo 40 years ago, got a universal thumbs down in the press for Estorvo, a slick Kafkaesque movie about a paranoid middle-class drop out in Rio. But - if we leave out the von Trier as a special case - the Leaden Palm must go to Arnaud Desplechin's 157-minute Esther Kahn, an English-language French production shot in London about a Jewish girl (Summer Phoenix) in the turn-of-the-century East End breaking away from her working-class immigrant family to become an actress. The anachronistic script, replete with four-letter words and a Jewish mother upbraiding her daughter for 'wanking', is ridiculous, as is the notion of an actress with so little stage presence and no understanding of vocal projection becoming a star in the British premiere of Hedda Gabler .

To conclude on a more positive note, Juliette Binoche is radiant in Michael Haneke's first French picture, Code Inconnu, a perceptive look at the overlapping lives of a French actress, a war correspondent, a farmer's teenage son, a black teacher of deaf children, and a Romanian beggarwoman in present-day Paris. A sequence in which an angry young Arab torments Binoche on a Metro train is among the most memorable of Cannes 2000.

fields.headline: A top hotelier reveals all
fields.standfirst:
The Grimaldi, Nice
Joanna Zedde, owner
fields.trailText: How long have you run the hotel?
fields.body:
How long have you run the hotel?

My husband and I bought The Grimaldi in 1998. I have lived in the South of France for 10 years and we spotted a gap in the market: there are lots of grand hotels on the Nice seafront, but very few smaller townhouse hotels. I think we were one of the first. Our guiding principle is 'cheap and chic'.

Any famous guests?

We have had quite a few French personalities, the most famous of whom is probably Vanessa Paradis, before Johnny Depp. Earlier this year Ashley Judd was also a guest. She used another name, and we kept thinking that she looked very familiar - it was only after she left that we realised who she was. She was very nice.

Any unusual requests?

A Valentine's Day guest this year wanted a perfume specially made for his wife at Gras, the town in Provence where there are three or four perfume producers. He told us she liked Lily of the Valley, so we made her a unique perfume and it was waiting for her when she arrived. It's not unusual but it is such a nice idea, and it costs only £25.

What about a night out?

The Riviera has the highest concentration of Michelin-starred restaurants in France, outside Paris and Lyons. There were many new one-star restaurants in Nice this year, such as the Hostellrie Jerome. It is really good value, with menus starting at £24 and fantastic Mediterranean cooking. I think one of the most enjoyable things to do is have dinner at one of the bistros on the beach and watch the sunset. The shows in the casinos are also quite fun. The best time to visit is July, when there are several jazz festivals in the area. However, we are quite busy now: the hotels in Cannes get booked up during the film festival by the stars and their entourages so all the camera crews come and stay here!

What about a day out?

I think the market in Nice is wonderful - there are armfuls and baskets of flowers everywhere. Nice is also a good base from which to visit the surrounding medieval villages. Saint Paul de Vence is apparently the most visited village in France. My advice is to go late in the day, when it is quieter, and have dinner there. Unfortunately I don't think there are any more secrets left on the Riviera, but did you know that the reason why the Nice seafront is called the Promenade des Anglaises is because the English built it. There is a huge expat population along the coast and even an English radio station and newspaper now.

webTitle: It's a woman's world, on Sunday

fields.headline: It's a woman's world, on Sunday
fields.standfirst: Rebekah Wade has ambition - but is that enough for a top tabloid editor?
fields.trailText: Rebekah Wade has ambition - but is that enough for a top tabloid editor?
fields.body:
When Rebekah Wade was announced as the new editor of News of the World last week, the press attention centred on the inevitable facets of Wade's appearance and character.

A glamorous 31-year-old redhead, known outside the newspaper industry for her relationship with Ross 'Grant Mitchell' Kemp, famous inside the industry for being a Murdoch editor-in-waiting. Her reputation for mental sharpness, untempered dedication and almost psychotic ambition precedes her. She would, say her peers, do anything for the Sun, where she was elevated from the deputy editorship, but more importantly would do anything to edit her own paper.

The stories of Wade's ultimatum to the News International management - 'either you give me the top job or I leave' - may be overplayed, but fundamentally they are true. Wade's name was often mentioned in connection with the Mirror, particularly in recent times, when editor Piers Morgan, a former and even younger News of the World editor than Wade, was under scrutiny in a share-dealing scandal.

But there were rumours that Wade was being linked to a non-existent vacancy as editor of the Mail on Sunday . Any shortlist for a tabloid editorship would have carried her name and so the heat was on News International to keep her in-house.

Scandal and stories often swirl around the sacking of any editor, but the sweeping aside of NoW 's Phil Hall has at its core a commercial rather than a personal motivation. The News of the World - Britain's largest-circulation newspaper - has hit the target with a couple of corking stories in the past 18 months, - such as the 'scoop of the year' that Jeffrey Archer was about to pull out of the mayoral race, having asked a witness to lie.

But while this and the 'entrapment' of Newcastle United directors into making incautious comments about the women of Newcastle, were textbook tabloid, other stories, such as London Burning star John Alford being exposed for cocaine dealing and England captain Lawrence Dallaglio's drug confessions, had worn rather thin.

In the six months to April the NoW's circulation averaged 4.065 million, down nearly 4 per cent on the same period the previous year. Unofficial figures say the May figures could be as low as 6 per cent below the same point in 1999.

When Morgan, then just 28, edited the paper in the mid-Nineties, the circulation touched 4.95 million; in 1989, circulation was as high as 5.4 million; and in its heyday, decades earlier, it sold as many as 8 million copies.

Wade will, it is hoped, get a grip on the slipping fortunes of the News of the World , but the background suggests that it will take more than a Queen Canute to stop the decline.

Over the past 15 years, women editors have not enjoyed a happy history in Sunday tabloids. Wendy Henry was in 1987 the first woman to edit a national newspaper when she was given the NoW hot seat by Murdoch, only to be poached by Robert Maxwell for the People. She was dismissed for printing a picture of infant Prince William having a wee.

Patsy Chapman was another female News of the World editor, but neither made the transition to a daily editorship. Neither did Brid get Rowe, who edited the Sunday Mirror and the People.

The Sunday tabloid market has been a far more fruitful ground than dailies for women wanting to get to the top in journalism. While Chapman was at the helm of the NoW, Eve Pollard was editor of the Sunday Express.

More recently, Rosie Boycott held the editorship of the Sunday and then daily Independent titles before moving to edit the Express . Amanda Platell, now William Hague's spin doctor, became editor of the Sunday Express after senior posts with Mirror Group and the Independent .

'I don't think it's surprising that women journalists have tended to be more successful on Sunday titles,' says one national newspaper executive. 'Because of the way newspapers were structured, the senior women tended to come from the features and "human stories" side of news papers - sides which are more important on the Sunday agenda. But the more recent high-flying women on national newspapers are as likely to come from hard news backgrounds - so I don't think it's a case of giving a woman a job to "feminise" a paper any more - if that ever was the case'.

Wade's job is non-gender specific: to pick up sales as quickly as possible. Though this is not an impossible task, the possibility of the NoW ever reaching 5.5 million again seem remote.

Roger Eastoe, managing director of the Mirror titles, has had his own circulation battle in stabilising the Sunday Mirror, where he says the fundamental changes in the market over the past 10 years have been shared by all the Sunday red-tops.

'In 1994 you had a change in Sunday trading,' Eastoe says. 'The important factors which followed for that market were: Sunday trading laws being relaxed, all-day drinking being allowed and the increase in live sports events on Sunday. These three factors all contributed to a fairly significant fall in that market. In some senses publishers have been pushing water up hill ever since.'

Talking of Wade's prospects at the World , Eastoe says: 'It will be very interesting to see what she can do. In some senses the formula has become a bit dated - but taking it upmarket is a problem because you risk losing a significant core of your readership.'

If Wade goes any way towards repairing the recent slip in NoW sales, she will be the toast of Wapping and a contender for the next editorship of the Sun.

Most pundits think her formula will have to be more and better sex scandals, along the lines of those involving Frank Bough and Ralph Halpern. This is what distinguished Henry's reign at the Screws.

One thing is certain: it will be questions of sex, not gender, that change the fortunes of Britain's largest-selling newspaper.

Emily Bell
