fields.headline: That's my boy...
fields.standfirst: The former Royal Court director takes his new film, and its 14-year-old star, to a packed press screening
fields.trailText: The former Royal Court director takes his new film, and its 14-year-old star, to a packed press screening
fields.body:
TUESDAY 9AM I am lost in the streets of Cannes with the hangover from hell. I have just watched a technical run-through of my film and my tension level has hit 10. The only people on the street are pale, anxious film types rushing from their early breakfast meeting to their '9.30'. Everyone is on the phone as they walk. The extraordinary thing about Cannes is that despite the surface glitz, most people get up early and work - only the tourists have suntans.

Unlike any other festival I have ever been to, Cannes is a workaholic's dream. 'Who did you meet?' my friends say on my return. Well, for the most part, it is the same people I would bump into on a wet Tuesday at the Ivy (Elton John aside). I meet an old friend who makes the mistake of asking how I am. I burble on about technical compromises: 'The sound isn't right, I'm worried about the reel changes...' etc. Rapidly realising I'm being just another neurotic director, they make their excuses and rush on. My producer, Jon Finn, takes me for a coffee and a brandy.

THURSDAY I am back at Heathrow to pick up the star of my film, Jamie Bell (age 14), and his mother Eileen, who have come down from Billingham in Teesside where they live. Jamie has never flown before so I promised I would go with him on his first trip. His worry over flying is entirely matched by my fear that neither he nor his mum have yet seen the finished film. A Daily Mail photographer is at Heathrow to meet him. Luckily, he is a decent fellow, so Jamie's first experience of press attention is a mild one. Part of me hopes the film will slip under the press radar so he does not have to deal with anything heavier.

FRIDAY The big day. A 2pm press screening and the 8.30pm official closing night film of Directors' Fortnight. Another technical run-through at some ungodly hour. Thankfully, the projectionist listens with great concern to my neurotic babbling: 'Why are the acoustics in here so bright?' I ask. 'The audience will deaden it, don't worry,' he replies. I decide to believe him and go and meet Jamie and his mum. Over an early lunch I am catatonic with anxiety. Jon takes Jamie swimming and I loiter in my room. I have been told not to watch the afternoon press screening but nevertheless try to slip in - just to make sure they are actually watching the right film.

The screening is sold out and the doorman is not having any of it. 'I have a ticket,' I plead. 'Full up,' he says. 'I am the director.' He looks me up and down. 'Still full up.' Totally frustrated, I rush by him as he shouts for security, and manage to hop into the projection box unseen. I watch through the small glass window. It certainly looks like my film. It is currently broken up into six sections, or reels, and the smooth transfer from one to another is totally dependent on the skill of the projec tionist. 'How's it going?' I ask him. He gives thumbs up and smiles. I relax a fraction, stay until I can hear the audience actually laugh then leave to be escorted off the premises by security.

After the screening, there is to be a press conference. Many of the crew from the film meet us in the lobby of the Carlton Hotel, then we walk over to the conference together. I suppose I had been expecting a small, informal gathering Royal Court-style, over a warm glass of wine. But here we are faced with a podium, microphones, and a packed tent with more than 150 people. Camera flashes, TV crews and a rapturous round of applause greet Jamie and his co-stars, Julie Walters and Gary Lewis. The response is overwhelming. I manage to catch the eye of Jamie's mum who seems to be asking: 'Did these people watch our film?'

Jamie sailed through the conference like a pro, with just the right balance of humour, innocence and generosity. I don't think I shall ever forget the experience of watching him afterwards, walking up the Croisette in bright sunshine, graciously accepting the applause of the audience lining the pavement.

The evening performance is the first time Jamie, his mother, Julie and Gary have seen the film. I sit next to Jamie anxiously waiting for his first reaction. fields.bodyText: TUESDAY 9AM I am lost in the streets of Cannes with the hangover from hell. I have just watched a technical run-through of my film and my tension level has hit 10. The only people on the street are pale, anxious film types rushing from their early breakfast meeting to their '9.30'. Everyone is on the phone as they walk. The extraordinary thing about Cannes is that despite the surface glitz, most people get up early and work - only the tourists have suntans. Unlike any other festival I have ever been to, Cannes is a workaholic's dream. 'Who did you meet?' my friends say on my return. Well, for the most part, it is the same people I would bump into on a wet Tuesday at the Ivy (Elton John aside). I meet an old friend who makes the mistake of asking how I am. I burble on about technical compromises: 'The sound isn't right, I'm worried about the reel changes...' etc. Rapidly realising I'm being just another neurotic director, they make their excuses and rush on. My producer, Jon Finn, takes me for a coffee and a brandy. THURSDAY I am back at Heathrow to pick up the star of my film, Jamie Bell (age 14), and his mother Eileen, who have come down from Billingham in Teesside where they live. Jamie has never flown before so I promised I would go with him on his first trip. His worry over flying is entirely matched by my fear that neither he nor his mum have yet seen the finished film. A Daily Mail photographer is at Heathrow to meet him. Luckily, he is a decent fellow, so Jamie's first experience of press attention is a mild one. Part of me hopes the film will slip under the press radar so he does not have to deal with anything heavier. FRIDAY The big day. Totally frustrated, I rush by him as he shouts for security, and manage to hop into the projection box unseen. I watch through the small glass window. It certainly looks like my film. It is currently broken up into six sections, or reels, and the smooth transfer from one to another is totally dependent on the skill of the projec tionist. 'How's it going?' I ask him. webTitle: Deep thinkers on the high seas

fields.headline: Deep thinkers on the high seas
fields.standfirst: Flying fish, shark and a close encounter with orang- utans: Caroline Boucher joins the 'Swannies' (and Lord Carrington) on an intellectually stimulating and gloriously relaxing tour of the South China Sea
fields.trailText: During the humid mid-afternoon heat the snake was sunning itself on the handrail. Unlike the mammals which had cleared out of the way of the highly vocal party of tourists toiling up Mount Kinabalu, the snake dozed on until one of the party tripped and put out her hand to steady herself.
fields.body:
During the humid mid-afternoon heat the snake was sunning itself on the handrail. Unlike the mammals which had cleared out of the way of the highly vocal party of tourists toiling up Mount Kinabalu, the snake dozed on until one of the party tripped and put out her hand to steady herself.

The fang marks spanned two knuckles, surprising for a measly three-footer, but at this point the humans played a blinder. The woman's husband caught the snake and held it correctly behind the head. The snake was identified from a book as a Wagler's Pit Viper (poisonous) and the doctor administered the correct antidote. Then the woman was taken to hospital and released later that evening.

There's rarely such a dramatic interlude on a Swan Hellenic shore excursion, but this cautionary tale from northern Sarawak illustrates the ability of the company and its loyal cruisers to cope calmly with anything. Oh, and being eco-conscious, they released the snake back into the wild, possibly to repeat the whole performance.

That was probably the most life-threatening incident on SS Minerva's South China Sea cruise in February, although the ship's doctor (unpaid: they do it for a holiday) did have a diabetic passenger who had to be taken ashore at Singapore. And there were a couple of pregnancies (crew).

'Swannies', as regulars refer to themselves, don't rattle easily as they are a very particular brand of person. They are usually middle-aged and upward; they are well-informed and curious. They want to visit unusual places and learn about them, sometimes in depth. They are happy to sit through two or three lectures a day and will make avid use of the 4,000-book library. They like comfortable surroundings, never carry their own luggage and eat prodigious amounts of food at regular intervals.

As first-time Swan Hellenic passengers, we joined the boat at Ho Chi Minh City ('Oh call it Saigon,' said the Vietnamese guide. 'We all do because it's so much easier'). The degree of care showed as early as Heathrow and when we changed planes and prepared for a five-hour stopover in Bangkok, Swan Hellenic had the first-class lounge available with big sofas to sleep on and a buffet. When we got to Vietnam we hit the ground running, checked into the hotel to await the ship's arrival, looked round Saigon in the afternoon and next morning went on an excursion north of the city to the Cuchi tunnels, a huge underground labyrinth, often three layers deep, which was the Vietcong stronghold during the Vietnam War.

This was the first time we met some of our shipboard passengers and the initial impression was that everybody was keen to find things out. The guide was bombarded with questions, social, economic, political, religious; people were interested to know how the Vietnamese felt about the war, but, on the whole, tactfully so. Passengers already on board had come down the Vietnamese coast from Danang, so were well steeped in facts, but once back aboard as opinions were aired, two passengers came forward and offered to give an impromptu talk on their views of the war: one was a former adviser to Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon, the other was Commander-in-Chief of the US Pacific Fleet during the war. The packed lecture theatre included a former Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, a couple of rear admirals, judges, peers and QCs. Hardly surprising then that while we crisscrossed the notorious South China Sea there was an hourly pirate patrol added to the ship's security rota.

Feeling comparatively youthful and pretty ignorant we sank into shipboard life quickly and gratefully. I hadn't been on a cruise ship since I was a child, when every summer my family would sail to New York on a Cunard liner to summer with my aunt and then I'd puke my way back across the Atlantic. So when Minerva hit the open sea from the Mekong delta I had the pills ready, but we had a smooth crossing. She's a small ship by cruising standards - 346 passengers is her comfortable maximum. She was built by the Russians as a spy ship with an ice-breaking hull, became redundant at the end of the Cold War and was bought by and refitted for P&O, Swan Hellenic's parent company.

Her interior is like a country house hotel - oak panelling, traditional prints, carpeted staircases and spacious lounge, bars and dining room. Cabins range from the two Owner's Suites on the upper deck with private balconies (£3,995 per person on our leg of the cruise) via Suite (balcony, £3,765) and Deluxe (big window which had misleading one-way glass that rendered the cabin occupants entirely visible to the deck at night, £3,280) to the more ordinary cabins on A deck (windows) and B deck (portholes). There are small bathrooms, TV that shows a film a day, catches you up with CNN news and relays the daily lectures if you're too idle to make it to the lounge. And, of course, a set of Penguin Modern Classics on the bookshelf.

The library's leather armchairs are often occupied by a snoozer or two, somebody is usually poring over the giant jigsaw puzzle and the front pages of international papers are faxed through daily and pinned to the noticeboard along with the nautical chart. Guest speakers take it in turns to man the library desk and are always around for additional information. This cruise was packed with keen botanists (including the Carringtons) who thronged the expeditions on the trip with Dr Phillip Cribb, senior principal botanist at Kew, who had been a speaker on several trips before.

A large proportion of Swan passengers are returners. On our trip one couple were on their seventeenth Swan holiday, and one man was on his second - 70 years after the first, on which his parents sent him to the Mediterranean when he was at a loose end aged 17. Our oldest passenger was a spry old bird of 94, but there's a 96-year old regular who is planning a celebratory trip for his hundredth birthday. Passenger feedback is carefully noted. Minerva's predecessor was the smaller Orpheus up until 1997 and many regulars still talk of her almost tearfully. Thirty-three per cent of passengers do two back-to-back cruises in the winter.

Swan Hellenic was one of the first companies to venture into Libya, principally to visit the Roman city of Leptis Magna (featured in Escape last week). A couple recalled how after the boat docked apparently in the middle of nowhere, coaches were lined up waiting, an empty hotel was commandeered for toilet facilities and after the ship's crew had scrubbed them out, paper, soap, towels and handcream were set out. There were also tales of Swan Hellenic persuading closed museums to open and another couple remember the Blue Mosque in Istanbul opening its firmly shut doors.

Picnic bags and bottled water are handed out on excursions in exotic locations in the interests of health and safety and there's always a doctor or nurse in the party. The downside of health and safety is having to lug a lifejacket on to a sampan crossing the Kuching river, but such are the strictures of modern tourism. Next year Swan goes to the Phillipines for the first time to the joy of the charming crew (170-strong), the bulk of whom come from there, while the housekeepers are mainly Ukrainian.

The company discourages tipping, saying its staff are paid above average rates (all the passengers I talked to went along with this), and almost all shore excursions are included in the overall price. Another tradition is the policy of 'open sitting' at meals, initiated by the founder, Ken Swan, where the matre'd seats you next to people in the formal dining room and you simply join a table in the buffet deck room rather than returning daily to a set table. It's not as terrifying as I'd thought. Although dress is pretty casual during the day people dress formally (jacket and tie for men) in the evening for the main dining room, and there's usually at least one black-tie night. Entertainment was along classical lines, from a quartet of students at the Guildhall School of Music, followed by dancing to the Minerva band, interposed with a hilarious evening of songs by the Filipino crew. One couple on their first, and I should imagine last, trip on Minerva, were devastated not to find a casino and lavish floor shows.

Days at sea were utter bliss. We saw flying fish, a sizeable shark and a great deal of timber washed down from the Borneo coast. Key deck loungers at the rear of the promenade deck were commandeered by those in the know straight after breakfast, but there is so much space that finding a sunny or shady perch was never a problem. Eight circuits of the promenade deck constitutes a mile, which was our daily aim, and I dragged myself to the gym a couple of times; the seawater pool on the aft deck is precisely four strokes long, so really just for cooling off. But who needs exercise when the longest you can go without daytime food on Minerva is half an hour? Plus that massive library invites itself to be read. A random survey of on-deck reading would put John Grisham pretty near the top, but there were some corking holiday reads including Learning to Read Egyptian and Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time .

We missed one Sarawak leg of the trip because we opted for an overnight rainforest excursion into the Mulu National Park, which a party of us, led by explorer Robin Hanbury-Tenison, flew to in small planes. This was a new excursion - spending a short time walking through the rainforest and then exploring the surrounding cave system via longboats.We rejoined the boat in Brunei. Then, oh joy, another day at sea while we sailed down the coast of Sarawak to Kuching.

This was an interesting little town once you foraged round the backstreets and found silk and antique shops and the markets selling wonderful spices and alarming parts of fish. An afternoon trip to the Semmenggoh Wildlife Park, where there is a breeding programme for orphaned orang-utan, produced a mother and baby within touching distance.

Our final destination was Singapore, which seemed too teeming with traffic and vast shopping malls compared to our previous destinations, but we went on a couple of good excursions, particularly the World War II one, which made terrifying sense of the Japanese invasion from the land side when you stood by the narrow strip of water they crossed so easily. Many passengers had either ruled, served in or rebuilt Singapore, so there was much to be learnt.

Leaving Minerva was like being ejected from the womb. For 10 days we hadn't really had to make a decision other than what to eat next and whether another beer at 12.30pm was out of order. It is not the holiday for the cutting edge adventurer, but nor is it for the seeker of highlife. Cruising on Minerva is for those interested in history, culture, traditions and religions, who want to be pampered but not patronised, to bask but not be bored. I'd go back like a shot.

The Minerva returns to the region next January. A 17-day Legends of the Far East cruise, departing 29 January, costs from £3,660 per person for an itinerary that includes China, Hong Kong, Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia and Borneo. The theme is geology, natural history and art. Guest speakers include Professor Chris Stillman, a geologist specialising in volcanology (the cruise passes through one of the most active arcs of the Pacific Ring of Fire) and Nigel Colborn, naturalist and gardener, with a special interest in island ecologies and world flora. Reservations/brochures from 020 7800 2200.

webTitle: Racism goes to Labour's very top

fields.headline: Racism goes to Labour's very top
fields.trailText: Trevor Phillips (Comment, last week) is correct to point out New Labour's poor record on black representation. But his assertion that 'the leadership of the party is desperate to put competent non-white people into office' is, at best, naïve.
fields.body:
Trevor Phillips (Comment, last week) is correct to point out New Labour's poor record on black representation. But his assertion that 'the leadership of the party is desperate to put competent non-white people into office' is, at best, naïve.

I was elected to the National Executive of the Labour Party for three years in the Nineties and saw at first hand their approach. In Manchester, Birmingham and East Midlands constituencies, Asian candidates launched determined efforts to get selected. In every case, party officials (egged on by hysterical white MPs) countered with accusations of corruption and threats of disciplinary action. Where necessary, local parties were closed down to stop Asian party members voting for the candidate of the their choice.

As a member of the NEC at the time, I could see that the positive action for women was excluding black women. Of the record number of new women Labour MPs elected in 1997, only one was black.

In the mid-Eighties London had four black council leaders. Under New Labour London has none. The GLA selection process (which Trevor defends) was a disgrace. All the prominent black and Asian Labour activists were excluded by the selection panel.
Diane Abbott MP
House of Commons, London SW1

Mr Phillips is lucky to be chairman of the GLA, a post for which he was selected not elected. Does he think it would be fair if all blacks enjoyed similar discrimination? Perhaps he doesn't realise that many of the white faces he resents are also from ethnic groups - East Europeans, white Africans and Jews.
VW Levene
London W2

fields.headline: Outrage at Iraq
fields.trailText: Saddam's offer to take 300,000 Palestinian refugees living in Lebanon (News, last week) is not just astonishing but outrageous. If true, it confirms his disregard for human rights and the right of the Palestinian people to return to their country.
fields.body:
Saddam's offer to take 300,000 Palestinian refugees living in Lebanon (News, last week) is not just astonishing but outrageous. If true, it confirms his disregard for human rights and the right of the Palestinian people to return to their country.

I was born in Baghdad. I know that my family and friends are suffering under the sanctions, but they will never agree to this shameful suggestion. In any case, why would the Palestinians want to trade refugee camps in Lebanon for a life of hell under a dictator?
Professor A Almaini
Napier University, Edinburgh

Re the proposed removal of Palestinian refugees from Lebanon to Iraq. In the first place such a proposal, if implemented, would be a flagrant contravention of often-reiterated UN resolutions which state clearly that the refugees have an inalienable right to return home to Palestine. Second, it is unbelievable that these people who have suffered so much at the hands of Israel should be so cynically regarded that a proposal is mooted without any consultation about their destination to a country where inhumanity and injustice are paramount. Have these people, among whom are many that I count as friends, not suffered enough?
Jo Beech
Tonbridge, Kent

In the first place such a proposal, if implemented, would be a flagrant contravention of often-reiterated UN resolutions which state clearly that the refugees have an inalienable right to return home to Palestine. Second, it is unbelievable that these people who have suffered so much at the hands of Israel should be so cynically regarded that a proposal is mooted without any consultation about their destination to a country where inhumanity and injustice are paramount. Have these people, among whom are many that I count as friends, not suffered enough? Jo Beech Tonbridge, Kent

fields.headline: Roaring trade
fields.trailText: Your article 'The literary lion cubs that failed to roar' (News, 14 May) states that so far only 2,786 copies of John Lanchester's new novel  Mr Phillips  have sold in hardback. We published this novel in January and have sold just over 17,000 copies so far.
fields.body:
Your article 'The literary lion cubs that failed to roar' (News, 14 May) states that so far only 2,786 copies of John Lanchester's new novel Mr Phillips have sold in hardback. We published this novel in January and have sold just over 17,000 copies so far.

The BookTrack figure you report only represents a portion of our total market for the book.
Joanna Mackle
Publishing Director
Faber and Faber Ltd, London WC1

Sex matters

I was very pleased you gave space to 16-year-old Anna Stothard (Comment, last week) but I disagree with her dismissal of the importance of sex education in schools. Yes, it may be unnecessary, embarrassing and 'fairly disgusting' but in my opinion it is valuable information.

I don't actually think sex education is as far-reaching as it could be - for example, in teaching us about not just the clinical sexual act but about our sexuality. Unfortunately, Section 28 makes teachers uneasy about their position in helping confused teenagers and prevents a rounded and inclusive message being sent about sexuality to teenagers.

The same is not true of education about multicultural Britain where teachers would never be allowed to 'forget' to acknowledge our large Asian or black communities.
Hanna Lewin
Nottingham

No stunner

Like Freud, I do not know what women want, but I do know that not all men want the same kind of woman. The girl adorning Nicci Gerrard's article (Review, last week) would never make Page Three: her shortcomings are too obvious. On the other hand, her boyish legs and flat chest will attract many male broadsheet readers. The influence of class - and specifically the public school experience - must never be underestimated.
Bernard Ineichen
London SW10

A load of bull

I enjoyed your intelligent coverage of the arrival of the Blair baby, until I reached the astrological nonsense: 'Leo is a bull' etc. Why do you do it?
Brian Whitelaw
Chelmsford, Essex

V&A defended

I do not recognise the picture of the V&A painted by Deyan Sudjic in his article of 21 May (Review). The V&A is engaged in an important programme of regeneration. The British Galleries will transform a vast tract of the museum when it opens in 2001.

The Spiral is also a key that will help to unlock the city of treasures we hold in trust for the nation. Its development is overseen by a steering group that includes trustees, V&A staff and external advisers.

Such a landmark project could not be promoted by an institution 'mired in self-doubt and controversy', but one which sees the aims of treasure house, access and excellence as the proper mission of a museum in the twenty-first century.
Paul Ridley
Chairman of the Board of Trustees
Victoria and Albert Museum, London SW7

Party pooper

Thank you for the kind mention of my presence at Helena Kennedy's birthday party. It's gratifying to know that, simply by turning up to celebrate the 50th birthday of someone I've known for a couple of decades, I've at last hoisted myself into the 'New Establishment'.
Bill Paterson
London W1

We're no racists

Allow me to correct your article about the UK Independence Party (News, last week). The 'far right' have not invaded our party, and the 'BNP' have made no approach to merge. If they ever do they will be totally rejected.

We will field candidates from all ethnic groups at the next general election. We have two possible candidates for the Tottenham by-election - one is of Indian origin and the other Jewish. Our organiser in Leicester has a partner of Afro-Caribbean origin. We don't make very good racists, do we?
Mike Nattrass
Party Chairman, UK Independence Party

Poll position

Nick Cohen's poorly researched diatribe against opinion polls (Comment, last week) invites a sharp rebuttal. In the 15 elections since the war, the average error in party share of the 61 polls taken during those elections was 1.8 per cent, well within the plus or minus 3 per cent we'd claim to be able to hit 19 times out of 20.
Robert M Worcester
Chairman, Mori

fields.headline: Labour in new attack on 'elitism'
fields.trailText: A fresh assault on Britain's so-called elite was launched by the Government last night as a study was passed to  The Observer revealing new evidence of discrimination at the heart of the education establishment.
fields.byline: Gaby Hinsliff, Kamal Ahmedand Martin Bright
fields.body:
A fresh assault on Britain's so-called elite was launched by the Government last night as a study was passed to The Observer revealing new evidence of discrimination at the heart of the education establishment.

As part of a concerted strategy to capitalise on what it sees as a populist campaign to appeal to working-class voters, the Government last night intensified the debate over class and education by signalling that students from state schools were to be offered easier entry to Britain's leading medical schools.

The Health Secretary, Alan Milburn, will shortly unveil a pilot scheme in effect helping disadvantaged pupils win places at medical school with lower grades if they show academic potential untapped at school.

With the backing of Tony Blair, plans are also being made to introduce 'talent spotters' to tour state schools in an effort to identify promising students and encourage them to apply for places at top universities.

The plans emerged ahead of a report this week by Peter Lampl, a close adviser to the Government on education, which will show that thousands of state school pupils - some with the best grades in the country - are being turned down by Britain's best established universities.

Faced with a slump in the polls, the Government is determined to launch an all-out offensive on what it regards as the 'forces of privilege', facing down growing criticism that they are engaging in an old-fashioned class war.

'Our aim is advancing opportunity on the basis of merit and excellence,' the Prime Minister's official spokesman said yesterday. 'We are not erecting barriers, we are breaking them down.'

Over the next two weeks, speeches by John Prescott, David Blunkett and Gordon Brown will concentrate on the key anti-elitism theme which the Government is convinced will play well to its supporters. The attacks have been approved by Prime Minister Tony Blair, who will join the campaign when he returns from paternity leave.

The survey found that 39 per cent of places in all subjects at Britain's top 13 universities were filled by students from the private sector.

If selection had been purely according to grades, the figure should have been 28 per cent, the Sutton Trust research concluded. It was not known whether state pupils were being deterred from applying by perceived elitism or discriminated against by other factors.

At the top five universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, more than half the places were filled by students from independent schools.

The report will be seized on by Brown, who last week angrily attacked Oxford University for rejecting the comprehensive schoolgirl Laura Spence, who had applied to study medicine.

And it will further fuel what has now become a concerted Labour push to tackle what it sees as the snobbery and old school ties still holding talented teenagers back.

Prescott will underline the theme in a keynote speech on Tuesday attacking the 'forces of elitism'.

Blunkett, the Education Secretary, will also refer to the issue in a speech on Thursday and Brown will return to the subject the following week. Blunkett will announce plans for Government-supported talent spotting teams which universities will use to encourage disadvantaged students into the top universities.

The idea, which is based on a project at Harvard, has been successfully used at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (Umist), where the number of disadvantaged students matches the proportion in the local community.

'Britain has always worked well for the top 10 per cent in our society,' Prescott will say. 'We are fighting to change Britain, its economy and its institutions, so that it works well for all of our people.'

The Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, also joined the attack, calling for the civil service to open up to women and ethnic minorities.

The new agenda signals that the Government is moving on to a war footing, needled by William Hague's recent successes on tradi tional Labour issues such as pensions - a theme to which he will return this week.

Meanwhile, the Tories will return to the attack today with a fresh dossier of policies for the elderly, to target disillusioned pensioners.

Social security spokesman David Willetts will promise benefit changes for pensioners caring for an infirm spouse, and match Labour's commitments to breast cancer screening for women aged 65-69 and to abolishing mixed sex wards.

The Tories would also allow war widows to retain their late husband's pension if they remarried, pre-empting a Government review on war pensions.

fields.headline: The war of Laura's rejection
fields.standfirst: Thousands of bright pupils fail to get into Oxford. What is different about Laura Spence is that Labour saw an opportunity for point-scoring. Report:  Sarah Ryle,  Kamal Ahmed,  Martin Bright
fields.trailText: Locals know it as Monkey High, a huge comprehensive on the outskirts of Whitley Bay with a catchment area including the middle-class West Monkseaton where Laura Spence lives. But the school also takes in acres of council-estate kids who are as likely to covet a season ticket for St James' Park, home of Newcastle United, as a place at one of the country's élite universities. Before Laura hit the headlines, Monkseaton Community High School's best-known product was Michael Bridges, the Leeds United player and England under-21 international.
fields.body:
Locals know it as Monkey High, a huge comprehensive on the outskirts of Whitley Bay with a catchment area including the middle-class West Monkseaton where Laura Spence lives. But the school also takes in acres of council-estate kids who are as likely to covet a season ticket for St James' Park, home of Newcastle United, as a place at one of the country's élite universities. Before Laura hit the headlines, Monkseaton Community High School's best-known product was Michael Bridges, the Leeds United player and England under-21 international.

Laura was this year's only Oxford applicant from a pool of 100 sixth-formers, according to the head, Dr Paul Kelley. By the weekend, both Kelley and Laura said they were overwhelmed by the storm over her failure to win a place at Magdalen College, a state of affairs condemned by Gordon Brown and a raft of Labour colleagues, as an example of old-school-tie elitism.

Californian-born Kelley insists he did not expect the story to attract national attention, despite the fact that a remarkably similar story about another of his sixth-formers, Lara Dixon, caused a stir this time last year. Like Laura, Lara applied to Oxford, failed to get in and won a scholarship to Harvard, in her case to read business studies.

On the face of it, the only real difference is that this year Labour is cranking up its general election machine. 'To say I was surprised is understating it,' said Kelley, on his way to do yet another television interview. 'Stunned is closer. I did not believe that the Labour Party would take on the establishment in this way. It shows how badly I misread this. I am trying to steer the story away from Laura now and on to the crunch issue underneath all of this which is discrimination.'

From one viewpoint, Kelley's handling of the case could be judged as cynical: having enjoyed publicity one year as a result of a pupil's failed attempt to get into Oxford and subsequent success at Harvard, he has guided a second girl through the same process. His point about discrimination would have been less well made, he admits, if Laura had won a place at a college in, say, Des Moines, Illinois.

Whatever the rights and wrongs of the case, Gordon Brown's comments about Laura Spence have tapped into the Zeitgeist. All our national obsessions: class, education and elitism are represented in the experience of one shy schoolgirl.

'I can't really comment any further because it has got so political,' she told The Observer this weekend.

At just 18 years old, she has been startled to see her name, face and details of her academic performance printed on the front pages of national newspapers and bandied about by Cabinet Ministers on television.

The 'Laura Spence issue' was a gift to the Government. The question: could they make the juxtaposition of Oxford's dreaming spires and Tyneside's comprehensive girl work for Labour?

It took Downing Street three attempts to reap its political capital. At the Education Select Committee meeting last Tuesday, party managers hoped that Education Secretary David Blunkett would use the 'scandal of Oxbridge elitism' line if asked about Laura Spence. Nobody obliged.

On Wednesday, Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott was primed to deliver the same broadside if the opportunity arose at Prime Minister's Questions. He too drew a blank.

Chancellor Gordon Brown's equal opportunities speech to the unions on Thursday night,at last, provided a result: his tirade sparked a soundbite fest. David Blunkett and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook waxed irate on Radio 4's Today programme. Evan Harris, Liberal Democrat education spokesman, yesterday told the Government to concentrate on 'funding, funding, funding' for all universities.

Whatever Brown's motivation, the issue is real. New figures to be released this week by education guru Peter Lampl will show that children from state schools with excellent results are failing to get to the country's top five universities. Working with the Government's own figures Lampl will show that on results alone you would expect only a third of places to go to students from the private sector when, at present, the split is 50-50.

But, as ever, the issue is far more complex than the rhetoric would suggest. To the Oxford academics, the politicians' outrage is rich. Magdalen President Anthony Smith rushed to denounce Brown and Blunkett's use of Laura to beef up their left-wing credentials and to prepare the ground for funding cuts.

'Mr Brown said it was time we opened our doors to women and people from all backgrounds. Yet of the five successful candidates, three are women, three are from ethnic minorities and two are from comprehensives,' said Smith.

Laura was one of 22 applicants for five places. All 22 had 10 GSCEs at grade A*. All had brilliant A-level predictions. Laura herself picked up on this point at the start of her week in the spotlight when she was openly discussing her experience and her initial disappointment when Oxford turned her down before Christmas.

'At the time, I wanted to go there more than Harvard,' she admitted to her local paper, the Journal. 'The report from Oxford which came back to my school said they rejected me because they thought I might have potential, but they weren't sure. I think that the job of the interview committees is to find out whether you have potential.

'Personally, I think GCSE grades do demonstrate a certain amount of potential but probably it was just my personality - I'm not outgoing and wasn't ready to tell everybody "I'm wonderful".'

She has effectively undermined Robin Cook's point yesterday that Magdalen was guilty of prejudice when it stated that comprehensive pupils have less confidence than private-sector students.

Oxford insiders say the outside world simply does not realise how high the standard is. Schools believe that exam grades alone qualify candidates for admission.

The university points out that earlier this month it hired out Old Trafford, Manchester United's football ground, with Cambridge, in a joint initiative to boost applications from the North. A third of the sixth formers who attended said they would be applying.

But 1.9 per cent of Oxford's students come from schools in the North East, compared to 42 per cent from London and the South East. Cambridge barely does better, admitting 3 per cent from the region compared to 43 per cent from London and the South East.

The university knows it has a lot of work to do, but insists that attracting applicants is the key rather than addressing its admissions system.

According to Magdalen, Laura performed relatively poorly in the structured discussion section of her interview. It has been a steep learning curve since her head teacher tipped off a friendly reporter at the Journal.

Oxbridge: The facts

 73 per cent of judges appointed since 1997 have been to Oxbridge

 1.9 per cent of 1998 Oxbridge students were unemployed six months after graduating

 In 1999 Oxford graduates expected a starting salary of £19,000 rising to £37,800 after five years

 In 1999 Cambridge graduates expected a starting salary of £18,900 rising to £34,600 after five years

 Oxbridge sends about 900 graduates a year into the City (including law), but fewer than 100 into state school teaching

 In 1996 Oxbridge graduates accounted for 36 per cent of fast-track appointments to the Civil Service

 39 per cent of graduate recruits to the Civil Service in 1996 came from Oxbridge

 A survey in 1996 showed that 70 per cent of bishops were Oxbridge graduates

 37 per cent of hereditary peers were educated at Oxbridge (according to Lady Jay earlier this year)

Sources: Labour Research, Oxford Careers Service, High Fliers market research, Who's Who, 'A Class Act' by Andrew Adonis, General Synod

fields.headline: Admit you're wrong, Gordon Brown
fields.standfirst: The noted Oxford scientist takes issue with the Chancellor on his view of Oxford 'elitism'
fields.trailText: Dear Mr Brown
fields.body:
Dear Mr Brown

As Chancellor you surely formulate your policies in the light of meticulously researched statistical facts and figures. Yet this week you behaved like a Chancellor who is informed by a single shopper that the price of Woodbines is a bleeding liberty, believes it, and bases an important part of his budgetary policy on it. This week you have listened to tabloid tittle-tattle; you have used it to make political cheap shots; and above all you refused to climb down even when you had passed the point where you must have known you were mistaken.

The facts are these. Medicine is a notoriously over-subscribed subject, and many superb candidates are routinely beaten by even more superb candidates. As Alan Ryan pointed out in The Guardian last week, that doesn't make them bad runners. They enter another race and next time may outrun the competition. The young woman at the centre of your fuss went in for another race, at Harvard, and this time she outran the competition. Good for her. It doesn't mean the original race was unfair. Of the 23 candidates for only five places to read medicine at Magdalen, 12 had GCSE scores at least as good as hers.

It was reported - and you swallowed it - that she won a 'scholarship' at Harvard. By now somebody will have told you 'scholarship' in this context refers to the ordinary means-tested financial assistance Harvard hands out to its students. It does not carry the connotations of honour we associate with 'Scholarship'.

Moreover, Harvard have not accepted her to read medicine. If she had applied to Oxford to read almost any other scientific subject than medicine she would almost certainly have got in. She might have won a scholarship. I mean a real scholarship trailing clouds of glory - except that Oxford gave up Entrance Scholarships some years ago on the grounds that they were too elitist.

In your bullying tactics, you have been unfair to those successful candidates who were accepted. Surely you must realise that in order to make way for your favoured candidate, one of those superbly qualified young people would have had to have been rejected.

I genuinely believe that Oxford is not elitist, and this is supported by the recent Teaching Quality Assessment, which awarded Oxford full marks for its entrance procedures. But, important as that is, it has been overtaken by the fact that a holder of one of the three great Offices of State has been shown to be so wrong, yet refuses to acknowledge it.

Here at Oxford, we teach students not to base generalisations on one anecdote. We also teach them to admit it if they are conclusively shown to be wrong. 'New' Labour? You'll be really new if you now depart from all political precedent and apologise.

Yours sincerely,

Richard Dawkins,

Charles Simonyi Professor of Public Understanding of Science, Oxford

webTitle: Get over it, Laura. Grade A whingeing won't do

fields.headline: Get over it, Laura. Grade A whingeing won't do
fields.standfirst: Exams alone won't get you to Oxbridge, writes  Stephanie Merritt, a state pupil who made it
fields.trailText: Poor Laura Spence. Rejection is horrible. Who wouldn't sympathise with her disappointment and the battering her pride must have suffered on being told she wasn't good enough to get into Oxford?
fields.body:
Poor Laura Spence. Rejection is horrible. Who wouldn't sympathise with her disappointment and the battering her pride must have suffered on being told she wasn't good enough to get into Oxford?

To hope that insidious prejudices were at work is an instinctive reaction to soften the blow - I didn't get in, you tell yourself, because I'm not posh enough - the bastards. In the same way, rejected applicants from private schools comfort themselves with the idea that they did not get in because they didn't go to a comprehensive in the North East.

But to assert this as hard fact on the Today programme, with your publicity-hungry headmaster prompting you from the sidelines, appears self-serving, bitter and ridiculous.

Laura is not alone in this indignant display of sour grapes. A rejection from Oxford or Cambridge seems to fire a special kind of festering resentment that can last a lifetime, evident in snide jibes and accusations of elitism. That people feel this strongly is nothing to do with latent prejudices and the old school tie; it is because Oxford and Cambridge are internationally renowned as centres of excellence, a reputation they maintain by being discerning in their admissions - and no one likes to be told they are not good enough.

'It is a scandal that Laura should have to go and study in the States,' her headmaster said. Well, of course, she doesn't have to at all. She had other offers, and there are some very good departments of medicine at other British universities, many of them better equipped than Oxford's; in one sentence, he sweepingly dismissed them all. But for Laura, not even the thrill of a scholarship to Harvard has been enough to take the sting out of being turned down by Oxford.

Get over it, Laura. Oxbridge places are competitive, and always have been. Last year my brother - who, like me, went to a comprehensive - was rejected by Oxford. Like all Oxbridge applicants, including Laura, he is academically outstanding, but instead of bleating that he was a victim of snobbery, he was big enough to admit that maybe he just hadn't done too well in his interview. Determined not to be beaten, though, he worked hard, tried again this year and was offered a place.

The truth is that Laura Spence is not unusual; she is clearly bright, but if she'd done her research, she would have known that brandishing a few grade-A passes does not give you a God-given right to Oxbridge entrance, whatever your background. Nor does it mean you necessarily have the qualities to make the best contribution to college life.

Only American tourists are naive enough to imagine that our ancient universities are still full of effete Sebastians and Ruperts, swigging Pimms and punting. The people I met at Cambridge were as diverse as you could find at any university, but had this in common: we were there because we had the talent, and because we'd worked hard for it.

Gordon Brown may find it hard to believe, but Oxbridge is a meritocracy; I never felt it mattered at all where I went to school, and it hasn't mattered since. Of course, more students from comprehensives should be encouraged to apply - preferably by abolishing tuition fees and restoring grants - but Oxford and Cambridge are working hard to dismantle stereotypes, and the idea of a quota system is insulting. A commitment to the highest standards should not be confused with elitism, and Oxford and Cambridge should not be forced to lower their standards to satisfy a nervous government's push for populism.

The people who live, work and teach in these universities are best-qualified to judge who should be offered places. It is not the province of politicians.

fields.headline: Asylum policy 'risks racial tension'
fields.trailText:
Asylum: myths and reality - Observer special

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.body:
The policy of housing tens of thousands of asylum-seekers away from London and the South East has been condemned by the Audit Commission as a disaster that could raise racial tensions.

A report by the local government watchdog, to be published on Thursday, says the system is in danger of collapse unless there is an immediate injection of cash to help the regions cope with new arrivals. The report, 'Another Country', says that without support services, people will drift back south, where they will be ineligible for money or benefits.

At the same time, an investigation by The Observer has revealed that the Home Office is handing out lucrative dispersal contracts to poorly-regulated private companies in a desperate attempt to make the policy work.

One firm, Landmark, was found to be housing asylum-seekers in two crumbling tower blocks abandoned by the local authority as unfit for council tenants. In Nelson, a town in Lancashire with no refugee services, people had been housed without alerting the local authority.

Under a compulsory scheme introduced by Home Secretary Jack Straw last month, asylum-seekers are to be transported in 'clusters' around the country to relieve pressure on the capital and the South-east.

But a leaked copy of the Audit Commission report, seen by The Observer, says that evidence from voluntary schemes shows that by last March fewer than 2,000 asylum seekers. The target was 10,400.

One section reads: 'Inadequate support services outside London present a major barrier to dispersal.' Fewer than half of the legal firms geared to the needs of refugees have offices outside London. Mental health services, English language support and refugee community bodies are also in the capital.

The report concludes: 'Unless these barriers are overcome, problems will persist and could undermine the Government's social exclusion objective.'

Fazil Kawani, of the Refugee Council, said: 'We are being inundated with complaints from asylum-seekers being sent to very poor accommodation.

'We have said all along that for a dispersal to be a success and for asylum-seekers to be given a fair hearing, it is vital that they can access important services such as health care, interpreters and legal advice.'

webTitle: Grey panthers can save the paper tigers

fields.headline: Grey panthers can save the paper tigers
fields.trailText: Quite the oddest new thing in national newspapers this spring is your 'dotcom.telegraph' every Thursday. It is just so hectically, desperately young.
fields.body:
Quite the oddest new thing in national newspapers this spring is your 'dotcom.telegraph' every Thursday. It is just so hectically, desperately young.

How do you top a feature on eight 'Rich Kids' who made an internet million before they left university? With another, of course, on those who did it while they were still at school. Love bugs, geek gadgets, pop portals - no Channel 4 late-night show ever boasted such a hip-hopping array. 'Site for wannabe single mothers'? Yes, your swinging Daily Telegraph found it for you first. Charlie Moore flogs sex without shame.

Well... actually not, of course. The great leader, in his great leader column, remains attached to two-parent family values. He is the only editor who can batter the BBC for slighting the Queen Mum and demand that the Royal Ulster Constabulary survives in the same thousand words. So, what is all this frenzied dotcommery, now enshrined in a 12-page separate section, intended to achieve?

Hard question: easy answer. The Telegraph wants more young readers and the net advertising they bring with them. Young readers are (conventionally) a paper's future: ads pay Mr Conrad Black's present bills. And the same Mr Black, remember, has lately concluded that his Hollinger share price has suffered too much for lack of an internet profile. He's putting his small-town Canadian papers up for sale to finance the shift. Who can say who will own the dotcom.telegraph next?

Yet there is another, less conventional, factor at work here. You sense it when a youthful William Hague suddenly discovers the wonder of fat pension rises. Young readers may remain the audience that advertisers lust after most: but there will be far fewer of them around in the grey recesses of this 21st century. That shrinkage, ironically enough, may already be part of the Telegraph's dogged success.

Here, along the age range, are a few uncomfortable facts for followers of old Moore: 28 per cent of his readers - on the year-end NRS research - are over 65 now (as compared with 13 per cent of the Guardian's and 15 per cent of the Times's ). Add in those over 55 (another 18 per cent) and the Telegraph's readership becomes the creakiest in Fleet Street.

In April 1975 it sold 1.35 million copies; last month it sold 1.04 million (while both Guardian and Times were substantially up on a quarter-century ago). Where have all the buyers gone? To the graveyard, every one. The doughty modernising efforts of Max Hastings and, to be fair, Charles Moore haven't managed to shift that fatal profile.

With it go a further stack of nasty comparisons. Only 7 per cent of Telegraph readers are ABC1s between 15 and 24 (as opposed to 12 per cent for the Times ). Only 27 per cent of Telegraph readers are ABC1s who were educated to the age of 21 (as opposed to 48 per cent for the Guardian ). The Times has 627,000 readers under the age of 45 in full-time work: the Telegraph , for all its circulation lead, can boast a mere 560,000. The Guardian , which sells just under 400,000, has more well-educated professional readers under 45 (293,000) than the Telegraph (264,000) with its million-plus sale.

Such statistics, naturally, take their internet toll. More Times readers (1.046 million) than Telegraph readers (1.036 million) claim to have accessed the internet in the past 12 months. The Times has a clear lead among all full-time workers here. The Guardian and Telegraph are dead level among educated, professional web surfers. Something clearly needs to be done, and 12 pages of schoolkid dotcom millionaires would seem to be it.

But there is - crucially - another way of looking at the picture. Fleet Street has been waiting for years for the Telegraph's crude circulation figure to dip below the supposedly magical million mark. That was an aim in the Eighties as Telegraph defectors founded the Independent and in the Nineties as Rupert Murdoch slashed the cover price of the Times. And yet it hasn't happened. Indeed, the Telegraph's circulation last month was almost where it stood in April 1996. This tall timber stubbornly declines to fall.

Some of that, to be sure, can be attributed to the cosmetic surgery of subscription schemes, bulks and discounts. Nearly 400,000 copies go that way. Yet there are other, more complex, attributes in play.

One is the sheer, walloping strength of the Telegraph's Saturday package (set 2,791,000 readers against the Independent's 616,000) which also titillates the age profile at the margins. Yet, perversely, that profile may eventually be coming to the rescue, too. For the flipside of an ageing population could be that the paper that is strongest among the over-55s is also strongest in the biggest area for future growth.

Pensioner power isn't some notional concept. It wins local elections for William Hague. It scares Tony Blair rigid. Britain's population is shrinking, not growing. Fewer births: longer lives. The average western European was 29 years old in 1950. By 2050, on UN-monitored trends, that person will be nearly 48 - politically more conservative and wanting to call the tune.

If newspapers are going to die as the net sweeps on, the last to go will be the ones who serve the non-electronic generations. If ads are going to sell, they'll need the silver panthers. The age equation, you see, cuts two ways (unless Charlie Dotcom's single mums do their unprophesied duty).

webTitle: Burma guide book publisher stands firm against boycott

fields.headline: Burma guide book publisher stands firm against boycott
fields.trailText: Lonely Planet publisher Tony Wheeler remained defiant last week in the face of the call to boycott his titles until he withdraws a guide book to Burma. Tourism Concern, the ethical travel pressure group, and the Burma Campaign UK launched its boycott by dumping 'unwanted' Lonely Planet guides at the company's London offices. But speaking from his base in Melbourne, Australia, Wheeler said: 'This campaign actually makes me more determined. I am not going to be told by anyone what I can publish.'
fields.body:
Lonely Planet publisher Tony Wheeler remained defiant last week in the face of the call to boycott his titles until he withdraws a guide book to Burma. Tourism Concern, the ethical travel pressure group, and the Burma Campaign UK launched its boycott by dumping 'unwanted' Lonely Planet guides at the company's London offices. But speaking from his base in Melbourne, Australia, Wheeler said: 'This campaign actually makes me more determined. I am not going to be told by anyone what I can publish.'

The boycott call highlights the ethical debate about travelling to countries with repressive regimes. Tourism Concern identifies Burma as a 'rare but clear example' of a country that should not be visited by tourists. It points to direct links between the development of tourism and the widespread use of forced labour for public sector works. Tourism income sustains a brutal military regime, it says, and the elected leaders, under house arrest, have pleaded with tourists to stay away.

Wheeler agrees that it is a 'nasty government' but a two-page introduction to the disputed guide questions whether all opposition politicians are against travel and suggests that it is possible to support non-government sponsored tourism by staying at privately owned hotels and using public transport.

Tourism Concern's campaign quotes the opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, who said in January 1999: 'Guide book writers should listen to their consciences and be honest about their motivations. Profit is clearly their agenda.' Wheeler said: 'This is not an important book for us, it was pushed to the back of the pile before we published it in January. But just as an encyclopedia must cover the world, whatever the regime, I am not going to leave a gap.'

The debate about boycotting oppressive regimes has always raised difficult questions. There is a point when the positive effects of travel - the spread of ideas as well as the economic benefits - are outweighed by the sheer brutality of the regime. Many, including The Observer , drew that line on South Africa during apartheid. But should we stay away from China because of the suppression of human rights in Tibet? Escape carried a cover feature on Beijing earlier this year. Was it sufficient that we recorded the human rights abuses?

There is a solid liberal argument that the traveller - and the reader - should be allowed to make up his or her own mind. There is something disturbing about a boycott of a series of guide books, whatever offence one particular title might cause.

It is not possible to publish guide books without causing offence. Wheeler points to the difficulty of publishing maps of the India-Pakistan border and recalls how the Lonely Planet Malawi guide would be seized at the border by officials of the Hastings Banda regime.

For the record, on Escape we respect Aung San Suu Kyi's call not to visit her country and would not write about Burma as a tourist destination. But we will not be burning any books either.

webTitle: Murder riddle at Chaplin's Swiss mansion

fields.headline: Murder riddle at Chaplin's Swiss mansion
fields.trailText: A bizarre murder mystery was unfolding at the Swiss mansion belonging to the heirs of the silent movie star Charlie Chaplin yesterday, after a hanged man was found dangling next to the corpse of a decapitated woman.
fields.byline: Jason Burke and Peter Capella Geneva
fields.body:
A bizarre murder mystery was unfolding at the Swiss mansion belonging to the heirs of the silent movie star Charlie Chaplin yesterday, after a hanged man was found dangling next to the corpse of a decapitated woman.

The bodies, believed to be of a young married Moldavian couple with no ties to the Chaplin family, are thought to have been there several weeks.

They were found by the head gardener at the Manoir de Ban in a secluded part of the nineteenth century mansion's extensive grounds on Friday evening.

Michael Chaplin, the movie star's son, who called the police. Charlie Chaplin lived in the house in the village of Corsier-sur-Vevey from 1953 until his death in 1977 after he left America to escape the McCarthy witchhunts.

webTitle: How to fill the endowment gap

fields.headline: How to fill the endowment gap
fields.standfirst: Thousands of homebuyers have been warned of loan problems.  Maria Scott  presents a rescue guide
fields.trailText: University lecturer Colin Richardson is among thousands of people facing up to the possibility that their endowment policy will not repay the mortgage. He is bitter, and feels that the salesman who sold him the Legal & General policy, taken out 10 years ago to repay a £42,000 loan on the Richardson family home in Durham, misled him about how it would perform.
fields.body:
University lecturer Colin Richardson is among thousands of people facing up to the possibility that their endowment policy will not repay the mortgage. He is bitter, and feels that the salesman who sold him the Legal & General policy, taken out 10 years ago to repay a £42,000 loan on the Richardson family home in Durham, misled him about how it would perform.

'It was put forward as inconceivable that it wouldn't pay off the loan,' says Colin. He had asked clearly whether the policy would repay the loan. The salesman's reaction was 'almost a smile on the face'.

Yet 10 years later a letter from the company has warned Colin there may be a shortfall of almost £7,000 on his policy when the loan is due to be repaid in 15 years' time. He believes the policy was mis-sold to him, and is trying to find the best way to bridge the gap.

Here is a guide to dealing with endowment problems:

Do I have a case for compensation?

The Financial Services Ombudsman is receiving a record number of complaints about endowments, and they are unlikely to diminish this year as homeowners are warned of shortfalls. Fresh publicity about endowments resulting from last week's BBC Panorama programme is also likely to increase awareness among homeowners.

A shortfall will not necessarily produce compensation payments. Policies are now projecting gaps because companies are forecasting lower rates of investment growth in future than when the policies were set up. The Financial Services Authority warns, however, that it's no use complaining if you are 'simply unhappy about how your endowment has performed'.

Many people feel they were not adequately warned about potential shortfalls, however. A spokeswoman for the Ombudsman's Office says: 'If they say they weren't warned [that the loan may not be repaid], it would be up to the adviser to demonstrate that the person had received warnings.'

It would be useful to have written evidence of inappropriate reassurances, she adds.

In Colin's case, Legal & General insists that no guarantees will have been given, though he recalls being told that 'not only would it pay off the mortgage but almost certainly there would be money left over'. He was told there would be free life insurance with the endowment mortgage whereas, with a repayment loan, he would have to buy life cover separately.

None of this was written down. But for people in his position it may still be worth making a formal complaint to the seller of the endowment. In most cases this will have been the mortgage lender, acting as an agent of the insurer. Only if you are not satisfied with the insurer's response can you take your case to the Ombudsman.

One category of complaint that is going the policyholders' way is where cover was sold to someone who would pass retirement age when it was due to mature (see below).

What's the best way to pay off a shortfall?

The main options are to:

 Convert a sum equivalent to the forecast shortfall into a repayment loan. Make sure your lender understands what you want to do. Colin asked his lender, Cheltenham & Gloucester, how much it would cost per month to repay his £7,000 shortfall over 15 years. He was quoted around £100, about four times the amount Legal & General said it would charge to top up the endowment with an extra policy. When Cash contacted C&G it said the repayments would be just over £59; staff must have assumed he wanted to convert the entire loan.

 If you will be stretched to afford extra monthly payments involved, find out whether remortgaging could produce savings.

 Save in a tax-free Individual Savings Account. Your choice of Isa will depend on how much time you have until the end of your mortgage. If it is less than five years, it would be too risky to use a shares-based Isa. Phillip Cartwright of mortgage adviser London & Country says homeowners should be aware, however, that if they choose an equity Isa there will, again, be no guarantees that the investment will repay the shortfall. For some homeowners, the minimum monthly payments quoted by the insurer to top up the endowment will be lower than the minimum sums needed to start an Isa. But returning to the insurer may still be 'throwing good money after bad,' says Cartwright.

 Have you other investments that may mature in time to repay the shortfall? If you have spare savings available now, it may be worth paying a lump sum off the loan.

 Consider extending the term of the mortgage and endowment to give the policy longer to repay the loan.

 The least attractive option is to pay more money to the endowment insurer.

Payouts for Observer readers

Compensation for endowment mis-selling is being paid to readers who appealed to the Financial Services Ombudsman on the advice of Cash.

Madeleine Brierley, 53, a teacher from Lancashire, was delighted when the Ombudsman found in her favour after she complained about her CIS endowment: 'When I took out the mortgage I was 43, and it took me well beyond my retirement age, to 71.' She is to receive £14,500, for premiums paid plus interest.

 Financial Services Authority: 0845 606 1234 Ombudsman: 0207 216 0016

fields.headline: Chemical reaction
fields.standfirst: An additive scandal in Australia might be the boost organic growers need
fields.trailText: 'Red without rules' runs the oh-so-apposite advertising campaign for Australia's enormous Kingston Estate winery. 'Too bloody true, mate,' one is tempted to comment in the wake of an investigation into certain less than savoury cellar practices at the company's headquarters. It was student winemakers visiting from California who first made the allegations about 'illegal and unethical' winemaking techniques. Kingston, it has since been confirmed, did indeed use the banned substance silver nitrate to remove the smell of hydrogen sulphide (rotten eggs) from some of its wines. Silver nitrate sounds worse than it is, mind you. It is a perfectly legal additive in some countries, and the quantities found in the offending wines were well below the levels accepted for tap water.
fields.body:
'Red without rules' runs the oh-so-apposite advertising campaign for Australia's enormous Kingston Estate winery. 'Too bloody true, mate,' one is tempted to comment in the wake of an investigation into certain less than savoury cellar practices at the company's headquarters. It was student winemakers visiting from California who first made the allegations about 'illegal and unethical' winemaking techniques. Kingston, it has since been confirmed, did indeed use the banned substance silver nitrate to remove the smell of hydrogen sulphide (rotten eggs) from some of its wines. Silver nitrate sounds worse than it is, mind you. It is a perfectly legal additive in some countries, and the quantities found in the offending wines were well below the levels accepted for tap water.

All the same, this is a (minor) scandal the wine industry could do without. Or perhaps it isn't. First, the Aussies dealt with the matter openly and quickly. Secondly, the publicity about silver nitrate might make us think a little more carefully about how wine is produced in general.

It is a common misconception that wine is a natural product. But without chemicals, it is almost impossible to make drinkable wine. Ban sulphur dioxide as a legal additive, for example, and most wine would taste as flat as the Argentine pampas. Nevertheless, some wines are more natural than others. This is especially true in the vineyard, where organic and bio-dynamic producers eschew pesticides and herbicides (though not copper sulphate). This doesn't make them better winemakers, but it does mean their wines are 'greener'.

The Kingston affair could undermine the public's trust in 'conventional' winemaking. And I'm not only talking about silver nitrate here. Just as bad, in my view, was Kingston's legal but not exactly wholesome use of grapeskins to colour white juice (and sell it as red wine).

If you're worried about such developments, there are two alternatives. The first is to spend a little more on a bottle of wine (cheap plonk producers are often forced to trim corners). The second is to buy an organically certified wine. There's only one snag here: establishing authenticity. Not every winery that claims to be organic has been certified by one of the confusing array of organic bodies. Life would be much easier if there was a single accepted standard for organic wine. But don't hold your breath.

Confused? You wait until you start trying to understand EU regulation 2092/21 and the workings of the United Kingdom Register of Organic Food Standards. My advice is to invest in a copy of two really good books about organic wine: Friends of the Earth Organic Wine Guide by Monty Waldin (£8.99, Thorsons) and The Great Organic Wine Guide by Hilary Wright (£8.99, Piatkus), both of them full of wines that play by the rules.

fields.headline: Corporate victims
fields.trailText: A few weeks ago, during a tour of the Canary Wharf Group's marketing suite up on the thirtieth floor of Canada Tower, I was shown models of what will eventually be the 700ft skyscrapers housing the headquarters for HSBC and Citigroup.
fields.body:
A few weeks ago, during a tour of the Canary Wharf Group's marketing suite up on the thirtieth floor of Canada Tower, I was shown models of what will eventually be the 700ft skyscrapers housing the headquarters for HSBC and Citigroup. John Pagano, the Canary Wharf Group's cheerful vice-president for construction, was pleased with the way the work was going, the layered shell of each new building now rising effortlessly about its concrete core.

The two construction jobs had, he said, been given to different contractors. What, I asked, so they'll race each other to the top? 'Absolutely,' Pagano said. 'They're matching each other floor for floor at the moment.'

Last Thursday the hundreds of construction workers on the site stopped competing. Tools were downed and the massive spindle jibs of the cranes finally came to rest. The Sunday before, three of their colleagues - Martin Burgess, 31, Peter Clark, 33, and Michael Whittard, 39 - were killed when the crane they were erecting collapsed. Now it was time to observe a minute's silence.

It is very likely that the workers paying their respects last week used the time to remember other friends and colleagues in the building trade who have also died as a result of how they made their living. Britain's construction industry is second only to mining for the number of lives it claims each year.

Between March 1998 and March 1999 - a good year as it happens - 70 people were killed on British construction sites. That's the equivalent of more than two Paddington train crashes. Another 4,600 suffered major injuries, classed as limb breakages, amputations, blindings and the like.

But perhaps even more startling than the grim casualty score card is the rarity with which anybody is ever called to account for these deaths and injuries. Between 1996 and 1998 the Health and Safety Executive, under whose remit such accidents fall, investigated just 11 per cent of major injuries. In turn only 11 per cent of those - 1 per cent of the total - resulted in a prosecution. As to deaths, only 18.8 per cent of companies were prosecuted for associated infringements of health and safety regulations. However, not a single director or manager was hauled up in the courts to answer for what had happened to their employees.

Little can be said yet about the tragic events at Canary Wharf. Both the police and the HSE are investigating. Doubtless they will also want to look at the two other serious crane accidents which have occurred on the same Canary Wharf site over the past six weeks, fortunately with no loss of life.

But the deaths, coming in the very same week as the launch of a Government consultation paper on a new offence of corporate killing, cannot help but concentrate our minds on the horrible risks people are forced to take simply to earn a living.

The Government's initiative is to be welcomed. In theory it has always been possible to prosecute companies and their directors for the manslaughter of their employees, but in practical terms the definition of such a crime has been so vague that it has rarely been tried. No one was ever called to account in court for the death tolls in the 1987 King's Cross fire, or the 1988 Clapham rail crash or the 1997 Southall rail crash, even though subsequent inquiries into all three identified serious management failings right the way up the chain of command.

The proposed changes introduce a set of specific offences which should make it far easier to get a result. The only problem lies in the small print of the consultation paper: the Law Commission is proposing that the agency responsible for investigating and prosecuting such cases should be the very same agency that has already proved itself so woefully poor at the job, namely the Health and Safety Executive.

Why, when their record has been so dismal in the past - and in the present, for that matter - should we suddenly assume that they will be up to the new challenge? For their part the HSE argues that, were they to be given the role, the Government would also give them the necessary resources, but that would hardly address the question of their overall competence. If a brickie could not lay a straight wall you wouldn't suddenly give him the cash to build your whole house.

The HSE also argues that their failure in the past to prosecute in manslaughter cases hasn't been their fault but that of the damn Crown Prosecution Service, which keeps throwing them out. Between 1992 and 1998, the HSE passed 59 cases to the CPS, which proceeded with 18. Only four were successful. Doesn't this suggest that something was just a little lacking in the evidence the HSE had managed to gather? What's more, isn't 59 cases - a tiny fraction of the total work-related deaths for the period - a touch unambitious?

Then, of course, there is the more basic issue of separating investigating duties from prosecuting duties. It was long ago decided that it would be better if the task of mounting prosecutions was taken out of the hands of the police. Why should it be any different for offences arising out of health and safety legislation? The HSE refused last week to comment on the proposals but, according to sources close to the Law Commission, it was the HSE itself which lobbied to be given the job, a classic ruse by a besieged bureaucracy desperate to protect its turf.

Of course, if the Government really wants to do something about deaths and injuries on Britain's building sites, it could have a serious go at getting employers to treat their workers decently. In an increasingly fragmented business where contractors sub-contract jobs to firms who in turn sub-contract jobs and ever onwards, profit margins are shaved so thinly that complying with either employment law or safety regulations has no place on the business plan.

The Union of Construction and Allied Trades estimates that upwards of 50 per cent of those in the business are forced to sign on to jobs on a self-employed basis, thus sparing their employers the cost of National Insurance payments. The Working Time Directives, introduced in 1998, are designed to force firms to give even the self-employed holiday pay. But too many companies are simply ignoring the law and are challenging their employees with a stark choice between rocking the boat by taking them to an industrial tribunal or simply staying quiet. Too many choose the latter.

This may look like the most tedious end of already tedious employment wrangles. But if there's one thing you can say with any certainty about an exhausted construction worker it's that they are a surefire safety risk. Force a builder to keep working and he runs a good chance of becoming yet another gruesome statistic. And that is something Britain's construction industry already has more than enough of.

Ken's policies ... what policies?

Anybody foolish enough to try to judge Ken Livingstone's suitability for the job of London Mayor during his campaign on the basis of his policies got what they deserved. Sure, there was stuff about congestion charging and a lot of grandstanding about the virginal purity of bonds over the sluttish improprieties of Public Private Partnerships for the funding of the Tube, but after that it was all a bit vague.

During one session with him amid the clamour of the election, the nearest I came to a Livingstone policy pronouncement was a promise to book Enya for a concert in a London park and a proposal that the capital's citizens should take Sunday lunches by the river and then go for a nice stroll the better to improve their health.

So I knew just how short on solid ideas the man happened to be, but I had not realised exactly how intense this policy vacuum was. Last week, amid the ecclesiastical splendour of Emmanuel Hall, the temporary home of the Greater London Assembly, the new Mayor came before the new GLA members to be interrogated for the first time.

The questions themselves were truly the stuff of international moment: something on waste management in Sutton, the tram system in Croydon, and the placing of radio masts in both of them. Conservative member Andrew Pelling, whose questions these were, is clearly a man to watch if only to make sure he isn't trying to sidle up to you. He could bore for Britain.

Before the questions started Mr Livingstone asked to make a statement. Amid the more reported announcements of new appointments was one initiative which has so far passed without comment. During the election, he said, time had been a bit constrained when it came to the tiresome business of writing a manifesto. So, now that he had been elected, he was going to get his old friend, the Labour MP John McDonnell, to undertake a major consultation exercise to come up with what he called 'a consensual strategy for a decade'. In other words, the candidate has waited until after winning the election to work out his manifesto. Well, it's certainly a different kind of politics.
