It now has more than a million customers, with almost £8 billion of deposits between them, and the much-derided name is one of the best-recognised brands in financial services. It has done the easy bit. Offer generous enough rates - Egg is still losing money on every deposit - and wealthy customers will flock to you, whether they have to do it through the Internet, the post office or the high street. Egg will also have won a bit of kudos for being the first serious Internet player. But the real test will come when it moves rates down to more realistic levels, as it will have to eventually. The chances are that much of that £8bn will be off in search of the next sucker keen to build a customer base. The Pru is well aware of the risk, and Egg chief executive Mike Harris and his team are putting their effort into finding ways of keeping its customers, and attracting other less fickle ones, by offering extras such as credit cards, insurance and a service to help you choose investment products. There is a surfeit of companies offering these things, so it is questionable how much loyalty such products will command. Egg now acknowledges that the only way to get customers and keep them coming to the site is to offer them a current account, and it will launch one within the next 12 months. It is a pity it waited so long. Had it offered one even 12 months ago, it would have been virtually the only true Internet bank. Now, however, it will have to fight off every one from Halifax to the Co-op, who watched Egg's success and decided to get their own customers online quickly. Egg's reluctance to move early was understandable. Running current accounts is expensive, time-consuming and will probably require an agreement with a high street bank. There is not even the compensation of big profits - although Egg will benefit from not having branches, the real rewards will come from selling other services. Egg may build a profitable online bank, but that is by no means guaranteed. The £1.1bn to £1.4bn price range may be well below the £4bn estimated just months ago, but is still a lot of money. Based on the average rating of the banking sector, it would need pre-tax profits of £120m to justify that valuation. In fact, it lost £150m last year - and its income was just £24m. It is promising to break even as late as the end of 2001. Only retail investors with Egg accounts can apply for the shares. Only those with real faith in its ability to beat the banks should bother. Not yet in focus Focus Do It All was doing its best to scare Wickes investors into accepting its 430p-a-share offer for its rival do-it-yourself operator last week. It will not sell its 29 per cent stake, which will rise to 35 per cent if Wickes carries out its promised tender offer. And, it warns, it will 'remain an active shareholder' if it loses: in other words, its tanks will remain on Wickes's lawn. Focus clearly has its mind on Blue Circle, which escaped the clutches of rival Lafarge despite the French group owning a 29 per cent stake. Like Blue Circle, Wickes is promising great things, in the form of a 33 per cent rise in profits this year. It is also following the cement group by proposing to buy back up to a quarter of its shares. And, like Lafarge, Focus is not offering enough to secure the bid. Focus is right that the DIY market is consolidating. The problem is, it needs to react to that consolidation much more than Wickes does. Focus made much of the competition from B&Q's Warehouses, and Wickes admits its sales do suffer when one of these giants opens alongside. But Wickes's distinctive offering, which targets the jobbing builder rather than the Changing Rooms addict, means the impact is relatively small and short-lived. Can Focus say the same? Wickes's limited product range means it is already enjoying many of the buying benefits which Focus claims the combined group would achieve. And putting the two businesses together in one site, as Focus proposes in some areas, would be likely to help neither brand. Wickes chief executive, Bill Grimsey will have to work hard to achieve his profits forecast for the year. If he suc ceeds - and Focus will be waiting to pounce if he doesn't - the 430p bid would represent just 12 times this year's earnings. That is not high enough to reflect Wickes's strong market position and potential for further growth. Reject. Hard slog ahead Rod Eddington, the new chief executive of British Airways, must be wishing he had cut the group's final dividend. Luc Vandevelde, the new man at Marks & Spencer did, and the retailer's shares jumped 16 per cent on the week while BA made up half that ground. M&S is still making money, while BA made its first loss since privatisation, but both of the new bosses face similar challenges. At M&S, a 1.5 per cent rise in clothing sales in the past few weeks is hardly exciting, given the scale of investment in getting the product right. While the look of the stores is improving, and some of its ranges are getting closer to what customers want, Vandevelde admits that winning customers back will be a long, hard slog. At BA, Eddington will have to devote as much effort to cost-cutting as his predecessor Bob Ayling did. A glance at past accounts shows how big a challenge that is. BA claims to have delivered 'efficiency improvements' of £1.1bn over the past three years. Yet BA has slumped from a £640m profit to last year's £244m loss. Costs in each of those three years have risen ahead of sales. Shares in both companies are now trading at less than half of their 1997 peaks. If the new chiefs live up to their promise, they should recover, but only the brave will bet on when that will be.

fields.headline: Trimble triumphant
fields.standfirst:
Henry McDonald on a week in which the Unionist leader lived on his nerves but finally pulled through

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Towards the end of a decisive week for Ulster Unionism and the Northern Ireland peace process the phone calls from the Province to a corner of the Pacific Far East became more and more frantic.
fields.body:
Towards the end of a decisive week for Ulster Unionism and the Northern Ireland peace process the phone calls from the Province to a corner of the Pacific Far East became more and more frantic.

David Trimble and his campaign team at their headquarters in Stormont kept in contact with unionism's most famous absentee - deputy Ulster Unionist leader John Taylor. Ever since the IRA launched its historic offer to put arms beyond use and allow independent observers to inspect its weapons dumps, Taylor has been a critical figure for Trimble.

Initially he had welcomed the IRA statement on 6 May but then appeared to backtrack and demanded further conditions from the British Government on the retention of the union flag over government buildings and the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Taylor, the bombastic, sub-aristocratic and eternally mercurial MP for Strangford, had the potential to make or break Trimble's plan to re-enter a power-sharing government with Sinn Fein.

If Taylor said yes to the deal then he could sway a critical band of wavering delegates to the 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council, the UUP's ruling body which met yesterday at Belfast's Waterfront Hall to ratify the proposal.

Taylor had gone Awol, taking himself off on an Industrial Development Board sponsored trip to Japan and Taiwan apparently just when his leader needed him most. The last time Trimble had faced such a knife-edge vote, back in November when the UUC first voted to join the ill-fated three-month coalition, Taylor was also absent. In the run-up to that decision he had spent a week before the UUC meeting in Iran.

But it now seems Taylor's latest absence actually played into the hands of the Trimble camp rather than his rivals, led by rejectionist MP and opponent of the Good Friday Agreement, Jeffrey Donaldson. 'With John out of the country at least that meant he couldn't be got at. John loves to play the knight in shining armour who rides in at the last minute to save the day. You have to make John think he's loved, that he's indispensable, that's why he holds off until the last minute,' said a Trimble aide.

The trans-Asia telephone chats between Trimble and Taylor paid off. The UUP leader's unpredictable deputy drafted an article for yesterday's issue of the unionist daily, the Ulster Newsletter, outlining why he would vote yes on arrival back from Taiwan.

While Taylor toured factories in Japan and Taiwan last week, Trimble toured the less exotic towns and villages of rural Protestant Ulster drumming up support for his analysis that the war was over and unionists should go back into government with their former enemies.

In the last five days of the campaign to persuade an estimated 100 to 150 floating voters on the UUC to back him, Trimble spoke at more than 20 separate venues. At times he faced outright hostility, particularly in Lisburn, the main town in Donaldson's Lagan Valley constituency.

On Tuesday night Democratic Unionist Party supporters had stood outside Trimble's home in Lisburn shouting and chanting abuse for two hours.

One member of the Trimble team who travelled with him to the north-west of the Province on Thursday said the UUP leader was 'physically shaking in the car' during their journey. Whether this was due to nerves, exhaustion or a combination of both, he did not say.

Trimble's strategy was twofold: to tour the country and talk to the UUP's constituency associations and to take the battle to where it counts in modern politics - the airwaves.

In the previous week the anti-agreement faction of Ulster Unionism and in particularly Donaldson had set the pace. The No camp used tactics such as tele-canvassing and posted out glossy three- and four-page documents to each of the 860 delegates urging a No vote. They were advised by David Lyle, a leading PR agent in Belfast whose main business for his advertising agency McCann Erikson (until now at least) has ironically been ad campaigns for the Northern Ireland Office.

The shock troops of the No campaign were the Young Unionists, the junior wing of the UUP who collectively sound and even dress like Tory Boy, the teenage Conservative fanatic invented by the comedian Harry Enfield. Zealous, right-wing and uncompromising, the sharp-suited Young Unionists were inflicting major damage on the Trimble camp with their highly organised tactics centred on unionist fears that Martin McGuinness, the former IRA chief-of-staff and Sinn Fein MP, was about to go back into government.

Trimble however had some unlikely allies of his own who knew infinitely more about McGuinness and his evolution from armed struggle to pragmatic politics than the Young Unionists ever could. Sean O'Callaghan, the IRA double-killer turned police agent, agreed to come to Belfast and speak at a number of public engagements in favour of Trimble. O'Callaghan joined the IRA at 15, rising to become its southern commander. He is someone who has intimate knowledge of republican leaders like McGuinness. The ex-IRA man had a brutally frank message for the UUP.

'I told them that I came from a republican family and had been in the IRA and yet with every fibre of my being the IRA's statement on May 6 meant that the war was over for good. I told them at every opportunity that they should back Trimble,' he said.

It was a mantra he continued to repeat throughout the week on both local television and radio.

Even without O'Callaghan it was clear Trimble was winning the battle of the airwaves in televised clashes with Donaldson and his arch-rival Paisley.

Trimble's exterior opponents in Irish nationalism meanwhile kept their counsel throughout the week preferring to remain silent lest an intervention might give the No unionist camp ammunition to attack the UUP leader.

But the Irish government is still concerned that Trimble might make entry and continued participation in a new government conditional on a fresh set of demands such as the RUC's name.

'Any more pre-conditions from Trimble and nationalism, particularly Sinn Fein, will go bananas. This is the last throw of the dice from the Provos, they are going to withdraw their offer if there are any more pre-conditions,' a senior source in the Irish government told The Observer .

The threat of republican violence still looms over the political process. Last Wednesday evening the Real IRA fired a mortar bomb at a British Army observation post near Crossmaglen in south Armagh. The Real IRA attack was clearly designed not only to disrupt the peace and undermine efforts to re-estab lish devolution but also put two-fingers up to the Provisionals' leadership. The Irish police acted swiftly on Thursday and Friday to curb a potential terrorist atrocit, arresting seven alleged members of the Real IRA in Dublin, Louth and Donegal, including the organisation's leader.

Meanwhile the loyalists were also engaged in violence despite protestations that their ceasefires are intact. On Wednesday the UVF attempted to kill a man they suspect was involved in the murder of the organisation's mid-Ulster brigadier, Richard Jameson. Two days later the group responsible for Jame son's murder, the LVF, shot Martin Taylor dead in north Belfast.

This violent backdrop only increased doubt in some UUC members' minds that the terrorist wars were far from over.

But the final tactic of the No camp was their best to date - an alternative form of devolution with potential for power-sharing put forward by Donaldson late on Thursday evening.

Donaldson's plan, which predicated a return to all-inclusive government on the actual destruction of IRA arms, was circulated to all 860 delegates.

But within hours the Irish government, the SDLP and Sinn Fein were pulling the Donaldson plan apart. With one voice Irish nationalism rejected any participation in what an Irish government source described as a 'talking shop devoid of real power.' Trimble took note and pointed out that Donaldson's plan was unworkable given the hostility of nationalist parties to the idea.

On the eve of the vote the Trimble camp were taking nothing for granted, with estimates that a narrow margin of 20 votes might be enough to win the day. Those closest to the UUP leader said he had even 'psychologically pre pared himself' for the prospect of defeat and the end of his leadership.

But in the final hours leading up to the historic vote on Ulster's future on Saturday morning Trimble and his allies got what they were looking for - an endorsement from John Taylor.

Taylor arrived in Belfast after the overnight flight from Taipei looking remarkably fresh and relaxed. He confimed that he would be backing his leader after all.

'There had been problems on all fronts including the issue of the RUC's title. I am now satisfied we can support this. Things have moved.'

Whether this means that the British Government has granted Taylor and the UUP a concession on the RUC's name remains to be seen. The Irish government is opposed to a further dilution of the Patten report, believing it will undermine the IRA's offer to put arms beyond use. Northern Ireland may have a new power-sharing government on Thursday but issues remain unresolved.

Yesterday the 860 UUP delegates were herded into a hall where a performance of the opera Aida was being staged. The UUC members, who range from farmers on the Fermanagh border to wealthy businessmen from Belfast, were surrounded by the props of the opera including a mock pyramid and two mummy casks.

For 80 years since the foundation of Northern Ireland the Ulster Unionist Party have resembled political mummies, frozen in time, sealed in a closed world that shut out demands for equality and rights, unable to accept change that would have allowed Catholics for feel part of the state set up after partition.

Yesterday's narrow vote in favour of re-joining an historic coalition with Sinn Fein (459 for, 403 against) means new unionism has left behind the past of No Surrender and Not an Inch.

Now unionism via David Trimble has re-entered history to seize control of its own destiny. As Trimble put it yesterday during his second speech at the end the three hour long debate in the Waterfront: 'Don't trust me, trust yourselves.'

webTitle: Global net soars above legal eagles

fields.headline: Global net soars above legal eagles
fields.standfirst: www.briefhistory.com/footnotes/
fields.trailText: The news that a French judge has ruled that Yahoo France has to block access to US-based sales of Nazi memorabilia has occasioned much scornful laughter in Anglo-Saxon circles. How quaint, people say. The poor booby clearly has no idea of how the net works. And how very, very Continental to think that the French legal code can somehow lord it over an internet company - and a US one at that. Don't these clowns realise that the net is a global system which transcends the territorial jurisdictions of mere states?
fields.body:
The news that a French judge has ruled that Yahoo France has to block access to US-based sales of Nazi memorabilia has occasioned much scornful laughter in Anglo-Saxon circles. How quaint, people say. The poor booby clearly has no idea of how the net works. And how very, very Continental to think that the French legal code can somehow lord it over an internet company - and a US one at that. Don't these clowns realise that the net is a global system which transcends the territorial jurisdictions of mere states?

There is, however, apparently one exception to this general rule about the transcendental power of the net and the feebleness of earthly powers, namely the United States of America. Two years ago, the Congress of that vibrant land enacted the Digital Millennium Copyright Act - ostensibly to strengthen copyright rules on the Internet, but in fact to signal US legislators' collective appreciation of favours rendered by the US multimedia industry.

The DMCA was designed to make it easier for copyright holders to protect their intellectual property in a wired world. But to this (legitimate) purpose it also added - at the behest of the industry - another sweeping provision. The Act made it a criminal offence to design any method of circumventing copy-protection systems.

Shortly after the DMCA became law, the DVD business started to explode, mainly because the technology offers a way of providing digital-quality movies on disk. The contents of these pre-recorded DVDs are encrypted using a technique called CSS (for Content Scrambling System). Decryption programmes for Windows and Macintosh computers were supplied by the multimedia industry as a matter of course, so that users of these computers could watch DVD movies on their machines. But the industry did not provide a decryption programme for the Linux operating system, with the result that Linux users were unable to play their (legally acquired and paid-for) DVDs on their computers.

The Linux community being what it is, someone cracked the CSS system and posted details on the net. Shortly afterwards, a small decryption programme called DeCSS began to circulate, and Linux users settled back to enjoy watching their DVDs. One of them, a Norwegian teenager called Jon Johansen, who belongs to Masters of Reverse Engineering (MoRE), the group that created the DeCSS DVD playback utility for Linux, posted the code on his father's website.

On Monday, 24 January, officials of Norway's Department of Economic Crime knocked on his door and hauled the lad off to a police station for interrogation. They would have taken his father too, were it not for the fact that he was too ill to leave home. Johansen pere et fils were later indicted.

On what grounds? That they have violated the Norwegian legal code? Not a bit of it - the charge is that the Johansens have allegedly broken the law of the United States . The whole scenario is preposterous and the case will, one hopes, be thrown out by a robust Norwegian judge. But in the meantime, where are the hoots of derisive laughter of the kind that were directed this week at a technologically illiterate French judge?

A memo to employees of Boo.com and similar enterprises: there is an interesting New York website which has been up since 8 February. It's called StartUpFailures.com and it provides counselling for redundant dot-communists. According to its founder, Nicholas Hall, the purpose of the website is 'to take the stigma out of failing and help you recover quickly from the failure and get back in action'.

I'm going to open a UK branch. I was going to call it BooHoo.com, but that's been taken. It's a tough life on the electronic frontier.

John Naughton

Republicans want stocks to pay for welfare

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Camden is a community at war with itself, where the unprecedented, uninterrupted years of American prosperity have made little impact. It is not quite the nation's poorest town - there are a few places straddling the Mexican border which beat it to that honour - but almost. It lies across the Delaware River from Philadelphia and across the Trenton bridge from New York - the bridge that boasts, 'What Trenton Makes, The World Takes'. Except that no one makes much around here any more.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy in Camden, New Jersey
fields.body:
Camden is a community at war with itself, where the unprecedented, uninterrupted years of American prosperity have made little impact. It is not quite the nation's poorest town - there are a few places straddling the Mexican border which beat it to that honour - but almost. It lies across the Delaware River from Philadelphia and across the Trenton bridge from New York - the bridge that boasts, 'What Trenton Makes, The World Takes'. Except that no one makes much around here any more.

Along the waterfront, stores are boarded up; the only sounds audible from a peeling apartment block are the tuneless humming of a harmonica and the machine-gun banter of a row among those sitting on the front steps. The stench of urine hangs in the steamy summer afternoon. The celebrated new aquarium is closed.

Camden was once the man ufacturing capital of South Jersey. But now the jobs in the shipyards, at the Campbell's soup factory and the RCA Victor company, have all gone. During a decade in which the stock market tripled, Camden's tax base has slumped by 11 per cent despite an injection of $1 billion in 'extraordinary municipal aid' by the state. Indeed, the economic boom may actually have hurt Camden, as new opportunities in proserpous neighbouring areas seduced the more employable citizens away, leaving the poor and unskilled to stay behind.

The city government has collapsed and is run by a state board. The police department is being overseen by a state prosecutor after allegations of connections to organised crime. The school system is so bad it has a state auditor. The inept public housing authority has been taken over by the federal department of urban development.

The Rev Michael Doyle, pastor of the Sacred Heart church in South Camden, says Camden has been aban doned by the federal government, the state and county, all of whom have lost interest in the poor. 'American citizens are not being slaughtered on any frontier except the urban one - the neighbourhoods are concentration camps of poverty.'

The conservative Ronald Utt at the Heritage Foundation will tell you that 'the environment is so toxic to normal economic activity, crime is so great and government corrupt. The nature of the problem is that there is little normal family structure ... Camden has a hideous attitude towards anything that leads to a more positive lifestyle.'

His solution: 'Aggressive social security reform.' And this is what his election candidate, George W. Bush, has suddenly brought to the campaign fore. Welfare rolls are still regarded as a good measure of poverty in America, and they have tumbled - halved since 1996, when the Clinton adminstration ended the automatic right to welfare, obliged the poor to work and limited the duration of life on welfare to five years. The federal legislation dovetailed with schemes in many areas limiting a claimant's time on welfare to two years, after which they would be cut off if they had not found and kept employment.

The welfare measurement therefore conceals America's secret curse - a poverty that has changed in texture but which still contrasts starkly with the new gilded age. While the elderly and those in rural areas are not so poor as in the past, children are poorer and one black family in four qualifies. Poverty has become redefined by race, sex and the city.

Single mothers are the largest and fastest-growing segment of the poor. Never before has so much been spent on subsidising the working poor, while the level of assistance to the non-working poor has fallen sharply. Not everyone can hold down a job - there are problems with childcare and transport, alcohol, drugs and domestic violence.

This is the backdrop to the first real salvo of the forthcoming presidential election campaign, which formally opens after tomorrow's Memorial Day holiday. George W. Bush, the man who hopes to prise the presidency back for the Republicans, has stepped boldy up to what is called the 'Third Rail' of American politics, the hot potato of social security. Creeping ahead in the opinion polls, he wants to introduce the play-the-market ethos of the boom to its own underbelly, to part-privatise the entire infrastructure. He would allow all workers to invest part of their 12.4 per cent payroll taxes into their own private accounts.

This would allow workers to capture for themselves some of Wall Street's high returns. Bush is convinced that 'people have an understanding of how markets work, and are used to securing a higher return on their savings'. Bush is therefore urging workers to play the very stock market that many of his advisers (not least the Chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan) warn could slump at any moment.

Al Gore is biting back, accusing his rival of 'rolling the dice' with a 'survival-of-the-fittest retirement system'. He has countered with his own package, which does nothing to alter the benefits structure, but instead relies on projected budget surpluses and diverts up to $200 billion from general revenues into social security. This shift from payroll taxes to income tax and general revenues would, he claims, keep the system afloat until 2050, without any cuts in benefits.

'One of the reasons why social security has been so successful,' says Gore's spokesman Chris Lehane, 'is that it's a social compact between generations. To play around with privatising it, when there's no need to privatise it, will only lead to bad results.'

A recent survey by the Washington Post and ABC TV showed three in five voters favouring private retirement accounts. But there won't be too many of those opening up in Camden, New Jersey.

fields.headline: British deal fuelled Balkan war
fields.standfirst:
Military sale to Slovenia flouted Tory foreign policy

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Britain flouted its own foreign policy by approving the sale of millions of pounds worth of military equipment to a former Yugoslav republic only days before the outbreak of the bloody Balkans war,  The Observer  has established.
fields.body:
Britain flouted its own foreign policy by approving the sale of millions of pounds worth of military equipment to a former Yugoslav republic only days before the outbreak of the bloody Balkans war, The Observer has established.

Eight days before Slovenia became the first area to break from the unified Yugoslavia in 1991, a British firm delivered communications equipment to the Slovenian forces to help them fight the Serb-led Yugoslav army.

The revelation that this deal was approved by the Conservative Government will embarrass former Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, who was the principal architect of the West's policy of supporting a unified Yugoslavia. He had warned the republics to stay in the federation.

Until now, Germany has shouldered the blame for the Balkan tragedy by prematurely recognising the breakaway republics of Slovenia and Croatia. Britain's help to Slovenia casts a new light on events.

Labour MP Ann Clwyd, who sits on the House of Commons International Development Select Committee, said: 'These revelations show once again that the export of military equipment from Britain needs to be much more rigorously scrutinised.'

After Slovenia declared independence, the Yugoslav army began its military offensive against the 'rebel' republic. The ensuing 10-day war signalled the start of the conflicts that ultimately killed hundreds of thousands.

Three months after Britain exported military equipment to Slovenia the United Nations imposed an arms embargo on the region.

The Observer has obtained details of the multi-million-pound contract between the Slovenian Defence Ministry and Racal, the British defence and communications group. A fax dated 29 May, 1991, from one of Racal's military subsidiaries, Racal Tacticom, to the Slovenian Defence Ministry lists four batches of tactical military communication equipment worth £5 million.

Racal's communications network played a vital role in helping Slovenia beat the Serb-led Yugoslav forces. The equipment arrived on 17 June, eight days before the war of independence began.

Janez Jansa, then Slovenian Defence Minister, praises Britain for its role in his memoirs. He writes: 'The government of one of the more decent Western states has, on our request, officially approved the export of mili tary radio stations with secure data transmission to Slovenia.'

One senior source at Racal Defence Electronics confirmed that it had delivered the equipment after it received an export licence from the Department of Trade and Industry. He said the contract was with the 'regional government' of Slovenia, and the export was for 'the purpose of national defence'.

Misha Glenny, a Balkans expert, said: 'If the British Government was fully aware of this, it would imply that the Government was covertly operating in contradiction of its stated policy and aims. It would also shift some of the responsibility carried by Germany.'

The former Slovenian Defence Minister's book also claims that the British Embassy in Belgrade learnt that the Yugoslav air force was planning to shoot down a Slovenian aircraft due to carry the equipment to its new owner. According to Jansa, the British tipped off the Slovenians, who decided to send the cargo by road. Government sources in Slovenia confirm that the aircraft that was to have delivered the shipment was a passenger plane owned by Adria Airways, the national airline. The jet was to have flown from Gatwick to the capital Ljubljana, in central Slovenia.

Suggestions that the British Embassy in Belgrade knew of the military shipment and warned the Slovenians are strongly denied by Sir Peter Hall, who was ambassador in Belgrade. He said: 'These allegations of British Embassy involvement are without foundation... I had no, absolutely no, knowledge of any military equipment being sent from Britain to Slovenia. Indeed, given the great tension in the region at the time I would be surprised that any such equipment would have been sent at all.'

The Observer contacted Lord Hurd and Peter Lilley, who was then Trade Secretary, with details of the arms shipment. Both declined to respond. A spokesman for the Blair Government refused to comment, saying it needed permission from Racal to give details of any export licence.

Lord Owen, the EU peace negotiator in Bosnia, said: 'I am surprised that such sales took place, particularly as the British Government, the US and Nato's view was to keep the Federation of Yugoslavia together. But this equipment was not aggressive - it was radios not guns. I think it sails close to the border but does not cross it.'

Blaz Zgaga works for the Slovenian daily 'Vecer'.

webTitle: Britons quit Freetown as the terror spreads

fields.headline: Britons quit Freetown as the terror spreads
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Fresh reports of murders, rapes and hand amputations by the rebel forces in Sierra Leone emerged yesterday, as British aid workers in Freetown were put on red alert for fear of a rebel hit squad seeking 'soft' targets.
fields.body:
Fresh reports of murders, rapes and hand amputations by the rebel forces in Sierra Leone emerged yesterday, as British aid workers in Freetown were put on red alert for fear of a rebel hit squad seeking 'soft' targets.

The Department for International Development in London warned aid agencies to get out. One aid agency source said the department had said it had received 'credible intelligence' that a rebel assassination squad of the Revolutionary United Front fighters may be in Freetown.

Christian Aid withdrew its team of four yesterday, while a spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross said it and other agencies were reviewing security. The Foreign Office warned that Sierra Leone 'remains dangerous' and advised any Briton thinking of returning here not to do so.

The nature of the 'credible intelligence' is unclear, but the threat is believed to come after President Tejan Kabbah, who is backed by Britain's military presence, announced that RUF leader Foday Sankoh would shortly come to trial. The security fears for the British community follow the RUF's killing of American Reuters reporter Kurt Schork and Spanish camerman Miguel Gil Mareno on Wednesday.

Human Rights Watch revealed evidence of fresh atrocities by the RUF up country. HRW spokesman Peter Bouckaert told The Observer in Freetown: 'What we are most concerned about is the possibility of another Kosovo or East Timor happening behind RUF lines, a massive retaliation against civilians. The RUF have the potential to do this, they have a history of extreme violence and the evidence we are getting on the ground points to massive abuse.'

Last week a team from HRW interviewed refugees from Masiaka and Lungi who had fled to the capital. One victim of the RUF was a 10-year-old girl, who had been captured outside a village with her parents and 10 brothers and sisters. She was flogged, then raped. 'She was a tiny girl,' said Bouckaert. She said her father died of exhaustion. The rebels, she said, grabbed hold of her sister, Mawa Camara, aged 20, the mother of a young baby. 'They cut off both her hands and a foot,' said the girl.

'Then she died. They cut off the hands of another woman and a man,' she said, but did not know what happened to them later.When government troops attacked the rebels, she made her escape.

'Mabinti' - not her real name - aged 16, left Masiaka, east of Freetown, fearing the RUF. She walked through bush roads in an attempt to flee to safety. The next morning she saw a young girl and a man lying by the side of the road. The hands of the girl had been cut off, and the man's right foot had been cut off. Both were still alive, but barely breathing.

These are the first reports of amputations that Human Rights Watch has heard for a year. The tactic of 'terror amputations' was first used by the RUF, but other factions in the civil war, including those now loyal to the British-backed government, have been guilty of it.

Another witness was a 20-year-old woman, Aisatu. She was seized by the rebels, many of whom were child soldiers, and gang-raped over three days. Her husband could only witness the rapes, helplessly. She saw one boy being slashed in the back with a machete. Brouckaert said: 'What we don't want to happen is another Kosovo, where an abusive force is given a large window of opportunity. We are very concerned that Unamsil (the UN Mission in Sierra Leone) are not taking the possibility of retaliation into their planning.'

Senior British military sources close to Brigadier David Richards, head of the joint forces operation here, are concerned that the progress of government forces against the RUF is much slower than it should be. The rainy season, which will slow down movement on the ground, is approaching, and the critical diamond fields remain in rebel hands.

The acting Defence Minister, Chief Sam Hingi Norman, criticised the UN's failure to carry out its mission. 'Some say the UN give up their weapons easily, but drive round Freetown forcefully.'

When the rebels first struck, some Jordanian officers abandoned their posts to the east of the capital and fled to the docks, to board a Danish-crewed ship. The Zambian battalion is believed to have handed over six armoured personnel carriers to the rebels. Human Rights Watch is also critical of some of the government's allies, who have also been responsible for human rights violations.

Norman is the man to receive any gift of arms from the British, a decision being considered at Cabinet level. He told The Observer he believed it was possible to 'immunise' children against bullets by traditional ceremonies - carried out by witch-doctors. Wasn't that juju? 'We don't call flak-jackets juju. Immunisation works. It works for me,' he declared, laughing.

Liberian President Charles Taylor said the Sierra Leone government's plan to put rebel leader Foday Sankoh on trial was foolish and could threaten the release of the last UN peacekeepers held by the RUF. 'It does not make any sense at this time to deal with the question of Foday Sankoh before disarmament and demobilisation and before elections are held,' he told reporters in his capital of Monrovia.

The RUF released 180 captives on Friday, and Taylor was confident that the rest, numbering about 70, would follow them to Liberia soon.

webTitle: Defiant anti-Milosevic protesters rally as Belgrade clamps down

fields.headline: Defiant anti-Milosevic protesters rally as Belgrade clamps down
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Protestors were rallying in Belgrade's Republic Square last night as the Serbian government threatened to introduce a stringent anti-terrorism law.
fields.body:
Protestors were rallying in Belgrade's Republic Square last night as the Serbian government threatened to introduce a stringent anti-terrorism law.

The rally was a crucial test of credibility for Serbia's political opposition, which has drawn fierce criticism for lacking leadership during the country's escalating crisis.

In the past week, the regime of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic has ratcheted up the tension, arresting activists from the student-based resistance movement Otpor and branding its members 'terrorists', 'traitors' and 'agents of Nato'. In the wake of growing activism from the wider student body, it closed universities on Friday - making campuses no-go zones for all but those entering faculty buildings to take examinations.

Details of the anti-terrorism law have not been released, but analysts fear it may allow indefinite detention, arbitrary closure of non-state media and the disarming of citizens who hold guns; effectively introducing a state of emergency.

The regime will not be drawn on introducing the law, but top Socialist Party member Nikola Sainovic said last week: 'The Socialist Party believes we will be successful in the fight against terrorism and against Nato.

'The work of Otpor has a violent character, disrupts public peace and order and the security of the country - and these activities will be prevented,' he said.

Otpor activist Slobodan Homen responds that it is Otpor's non-violent character that gives it popularity and strength.

According to Otpor insiders, polling from Milosevic's own party shows that Otpor outstrips the ruling Socialist Party in popularity. They say that Otpor has 28 per cent of popular support and Milosevic only 14 per cent. The stakes were high for the opposition yesterday. The number of protesters attending and the performance of speakers was crucial to bolstering credibility.

Homen says that Otpor activists do not want power. 'We don't want to be members of parliament. We just want to get rid of the regime.' Homen says that Otpor has delivered an unequivocal message to the opposition: 'We are ready for a campaign of civil disobedience. We can stop exams in the faculties and we can organise.

'If you are not willing to take appropriate steps, we will do it alone.'

The number of protesters attending and the performance of speakers was crucial to bolstering credibility. Homen says that Otpor activists do not want power. 'We don't want to be members of parliament. We just want to get rid of the regime.' Homen says that Otpor has delivered an unequivocal message to the opposition: 'We are ready for a campaign of civil disobedience. We can stop exams in the faculties and we can organise. 'If you are not willing to take appropriate steps, we will do it alone.'

webTitle: Rail plans to revive axed Beeching lines

fields.headline: Rail plans to revive axed Beeching lines
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Rail is set to win more than £2 billion a year extra in state funding for the next decade to expand the network and reverse the Beeching line closures of the Sixties.
fields.body:
Rail is set to win more than £2 billion a year extra in state funding for the next decade to expand the network and reverse the Beeching line closures of the Sixties.

Track and stations that have been disused since as long ago as 1962 are likely to be revived to carry freight and commuter services. This will create extra capacity and allow high speed trains to run faster and on time.

Operators will be offered cash for new trains in return for promises to improve services. New signalling, track and safety systems will receive state funding, Minister will announce in July.

The news will come as a major boost to the booming railway industry and frustrated passengers, but is the final proof that privatisation has failed in its primary purpose - to take the burden of rail off the taxpayer.

And the first package of extra funding could be swallowed up to rescue just one project: the second stage of modernising the West Coast Main Line to allow tilting trains to run at 140mph with automatic signalling by 2005.

The scheme will be threatened next month when the regulatory authorities confirm that Railtrack's costing for the original scheme has doubled to £3bn and the company has insufficient resources to fund it, The Observer has learnt.

The Government will have to pick up much of the bill or see the project fall apart. Failure would almost certainly lead to Virgin Trains, the route's main operator, suing Railtrack.

Despite this prospect of an early snag, Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott is desperate to ensure new cash is not disappear into inefficiency or into shareholders' pockets. Train firms' new contracts will be written to force them to improve their performance.

One Government source said: 'We are not going to give money for old rope. The operators should be running the trains on time as a matter of course. This is about new stations, rolling stock, safety systems, track and signalling.'

The new plan is designed to ease congestion around bottlenecks in London, the Midlands and Manchester.

New freight routes would be opened from Felixstowe to Nuneaton, and the East Midlands to Manchester and Scotland. Lines parallel to the East Coast Main Line could be restored to take freight and local traffic, while capacity will be doubled between Birmingham and Coventry.

Meanwhile, Morton is shortly to reveal the new 'rail map' of Britain, tearing up many franchise areas. Metropolitan authorities will take control of running and funding local services in big conurbations such as Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester, Leeds and Glasgow.

 The French-owned Connex is expected to lose its franchise to run south-central commuter services into London when the first new contracts are awarded this summer, industry sources said.

fields.headline: Why corporate killers must pay
fields.trailText: The Financial Services and Markets Bill (no, please, read on - it does get more interesting), has become so emasculated, say some close observers, that it would not be out of place waving a palm frond at the court of Suleiman the Magnificent.
fields.body:
The Financial Services and Markets Bill (no, please, read on - it does get more interesting), has become so emasculated, say some close observers, that it would not be out of place waving a palm frond at the court of Suleiman the Magnificent.

For those who have not been riveted by its bumpy progress through the upper and lower Houses, it is meant to be the enabling legislation that gives Howard Davies and the Financial Services Authority a set of gnashers that would not disgrace a great white. However, it would appear that when the rules finally pass under Her Majesty's rubber stamp, Davies and his Authority will look more like the Pathetic Sharks from the popular vulgar comic, Viz .

Coincidentally, I caught a snippet of commentary on the radio about proposed legislation which, said the commentator, 'has received hardly any coverage', and would essentially lead to the liability of auditors being limited, resulting in 'a bonanza for the big five accounting firms'.

According to the aggrieved broadcaster this was the result of strenuous lobbying from the consultants, many of whom have been shamelessly courting government and who already benefit from what is often a suspiciously haphazard procurement process in the service sector.

The problem with corporate legislation is that it only really arouses ire and passion in those who are likely to be tonked by the rules. The public at large find it hard to gauge what they would gain from such legislation, while the companies which would be on the receiving end are expensively briefed on exactly what they stand to lose. It is only when you have been mis-sold a pension, or when the redemption value of your endowment mortgage covers only the purchase of the front door that you are left to ponder 'why isn't that against the law?'

For the Government, introducing complex legislation along the lines of the Financial Services Act is a thankless task. Your corporate donors dump you as quickly as they can, and it wins no votes. It has to be a selfless gift to the national wellbeing. Which is why the introduction of a Bill which would create the offence of corporate killing is such an intriguing possibility. For here you have a potential flashpoint where the corporate lobby will find itself in direct, public opposition to the will of the people.

For those who, like me, regard the fact that not one single resignation or suspension of any director has arisen as a result of the Paddington rail disaster as a national disgrace, it comes as some comfort. For the more mundane but equally shocking everyday examples of casualties in the building industry it could be a more significant if less newsworthy move. The existing corporate manslaughter charge carries a very high burden of proof: a company is found guilty only if an individual within it can be convicted of the offence. Only three prosecutions have ever been successful.

Already some business lobbyists are bridling at the suggestion that individuals should be charged or directors disqualified under the suggested changes in the law put up by Home Secretary Jack Straw.

One can't help feeling that companies have very much brought this potentially onerous increase in liability on themselves; a more humble and gracious attitude to accepting that your firm has been profoundly at fault when lives are lost might negate the need for a 'dangerous directors act'.

But high-profile dismissal is reserved for bottom-pinching at the Christmas party rather than for when workers repeatedly fall to their deaths from your scaffolding. Moves which will hopefully allow for the financial mutilation of negligent companies as well as for possible disqualification and perhaps prison, in extreme cases, for directors is long overdue.

One hopes that the Government's championing of this more digestible piece of corporate legislation will not meet the sticky fate of its other efforts to control the governance and behaviour of companies.

Emily Bell

fields.headline: And still they don't learn ...
fields.trailText: At the end of his recent James Meade Memorial Lecture at the London School of Economics, Gordon Brown departed from his set text and said his ambition was 'to make this country a far fairer and a far more equal society'.
fields.body:
At the end of his recent James Meade Memorial Lecture at the London School of Economics, Gordon Brown departed from his set text and said his ambition was 'to make this country a far fairer and a far more equal society'.

Such a settlement would not have sounded exceptional coming from Old Labour, but it constituted a slight difference from the way New Labour (if indeed it is still New) presents itself to Middle England and to the financial markets. The markets are supposed to be the bane of left-wing parties in this country, and the traditional belief is that Labour has to guard against the weakness of the currency.

All manner of departures from the true path of Labour - or indeed of social democracy - are rationalised by the need to please the markets and avoid devaluation.

The traditional belief, however, is something of a myth. It is not a weak currency that Labour governments tend to be associated with: on the contrary, it is a strong currency, or rather an overvalued currency.

As my correspondent Francis Chronnell points out: 'Labour have so identified themselves with the "weak currency" issue that they have, this time, pursued policies that kept the pound "strong" (a good thing), but also "overvalued" (a bad thing).'

The currency issue brings us to the nub of the struggle in Labour's approach to economic policy. At one level the Labour team gives the impression that British economic history began on 1 May 1997; at another it bends over backwards to learn what it thinks are the lessons of history.

But the real lesson of history is that Labour inherits an overvalued pound; that the overvalued pound wreaks grave damage on the economy; and that it is only with the greatest reluctance that the Chancellor and the Prime Minister of the day acknowledge that the pound must come down to a more realistic and competitive level.

Sometimes they refuse to recognise the obvious when it is staring them in the face, and the markets force it upon them.

Then the markets - or the 'gnomes of Zurich' as Harold Wilson used to call them - get the blame, and Labour spends a long period in opposition vowing that it must never again be seen as 'the party of devaluation'. And the cycle repeats itself.

The present Chancellor reiterated his belief in a stable and competitive pound as the pound became ever less stable and ever more uncompetitive over the course of 1997, 1998, 1999 and the first few months of this year.

Then, during that very same lecture at the LSE, he finally conceded that the 'euro-sterling exchange rate cannot be justified by any view of long-term economic fundamentals'. The publicity focused on his subsequent remark, which ruled out 'a return to the short-term quick fix' (in other words, intervention to push the pound down, or to ease the pressure on interest rates by raising taxes).

But the significance of the occasion was that the Chancellor had finally joined the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) in its efforts to talk the pound down.

During the Chancellor's lecture, a remark James Meade himself made not long before his death came back to me. 'We nationalised the Bank of England in 1946 in order to prevent another 1931.'

This was a reference to the way the Labour government of 1929-31 (with Ramsay Macdonald as Prime Minister and Phillip Snowden as Chancellor) had been wrecked on the rock of the overvalued pound. Christopher Dow noted in Major Recessions: 'Up to 1931 much of what [economic] policy there was came from the Bank of England (throughout the period under Montague Norman, and still privately owned).' It was Sidney Webb, founder of the LSE and a member of the Macdonald government, who said after that government collapsed and Britain finally went off the gold standard: 'Nobody told us we could do this.'

The gold standard exchange rate had been $4.80 to the pound. The subsequent downwards float assisted the Thirties economic recovery. At the beginning of the second world war, in September 1939, the pound was fixed at $4.03, where it remained until 1949.

The difficulties of the Attlee government of 1945-50 were aggravated by the fact that an economy debilitated by the war could not sustain a patently overvalued exchange rate; but, encouraged by the Treasury and the Bank, Hugh Dalton and then Sir Stafford Cripps resisted devaluation and prolonged the agony. The 1949 devaluation brought the pound down from $4.04 to $2.80.

The two Labour governments of Harold Wilson in 1964-70 stuck to an overvalued pound until brought down by the markets in November 1967, when it was set at $2.40. From the beginning Wilson had staked his reputation on not devaluing.

The Americans, deeply involved in Vietnam, did not want to deal with the repercussions on the wider financial system that a sterling devaluation might (and eventually did) bring.

Wilson's biographer, Ben Pimlott, notes that the help the Americans gave to prop up the pound before 1967 was contingent on our support for them in Vietnam and 'no British devaluation and no British withdrawal from East of Suez'.

Roy Jenkins devoted his years as Chancellor, 1967-70, to 'making devaluation work', among other things. But in the Heath-Barber boom of 1973-74, and the early phase of the Labour governments of 1974-79, rapid inflation (reaching 27 per cent at one point) again made British industry uncompetitive.

The necessary devaluation was again postponed, with the pound propped up by the new financial wealth of Saudi Arabia, Nigeria and other oil producers, much of which was temporarily deposited in London until the 1976 panic.

As Denis Healey reminds us in his memoirs, by early 1976 'the Treasury was beginning to think that all these foreign funds were keeping our exchange rate too high for our commercial good, and that a gentle and controlled depreciation was in order. What we got, in fact, was a rout.'

Healey, who was of course Chancellor, recalls: 'I soon learned that there is not much point in complaining when the financial markets behave like hysterical schoolgirls. You can not buck the markets. But you can move them in your direction if you try to understand their psychology.'

The Labour government's resort to the International Monetary Fund in 1976 - the UK was the last major industrial country to do so - was humiliating, and still haunts the party. But the real problem was the overvaluation that gave rise to the subsequent crisis.

While the debate about intervention to deal with the latest episode of Labour's Misadventures With An Overvalued Pound has proceeded, the markets have finally turned, and the pound has begun to fall.

How this fall is handled could well determine the fate of this Government. In my experience, power in these matters always lies elsewhere: governments think financial markets are all-powerful; but the financial markets hang on every word that governments say about the currency.

Why, oh why, did this government - just like its Labour predecessors - wait so long to acknowledge the damage the high pound was doing? History is not entirely bunk.

fields.headline: Union chief joins Nirex board
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Sir Ken Jackson, the union leader closest to Tony Blair, is to be appointed by the Government to the board of nuclear waste management company Nirex.
fields.body:
Sir Ken Jackson, the union leader closest to Tony Blair, is to be appointed by the Government to the board of nuclear waste management company Nirex.

The appointment of the head of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union is part of an attempt by Ministers to face up to the controversial problem of long-term nuclear waste storage. The issue has been off the political agenda since March 1997, when plans by Nirex for a £1.9 billion underground facility for geological research into nuclear waste storage at Sellafield in Cumbria were thrown out by Conservative Environment Secretary John Gummer.

The Labour government has faced acute problems over what to do with highly toxic intermediate-level nuclear waste - generated when spent fuel is reprocessed.

It is now stored at ground level on the Sellafield site operated by reprocessor British Nuclear Fuels, but this is not a satisfactory solution for material which will remain radioactive for hundreds of years.

BNFL estimates that some 110,000 cubic metres of intermediate-level waste will be generated by 2020 if reprocessing continues at Sellafield.

Last year, a House of Lords committee recommended that Parliament approve plans for a deep storage site and suggested that between 15 and 20 sites across Britain be investigated.

A government green paper is due next month, but it is unlikely to recommend storage sites.

Jackson believes the Gummer decision was a mistake, and says the Government now has a tough job persuading the public to accept the need for a storage site. He believes that Nirex must succeed for there to be a credible nuclear waste strategy.

The Government is also set to appoint to the board leading social scientist Professor Andy Blowers of the Open University.

fields.headline: Will this Flametree flower?
fields.standfirst:
In the first of a series following the fortunes of a wannabe website, Jamie Doward counts down to the launch of an online 'zine' for working mothers

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In the first of a series following the fortunes of a wannabe website,  Jamie Doward counts down to the launch of an online 'zine' for working mothers
fields.body:
It's Tuesday morning and things seem to be going relatively smoothly in the offices of the fledgling dotcom company Flametree. All right, the builders over the road from the company's offices in London's Victoria had banjaxed the offices' computer and phone systems a few days earlier - temporarily rendering the business inoperable, but there is a feeling among the staff of this online zine for working mothers that the start-up will hit its early summer launch date.

The company's brand is now taking shape, helped by a serious spot of freeform thinking initiated by an outside consultant. Flametree's founders, having experimented with a number of words and concepts, have decided that, if the business were, er, a car, it would be a Volkswagen Golf. 'It's not flashy: it works, it's solid, it meets expectations, it can carry the family, but you can drive it yourself,' explains Rosemary Leith, who has a background in investment and is a company co-founder.

And the 17 investors (including Seattle Coffee company founder Ally Svenson) who have ploughed nearly £1 million of their money through an initial 'friends and family' round of fund raising, will be relieved to know that the founders also believe that, if it were, er, a colour, it would be lavender.

'We felt that represented the right combination of emotions and balance between feminine and masculine,' says Jayne Buxton, the other co-founder and a former consultant with Gemini Consulting who specialised in analysing the changing nature of women in the workplace. 'In-terestingly, we ended up with a lot of lavender on the site.'

Flametree's brand must also live up to a number of key values if it is to succeed, the pair argue. Integrity is, Buxton and Leith believe, vital. It is a value that they, as working mothers, aspire to and hope to communicate to staff. 'It's about not missing a football match or a ballet show,' Leith says. Practicality and relevance are also considered vital brand components.

'Inspiration' is another word bandied around at company meetings. 'It's giving people a sense of what can be done,' Buxton says, 'providing them with case studies of what people, some famous, some not, have achieved.'

The name, like the elements which make up the brand, was carefully chosen. Buxton and Leith, both 38, trawled hundreds of alternatives before deciding that Flametree hit all the right buttons. 'It represents a combination of rootedness and inspiration, which is what we want to be,' says Buxton.

The name Flametree was actually suggested by the site's editor, former Sunday Times journalist Hannah Charlton, who has been charged with the tricky task of building the firm's profile. On Tuesday one issue she was focusing on was what to put on the 3,000 postcards the company will shortly be sending to potential users.

The company has commissioned a photographer to take around 300 images, which Flametree hopes will help users understand what it stands for. The photographs range from a hand reaching for a dishwasher dial to a child's book balanced on the corner of a computer keyboard. 'The photos are very iconic,' Charlton says. 'We didn't go for faces.'

One image - a picture of two pairs of Wellington boots, one for an adult, the other for a child - seemed to be suitably evocative of the Flametree brand.

It sounds a little bit like a new version of Ab Fab (yes, Lynn Franks, the PR guru who inspired the comedy series, is a contributor to the site), but to have got Flametree to this stage has been no laughing matter.

The idea for the site was conceived only late last year, and since then Buxton and Leith have been frantically hunting around London for staff, offices, brand experts, web designers, technology gurus and, most importantly, business partners.

The company intends to make money from a number of e-commerce sources. Flametree believes that the quality of writers it has on its site will make it a must-visit destination for busy mothers (chiefly in the A,B and C1 categories) who will be able to order everything from home-helps to party arrangers.

In addition, there will be a recruitment site which will concentrate on advertising jobs for women. Each time a user buys a service, Flametree takes a commission. Working out what this should be and drawing up legally binding contracts has taken many hours of Buxton and Leith's time. 'Ultimately, if you own a business, it's up to you to check every detail; and it's up to you to get them delivered; and it's up to you to sit there and make sure they sign them,' Buxton says. The company is also talking to a number of companies about sponsoring its site.

Flametree has decided to go for what is known in the trade as a 'soft' launch before embarking on a PR blitz announcing Flametree's inception to the world. The plan is to stage a series of soirées at the company's offices. The invited 'friends of Flametree' will test the site and help Flametree learn what can be improved. As an inducement to join in, Flametree plans to pick participants from the forums and offer them useful rewards, such as free life skills courses or one-on-one chats with Flametree's band of online experts.

Getting the tone of Flametree's content right - from case studies to celebrity interviews - is another of Charlton's key concerns. However, just weeks before the launch, only one section has so far been loaded on to the site. Gremlins have conspired to prevent the company's outside technology partner from loading the content automatically, so Flametree's staff have had to do it manually.

As the company moved into its new offices only three weeks ago, this set-back couldn't have come at a worse time. Computers and other office paraphernalia have yet to find a proper home - and some staff have yet to arrive.

The company's offices, just up the road from London's Victoria station, were chosen because Buxton and Leith refused to pay the sky-high rents demanded in some of the capital's plusher locations.

The £1 million the pair have raised is enough, they believe, to cover all of the company's start-up and running costs for the next 12 months, providing that they don't start spending with the profligacy of some well known internet companies (mentioning no names - anagram of obo).

With this in mind, Flametree deliberately avoided taking money from venture capitalists when seeking initial financing - despite the fact that it was available.

'You have more flexibility to implement your own vision of the business, instead of being pressured by a VC about when you should float,' Buxton says.

The business model was drawn up by February and the pair then spent two months visiting the homes of potential investors to sell them the idea. Some bought in because they knew the two women, others because they liked the company's concept. Some declined. Whether the latter were right will become apparent very soon.

webTitle: Elian lands in media chiefs' own backyard

fields.headline: Elian lands in media chiefs' own backyard
fields.standfirst: The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: Proving once again that God has a sense of humour, Elián González has landed in the most media-centric neighbourhood on Earth.
fields.body:
Proving once again that God has a sense of humour, Elián González has landed in the most media-centric neighbourhood on Earth.

The beast that has stalked the six-year-old Cuban since a shipwreck last year - the television trucks and and the federal marshals with their barricade tape - now lives on Newark Street in Washington's Cleveland Park.

The beast has brought, shall we say, concern to the leafy glade, home to a high concentration of Washington editors and publishers.

'The neighbours are scared of the media frenzy that they had in Miami,' said Derry Craig, who lives around the corner from Elián's new home, the Rosedale estate, which is owned by a foundation for exchange students.

Craig's husband, Gregory, who was President Clinton's lawyer in the late unpleasantness of impeachment, and thus no stranger to such frenzies, took his clients, Elián and his father, Juan Miguel González, to Newark Street late on Thursday to begin their latest experience of America.

Cleveland Park is not Miami. In fact, 'this is not America,' said Debby Weil, a dotcom marketing manager who lives on Newark Street. 'It's an incredibly privileged, upper-percentile place.'

The street is the heart of Cleveland Park, not Washington's most exclusive neighbourhood, but home to more than a few chieftains.

Donald E. Graham, publisher of the Washington Post; Jim Lehrer, the public television news anchor; David Ignatius, the next editor of the International Herald Tribune; and Michael Oreskes, Washington bureau chief of the New York Times, to name a few, are Elián's neighbours.

Because it is such a media-rich environment, 'there is mild amusement that the chickens have come home to roost,' Weil said. Elián will be staying at Rosedale, a 1793 dwelling surrounded by a gorgeous greensward that was, until today, the public dog run. 'The first thought was, "Can we still walk our dogs?"' Weil said. Yes, but only on a narrow strip between the tape and the street, and only on a leash. So there was a muted howling at the dog run this morning, and it was not coming from the dogs.

Directly across the street from Rosedale stands the home of a conservative pundit who writes for the New Yorker and insisted on anonymity. He finds the arrival of Elián in the neighbourhood - where he says 'Dukakis for President' bumper stickers still cling to those Volvos - beyond satire.

'The moment it was announced - "Guess who's coming to dinner!" - all these [Attorney-General] Janet Reno devotees, who a month ago were saying, "Good for Janet for getting him out," are now singing a far different aria,' he said. 'Now their little darling is in their backyards, the cry has gone up, "What about the dogs?"'

A novelist, Ward Just, who has chronicled the political culture of Washington since the Sixties, picked the change in the neighbours' perception of the event. 'I predict,' he said, tongue deeply embedded in cheek, 'many op-ed articles about the intrusiveness of the press, some written by newspapermen. There's going to be a lot of new interest in normalising relations with Cuba. And if all else fails, they'll call for Reno's resignation.'

webTitle: Thousands of schools face debt crisis

fields.headline: Thousands of schools face debt crisis
fields.trailText: Thousands of run-down schools are facing crippling debt because their budgets are too low to cover the spiralling costs of education. New figures from the Department for Education reveal that 2,470 schools - more than 10 per cent of the schools in England and Wales - were in deficit last year.
fields.body:
Thousands of run-down schools are facing crippling debt because their budgets are too low to cover the spiralling costs of education. New figures from the Department for Education reveal that 2,470 schools - more than 10 per cent of the schools in England and Wales - were in deficit last year. Senior education sources estimate the total debt could be as much as £200 million.

This week Education Secretary David Blunkett will announce measures to reduce paperwork faced by schools. In a speech to the National Association of Head Teachers on Thursday he will say directives and initiatives delivered to schools by his department must be cut in half.

He will also praise teachers for the good work they are doing to raise standards in the teaching of maths and English.

Blunkett has often been barracked at education conferences for his attacks on teachers and failing schools, and for his controversial proposals to bring in performance-related pay.

He knows he must do more to praise the profession in the run-up to the general election, just as Home Secretary Jack Straw did with the police in a speech to the Police Federation two weeks ago.

Critics say the debt figures reveal how far Blunkett has to go to ensure that schools are delivering better standards. Tony Blair has told Ministers they have to ensure that policies are seen to work 'on the ground' to convince disillusioned voters the Government is turning around years of underfunding. The debt figures blow a hole in Government attempts to resolve school problems with one-off windfall payments, agreed in the Budget, of between £9,000 and £40,000. Head teachers point out that instead of being used to buy new equipment, the payments are disappearing into a black hole of debt.

'The saddest thing is that we are trying to prepare children for a modern world in tatty classrooms, with tatty books and computers that are completely out of date,' said Kevin Short, the brother of International Development Secretary Clare Short.

Last week Short announced he had resigned as head teacher of Hamp Junior School in Bridgwater, Somerset, after becoming disillusioned with mounting paperwork and too much time spent out of the classroom at meetings.

Speaking to The Observer, he revealed how he had to cut back on modernising his school because he was fighting a deficit of £30,000. He said the school could not afford a full-time caretaker and that he had to come in at weekends with other volunteers to do decorating.

One school on Tyneside has debts of £128,000, up from £44,000 the year before, while another has debts of £112,000, up from £32,000

Judith Elderkin, head teacher of Marlborough Road Primary School in Salford, Lancashire, said she was considering laying off two senior senior members of staff because money was so tight.

Her school faces a deficit of £100,000 this year. 'As staff costs make up 90 per cent of my budget that is the area you have to look at,' she said.

webTitle: Qayyum cracks this nut better than Mallett

fields.headline: Qayyum cracks this nut better than Mallett
fields.trailText: Match-fixing The pursuit of the fixers must be relentless and the Qayyum Report is thorough and to be commended. But it is not helped by the sort of allegations that came from the former Australian spinner Ashley Mallett last week.
fields.body:
This is progress. The Qayyum Report is thorough and to be commended. There were fears that there might be some judicious editing along the way, but, having seen excerpts of the more damning depositions given to the judge, it is my impression that all the more shocking allegations are still addressed in the report, which is now public property and being perused by Lord Griffiths, the chairman of the Code of Conduct Commission set up by the ICC.

You can quibble with the conclusions and the punishments suggested (does a life ban affect Salim Malik? Is Ata-ur Rehman really more culpable than Wasim Akram or Mushtaq Ahmed?), but not the conscientious approach of a judge who has been prepared to delve into the mire of match-fixing with far more single-mindedness than his predecessors. He has set an acceptable standard for future inquiries and has been open about the problems he encountered.

Indeed, judging from the allegations, primarily from former Test bowler Manoj Prabhakar, that are surfacing in India, Pakistan have been far more diligent in their pursuit of match-fixers than their Asian neighbours. Prabhakar's evidence implicates both Mohammed Azharuddin and Ajay Jadeja, but there is also the suggestion of a cover-up in the highest echelons of Indian cricket. Qayyum's report, so long in coming, has at least confronted the issues, and has been open about the problems he has encountered.

Proof remains an elusive commodity and Qayyum was scathing about the lack of cooperation he received from certain players. He came to the conclusion that 'most of the people appearing were not telling the truth'; he is incredulous that Waqar Younis claimed never to have heard of match-fixing and observes that Inzamam appears to be suffering from 'amnesia'.

Moreover, the evidence of Mushtaq Ahmed was clearly not utterly convincing to Qayyum: 'He [Mushtaq] denied that he'd taken money from Saleem Parvez but said that his performance in the said match was very good. When questioned as to how he knew which match the counsel was referring to, Mushtaq had no answer.'

At present, Wasim Akram survives, his reputation tarnished but still eligible to play the game, and, no doubt, anxious to talk about it on Channel 4 this summer. But for Ata-ur Rehman perjuring himself or Rashid Latif fiddling with his tapes, who knows? Wasim 'cannot be said to be above suspicion', said the judge, who feels 'all is not well here and Wasim is not above board'.

The pursuit of the fixers must be relentless, but it is not helped by the sort of allegations that came from the former Australian spinner Ashley Mallett last week. Referring to the Sydney Test of 1998 between Australia and South Africa, he concluded: 'In the wake of what transpired with Cronje, I am highly suspicious of this Test. Little things happened in the sessions which did not feel right.'

He noted that Glenn McGrath scored some runs (14), that Cronje played an 'uncharacteristic' shot, that the off-spinner Pat Symcox did not stick to the plan - put forward by Mallett, who had been advising the South African spinners - of bowling an attacking line outside the right-handers' off stump; and he highlighted what he considered to be dodgy team selection. And that was it - nothing more than circumstantial evidence.

By the same token, I might be able to convince you that the famous Test between England and Australia at Old Trafford in 1902 - Fred Tate's match - was fixed. Immediately the selectors come under suspicion: CB Fry, SF Barnes and Gilbert Jes sop were all dropped, prompting captain AC MacLaren's famous remark, 'My God, look what they've sent me.' But perhaps MacLaren himself was in on the scam because on the morning of the match he omitted George Hirst, England's champion all-rounder, and picked instead Sussex's Tate for his one and only Test match. In Australia's second innings, Tate dropped a sitter at deep square-leg. Even so, England required only 124 runs for victory; the captain shuffled the batting order curiously and last man out with four runs required was Tate. What might Ashley Mallett have made of all that?

webTitle: Two die in holiday fair tragedies

fields.headline: Two die in holiday fair tragedies
fields.trailText: Two people were killed in separate Bank Holiday fairground accidents yesterday. A girl of 13 died in Cornwall and a woman of 28 died and two men were seriously injured in west London. The girl who died was hurled from a ride called Top Spin - into which people were individually strapped - operating at a travelling fair in Redruth, Cornwall. She was taken to Treliske hospital but died later of her injuries.
fields.body:
Two people were killed in separate Bank Holiday fairground accidents yesterday. A girl of 13 died in Cornwall and a woman of 28 died and two men were seriously injured in west London. The girl who died was hurled from a ride called Top Spin - into which people were individually strapped - operating at a travelling fair in Redruth, Cornwall. She was taken to Treliske hospital but died later of her injuries.

As the girl fell she hit another girl on the ground, who was later treated for minor injuries. The fair was closed and police sealed off the area.

The hydraulic ride lifted people 10 metres into the air before lowering them to the ground.
