fields.headline: Bottled-up Cork starts to mature
fields.standfirst: In 1995 he was a match-winner against the West Indies. Now he's starting his rehabilitation...
fields.trailText: Third Test In 1995 he was a match-winner against the West Indies. Now he's starting his rehabilitation... Vic Marks meets Dominic Cork.
fields.body:
Dominic Cork will not be flicking anxiously through Teletext when the England team for Thursday's Trent Bridge Test is announced today. He knows that he's some way down the pecking order; that Andrew Caddick, Darren Gough and Ed Giddins are currently unassailable and that he has barely been mentioned for a recall this summer despite injuries to Headley, Silverwood and Mullally. Which does not mean that he is no longer desperate to play for England again. He is. But for the moment his energies can only be devoted to the less exalted task of captaining Derbyshire.

'I don't think about playing for England all the time - I did a couple of years ago,' says Cork. 'But it has been so frustrating, knowing you're good enough yet being sidelined.' And he's right. He is one of the few English cricketers (Graham Thorpe is another) outside the England team, who has proven that he has what it takes to excel at the highest level. But he hasn't played for his country since November 1998.

Remember the heady days of 1995. Cork began his debut Test at Lord's against the West Indies as an into-the-wind support bowler; he ended it as the charismatic strike bowler landed with the dreaded sobriquet 'the new Botham' after an astonishing haul of seven for 43 in the second innings. On to Old Trafford and he performed the hat-trick in England's second victory of the series. In his first five Tests, he had taken 26 wickets and had easily topped the bowling averages. In a month, Cork had suddenly touched heights denied the vast majority of cricketers throughout their entire careers.

'For six months after my debut my head was swirling,' he says. 'I loved the success, of course. But it was like a blur. So many people wanted to talk to me. I remember feeling glazed; they were talking but I wasn't listening. It was so claustrophobic. My life changed so quickly. I wasn't prepared for that; I don't know how you can be. I remember driving to March in Cambridgeshire for a NatWest game straight after that Lord's debut. In the pub they were all cock-a-hoop, wanting to celebrate. But I was so drained I had to say, "Sorry, lads, I'm exhausted" - and took to my room.'

Since then it has been a rollercoaster career, now stuck on 27 Test appearances. He was the leading wicket-taker in South Africa in 1995-96 and ever present when England defeated South Africa here in 1998. In between there have been some major dips, culminating in his absence from the England team since the second Test against Australia at Perth in 1998. His performances deteriorated, but, far more damaging, he was labelled a troublemaker. There were personal problems stemming from his marriage break-up and he was splashed on the front pages rather than back pages - for the wrong reasons.

He accepts the loss of form argument. 'Because of the start I had I was an easy target, but I'm honest if I've not done it out on the field. I can put my hand up when I've failed.' His explanation for his barren spells as a bowler is bullish, though. 'Maybe I was too much of a team man. I never turned down a bowl - you can't when you're playing for England.

'Sometimes I may have bowled too much and played through injuries. I could have been more selfish. Sometimes I tried too hard. I got greedy and tried to bowl the miracle ball too often [that's the one designed to pitch leg, hit off, but which usually ends up on the mid-wicket boundary]. But I'd say I'm more disciplined now, but still aggressive.'

He says captaincy has helped. 'Standing at first slip for Derbyshire I can watch Matt Cassar, for example. Against Yorkshire a couple of weeks ago he bowled quickly, but he wanted to bowl quicker still. I could see that he was forgetting that rhythm was the key and told him so.' A new role here for the 28-year-old old pro, who in his England days was seldom bracketed as captaincy material.

For example, there are a few paragraphs in David Lloyd's book. Referring to the New Zealand tour of 1997, Lloyd says: 'After an initial burst of enthusiasm, he regressed into a brooding mood and often seemed to be deliberately drawing attention to himself and his problems... If it is not one thing with Cork, it is another. I sometimes feel that his problem is cricket itself and a basic inability to handle it.'

Cork is well aware of what has been written about him. 'Don't believe those who say "Oh, I never read what's in the papers." See your name there and you're bound to read on. In the past I would have bitten back in the press and they would say: "There he goes, moaning again." I now realise that that sort of stuff is going to damage me. I know I've got this tag as a troublemaker and a bad apple, but I don't deserve that.' Now he won't be drawn into a slanging match and insists: 'I'm not bitter.'

His 'boorish behaviour' on the field was also criticised by Lloyd. Sometimes this is a question of interpretation. Against the West Indies, those histrionic appeals as he was rampaging through the middle order could be seen as a welcome sign of a new, aggressive English side that refused to be cowed by anyone. When wickets were scarcer and England were struggling, such aggression was deemed to be childish and nauseating.

I am a different person on the field than off,' he says. 'In the middle I am aggressive, up front and I like to have a chirp. Afterwards I'll talk to anyone.' He recalls the Melbourne Test, won by England on the last Ashes tour: 'Even though I was twelfth man, I was so proud of the team; there was no jealousy. I kept scampering on to the pitch with drinks after every Aussie wicket fell, geeing up our bowlers. Even then I had a chirp at Steve Waugh.'

But at the end of that tour he was utterly downcast. 'I wasn't picked for the one-day tournament so flew home early. When I arrived I read that I wasn't even in England's preliminary squad of 38 for the World Cup. No one had told me. That omission hurt since it obviously wasn't just a cricketing decision. It was personal.'

Since then, leading Derbyshire has dominated his cricketing life and, of course, that has not been dull either. There was a battle within the club ending with the ousting of Harold Rhodes from the cricket committee. 'As captain I'm accountable; they can sack me if they like. In which case, the coach and I should be able to make the key cricketing decisions.' There has also been a remarkable exodus from Derby (DeFreitas, Rollins, Blackwell, Weston and Harris all left last year) yet they survive. In his two years in charge, Derbyshire have reached a Lord's final and acquired first-division status in the Championship.

He says that captaincy has matured him; that he's a better communicator now, who is less likely to bottle up his frustrations and all is tranquil on the personal front. He is also encouraged by the new England regime and their willingness to take on board so-called mavericks such as Phil Tufnell, Caddick or Giddins. And he recognises that he has to rebuild his international career via performances on the pitch rather than bleatings in the press. So when the England selectors name an unchanged side for Trent Bridge today, Cork can accept their decision. Which is a start towards his rehabilitation.

webTitle: Britain hunts net paedophiles escape the web

fields.headline: Britain hunts net paedophiles escape the web
fields.standfirst: A US website sting operation against child abusers has pointed the way forward for this country to crack down on cyber-criminals.  Kamal Ahmed and  Jamie Doward  report
fields.trailText: The Government is to strengthen the law against paedophiles using the internet following fury over the Kevin Lockley case and rising concern that children using the net are vulnerable.
fields.body:
The Government is to strengthen the law against paedophiles using the internet following fury over the Kevin Lockley case and rising concern that children using the net are vulnerable.

Lockley, who threatened to rape a child, was jailed for 18 months last week after being caught surfing the net looking for under-age girls. He was trapped on a fake website set up and monitored by police in a US sting operation.

The judge in the case demanded the penalty be strengthened beyond the maximum two years for using the internet to procure children for sex. If charged with attempted child abuse, Lockley may have received life.

Ministers are set to amend the Regulating Investigating Practices Bill passing through Parliament and use the sexual offences review, to be published next month, to boost police powers to seize computer material if there is a suspicion of child abuse.

Ministers agree that sentences should be increased for paedophiles who use internet chat rooms to procure children for sex. Abusers pretend to be children and set up meetings without the knowledge of the child's parents.

'The international paedophile business is... increasingly sophisticated,' said Charles Clarke, Home Office Minister. 'This vile business needs to be confronted by all means possible.'

At present, child abusers who encrypt images or information on their computers and refuse to reveal the decoding key will face a maxi mum two years' jail. They also avoid being placed on the sex offenders' register.

Ministers say plans for toughening the law, drawn up by John Carr, a key government adviser on paedophiles and the internet who is close to Clarke, are being seriously considered.

A paper by Carr and Chris Atkinson of the NSPCC, seen by The Observer, has been handed to the Government. 'We would like to see sentences toughened, especially where there are strong grounds for believing that the person not handing over their [decoding] key is doing so deliberately in order to avoid a more serious charge relating to child pornography or other child sex offences,' the report says.

'Two years imprisonment and a fine hardly seems enough when, potentially, the offender knows they could otherwise easily be facing a much, much longer sentence. Lawyers who work this out might... advise their clients to refuse to hand over the key and accept the lesser charge with the lower tariff.'

It has been pointed out that if Gary Glitter had encrypted the child pornography on his computer and then refused to decode it, he would have escaped sex offence charges.

'Cases against known child pornographers or paedophiles in the UK have been abandoned precisely because the offenders were "smart" enough to encrypt their photographs or emails and then refuse to decrypt them to show clean, coherent copies to the police,' the report says.

'With the arrival of the new, stronger and inexpensive encryption technologies this problem is set to worsen.'

Lockley thought he was meeting a nine-year-old girl called Amy in the Regents Palace Hotel in central London. But police officers from London and California set him up and he was arrested. He tried to procure girls after logging on to what he believed was a paedophilia website. It was actually a sting by US police.

The UK problems follow a series of scandals in America over paedophiles preying on children via the internet. One American teenager, Katherine Tarbox, has written a book about how an internet predator almost sexually assaulted her. Having developed an online romance with 'Mark', whom she believed was 23, Tarbox, then 13, arranged to meet him in a hotel. Mark was really Frank, aged 41. Only quick thinking by a friend who alerted police saved her from a potentially horrible fate. Francis John Kufrovich was sentenced to 18 months under the Communications Decency Act.

Each month it is likely that at least one of the 50 attorney's offices in the US will convict an adult of sexually abusing a child having initiated contact via the internet. This month a Utah man was charged with sending child pornography to someone he believed to be a 12-year-old girl, having contacted her in an internet chat room.

The 'child' was really a US customs agent. Police officers discovered that 'Tom', as the defendant called himself online, had also contacted a 15-year-old girl, asking her for sex. She testified at his trial.

Sting operations, using police officers posing as children to catch paedophiles on the internet, are increasingly common in the United States. But the Lockley case in Britain last week highlighted the gap between US and UK methods. Sting operations are rare in the UK, and internet ones are unheard of. Lockley was only caught through US detective work.

But some senior UK officers believe there is a need for a more active approach. 'Hardly anyone in the UK is doing any proactive work. The Met has a couple of officers doing online investigations, Greater Manchester and West Midlands about the same. Even New Zealand has more people looking at this than we have,' said one disgruntled police source.

US detective Michael Di Matteo, the man behind the fake website which trapped Lockley, who has worked with the United Kingdom's police several times before the Lockley case, argues that the proposed changes to UK law can only help catch paedophiles.

'I had a case back in 1995 with Kent police involving this person who had been locked up for 11 years in a secure mental facility.

'He had raped an 11 year-old-girl and left her for dead. He contacted us over the internet (about procuring a child) when he came out and we informed the police in Kent. This (the Lockley case) is not a one-off.'


Kamal Ahmed
Jamie Doward

fields.headline: Kapil in 'fix' sting
fields.trailText: Match-fixing
fields.body:
Kapil Dev suffered another blow to his already-dented reputation when it was reported that several key Indian players and senior officials alleged that they had covered up for him over allegations that he bribed a team-mate.

An undercover television documentary screened yesterday appeared to corroborate the claim made by Manoj Prabhakar, the former Indian all-rounder, that several key members of the Indian squad knew of Dev's attempts to offer him £35,000 to play badly.

In a series of secretly filmed interviews, officials from India's ruling cricket board also privately lament the fact that match-fixing in India is rife. Jaywant Lele, the secretary of the Board of Cricket Control in India, admits 'three persons' are involved. He names them as Kapil Dev, Mohammed Azharuddin and Ajay Jadeja.

In another interview, India's former coach Ajit Wadekar, concedes that Prabhakar did complain to him in 1994 that he had been offered a bribe by Dev to underperform during the Singer tournament in Sri Lanka. Wadekar went on to deny all knowledge of the offer to a judge. The judge's report into match-fixing later exonerated the Indian squad. 'Who reads the report?' Wadekar tells Prabhakar with a shrug.

Other allegations in the documentary, which was made with the assistance of Prabhakar, who secretly recorded several of his ex-team-mates using a camera hidden in a bag, include:

* The Dubai-based underworld don Dawood Ibrahim visited the dressing room of the Indian squad to talk to Kapil Dev during a match at Sharjah during the Nineties. Dawood is widely believed to be responsible for much of the illegal betting on the subcontinent.

* Mohammed Azharuddin disclosed £2.5 million of income he could not explain to the tax authorities three years ago under a government amnesty scheme. While the amount was known, the identity of the Indian player involved was not.

* The 1997 Titan Cup was 'definitely fixed', according to Mumbai police commissioner Rakesh Maria. Maria also claims the South African squad have been involved in match-fixing 'for some time' and says it costs £150,000 to fix a match.

In a conversation secretly filmed in his Bombay office, Maria also names Azharuddin, Jadeja and Nayan Mongia as being involved in match-fixing. Azharuddin owns several penthouse properties and has changed his mobile phone numbers every month throughout his playing career, he adds.

Tarun Tejpal, the editor of the Indian website tehelka.com responsible for the undercover investigation, yesterday said he would hand over more than 40 hours of secret footage to India's Central Bureau of Inquiry (CBI). The CBI is now investigating the match-fixing affair. 'If the government doesn't act now it is scandalous. If the BCCI doesn't act either it is equally scandalous,' he added.

Speaking at a press conference in a Delhi hotel, Manoj Prabhakar yesterday admitted he had cheated on his friends by filming them secretly, but said he had done it to try to clean up the game.

These latest revelations are likely to throw an ugly shadow over the one-day Asia Cup, involving India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh, which starts in Dhaka today. On Friday Kapil Dev, India's coach, angrily brushed aside the suggestion he should withdraw from the tournament, and dismissed Prabhakar's bribery claims- made earlier in the week as 'malicious' and untrue.

Yesterday, however, two other witnesses secretly filmed by Prabhakar appeared to confirm his version of events. Navjot Sidhu, a former India player, admits that he saw Dev go into Prabhakar's hotel room. He also recalls Dev leaving shortly afterwards, and says he saw Prabhakar storm out furiously complaining about the offer.

Sidhu refuses to go on the record about the incident, claiming Dev has done many favours for him in the past. Nayan Mongia, the former Indian wicketkeeper, also recalls the encounter. 'There was so much noise that everyone noticed,' he said.

In another illuminating section, Ali Irani, the Indian squad's former physiotherapist, describes Ajay Jadeja as a 'mischievous thug'. 'You know what he used to do? Jaddu [Jadeja] used to tell Azhar [Azharuddin]), "Whatever you want me to do just tell me".' Irani also describes Judge Chandrachud, whose inquiry concluded there was no match-fixing in India, as a 'fool'.

An undercover television documentary screened yesterday appeared to corroborate the claim made by Manoj Prabhakar, the former Indian all-rounder, that several key members of the Indian squad knew of Dev's attempts to offer him £35,000 to play badly. In a series of secretly filmed interviews, officials from India's ruling cricket board also privately lament the fact that match-fixing in India is rife. Jaywant Lele, the secretary of the Board of Cricket Control in India, admits 'three persons' are involved. He names them as Kapil Dev, Mohammed Azharuddin and Ajay Jadeja. In another interview, India's former coach Ajit Wadekar, concedes that Prabhakar did complain to him in 1994 that he had been offered a bribe by Dev to underperform during the Singer tournament in Sri Lanka. Wadekar went on to deny all knowledge of the offer to a judge. The judge's report into match-fixing later exonerated the Indian squad. 'Who reads the report?' Wadekar tells Prabhakar with a shrug. Other allegations in the documentary, which was made with the assistance of Prabhakar, who secretly recorded several of his ex-team-mates using a camera hidden in a bag, include: * The Dubai-based underworld don Dawood Ibrahim visited the dressing room of the Indian squad to talk to Kapil Dev during a match at Sharjah during the Nineties. Dawood is widely believed to be responsible for much of the illegal betting on the subcontinent. * Mohammed Azharuddin disclosed £2.5 million of income he could not explain to the tax authorities three years ago under a government amnesty scheme. While the amount was known, the identity of the Indian player involved was not. * The 1997 Titan Cup was 'definitely fixed', according to Mumbai police commissioner Rakesh Maria. Maria also claims the South African squad have been involved in match-fixing 'for some time' and says it costs £150,000 to fix a match. In a conversation secretly filmed in his Bombay office, Maria also names Azharuddin, Jadeja and Nayan Mongia as being involved in match-fixing. Azharuddin owns several penthouse properties and has changed his mobile phone numbers every month throughout his playing career, he adds. Tarun Tejpal, the editor of the Indian website tehelka.com responsible for the undercover investigation, yesterday said he would hand over more than 40 hours of secret footage to India's Central Bureau of Inquiry (CBI). The CBI is now investigating the match-fixing affair. 'If the government doesn't act now it is scandalous. If the BCCI doesn't act either it is equally scandalous,' he added. Speaking at a press conference in a Delhi hotel, Manoj Prabhakar yesterday admitted he had cheated on his friends by filming them secretly, but said he had done it to try to clean up the game. These latest revelations are likely to throw an ugly shadow over the one-day Asia Cup, involving India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh, which starts in Dhaka today. On Friday Kapil Dev, India's coach, angrily brushed aside the suggestion he should withdraw from the tournament, and dismissed Prabhakar's bribery claims- made earlier in the week as 'malicious' and untrue. webTitle: Trucker 'left to rot' in prison prison

fields.headline: Trucker 'left to rot' in prison prison
fields.standfirst: Forgotten victim of the Balkan war warrisked his life to supply Nato troops and was jailed after 'farcical' trial
fields.trailText: He shares a cramped, squalid cell with 10 other inmates. The toilet is blocked. There is no running water. He does not speak the language and is painfully thin. His family fear for his sanity.
fields.body:
He shares a cramped, squalid cell with 10 other inmates. The toilet is blocked. There is no running water. He does not speak the language and is painfully thin. His family fear for his sanity.

Richard Hudson, a truck driver from Derbyshire, is the forgotten man of the Balkans conflict: jailed for a crime his supporters and campaigners insist he did not commit. His family fear that they will never see him again.

His father Gordon, 73, who has cancer, launched a last-ditch appeal this weekend to the supreme court in Macedonia to have his son freed from his sentence for allegedly causing the deaths of two men in road accidents.

Having spent nearly £4,000 battling for his son, Gordon Hudson also denounced Nato for 'abandoning' him to rot in jail for political reasons. But his hopes of seeing his son again are fading and now depend on the Macedonian and UK governments allowing the two-year sentence to be completed in a British prison.

Government sources last night told The Observer that ministerial and diplomatic approaches had been made behind the scenes to the Macedonian authorities. 'We are trying to speed things up,' said the Foreign Office.

Richard Hudson, 45, was on his twelfth trip driving vital supplies to British troops serving with Nato's K-For soldiers. He stopped to help after seeing a road crash in which two local men died. Their car was travelling at around 125mph in a 75mph zone when it skidded off the road and rolled over.

Hudson was arrested by Macedonian police seeking a scapegoat in a country which had backed the Serbs in the Kosovo conflict. Hostility towards Nato drivers had reached boiling point.

Despite denials from witnesses, police claimed Hudson's lorry was on the wrong side of the road travelling at 75mph, forcing the oncoming car to swerve. Attempts by Hudson's lawyers to test the car driver's body for alcohol or drugs were rebuffed.

A few months before the accident, a Nato soldier had crashed into a car, killing a Macedonian minister and his family. Nato stepped in, blocked police access to the scene and whisked the soldier home to Norway.

Other Nato drivers have also been spirited away from crashes to avoid notoriously rough local justice. Hudson was not so lucky. He was on his way to pick up his Nato driver's pass when he stopped at the accident.

Because he never collected the pass, Nato denied he worked for them and insisted Hudson was employed by Eddie Stobart, the British hauliers. The company has been criticised by Hudson's family for failing to donate to their fighting fund .

Stephen Jakobi, director of the charity Fair Trials Abroad, told The Observer the case was 'one of the worst injustices I have seen..

'Tachograph readings showing that Mr Hudson was travelling at 75mph were actually registering speeds he had done in Greece, three hours before. Police deliberately withheld the relevant tacho. Diagrams produced to show that the lorry was diagonally across the road were total conjecture.'

'This guy has been abandoned by Nato. He is in some danger in that prison. Local media, which reported him as guilty even before the trial, have been calling him a soldier in a place where anti-K-For feeling is very high.'

His sister Frances has visited him in Skopje jail several times. 'It is very distressing to see him in such terrible conditions,' she said.The prison is filthy. He is in a cell with 10 men, no running water and a blocked toilet. It's foul.'

"The whole thing is such a farce. During the court case one expert witness actually said the accident would not have happened if the car hadn't been speeding, but nobody listened. All we can do now is wait for the supreme court, but they need him too much as a scapegoat.'

It is a waiting game too for Gordon Hudson and his wife, Margaret, at home in Findern, Derbyshire,

Gordon said: 'Nato have simply ignored their responsibility to a driver whose safety they were happy to put at risk. They went to the Balkans to save foreign civilians but they can't save a British one.'

webTitle: Army to test women for combat roles

fields.headline: Army to test women for combat roles
fields.trailText: Women are to train for combat roles in the Army alongside male soldiers in a controversial move that breaks with centuries of British military tradition.
fields.body:
Women are to train for combat roles in the Army alongside male soldiers in a controversial move that breaks with centuries of British military tradition.

In tests later this year, females will team up with men in a series of trials aimed at establishing how they fare in the so-called 'teeth' arms of the services - those expected to be directly engaged in fighting. The tests are a major step towards having British women going into frontline battle for the British Army.

A panel of experts will submit a report - entitled 'A Study of Combat Effectiveness and Gender' - to Ministers within 12 months. Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, commissioned the inquiry last year.

The exact form of the trials has yet to be decided, though they are expected to test the viability of mixed-gender tank crews, all-women crews, mixed infantry units and all-women infantry units as well as less radical innovations. The tests, likely to involve a series of military exercises, will also examine how the men react to the presence on the battlefield of women, and compare how each sex copes with the mental and physical demands of combat.

A Ministry of Defence spokesmen confirmed the trials. 'Nothing had been ruled out,' he said. There are 17,000 women in the Army, and only 24 per cent of its jobs are reserved for men. Most of these are in the Household Cavalry division, the Royal Armoured Corps and the infantry.

It has traditionally been thought that women could not cope with the heavy physical demands of frontline fighting and that mixed-gender armoured units were impracticable.

'There are many roles that have historically and conventionally been denied to women, and Ministers are keen to challenge prejudices,' said one Ministry of Defence source. 'Though the trials won't necessarily result in any relaxation of the restrictions... If there is no negative impact on combat [capability] there will obviously be a strong case for change.'

A source close to Hoon denied the policy was driven by 'political correctness. The guiding principle is opera tional effectiveness,' he said. Recent trials of women sailors on submarines resulted in the ban on female submariners remaining. However, the Army finds it increasingly hard to recruit, creating pressure for change.

The trials are likely to provoke a strong reaction from many soldiers. 'It's ludicrous,' said one serving infantry officer last night. 'Can you imagine women fighting with their bare hands in a trench?'

Others spoke of the potential problems of mixed-gender combat units, claiming that men's judgment would be impaired by 'instinctive urges' to go to the aid of female comrades. 'It would tear the Army apart,' said one former soldier, who resigned last year.

Giving women combat roles would bring Britain into line with the armies of the US, Canada, Holland, Norway and Israel.


Jason Burke

fields.headline: Derry's H-block ruler
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A former IRA prisoner who was once sentenced to hundreds of years in jail will next week become the first Sinn Fein mayor of an Irish city since the republican hero of the independence war, Terence MacSweeney.
fields.body:
A former IRA prisoner who was once sentenced to hundreds of years in jail will next week become the first Sinn Fein mayor of an Irish city since the republican hero of the independence war, Terence MacSweeney.

Cathal Crumley, 42, who spent three years on the blanket during the H-block protests, is set to be elected Mayor of Derry on 5 June.

The last time a Sinn Fein councillor was elected mayor of an Irish city was in 1920, when MacSweeney became the first citizen of Cork and Lloyd George was still Prime Minister of Great Britain and Ireland. MacSweeney died in the same year, after 74 days on hunger strike in Cork jail in protest at his incarceration by the British.

For a new generation of IRA members like Crumley, MacSweeney's death fast provided inspiration during the first decade of the current Troubles.

'I think I have a very strong sense of the history of this. The party in Derry is very proud that we may be the first to have a Sinn Fein mayor since partition. It's a very important breakthrough, given the fact that over the last 30 years Sinn Fein has been demonised and denigrated from all quarters. This represents the breaking down of our exclusion even on our local council. We've been trying to get the top position since 1985,' Crumley said.

The father of three is the embodiment of the new Sinn Fein that has evolved over the last 10 years since the peace process began. Clean- cut, courteous, articulate, always a shirt and tie on hand for a photo-opportunity, Crumley was among the first wave of former prisoners to enter electoral politics after the 1981 hunger-strike.

The modern Sinn Fein's foray into Northern elections took place a year later when Crumley stood alongside Martin McGuinness as the party's candidates in Derry for the Assembly. At the time he was unable to canvass because he was being held in Belfast's Crumlin Road jail on the word of two IRA supergrasses, Bobby Quigley and Raymond Gilmour. Crumley spent four years on remand during which he was given nine life sentences. He was released on appeal in 1986.

Sitting in a cramped upstairs room of Sinn Fein's heavily fortified Gable Street office in Derry's Bogside, the artefacts of the armed struggle surround Crumley. These include a mounted poster with passport-size pictures of every one of the IRA Derry Brigade's volunteers killed over the last 30 years.

But despite his own background, Crumley vows that he wants to be mayor for all Derry's citizens, including unionists living on the mainly Protestant Waterside across the River Foyle.

'I will be pragmatic and sensible. But I won't be attending things like Remembrance Sunday because I am an Irish republican. But I will endeavour to attend other functions, which might involve Protestant/unionist areas. We will extend the hand of friendship to everyone and I won't set out to cause offence to anyone.'

On the other side of the Foyle, community workers who operate in Protestant estates are sceptical that a Sinn Fein mayor will be acceptable on the unionist Waterside. John Guthrie, who lives in the loyalist Tullyally area, predicts that the Protestant community will 'seclude itself from civic life over the next 12 months'.

Guthrie has no personal problem debating with his republican opponents, but believes the majority of unionists in the city will boy cott functions attending by a Sinn Fein mayor.

'The pressure will come on people like me not to turn up for meetings and functions organised by the new mayor. The perception on this side of the river is that his election represents the further alienation of the Protestant-unionist tradition in this city.'

Crumley said: 'I will carry out my job on an equitable and fair basis. I would be a fool to say there aren't contentious issues in the city like the Apprentice Boys march in August, but I will cross that bridge when I come to it - literally.'

As he prepares himself to follow in MacSweeney's footsteps, Crumley reflects on his days in H-block. 'I couldn't have possibly foreseen while on the blanket that one day I would be mayor of my own city. It's a strange turn of events, but it shows how far the struggle has come.'

webTitle: Ireland: Follow the money and you'll find Charlie

fields.headline: Ireland: Follow the money and you'll find Charlie
fields.trailText: How rich do you have to be to lose track of a million pounds? The question came up last week at the Moriarty Tribunal, which is investigating the payment of large sums of money to former Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey.
fields.body:
How rich do you have to be to lose track of a million pounds? The question came up last week at the Moriarty Tribunal, which is investigating the payment of large sums of money to former Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey.

It's easier to mislay that kind of money if you are the financial controller of a large firm, accustomed to handling between IR£10 and IR£12 million a week. That was the explanation which Ben Dunne, who once ran Ireland's largest chain of supermarkets, offered for his lapse of memory.

Dunne has already admitted paying close to a million pounds to help the former Taoiseach out of trouble. In 1979, when Haughey took office, he was in debt to the tune of IR£l.143m. There was concern that he could be declared bankrupt.

Rich friends, and friends of friends, were asked to bail him out. One was Dunne. He expected to pay between IR£700,000 and IR£900,000.

But the tribunal has uncovered evidence that his generosity came closer to IR£2m. Dunne seemed surprised. It would have been easier to remember, he told the tribunal, if the money had been paid in one go rather than 'on the drip' in sums of a few hundred thousand pounds at a time. There was the further complication that the money often travelled through a number of countries and accounts - e.g. from Hong Kong to London to the Cayman Islands and back to Dublin.

Dunne's contributions to Haughey's famously extravagant life style were only the start of it. He became Taoiseach in l979. During the next 17 years he received IR£8.6m in donations and loans from businessmen. These included prop erty developers, a Saudi sheikh, and a leading Irish hotelier.

Counsel for the tribunal made the point that the sum of IR£8.6m may be an overestimate, because some of it was almost certainly transferred between several bank accounts. It was also revealed that the total did not include Haughey's salary as a TD or Government Minister. These came in the form of cheques and were cashed at once.

The public has long been fascinated by the question of how and where Haughey got his money. There was the estate just outside Dublin, the island off the coast of Kerry, the family yacht and much else besides. Even so, it was startling to hear that a 'bill-paying service' operated on his behalf dealt with invoices totalling IR£1.4m in just five years between l985 and January 1991.

Bertie Ahern says he finds the revelations about his predecessor's financial affairs 'deeply shocking'. Haughey, he added, had 'betrayed the ethos' of Fianna Fail. This first explicit attempt to distance himself from his ex-mentor may be too little, too late.

There was a time, before the recent spate of tribunals looking into political cor ruption, when most Irish people were prepared to believe that this was confined to the so-called 'golden circle' close to Haughey. Since then we have heard of large sums paid to elected councillors to change planning decisions.

A former senior official in Dublin Corporation has admitted receiving a quarter of a million pounds from just one builder.

All the political parties have expressed outrage at these revelations and pledged to set up ethics committees which will prevent them happening again. But the public perception remains that politics and patronage are so closely intertwined because there is no real will at the top to disentangle them.

This argument got another boost last week when Hugh O'Flaherty, a former senior judge, was appointed as a vice president of the European Investment Bank at a salary of IR£147,000 a year. Last year O'Flaherty resigned from the Supreme Court after intervening in a case in which a Dublin architect, sentenced to four years in jail for drunk driving causing death, was released after just one year.

In a report on the case by the Chief Justice, O'Flaherty's intervention was described as 'damaging to the administration of justice'. The appointment, defended by Ahern, has caused uproar.

The Irish Times , in a scathing editorial, asked if this would set a precedent which might lead to Haughey 'being nominated to represent us on the world stage'.

The question people are asking now is, what further tales of sleaze will emerge and will they damage Ahern? They may get some answers within a matter of weeks, when Haughey is due to give evidence to the Moriarty Tribunal.

There was a time, before the recent spate of tribunals looking into political cor ruption, when most Irish people were prepared to believe that this was confined to the so-called 'golden circle' close to Haughey. Since then we have heard of large sums paid to elected councillors to change planning decisions. A former senior official in Dublin Corporation has admitted receiving a quarter of a million pounds from just one builder. All the political parties have expressed outrage at these revelations and pledged to set up ethics committees which will prevent them happening again. But the public perception remains that politics and patronage are so closely intertwined because there is no real will at the top to disentangle them. This argument got another boost last week when Hugh O'Flaherty, a former senior judge, was appointed as a vice president of the European Investment Bank at a salary of IR£147,000 a year. Last year O'Flaherty resigned from the Supreme Court after intervening in a case in which a Dublin architect, sentenced to four years in jail for drunk driving causing death, was released after just one year. In a report on the case by the Chief Justice, O'Flaherty's intervention was described as 'damaging to the administration of justice'. The appointment, defended by Ahern, has caused uproar. The Irish Times , in a scathing editorial, asked if this would set a precedent which might lead to Haughey 'being nominated to represent us on the world stage'. The question people are asking now is, what further tales of sleaze will emerge and will they damage Ahern? They may get some answers within a matter of weeks, when Haughey is due to give evidence to the Moriarty Tribunal.

webTitle: Campaigners see 'good chance' of Section 28 change

fields.headline: Campaigners see 'good chance' of Section 28 change
fields.trailText: Campaigners against the Scottish Executive's planned repeal of Section 28 are growing in confidence that marriage will be recognised in the new legislation
fields.body:
Campaigners against the Scottish Executive's planned repeal of Section 28 are growing in confidence that marriage will be recognised in the new legislation. Sources in the Roman Catholic Church believe there is a 'good' chance of an amendment tabled by Labour MSP Michael McMahon being accepted.

On Friday, the Church sent emails to all members of the Local Government Committee in Holyrood, calling on MSPs to support McMahon's amendment as an 'opportunity to draw a line under the issue' of Section 28.

On Tuesday the Local Government Committee will consider two amendments to the repeal of Section 28. The Tories have tabled one that calls for marriage to be recognised. McMahon has tabled another that recognises marriage and attacks intolerance of other life styles. If the committee accepts either amendment, it would be included in the legislation.

The Executive could attempt to change the wording again later, but this is highly unlikely. The Catholic Church's email has strengthened the resolve of McMahon, who told The Observer the Executive 'can't sustain their argument' against alternatives to Section 28.

McMahon felt the mood 'for concession was growing'. For months the Labour backbencher has kept out of the headlines while leading the rebellion over the Government's repeal of Section 28, or Clause 2A. The latest Catholic initiative has encouraged him to go public. He said: 'I don't think the Executive want to change, but this letter from the Catholic Church has given them a lot of thinking to do over this weekend.

'At Thursday's question time David McLetchie asked Jim Wallace [acting First Minister] why marriage could be included in legislation in England but not north of the border. Jim said devolution meant Scottish solutions for Scottish problems. Firstly, what exactly is the Scottish problem here, and secondly I don't think Jim has the answer.'

Earlier last week McMahon thought his amendment would fail. He claims he has not been lobbying the Local Government Committee, but yesterday said he was aware of growing support among members.

The Catholic Church has signalled that a concession towards marriage would end its high-profile campaign against repeal of Section 28. Information Officer Ronnie Convrey gave evidence in favour of including marriage in the legislation to the Equal Opportunities Committee in February.

Communities Minister Wendy Alexander announced the repeal of Section 28 last autumn. It had been on the policy books of Labour, the SNP and the Liberal Democrats for 10 years. When Stagecoach millionaire Brian Souter began to campaign last January against repeal, the Executive changed its position. Instead of withdrawing the clause that forbids local authorities to promote homosexuality, it suggested a wording recognising 'stable relationships'. This changed again a fortnight ago when it adopted the SNP's policy of statutory guidance for teachers.

A spokesman for the Executive dismissed suggestions it would concede McMahon's amendment. A spokesman for the Catholic Church said that, while it preferred McMahon's amendment, the Church was 'unconvinced of the need to repeal Section 28 at all'.

webTitle: Straw pulls plug on counselling for wife-beaters

fields.headline: Straw pulls plug on counselling for wife-beaters
fields.trailText: There is no cure for men who beat their wives or partners, according to new Home Office research.
fields.body:
There is no cure for men who beat their wives or partners, according to new Home Office research.

The shock findings have led to a complete rethink of the way domestic violence is dealt with by the criminal justice system. As a result, Home Secretary Jack Straw will remove funding from therapy sessions designed to treat men guilty of domestic violence and instead put money into refuges, stricter enforcement of injunctions against offenders and electronic tagging to keep violent men away from their former spouses and girlfriends.

Research into a series of pilot schemes set up to tackle repeat offenders found that only around 25 per cent of men completed the courses, which cost the taxpayer £6,000 a time.

The news was given a ringing endorsement by women's groups last night, but challenged by professional counsellors who described the move as 'bleak'.

As part of the drive to cut re-offending, the Home Office aims to push 10,000 people through rehabilitation projects by the end of 2001/2. Early indications suggest that all the programmes, including those for sex offenders, drug abusers and violent criminals, have generally been a success.

However, the Home Office was shocked to find that the offenders who seemed beyond treatment were those guilty of domestic violence. The Home Office is now developing a 'reverse tag' which would alert the police when an offender approached the home of women they had assaulted.

Harry Fletcher of the National Association of Probation Officers described the findings as 'extremely worrying'. 'We had assumed all intensive offender programmes reduced crime significantly. If it's not the case with domestic violence, then there must be a re-evaluation of programmes and enhanced protection for women.'

The latest Home Office figures show that there are around 835,000 incidents of domestic violence each year. Two women are murdered every week in England and Wales by their current or former partner.

Sandra Horley, chief executive of Refuge, the country's largest single provider of support to abused women and children, said: 'I am not a hardline feminist and I am not against men receiving help, but in many years of experience I have known only one man who has changed his behaviour.

'The problem with group therapy is that it may become a talking shop, and there is evidence to show that men actually become more cunning in the way they disguise their violence.'

But the British Association of Counselling, the country's largest professional body for therapists, disagreed that all violent men are beyond rehabilitation. 'It all depends on what kind of counselling they have been measuring the success of,' said BAC chairman Craig McDevitt, head of student counselling services at Edinburgh University. 'It contradicts evidence in my field of programmes which have been successful. Often people who commit domestic violence have a history of having experienced similar violence. The first stage of the counselling process is to help the person make sense of their behaviour as something they have learnt.'

'Also, any programme that people have been forced to participate in will have a higher failure rate.'

webTitle: Official: Joggers can do it for miles longer

fields.headline: Official: Joggers can do it for miles longer
fields.trailText: Forget candle-lit dinners, lacy lingerie, oysters and that little blue pill Viagra. If your desire is flagging, then put on your jogging shoes - and start training for a marathon.
fields.body:
Forget candle-lit dinners, lacy lingerie, oysters and that little blue pill Viagra. If your desire is flagging, then put on your jogging shoes - and start training for a marathon.

Older men whose libido is wilting can develop the sex drive of a man half their age by taking regular and intensive exercise, scientists have discovered.

Athletes often attest that taking exercise boosts sex drive, but that is usually thought to be simply because of the sense of well-being from being fit.

But researchers at the Newcastle University Medical School have found that older men who get their blood racing every day have far higher levels of the male sex-hormone testosterone - the biggest single determinant of sex drive in men - than couch potatoes. Regular exercise also leads to a dramatic rise in the level of growth hormone - often taken illegally by athletes to promote strength - which also enhances the feeling of well-being.

In adulthood, levels of both hormones decrease with age, especially after 40. Lower levels of growth hormone tend to result in less muscle, more fat and weaker bones. Falling levels of testosterone often result in loss of sex drive and reduced potency. However, the effects of ageing can be reversed by hard exercise - driving the levels of the hormones up, and giving older men the sex-drive of someone twenty years younger.

Men aged 55-65 who run more than 40 miles a week - the equivalent of training for a marathon - were found to have higher levels of both hormones compared to men of a similar age who did no regular exercise.

Pat Kendall-Taylor, professor of endocrinology at University of Newcastle, who carried out the research, said: 'Men who do regular exercise not only benefit from better health but actually produce the hormones associated with younger bodies and sexual activity. The implications are clear: good steady exercise is to be recommended.'

Kendall-Taylor and her team recruited ten 'runners' from athletic clubs and ten healthy but inactive men from social clubs. The average level of growth hormone was four times higher in the runners, whose testosterone levels were about 25 per cent higher. Kendall-Taylor said: 'The differences were quite definite - enough to make a significant difference.'

However, the exercise has to be sustained to have any effect. Ageing Lotharios looking for a quick fix will be disappointed: a quick run before a romantic evening will make little or no difference.

webTitle: Pre-teen girls are slaves to a thin image

fields.headline: Pre-teen girls are slaves to a thin image
fields.standfirst: A fifth are on diets - not to gain a boyfriend but to attain career success
fields.trailText: They are confident, ambitious and don't care about sex or boys. But Britain's schoolgirls are still slaves to the culture of thin.
fields.body:
They are confident, ambitious and don't care about sex or boys. But Britain's schoolgirls are still slaves to the culture of thin.

Startling new statistics show that a fifth of girls from 11 to 17 are on a diet. One in seven 11-year-olds and one in three 16-year-olds are trying to lose weight.

The findings of one of the most comprehensive surveys ever completed on the country's schoolgirls will confirm parents' and doctors' worst fears: that the 'thin is beautiful' culture is pushing children into diets causing them to miss out nutrients vital for the health of their growing bodies.

Worryingly, the girls know they shouldn't be dieting and 80 per cent said they are happy with the way they look. But the most compelling evidence that they are not came from the numbers on diets, with 90 per cent of girls admitting they felt pressure to 'look perfect'.

The Guide Association research, called Today's Girl, Tomorrow's Woman, pointed to reasons other than wanting to look good for the opposite sex for dieting.

Apart from being thin, success was what most girls wanted. An overwhelming number of today's schoolgirls would choose a good career over a good relationship, and they believe it is up to them to achieve it.

A family is the last thing on their minds, with pregnancy coming second only to failing exams as the biggest fear in their lives.

With almost half believing their lives would be better if they were more attractive and that successful people have 'the right look', it is easy to see how top jobs are becoming equated with looking good.

But a more positive note in the report was the resounding snub given to pop stars such as Britney Spears and Geri Halliwell as role models. Only 10 per cent chose a celebrity, while an overwhelming 50 per cent voted for their mothers as the perfect figurehead.

Take Cassie, 17, who lives in Norwood, Surrey. According to the stereotype, she should be experimenting with drugs, drink and sex and yearn to look like Jennifer Lopez.

Cassie has a boyfriend, but he lives quite far away and she sees him only fortnightly or so. She is far more interested in studying for her A levels and her biggest worry is that she won't get the grades she needs to study microbiology at university. She buys teenage magazines occasionally, but thinks the sex content is boring and that children her age are too immature to have sex, but believes that contraceptives should be available to them to prevent the 'greater of two evils'.

'Being happy is my biggest aspiration, but a good job is second,' she said. 'My role model would have to be my mum - not really any celebrity - because just by appearing on TV doesn't mean they have any qualities you can admire. My mum is caring and patient and she gave up a high-powered job to look after my brother and me, which I think is a really amazing thing to do. I don't think I would do it.

'I don't want to look like Posh Spice or anything; I like being me. There's definitely pressure on girls to be slim and dress well, but you don't have to succumb to that, although the pressure has definitely eased as I've got older.'

The research suggests Cassie's attitudes are the norm not the exception, although Stephanie, 13, from Erskine, will disagree on being satisfied with her looks. 'I am on a diet because my bum and my thighs are too big. I know I should exercise too, but I can't afford to join a gym.

'I don't care about boys, but my friends take the mickey sometimes and I don't want to be fat. I just don't eat lunch, but my mum makes me eat my tea, although I've told her no more chips. If she's not in the house, I give half the food to my neighbour's dog.'

Government estimates say less than 10 per cent of Britain's children are actually overweight and few of them are the ones on diets.

Girls like Stephanie risk developing not only eating disorders, but osteoporosis, skin disorders and fertility problems. But researchers interviewing the 500 girls, across all social and ethnic categories, found high levels of confidence and forward thinking.

Girls were presented with seven choices of lifestyle and asked which appealed most. Each was presented as a real woman. The most popular - almost 40 per cent of the vote - was 'Sarah'. A university graduate, she had a senior position in a large firm with frequent trips abroad. She drove a sports car and had lots of friends, but no boyfriend.

The three least popular lifestyles were divorced or married women with children.

A resounding 80 per cent said they didn't mind if they had a boyfriend or not, but by far the biggest worry surrounding relationships was unwanted pregnancies. They wanted more access to contraceptives - 76 per cent thought the morning-after pill should be easier to get hold of, and 80 per cent would ask a boy to use a condom.

webTitle: Asteroid trackers plan to avert Armageddon

fields.headline: Asteroid trackers plan to avert Armageddon
fields.standfirst: Space probe will allow detection and deflection of rocks hurtling to Earth, reports  Robin McKie
fields.trailText: One did for the dinosaurs. Another flattened a large part of Siberia 90 years ago. And one day Britain - not to mention Europe and the rest of the world - may suffer a similar fate.
fields.body:
One did for the dinosaurs. Another flattened a large part of Siberia 90 years ago. And one day Britain - not to mention Europe and the rest of the world - may suffer a similar fate.

Armageddon - triggered by an asteroid hurtling into our planet - is a genuine risk. Now some scientists are pressing the European Space Agency (Esa) to construct a satellite called Gaia which could pinpoint errant chunks of rock that threaten Earth.

The probe - the most accurate telescope ever built - would track objects a kilometre or more in diameter, allowing scientists to predict their path years before their collision with our planet. Rocket-born nuclear bombs could then be launched to nudge them from their deadly paths.

'Gaia will carry a set of giant video cameras that will take colour, stereoscopic images of more than a billion stars, galaxies and other objects,' said one of the project's leaders, Dr Jerry Gilmore, of Cambridge's Institute of Astronomy.

'Essentially we are going to take a 3-D movie of the Milky Way. We will be able to construct a map of the heavens of such unsurpassed accuracy that we will be able to solve a host of major astronomical problems: the origin of the Milky Way, the shape of the universe - and the likelihood of Earth being battered by an asteroid.'

Earth's prospects of being destroyed by a large chunk of planetary masonry are currently being investigated by a government task force set up by Lord Sainsbury. The three-man team - made up of senior science administrator Harry Atkinson, environmentalist Sir Crispin Tickell and Professor David Williams of University College, London - will report in a few weeks.

The team believes there is a real risk, albeit a small one, that Earth will suffer a major asteroid impact, and that more international co-operation is needed to track the most dangerous objects. It has been calculated - by studying the rate at which lunar craters were formed by crashing meteorites and asteroids - that Earth will be struck by an object greater than a kilometre in diameter every 500,000 years.

Nasa recently established a Near Earth Object programme which has tracked 400 of the estimated 1,000 kilometre-plus asteroids in our part of the solar system. 'None are likely to strike our planet in the foreseeable future,' said Donald Yeomans, the programme's chief. 'However, there are hundreds out there that we just don't know about.'

Scientists say asteroids greater than a kilometre in diameter will cause global devastation. 'They will throw up vast clouds of dust that will blot out the sun, pour down acid rain, freeze the planet, and destroy all civilisations,' said Yeomans.

Nasa's survey programme is restricted to ground-based telescopes and radio observatories. Gaia's telescopes would detect an object the size of a shirt button on the Moon.

To achieve such precision the probe would have to have virtually no moving parts with every component maintained at a precise temperature to ensure no thermal buckling or movement.

Due to be launched by an Ariane 5 rocket in 2009, Gaia is short-listed for £350 million of Esa funding, but is in competition with a proposed probe to Mercury. Gaia is the favourite to gain approval in September.

'Gaia will carry out all sorts of different kinds of astronomy,' said Gilmore. 'However, the real bonus is that it could save us from the same fate as that suffered by the dinosaurs.'

Pinpointing an asteroid decades before it strikes Earth is one thing. Doing something about it is quite another. Blowing it up with a nuclear bomb - as Bruce Willis did in the film Armageddon - would do more damage than good, say scientists, for the blast would probably pepper Earth with cosmic shrapnel. 'However, nudging it off its trajectory with an A-bomb explosion, so that it missed us completely, might well work,' said Yeomans.


Robin McKie

'None are likely to strike our planet in the foreseeable future,' said Donald Yeomans, the programme's chief. 'However, there are hundreds out there that we just don't know about.' Scientists say asteroids greater than a kilometre in diameter will cause global devastation. 'They will throw up vast clouds of dust that will blot out the sun, pour down acid rain, freeze the planet, and destroy all civilisations,' said Yeomans. Nasa's survey programme is restricted to ground-based telescopes and radio observatories. Gaia's telescopes would detect an object the size of a shirt button on the Moon. To achieve such precision the probe would have to have virtually no moving parts with every component maintained at a precise temperature to ensure no thermal buckling or movement. Due to be launched by an Ariane 5 rocket in 2009, Gaia is short-listed for £350 million of Esa funding, but is in competition with a proposed probe to Mercury. Gaia is the favourite to gain approval in September. 'Gaia will carry out all sorts of different kinds of astronomy,' said Gilmore. 'However, the real bonus is that it could save us from the same fate as that suffered by the dinosaurs.' Pinpointing an asteroid decades before it strikes Earth is one thing. Doing something about it is quite another. Blowing it up with a nuclear bomb - as Bruce Willis did in the film Armageddon - would do more damage than good, say scientists, for the blast would probably pepper Earth with cosmic shrapnel. 'However, nudging it off its trajectory with an A-bomb explosion, so that it missed us completely, might well work,' said Yeomans. Robin McKie

webTitle: Unsolved murder of teenage mother exposes Brighton's sleazy secrets

fields.headline: Unsolved murder of teenage mother exposes Brighton's sleazy secrets
fields.standfirst: Campaigners for justice accuse police of incompetence in a case of drugs, theft, revenge and murder in a graveyard. Tony Thompson reports
fields.trailText: With its large gay community, celebrity residents and beachfront cafés, Brighton is regarded as one of the hippest, most laid-back towns in Britain. But a glimpse of its seamy underbelly emerged last week
fields.body:
With its large gay community, celebrity residents and beachfront cafés, Brighton is regarded as one of the hippest, most laid-back towns in Britain. But a glimpse of its seamy underbelly emerged last week as campaigners offered a £50,000 reward to find the killers of a 19-year-old girl sucked into a world of drugs and depravity.

The case of Katrina Taylor has focused attention on the increasing problems of Brighton and on its crumbling estates a short distance from the homes of such famous residents as Zoë Ball, Chris Eubank and Heather Mills, Paul McCartney's new girlfriend. Against a backdrop of a dramatic increase in burglaries, muggings and shootings, private investigators trying to find Taylor's killers last week revealed that they had received death threats as fly-posters were put up around town calling for justice for a woman whose life was ruined by drugs.

Katrina Taylor was found stabbed to death in a graveyard in July 1996. Despite a big police inquiry and two Crown Court trials, no one has been found guilty of her murder. Campaigners believe this is because of the local force's failure to investigate the crime properly. They want a full investigation by the Police Complaints Authority.

Last week they began distributing a list of Sussex officers who are accused of varying degrees of incompetence, from allegedly failing to investigate the background of key witnesses to failing to respond to information about the whereabouts of the accused. The campaigners have uncovered evidence that they say links the murder to a fraud gang operating out of nearby Peacehaven and claim this has not been properly investigated.

The murder attracted great publicity when it was discovered that the victim had taken part in a police murder reconstruction in 1986, posing as nine-year-old Nicola Fellows who had been found strangled in a Brighton park along with a friend. Ten years later, Katrina was struggling to bring up her baby daughter and fund her £200-per-week heroin habit.

Late in the evening of 8 May 1996 she agreed to act as lookout while her boyfriend Mattie Laurie and friend John Cosham burgled a house belonging to Neisha Williams, the former girlfriend of a drug dealer. As well as stealing personal belongings, the thieves set fire to furniture and flooded two rooms. After using her contacts to find out who had been responsible, Williams formed a posse which rampaged through Brighton hellbent on revenge.

Among the members of the gang were her ex-boyfriend Trevor Smith, a white Londoner obsessed with black culture who had a string of previous convictions. He called his flatmate, Fergal Scollan, who had previous convictions for assault and actual bodily harm. With Smith he had begun a large-scale operation growing super-strong 'skunk' cannabis. Williams's brother, Simon, was also in the posse.

Laurie could not be found - he had already been arrested for the robbery - so the posse tracked down Cosham. He was beaten and stabbed in both legs with a screwdriver. A friend who was found with him was stabbed in the face, beaten with a hammer and repeatedly kicked in the head. The posse then moved on to track down Katrina Taylor. They forced their way into her family home and attacked her sister, but Katrina was nowhere to be found.

The following day Katrina was arrested for her part in the burglary. Detectives asked magistrates to remand her in custody, but she was granted bail to look after her eight-month-old daughter. Nearly two months later Simon Williams spotted her outside a hotel. He persuaded her to go with him to 77 Centurion Road, the council house to which Neisha Williams had moved. Williams called Smith and Scollan who rushed back to Brighton from London. The evening began with a shouting match; at one point a knife was held to Katrina's throat and she agreed to pay for the damage caused by the burglary at the rate of £10 per week from her unemployment benefits. At 11.15pm screaming was heard in a graveyard a short walk from Centurion Road. Katrina's body was found the next morning by a man walking his dog. According to the pathologist's report, she had been held from behind and stabbed from the front by either one or two people.

Within weeks, a team of 50 detectives and 15 forensic experts had gathered 400 exhibits - including the murder weapon, which Simon Williams had disposed of down a drain in Peacehaven - and 150 statements. Neisha and Simon Williams, along with Smith and Scollan, were arrested and charged with murder.

At the trial at Lewes Crown Court in June 1997 Neisha and Simon Williams claimed Katrina had left the flat that evening with Scollan and Smith, who later returned saying she was dead. Scollan and Smith claimed she had left with the Williamses and that the exact opposite was true. Both men said they believed Simon Williams had killed Katrina and they had gone into hiding. Simon Williams admitted trying to dispose of the murder weapon.

Neisha was found guilty of false imprisonment but she and her brother were cleared of murder. Smith and Scollan were found guilty. Smith and Scollan launched an immediate appeal claiming the judge had misdirected the jury over aspects of the evidence. The Court of Appeal ordered a retrial which began at the Old Bailey in October 1999.

For legal reasons, Neisha and Simon Williams did not give evidence. Lawyers for Smith and Scollan successfully argued that there was no case to answer, and the judge directed that both men be acquitted of murder because of insufficient evidence. Scollan had a charge of false imprisonment dropped. Smith admitted the same charge and was sentenced to 30 months but walked free because of time served.

Katrina's mother, Kathy, told The Observer : 'I am disgusted how this has turned out. It has destroyed my faith in the justice system and the police. My daughter was stabbed to death and no one has been made to pay. I won't rest until they are.'

Kathy will meet campaigners this week to discuss options for moving forward. A spokesperson for Sussex Police said: 'The police thoroughly investigated this murder. The file remains open, and if anyone has information we would urge them to come forward.'

webTitle: Freedom Ship 'will be target for terrorists'

fields.headline: Freedom Ship 'will be target for terrorists'
fields.standfirst: Experts warn of crime wave, security crackdown and danger of hostage-taking on mile-long vessel
fields.trailText: It has been billed as a maritime Utopia sailing the seven seas. But security experts are warning that the 40,000 people who are expected to buy homes on the mile-long, 300-yard wide Freedom Ship may find life closer to  Blade Runner than The Good Ship Lollipop .
fields.body:
It has been billed as a maritime Utopia sailing the seven seas. But security experts are warning that the 40,000 people who are expected to buy homes on the mile-long, 300-yard wide Freedom Ship may find life closer to Blade Runner than The Good Ship Lollipop .

The vessel's very name may prove deeply ironic, for there will be one security man to every 15 residents, homes will be ringed with electronic surveillance equipment, the ship's police will have access to firearms, the captain will have absolute power, and there will be a jail in which to dump miscreants.

A squad of intelligence officers will monitor threats to security, both from inside the ship and externally from pirates and terrorists. The ship will be equipped with 'state-of-the art defensive weapons' to repel attacks and the system of government sounds remarkably similar to that of some of the world's least savoury regimes.

Construction is to start later this summer in Honduras. More than 15,000 labourers will work for 24 hours a day to get the ship built by 2003. Already more than a fifth of the 20,000 residential units, which cost from £80,000 to £5 million, have been sold, with sales averaging £4.7m a week. Many have been sold to clients in Britain and Europe. The US businessmen and engineers behind the project are so confident they are already planning three more Freedom Ships.

'It is a new lifestyle for this new millennium,' said Roger Gooch, marketing director of the Freedom Ship.

The promotional literature for the project paints a magnificent picture of a luxurious tax haven that progresses steadily across the world's oceans, served by a fleet of light aircraft and speed boats. There will be shops, parks, concert halls, schools, homes and even a university on board. A huge duty-free shopping mall will generate significant revenue, it is claimed. The ship is so big - six times larger than any other vessel ever built - that a 100ft wave will hardly affect it, the builders say.

The captain will be in a position to enforce the laws of whichever country's flag under which Gooch and his colleagues decide to sail her. Traditionally, states such as Panama have provided so-called flags of convenience, though Gooch said the ship's management were considering two European Union nations as possibilities.

The ship's private security force of 2,000, led by a former FBI agent, will have access to weapons, both to maintain order within the vessel and to resist external threats. They can expect to be kept busy, according to sociologists, maritime security experts, criminologists and intelligence experts consulted by The Observer last week. 'The ship will have all the problems of any small city, including crime, outbreaks of disorder, juvenile delinquency, neighbourhood disputes, everything,' said Mike Bluestone, a London-based security consultant. 'And the ship will be a prime target for terrorists. It would be perfectly possible to hold the entire vessel to ransom by seizing a few well-chosen hostages.'

Residents will be cosmopolitan, and that may not help social cohesion, says Ivan Horrocks, a security specialist at the Scarman Centre at the University of Leicester. 'When you create an artificial environment involving people with very different ethical, cultural, political and legal customs and values, the potential for tension is very great. It could well be more of a dystopia than a Utopia,' he said.

But others are more sanguine about the Freedom Ship's prospects. One of the major attractions of the vessel, according to Gooch, is its freedom from taxes. Professor Ken Roberts, a sociologist at Liverpool University, believes that if people merely use the ship as a mobile tax haven, then it could function socially. 'People who have an international occupational life might find it attractive, though I do not see people with that kind of money spending all their lives on a ship,' he said.

Others note that residents may be preoccupied with less drastic problems than the threat of piracy. Many of the first units to be sold have gone to Germans, raising the spectre of towels already on deckchairs by the time the rest of Europe's aspirant global voyagers make it to the pool.


Jason Burke

webTitle: Blow here and we'll see what's wrong with you

fields.headline: Blow here and we'll see what's wrong with you
fields.trailText: Picture the scene: a doctor examines a patient suspected of having stomach ulcers and asks him to blow on a specially impregnated card. Chemicals in his breath, released by his ulcers, cause blue spots to appear in a matter of seconds, confirming the diagnosis.
fields.body:
Picture the scene: a doctor examines a patient suspected of having stomach ulcers and asks him to blow on a specially impregnated card. Chemicals in his breath, released by his ulcers, cause blue spots to appear in a matter of seconds, confirming the diagnosis.

Or consider the example of a factory believed to be spewing cancer-causing pollutants into the air. Environmental health officials leave a similarly coated card in the neighbourhood, and once again blotches quickly betray the presence of a harmful chemical, in this case a dioxin.

Finally, there is the case of an athlete thought to have consumed a banned drug. No need to wait for complex blood or urine analysis to be completed. The same simple card trick will instantly reveal their guilt or innocence.

These remarkable diagnoses may be commonplace in the near future, thanks to a remarkable universal sensor based on the sex life of yeast. The procreative urges of the biological agent that makes our bread rise, and turns barley to beer, may soon help pinpoint deadly chemicals in our bodies, homes and factories.

'Essentially we have created a library of millions of different, genetically engineered yeast cells capable of responding to virtually any chemical you can think of,' said molecular biologist Professor John Findlay, leader of the biosensor team.

'We have developed the potential for screening our environments - both internal and external - for traces of chemicals, right down to the level of a couple of parts per million.'

Findlay's research at Leeds University has focused on membranes, the gossamer-thin skins that cover all living cells, and protect them against chemical and biological invasions.

Membranes form an entire coat around a cell, except at key points where long protein receptors form pathways from the surface down into the cell's interior. These control the exchange of chemicals, nutrients and waste products.

First, a chemical latches on to the external end of the receptor, triggering a signal that passes along the receptor, eventually activating the internal end that is sticking into the cell's interior.

'Yeast uses receptors to detect chemicals - called pheromones - which are given off by other yeast cells,' said Leeds researcher Mark Wigglesworth. 'The cell then knows it is near another yeast cell - and can mate with it.'

In exploiting this yeasty sexual urge, Findlay took the receptor protein gene and mutated it, creating thousands of versions, each one changed in a unique way. These receptors no longer reacted to the yeast pheromone, but to a vast range of different chemical substances ranging from relatively simply chemicals such as carbon monoxide to highly complicated organic molecules, including those given off by living organisms.

Then the Leeds team used a genetically engineered yeast strain whose receptor protein - when stimulated by a chemical visitor - released a special molecule that in turn triggered a biological cascade to spread through its interior, causing the cell to turn blue.

'Essentially, we have a line of yeast cells so they no longer react to a single pheromone, but to a vast range of other chemicals,' said Findlay.

'In fact, we still do not know exactly what chemicals the yeast will react to, for we created our library only a few months ago. However, we do know we now have millions of different mutant yeast sensors. All we have to do is put a chemical near a sample, and, if it turns blue, we shall have found a yeast sensor for that chemical.'

Only a few molecules of chemical are sufficient to trigger a visible reaction from a yeast cell, say the Leeds researchers, which should allow their biosensors to detect substances at levels of one part per million.

Their ideas have now been patented and the team, and their industrial collaborators, Lanehawk, are seeking partners with whom they will exploit their yeast detectors.

'We want to develop a simple way of embedding our cells in a matrix,' added Findlay. 'Then we can take a slice of it, thus creating detectors cards that should be able to pinpoint virtually any chemical in the body or in the environment. This has enormous potential.'
