webTitle: Real men don't eat quiche. They bake it

fields.headline: Real men don't eat quiche. They bake it
fields.trailText: Will you pamper yourself with L'Oréal this weekend 'because you're worth it'? Will the kitchen floor sparkle after you give it the once-over with the Dyson and a dab of Flash?
fields.body:
Will you pamper yourself with L'Oréal this weekend 'because you're worth it'? Will the kitchen floor sparkle after you give it the once-over with the Dyson and a dab of Flash?

Will your whites be the envy of your street now you have switched to Persil tablets? And what will you cook to treat your partner when they come home? Chicken Tonight?

You will? Congratulations: you are a typical British man.

As evidence grows that caveman is giving way to man about the house, leading firms are for the first time targeting traditional women's products at the male market. Oxo, chicken, pet food, washing-up liquid, children's products, hair conditioner, bathroom cleaner, fragrances and slimming foods are being sold to what admen have nicknamed the homme sensuel .

Stars such as Ian Wright (Chicken Tonight), Robbie Coltrane (Persil tablets), Michael Schumacher (L'Or-éal) and Jason McAteer (Wash and Go) are forcing off screen the Oxo mum, Nanette Newman with the soft Fairy Liquid hands, and Birds of a Feather Pauline Quirke and Linda Robson with their Surf suds.

Forget the 'sex, booze and more sex' sales pitch which has been used to sell men anything and everything. Advertisers are adopting the soft sell for the stay-at-home generation who get their thrills from doing the dusting and cooking.

New research shows more than one third of men are donning their aprons and elbowing women out of the kitchen. More than half are regular supermarket shoppers. From almost nothing 10 years ago, the average man now spends around £3,000 a year on grooming, cooking and cleaning.

Helen Park, brands PR manager at Unilever, which has dumped the traditional Oxo family in favour of single men and friends, says husbands are becoming wives and single men are behaving more and more like women.

'Married men are getting much more involved in the family. The sight of the slovenly husband loafing around while his long-suffering wife does all the work is, thankfully, becoming more and more rare.

'Single men are also getting more involved in what they once thought of as so-called "women's work". The bachelor pad full of mouldy old take-away trays, over-flowing ashtrays and giant pyramids of beer cans is becoming out of date.'

And it is not just household chores. The new man about the house is now the one rushing off to Ikea to salivate over sandblasted glass and brushed steel kitchens. Moss Bros, which owns Cecil Gee, Blazer and Savoy Taylors Guild, announced a sharp slump in sales on Friday and warned of job cuts and shop closures.

Rowland Gee, the company's managing director, put the drop in business down to men switching their spending from clothes to their homes and electrical goods. A flick through the latest men's magazines shows the 'gentleman's outfitter' is right to be worried. New homeboy is spoilt for choice in the advertisments in GQ, Arena and Stuff magazines.

Melanie Howard, co-founder and director of the Future Foundation, says firms are responding to men's complaints that they are being 'pigeon-holed' as lads. 'All our research shows that men don't like commercials where they bring home the bacon and the stay-at-home woman cooks the tea.

'Men want something that reflects their changing lives - something more subtle. New forms of male reality are emerging.'

Andy Milligan at Interbrand Newell and Sorrell, who has charted the rise of the new man, says advertisers are 'ahead of the curve'.

'More and more women are abdicating the traditional stay-at-home role, while men think it is cool to be caring and nurturing.

'Look at Dennis Wise taking his son to lift up the FA Cup last weekend, or David Beckham rowing with Alex Ferguson when he takes time off to look after his ill son while Posh is on the catwalk.

Congratulations: you are a typical British man. As evidence grows that caveman is giving way to man about the house, leading firms are for the first time targeting traditional women's products at the male market. Oxo, chicken, pet food, washing-up liquid, children's products, hair conditioner, bathroom cleaner, fragrances and slimming foods are being sold to what admen have nicknamed the homme sensuel . Stars such as Ian Wright (Chicken Tonight), Robbie Coltrane (Persil tablets), Michael Schumacher (L'Or-éal) and Jason McAteer (Wash and Go) are forcing off screen the Oxo mum, Nanette Newman with the soft Fairy Liquid hands, and Birds of a Feather Pauline Quirke and Linda Robson with their Surf suds. Forget the 'sex, booze and more sex' sales pitch which has been used to sell men anything and everything. Advertisers are adopting the soft sell for the stay-at-home generation who get their thrills from doing the dusting and cooking. New research shows more than one third of men are donning their aprons and elbowing women out of the kitchen. More than half are regular supermarket shoppers. From almost nothing 10 years ago, the average man now spends around £3,000 a year on grooming, cooking and cleaning. Helen Park, brands PR manager at Unilever, which has dumped the traditional Oxo family in favour of single men and friends, says husbands are becoming wives and single men are behaving more and more like women. 'Married men are getting much more involved in the family. 'Single men are also getting more involved in what they once thought of as so-called "women's work". The bachelor pad full of mouldy old take-away trays, over-flowing ashtrays and giant pyramids of beer cans is becoming out of date.' And it is not just household chores. webTitle: Electric village refuses to die as plant closes

fields.headline: Electric village refuses to die as plant closes
fields.standfirst: Kinlochleven was built to make aluminium. Now its people want Holyrood to help bring in the tourists
fields.trailText: It's called the electric village. There isn't much to see: a Co-op, hardware store and a couple of bars. A thousand people live there and next month their reason for staying will close.
fields.body:
It's called the electric village. There isn't much to see: a Co-op, hardware store and a couple of bars. A thousand people live there and next month their reason for staying will close.

Kinlochleven was born a century ago as a company town. The North British Aluminium Company built a hydroelectric scheme in the hills high above the village to power an aluminium smelter. It was the first large-scale industrial project in the Highlands. In three weeks the smelter will stop for good.

Scottish industrial history suggests this will be a disaster. Like shipyards and coal mines, Kinlochleven's closure will leave a legacy of misery for generations to come. But the community in the electric village is refusing to lie down and die.

Its leaders lobbied Holy rood last week and expect a visit from the Holyrood Finance Minister, Jack McConnell, in a fortnight. They tell a tale of optimism. Kinlochleven is to become a model for regeneration, say campaigners.

Making aluminium is 'like alchemy', according to local councillor Drew McFarlane-Slack. First you convert bauxite from West Africa or Australia into alumina. Then you place it in a bath of cryolite and run 40,000 amps through the mixture until aluminium falls to the bottom.

The process requires vast amounts of energy, hence the need for a hydroelectric scheme to power the smelter. It was built by Scots and Irish navvies alongside workers from Eastern Europe at the turn of the century.

The alchemy now being attempted is to make Kinlochleven a tourist attraction and vibrant economy. The community has corporate guilt on its side. When Alcan closed a plant at Invergordon there was a public outcry. The firm learnt its lesson and gave six years warning of the closure at Kinlochleven. It also decided to invest money in cleaning up the site.

Most significantly though, Alcan, one of the largest landowners in Scotland, decided to give the community the surrounding land. The village has been transferred to community ownership, and the company plans to hand over a further 10 square miles of the glen. 'We have a special responsibility,' says Craig Reilly of Alcan. 'If it wasn't for us there wouldn't be a Kinlochleven.'

Lochaber Ltd, the local enterprise company, set up Kinlochleven Land Development Trust to develop the community. KLDT plans to use the market value of the land to leverage money from European funds to pay for further developments.

KLDT has already invested in a business park and improvements to tourist facilities. Its next plans include an outdoor activity centre, a micro-brewery and an industrial heritage museum. The smelter employed 300 people six years ago. Only 50 remain to be offered retraining.

Jackie Wright of Lochaber Ltd says the aim is to use public money until private enterprise takes over. 'For the past 100 years Alcan has offered a cradle-to-grave support for this community. That will never happen again. We just hope to start the ball rolling on Kinlochleven's future.'

It is a ball that costs £4.5 million. That's what KLDT hopes to persuade Jack McConnell to give them so that they can win matching funding from the EU and pay for their various plans.

In the village café Ruby Brown sips coffee and looks out on the rain-soaked industrial plant. She worked in the canteen and is unsure of the future. 'You don't know, do you?' she says. 'We have heard all the plans but will they ever happen?' The answer lies with McConnell.

The electric village is a model for how a community can re-invent itself. The people of Govan, constantly threatened with losing their shipyard, may look enviously at Kinlochleven. So may countless other communities trying to cope with the closure of large employers and the end of the industrial era.

The Scottish Executive could find it pays to invest in the electric village to learn lessons for the whole nation.

webTitle: British trucker 'left to rot' in Balkan prison

fields.headline: British trucker 'left to rot' in Balkan prison
fields.standfirst: Dying father pleads for son who risked his life to supply Nato troops and was jailed after 'farcical' trial
fields.trailText: He shares a cramped, squalid cell with 10 other inmates. The toilet is blocked. There is no running water. He does not speak the language and is painfully thin. His family fear for his sanity.
fields.body:
He shares a cramped, squalid cell with 10 other inmates. The toilet is blocked. There is no running water. He does not speak the language and is painfully thin. His family fear for his sanity.

Richard Hudson, a lorry driver from Derbyshire, is the forgotten man of the Balkans conflict. He was jailed for a crime his supporters and leading justice campaigners insist he did not commit, and his family fear that they will never see him again.

His father Gordon, 73, who has cancer, launched a last-ditch appeal this weekend to the supreme court in Macedonia to have his son freed from his sentence for allegedly causing the deaths of two men in road accidents.

Having spent nearly £4,000 of his life savings battling for his son, Gordon Hudson also angrily denounced Nato for 'abandoning' him to rot in jail for political reasons. But his hopes of seeing his son again are fading and now depend on the Macedonian and British governments allowing the two-year sentence to be completed in a British prison.

Government sources last night told The Observer that British Ministerial and diplomatic approaches had been made behind the scenes to the Macedonian authorities.

'In the circumstances of Mr Hudson's father's poor health, we are trying to speed things up,' said a Foreign Office spokesman. 'We know the family has grave concerns for Mr Hudson's safety...and we have asked the Macedonian Ministry of Justice for assurances that he is safe.'

Richard Hudson, 45, was on his twelfth trip driving vital supplies to British troops serving with Nato's K-For forces when his nightmare began.

He stopped to help after witnessing a road crash in which two young local men died. Their car was travelling at around 125mph in a 75mph zone when it skidded off the road and repeatedly rolled over.

Hudson was arrested by Macedonian police seeking a scapegoat in a country where sympathies had lain with the Serbs in the Kosovo conflict and hostility towards Nato drivers had reached boiling point.

Despite denials from witnesses, police claimed Hudson's lorry was on the wrong side of the road travelling at 75mph, forcing the oncoming car to swerve. Attempts by Hudson's lawyers to test the car driver's body for alcohol or drugs were rebuffed.

A few months before the accident, a Nato soldier driving on the wrong side of the road had crashed into an oncoming car, killing a Macedonian Minister and his family. Nato immediately stepped in, blocked police access to the scene and whisked the soldier home to Norway.

Other Nato drivers have been similarly spirited away from high-speed crashes to avoid notoriously rough local justice. In one case a military helicopter lifted an American driver out.

Hudson was not so lucky. He was on his way to pick up his Nato driver's pass when he stopped at the accident. Because he never collected the pass, Nato, reluctant to become involved, denied he worked for them and insisted Hudson was employed by the UK firm it contracted, hauliers Eddie Stobart, who in turn sub-contracted the work to his employer, a firm called Andrew Vest in Derby.

Stobart, a successful British haulage firm, has also come under fire from Hudson's family, who are still awaiting a promised donation from the company to their fighting fund.

Stephen Jakobi, director of the charity Fair Trials Abroad, told The Observer the case was 'one of the worst injustices I have seen. The police deliberately did not use relevant evidence.

'Tachograph readings presented to the court to show that Mr Hudson was travelling at 75mph were actually registering speeds he had done in Greece, some three hours before the accident happened. Police deliberately withheld the relevant tacho. Diagrams produced to show that the lorry was diagonally across the road were total conjecture - the lorry would have jack-knifed.

'What's so dreadful is the way this guy has been abandoned by Nato. He is in some danger in that prison. Local media, which reported him as guilty even before the trial, have been calling him a soldier in a place where anti-K-For feeling is very high.'

Other truckers heading for the region have taken Hudson food parcels and his sister Frances has visited him in Skopje jail several times.

'It is very distressing to see him in such terrible conditions,' she said. 'The prison is filthy. He is in a cell with 10 men, no running water and a blocked toilet. It's foul. The place is overrun by cats and the kitchens and everywhere stink of their urine.' She added: 'No one speaks English and he feels very isolated. Other prisoners have been beaten and he has had verbal abuse and threats.

'We were hoping K-For would send a legal adviser, but nothing. The whole thing is such a farce. During the court case one expert witness actually said the accident would not have happened if the car hadn't been speeding, but nobody listened, nobody listened to anything.

'All we can do now is wait for the supreme court, but they need him too much as a scapegoat.'

It is a waiting game too for Gordon Hudson and his wife, Margaret, at home in Findern, Derbyshire,

Gordon said: 'As far as I'm concerned, Nato have simply ignored their responsibility to a driver whose safety they were happy to put at risk. They went to the Balkans to save foreign civilians but they can't save a British one.'

fields.headline: Are you a BOurgeois BOhemian?
fields.standfirst: We've had Hippies, Yuppies, Buppies and Dinkies. Now it's time for the Bobos.  Melinda Wittstock in New York reports on the rise of the new urban upper class
fields.trailText: It's hard to miss them: The epitome of casual 'geek chic' and organised within the warranty of their Palm Pilots, they sip labour-intensive café lattes, chat on sleek cellphones and ponder the road to enlightenment. In the US they worry about the environment as they drive their gas-guzzling sports utility vehicles to emporiums of haute design to buy a $50 titanium spatula; they think about their tech stocks as they explore speciality shops for Tibetan artefacts in Everest-worthy hiking boots. They think nothing of laying out $5 for a wheatgrass muff, much less $500 for some alternative rejuvenation at the day-spa - but don't talk about raising their taxes.
fields.body:
It's hard to miss them: The epitome of casual 'geek chic' and organised within the warranty of their Palm Pilots, they sip labour-intensive café lattes, chat on sleek cellphones and ponder the road to enlightenment. In the US they worry about the environment as they drive their gas-guzzling sports utility vehicles to emporiums of haute design to buy a $50 titanium spatula; they think about their tech stocks as they explore speciality shops for Tibetan artefacts in Everest-worthy hiking boots. They think nothing of laying out $5 for a wheatgrass muff, much less $500 for some alternative rejuvenation at the day-spa - but don't talk about raising their taxes.

They are 'bourgeois bohemians' - or 'Bobos' - and they're the new 'enlightened élite' of the information age, their lucratively busy lives a seeming synthesis of comfort and conscience, corporate success and creative rebellion. Well-educated thirty-to-fortysomethings, they have forged a new social ethos from a logic-defying fusion of 1960s counter-culture and 1980s entrepreneurial materialism.

So proclaims David Brooks, the American journalist and self-avowed 'Bobo', who coined the phrase to describe the new cultural and corporate hegemony of his cosmopolitan, computer-savvy contemporaries, many of whom will no doubt recognise themselves in Bobos In Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There .

'These Bobos define our age. They are the new establishment. Their hybrid culture is the atmosphere we all breathe,' Brooks declares in his 'comic sociology' of Bobo manners and mores. 'Their status codes now govern social life.' A phenomenon in step with the hard-driving digital utopianism promised by the internet and its money-spinning 'new economy', not to mention the 'Third Way' politics of President Clinton and Tony Blair, the Bobos have seized upon an ingenious way to sell without selling out - or so they tell themselves.

Combining the free-spirited, artistic rebelliousness of the bohemian beatnik or hippie with the worldly ambitions of their bourgeois corporate forefathers, the Bobo is a comfortable contortion of caring capitalism. 'It's not about making money,' writes Brooks, 'it's about doing something you love. Life should be an extended hobby. It's all about working for a company as cool as you are.'

It is a world inhabited by dotcom millionaires, management consultants, 'culture industry' entrepreneurs and all manner of media folk, most earning upwards of $100,000 a year - their money, claims Brooks, an incidental byproduct of their maverick mores, 'the kind of money you happen to earn while you are pursuing your creative vision'. Often sporting such unconventional job titles as 'creative paradox', 'corporate jester' or 'learning person', Bobos work with a monk-like self-discipline because they view their jobs as intellectual, even spiritual. 'It is a reverse Midas touch: everything a Bobo touches turns to spirituality, everything has to be about enlightenment. Even their jobs are a mission to improve the world,' says Brooks, himself a political columnist for the conservative Weekly Standard.

Clearly the Bobo is not entirely new - think Virgin's Richard Branson, the Body Shop's Anita Roddick and Apple Computer's Steve Jobs. But suddenly Bobos are everywhere, or so it struck Brooks after four years abroad in the 1990s. His wealthy white-bread Pennsylvania hometown was now firmly focaccia, with half a dozen new gourmet coffee shops, independent booksellers and countless purveyors of 'fat smelly candles' and 'hand-painted TV armoires'.

'It was now impossible to tell an espresso-sipping artist from a cappuccino-gulping banker,' observed Brooks - but it wasn't just a matter of style. 'I found that if you investigated people's attitudes towards sex, morality, leisure time and work, it was getting harder and harder to separate the anti-establishment renegade from the pro-establishment company man. Most people seemed to have rebel attitudes and social-climbing attitudes all scrambled together.'

Sounds familiar, says British trend-spotter Peter York. 'I am a good example of a bourgeois bohemian, well a little more bourgeois than bohemian, but I'm it. I've been thinking about Bobos for months; they are all around me, and they've been a long time coming, in a sense, a no-brainer, an inevitable "end of history" phenomenon, with all ideological wars ended, religious schisms over.'

York says there are more than a million British Bobos, sharing with their US counterparts the same proclivities for spiritual growth, creative fulfilment, Tuscan-tiled stainless steel kitchens, distressed Third World antiques and hi-tech titanium sporting gear. 'Most likely they live in Notting Hill or some other urban confluence of dressed-down bohemian wealth, and their home decor says, "I've been there, I smoke a bit of dope".'

Names, I want names, I tell Brooks. 'Well, writing for The Observer counts,' he tells me, 'and the BBC, the BBC is a red-hot centre of Boboism, though [Jeremy] Paxman is too angry to qualify.

'As for me, I'm a confirmed Bobo. Now half-author, half-salesman, I've been stunned by how much I've taken up the selling fervour.' But not everyone is buying it.

'It's a misnomer, a simple- minded idea and a convenient cover for baby-boomers to feel proud of themselves,' says Debbie Geller, an American who produces BBC arts and culture documentaries. 'These Bobos are just normal middle-class people who can't accept that status because they've always hated it. They are living out a protracted adolescence.'

Toby Miller, a professor of popular culture at New York University, suspects Boboism has more to do with style than substance. 'But Brooks is on to something significant: the Bobo is at once a social liberal and an economic conservative; freedom and justice for all, they say, but don't worry about systematic economic inequality.'

Their political interests, Miller says, are either 'intensely close and personal' (abortion or gun control), or very remote (the rainforests, Tibet or Third World poverty.) But they will most likely express their conscience in their consumerism, relieved to be helping someone somewhere by collecting the hand-carved artefacts of distant cultures.

While bemoaning the Bobo's 'boring politics', Brooks believes the Bobos to be an élite superior to their intolerant and warring predecessors - 'they've certainly made shopping more fun, and they have a good morality for building a decent society,' he says.

'This is an élite that has been raised to oppose élites. They are by instinct anti-establishmentarian, yet somehow sense they have become a new establishment. They are prosperous without seeming greedy; they have pleased their elders, without seeming conformist; they have risen toward the top without too obviously looking down on those below,' he says.

Motivated by 'spiritual participation, but cautious of moral crusades and religious enthusiasms, they tolerate a little lifestyle experimentation, so long as it is done safely and moderately. They are offended by concrete wrongs, such as cruelty and racial injustice, but are relatively unmoved by lies or transgressions that don't seem to do anyone any obvious harm.'

For now, the old fiery antipathy between bourgeois and bohemian is a distant memory, tensions reconciled, and corporate advertising is finding inspiration in Jack Kerouac, Gandhi and 'Born to be Wild'.

We have reached the point, says Brooks, where 'the hedonism of Woodstock mythology has been domesticated and now serves as a management tool for the Fortune 500.

'The intangible world of information merges with the material world of money, and new phrases that combine the two, such as "intellectual capital" and "the culture industry", come into vogue. So the people who thrive in this period are the ones who can turn ideas and emotions into products.'

Indeed, the one realm of American life where the language of 1960s radicalism remains strong is the business world, says Brooks. 'We're by now all familiar with modern-day executives who have moved from SDS to CEO, from LSD to IPO. Indeed, sometimes you get the impression the Free Speech Movement produced more corporate executives than Harvard Business School.'

'Where do you want to go today?' asks the Microsoft commercial. Somewhere ex-otic. Somewhere lucrative. Somewhere 'fashionably en-lightened', maybe Brooks's new local supermarket. 'It's taken the ethos of California in the 1960s and selectively updated it. Gone are the Sixties-era things that were fun for teenagers, like free love, and retained are all the things that might be of interest to middle-aged hypochondriacs, like whole grains.'

Ten ways to tell you're a Bobo

Do you:

 Believe that shelling out £10,050 on a home media centre is vulgar, but that spending it on a slate shower stall is a sign you are at one with the Zen-like rhythms of nature?

 Work for a company as cool, hip and enterprising as you?

 GO ON adventure seeking vacations to the remotest parts of the world to X-treme ski, mountain climb or whitewater raft, or do you simply settle for a ride in the sport utility vehicle to the nearest haute-design shops and local purveyors of Third World treasures?

 Dress 'geek chic' or hippy chick - and don't forget the titanium Omnitech athletic gear?

 Have a newly renovated kitchen which looks like an aircraft hangar with plumbing - even after the feng shui?

 Give to Tibet, but not always to the local homeless?

 Feel cheated and betrayed if a big supermarket sign that normally says 'Organic Items Today: 130' today counts only 60?

 Earn upwards of £67,000 but were never in it for the money?

 Buy Third World to save the Third World?
fields.bodyText: It's hard to miss them: The epitome of casual 'geek chic' and organised within the warranty of their Palm Pilots, they sip labour-intensive café lattes, chat on sleek cellphones and ponder the road to enlightenment. In the US they worry about the environment as they drive their gas-guzzling sports utility vehicles to emporiums of haute design to buy a $50 titanium spatula; they think about their tech stocks as they explore speciality shops for Tibetan artefacts in Everest-worthy hiking boots. They think nothing of laying out $5 for a wheatgrass muff, much less $500 for some alternative rejuvenation at the day-spa - but don't talk about raising their taxes. They are 'bourgeois bohemians' - or 'Bobos' - and they're the new 'enlightened élite' of the information age, their lucratively busy lives a seeming synthesis of comfort and conscience, corporate success and creative rebellion. Well-educated thirty-to-fortysomethings, they have forged a new social ethos from a logic-defying fusion of 1960s counter-culture and 1980s entrepreneurial materialism. So proclaims David Brooks, the American journalist and self-avowed 'Bobo', who coined the phrase to describe the new cultural and corporate hegemony of his cosmopolitan, computer-savvy contemporaries, many of whom will no doubt recognise themselves in Bobos In Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There . 'These Bobos define our age. They are the new establishment. Their hybrid culture is the atmosphere we all breathe,' Brooks declares in his 'comic sociology' of Bobo manners and mores. 'Their status codes now govern social life.' A phenomenon in step with the hard-driving digital utopianism promised by the internet and its money-spinning 'new economy', not to mention the 'Third Way' politics of President Clinton and Tony Blair, the Bobos have seized upon an ingenious way to sell without selling out - or so they tell themselves. Combining the free-spirited, artistic rebelliousness of the bohemian beatnik or hippie with the worldly ambitions of their bourgeois corporate forefathers, the Bobo is a comfortable contortion of caring capitalism. 'It's not about making money,' writes Brooks, 'it's about doing something you love. Life should be an extended hobby. It's all about working for a company as cool as you are.' It is a world inhabited by dotcom millionaires, management consultants, 'culture industry' entrepreneurs and all manner of media folk, most earning upwards of $100,000 a year - their money, claims Brooks, an incidental byproduct of their maverick mores, 'the kind of money you happen to earn while you are pursuing your creative vision'. Often sporting such unconventional job titles as 'creative paradox', 'corporate jester' or 'learning person', Bobos work with a monk-like self-discipline because they view their jobs as intellectual, even spiritual. 'It is a reverse Midas touch: everything a Bobo touches turns to spirituality, everything has to be about enlightenment. Even their jobs are a mission to improve the world,' says Brooks, himself a political columnist for the conservative Weekly Standard. Clearly the Bobo is not entirely new - think Virgin's Richard Branson, the Body Shop's Anita Roddick and Apple Computer's Steve Jobs. But suddenly Bobos are everywhere, or so it struck Brooks after four years abroad in the 1990s. His wealthy white-bread Pennsylvania hometown was now firmly focaccia, with half a dozen new gourmet coffee shops, independent booksellers and countless purveyors of 'fat smelly candles' and 'hand-painted TV armoires'. 'It was now impossible to tell an espresso-sipping artist from a cappuccino-gulping banker,' observed Brooks - but it wasn't just a matter of style. 'I found that if you investigated people's attitudes towards sex, morality, leisure time and work, it was getting harder and harder to separate the anti-establishment renegade from the pro-establishment company man. Most people seemed to have rebel attitudes and social-climbing attitudes all scrambled together.' Sounds familiar, says British trend-spotter Peter York. 'I am a good example of a bourgeois bohemian, well a little more bourgeois than bohemian, but I'm it. I've been thinking about Bobos for months; they are all around me, and they've been a long time coming, in a sense, a no-brainer, an inevitable "end of history" phenomenon, with all ideological wars ended, religious schisms over.' York says there are more than a million British Bobos, sharing with their US counterparts the same proclivities for spiritual growth, creative fulfilment, Tuscan-tiled stainless steel kitchens, distressed Third World antiques and hi-tech titanium sporting gear. 'Most likely they live in Notting Hill or some other urban confluence of dressed-down bohemian wealth, and their home decor says, "I've been there, I smoke a bit of dope".' Names, I want names, I tell Brooks. 'Well, writing for The Observer counts,' he tells me, 'and the BBC, the BBC is a red-hot centre of Boboism, though [Jeremy] Paxman is too angry to qualify. 'As for me, I'm a confirmed Bobo. Now half-author, half-salesman, I've been stunned by how much I've taken up the selling fervour.' But not everyone is buying it. 'It's a misnomer, a simple- minded idea and a convenient cover for baby-boomers to feel proud of themselves,' says Debbie Geller, an American who produces BBC arts and culture documentaries. 'These Bobos are just normal middle-class people who can't accept that status because they've always hated it. They are living out a protracted adolescence.' Toby Miller, a professor of popular culture at New York University, suspects Boboism has more to do with style than substance. 'But Brooks is on to something significant: the Bobo is at once a social liberal and an economic conservative; freedom and justice for all, they say, but don't worry about systematic economic inequality.' Their political interests, Miller says, are either 'intensely close and personal' (abortion or gun control), or very remote (the rainforests, Tibet or Third World poverty.) But they will most likely express their conscience in their consumerism, relieved to be helping someone somewhere by collecting the hand-carved artefacts of distant cultures. While bemoaning the Bobo's 'boring politics', Brooks believes the Bobos to be an élite superior to their intolerant and warring predecessors - 'they've certainly made shopping more fun, and they have a good morality for building a decent society,' he says. 'This is an élite that has been raised to oppose élites. They are by instinct anti-establishmentarian, yet somehow sense they have become a new establishment. They are prosperous without seeming greedy; they have pleased their elders, without seeming conformist; they have risen toward the top without too obviously looking down on those below,' he says. Motivated by 'spiritual participation, but cautious of moral crusades and religious enthusiasms, they tolerate a little lifestyle experimentation, so long as it is done safely and moderately. They are offended by concrete wrongs, such as cruelty and racial injustice, but are relatively unmoved by lies or transgressions that don't seem to do anyone any obvious harm.' For now, the old fiery antipathy between bourgeois and bohemian is a distant memory, tensions reconciled, and corporate advertising is finding inspiration in Jack Kerouac, Gandhi and 'Born to be Wild'. We have reached the point, says Brooks, where 'the hedonism of Woodstock mythology has been domesticated and now serves as a management tool for the Fortune 500. 'The intangible world of information merges with the material world of money, and new phrases that combine the two, such as "intellectual capital" and "the culture industry", come into vogue. So the people who thrive in this period are the ones who can turn ideas and emotions into products.' Indeed, the one realm of American life where the language of 1960s radicalism remains strong is the business world, says Brooks. 'We're by now all familiar with modern-day executives who have moved from SDS to CEO, from LSD to IPO. Indeed, sometimes you get the impression the Free Speech Movement produced more corporate executives than Harvard Business School.' 'Where do you want to go today?' asks the Microsoft commercial. Somewhere ex-otic. Somewhere lucrative. Somewhere 'fashionably en-lightened', maybe Brooks's new local supermarket. 'It's taken the ethos of California in the 1960s and selectively updated it. Gone are the Sixties-era things that were fun for teenagers, like free love, and retained are all the things that might be of interest to middle-aged hypochondriacs, like whole grains.' Ten ways to tell you're a Bobo Do you:  Believe that shelling out £10,050 on a home media centre is vulgar, but that spending it on a slate shower stall is a sign you are at one with the Zen-like rhythms of nature?  Work for a company as cool, hip and enterprising as you?  GO ON adventure seeking vacations to the remotest parts of the world to X-treme ski, mountain climb or whitewater raft, or do you simply settle for a ride in the sport utility vehicle to the nearest haute-design shops and local purveyors of Third World treasures?  Dress 'geek chic' or hippy chick - and don't forget the titanium Omnitech athletic gear?  Have a newly renovated kitchen which looks like an aircraft hangar with plumbing - even after the feng shui?  Give to Tibet, but not always to the local homeless?  Feel cheated and betrayed if a big supermarket sign that normally says 'Organic Items Today: 130' today counts only 60?  Earn upwards of £67,000 but were never in it for the money?  Buy Third World to save the Third World?

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Inspectors arrive with troops to catch Pakistan's tax evaders
fields.body:
Inspectors arrive with troops to catch Pakistan's tax evaders

A campaign by Pakistan to assess unpaid tax prompted many shops to shut their doors in protest when tax officers arrived accompanied by soldiers. Tax evasion is a way of life in Pakistan.

Italian journalists on strike

Italian journalists staged the first of six days of strikes in a bid to reopen deadlocked contract talks. The action stopped publication of Sunday papers.

Spain's farmers in protest

Thousands of Spanish farmers marched through Madrid to protest against increases in fuel prices.

St Exupéry's plane found

Diver Luc Vanrell has discovered the remains of the plane that crashed into the sea off Marseilles in 1944, killing French writer and aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, author of Le Petit Prince.

Twins die

Doctors in Palermo separated Siamese twin sisters from Peru, but failed to save their lives.

Putin wins more allies in Russian Parliament

A Russian pro-government grouping voted overwhelmingly in Moscow to establish itself as the Unity Party, giving President Putin an expanded power base in the Duma, the lower house of parliament previously hostile to the Kremlin.

Ethiopia invades Eritrea

Ethiopian forces thrust deeper inside Eritrea after Eritrea announced it was pulling out its troops from all contested border areas. An Eritrean spokesman said: 'This is an invasion and an explicit violation of international law.' The two-year-old border conflict has killed more than 100,000 soldiers and spilled thousands of Eritrean refugees into Sudan.

'Collaborators' to stand trial
Lebanon's army said it was holding 1,488 members of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army (SLA) who surrendered during last week's withdrawal of Israeli forces from southern Lebanon. The army said it had referred 200 'collaborators' to military courts. The death penalty could theoretically be applied but no executions are expected.

webTitle: The laughing stock of the Millennium

fields.headline: The laughing stock of the Millennium
fields.standfirst: Britain's premier tourist attraction cost over £800m - yet young visitors say they have more fun at school on the internet. Gaby Hinsliff, Vanessa Thorpe and Burhan Wazir report
fields.trailText: The Dome is still open, the show inside still goes on. The public still file through its gates in their thousands - not enough to achieve the magic figure of 12 million needed to break even by the end of the year, but respectable by the standards of Britain's tourist traps.
fields.byline: Gaby Hinsliff, Vanessa Thorpe and Burhan Wazir
fields.body:
The Dome is still open, the show inside still goes on. The public still file through its gates in their thousands - not enough to achieve the magic figure of 12 million needed to break even by the end of the year, but respectable by the standards of Britain's tourist traps.

But the life has gone out of the project. Less than halfway through what should have been a triumphant first year of the new millennium, the monument to modernity and symbol of all that is great in the new Britain is dying on its feet, caught in a hail of ridicule as its creators and supporters duck for cover.

Last week it was left to the deputy Prime Minister to offer a semblance of a defence. For the second time John Prescott was called on to stand in for the Prime Minister at a time of crisis for the Dome, while his boss bonded at home with the tiny Leo. The detailed briefing papers prepared for Prescott's appearance at Prime Minister's Question Time last week simply were not enough to reassure him.

On Wednesday morning, an anxious Prescott sought out Lord Falconer in person and made clear to the minister in charge his desire to see the Dome spared the ignominy of early closure, despite its financial woes. One source close to Prescott sketched out the scene: 'He talked to Charlie - his view is mainly that he wants to see this thing run until the end of the year. He thinks that, despite what the media say, it has been successful - even if you only get six million people through the gates. He did not want to see it closing early.'

That such a fate could even be considered for the Dome - the symbol of Britain's confident advance into the next century - signals how badly things are still going behind the scenes.

Although Downing Street insists the plan remains for the Dome to stay open until the end of the year, the gloomy talk at Westminster is of whether one of the two firms bidding to run the site after 2001 could be persuaded to take it off the Government's hands any earlier.

Up to 80 MPs have signed a motion protesting against the latest decision to bail it out; the wildly optimistic forecast of 12 million visitors in a year has been almost halved; and the bitter game of shifting the blame around has begun.

After the turmoil of the past week, commercial sponsors quietly admit they have given up hope of a return on their £150 million investment in the Dome. It has simply been written off.

But they are far from the only former Dome enthusiasts to back off this week. The architect Richard Rogers has criticised the contents of his dome on Radio 4, the creator of the Millennium Show has spoken to The Observer of recruitment problems and, yesterday, one insider anonymously blamed the fiasco on 'a third-rate team' around the sacked chief executive Jennie Page.

The bubble finally burst six days ago in an anonymous meeting room on the 26th floor of the Millennium Commission's minimalist headquarters. The Commissioners had gathered to consider the Dome's second plea for more money in five months.

The mood, one source said, was of 'genuine anger' at being held to ransom, and the price extracted this time was the departure of New Millennium Experience Company chair Bob Ayling - the dagger wielded, not by the three politicians in the room, but by independent members including the former children's TV presenter Floella Benjamin.

It was all over in an hour and 40 minutes, and the NMEC emerged with another £29 million to stave off the latest crisis. For most lay observers, the only surprise was that a full-scale meltdown had been contained for this long.

At the birth of the Dome, the then Chancellor, Ken Clarke, was privately sceptical, happy to wish his old ally Michael Heseltine's scheme well - as long as Treasury money was not involved.

His reservations were then shared by shadow chancellor Gordon Brown who argued at a series of tense pre-election meetings in the party's Millbank headquarters that the Dome's budget was unconvincing and its themes too vague.

He favoured a series of new super-libraries or museums instead, while shadow culture minister Chris Smith wanted something smaller, less elaborate and more educational.

Even Lord Falconer now concedes that the original business plan on which profitability was pinned was 'flawed' and 'over-optimistic'.

Conventional wisdom paints Mr Prescott as the fairy godfather who persuaded a wavering Tony Blair to adopt the Dome shortly after the 1997 election, thundering at the Prime Minister: 'If we can't make this work, we're not much of a Government.'

Like all myths it contains some truth, but the real story is more complex. Other Cabinet ministers explain that the decision to take on the Tory project was made before the election by Blair and Peter Mandelson, both genuinely excited by the sheer scale of the project and aware of the potential backlash were Labour to dump it, with construction poised to begin.

The budget had already been pruned back from over £1 billion to £758 million, a process ex-chief executive Jennie Page subsequently described as 'hack and destroy'.

Throughout 1998 and 1999, the Commission repeatedly queried the NMEC's forecast of 12 million visitors, an estimate on which its financial success would depend.

By the end of 1999, the Commission had realised the NMEC risked a cash crisis in its first two months of opening.

And by February, following a dismal first few weeks, they were proved right: the NMEC asked for - and got - another £60 million to resolve 'cashflow problems'.

Publicly ministers have insisted that the latest handout is different, based on a new and sound business plan of stringent cutbacks.

But the uncertainty has sent staff morale plummeting: Mark Fisher, creator of the Millennium Show, admits it has been hard to replace technical staff who have left. Many are being lured away to work on the West End's big musicals instead.

And some sponsors say they were kept out in the cold during the latest drama, learning about the extra grant only after the event. Although they owe around £7 million between them in instalments still to be paid under sponsorship agreements, the NMEC did not approach them for a cash advance. Francis Thomas of Boots concedes: 'I think they would have known that we were not going to give it to them.'

The mood among many of the sponsors is now one of resignation. 'We are all such large corporations,' said one on Friday, 'that to be honest even an investment this big has been written off by now. There are other future sponsorships schemes which are taking up more of our time now.'

If the business plan has been savaged, the creative vision of the Dome has hardly escaped censure either. Sceptical MPs say the Government was too ambitious. 'It was part of the delusions of omnipotence that New Labour had, having won the election - we really believed that Tony Blair could walk on water,' says one veteran Labour backbencher. 'It wanted for a central idea. We had all the rhetoric, but it was vacuous and there was nothing there.'

The creative teams have complained of being held back by nervous commercial sponsors. But Boots says it gave considerable freedom to its partner in the Body Zone, John Hackney, while BT's Adrian Horsford says businesses certainly cannot shoulder the blame for creative flaws, adding: 'Clearly the zones belong to the NMEC and it was their responsibility to make them right. When the Talk Zone opened there were some things we were not happy with but we put those right.'

The sponsors have at least been cheered by the arrival of the French Disney executive P-Y Gerbeau. One added: 'He at least knew how to mend the doors when they broke and how to keep the lights on.'

Gerbeau's approach also impressed John Prescott, who held a half-hour meeting with him when he was first appointed. But the Frenchman faces an uphill task drawing an increasingly apathetic British public across London and through the Dome's doors.

Ironically the NMEC can claim that once there, most visitors do enjoy themselves: 84 per cent say they have had a good time. It blames the dwindling queues on damning media reviews, the strong British pound deterring tourists, and even on the fact that the 'Millennium effect' amounted to little more than an extended New Year's Eve for most Britons.

Meanwhile ministers tirelessly point out that if the Dome achieves its seven million visitors it will still be the second most popular paying attraction in Europe, beating rivals like Alton Towers.

Millennium Commissioner Floella Benjamin, whispered to have been the main player calling for Ayling's head, insisted that 'what I did behind closed doors is private,' but added: 'We should remember to be proud to be British and proud of what we have in

'The show is a magical thing and I certainly hope the new money means that we can continue until the end of the year. We have to give it a chance now.'

The next crunch point for the Dome will come in July, when ministers will decide between the two bids from Japanese bank Nomura or its rival Legacy - to take over and run the Dome site when the NMEC is wound up at the end of the year.

This sale is the Millennium Commission's best hope of recovering its money, and it will examine the Dome's finances again after the July decision is made.

Closing the Dome early would be politically unpalatable, and could cost between £100-£200 million if employees, suppliers and sponsors had to be compensated for the abrupt termination of their contracts.

Allowing the NMEC's successor to take the Dome off their hands early would be only a little less humiliating, and Nomura - regarded as the frontrunner - has flatly denied discussing the option with ministers.

But the suggestion has been floated in Westminster circles as one possible way out. One insider said: 'My understanding is that Nomura and Legacy both have indicated that they could come in at a mutually agreed time before or after the end of the year.'

Whatever happens in July, Nomura has clearly learnt from its predecessor's mistakes. Insiders say their plan would add the pizzazz the Dome is accused of lacking, keeping many of the exhibits but adding others to make the experience 'much more fun, a very strong high technology element - it is going to be much more buzzy.'

Crucially, it is only promising to attract a modest five million visitors. If the Dome had done the same, things might have been very different.

The £29 million cash injection might have purchased the Millennium Dome a reasonable cosmetic uplift in time for this Bank Holiday weekend. Instead, inside the structure, the battered zones resembled an ancient time-piece. Families who had braved the Saturday morning downpour milled around the echoing empty spaces, their faces puzzled and bored.

After last week's resignation of former British Airways chief executive Bob Ayling - chairman of the Millennium Experience Company - the Dome bore all the hallmarks of the final scenes of a tragedy.

Safe from the rain, a few open-minded visitors wandered from zone to zone. Robert Harris, 46, from Milton Keynes, held on to his three children.

'First time I've been here,' he said. 'Thought I'd come and see just exactly what everyone was complaining about. It is a bit disappointing, really. Not much to do, is there? Even the kids seem a little bored.'

Nearby, Emily Harrelson, 14, wandered back from an interactive station. 'Mummy,' she said, 'this is really boring. My internet does more than this.'

Her mother sighed. After only two hours at the Dome, the duo left the building, abandoning the Millennium Experience altogether.

Whatever happens in July, Nomura has clearly learnt from its predecessor's mistakes. Insiders say their plan would add the pizzazz the Dome is accused of lacking, keeping many of the exhibits but adding others to make the experience 'much more fun, a very strong high technology element - it is going to be much more buzzy.' Crucially, it is only promising to attract a modest five million visitors. If the Dome had done the same, things might have been very different. The £29 million cash injection might have purchased the Millennium Dome a reasonable cosmetic uplift in time for this Bank Holiday weekend. Instead, inside the structure, the battered zones resembled an ancient time-piece. Families who had braved the Saturday morning downpour milled around the echoing empty spaces, their faces puzzled and bored. After last week's resignation of former British Airways chief executive Bob Ayling - chairman of the Millennium Experience Company - the Dome bore all the hallmarks of the final scenes of a tragedy. Safe from the rain, a few open-minded visitors wandered from zone to zone. Robert Harris, 46, from Milton Keynes, held on to his three children. 'First time I've been here,' he said. 'Thought I'd come and see just exactly what everyone was complaining about. It is a bit disappointing, really. Not much to do, is there? Even the kids seem a little bored.' Nearby, Emily Harrelson, 14, wandered back from an interactive station. 'Mummy,' she said, 'this is really boring. My internet does more than this.' Her mother sighed. After only two hours at the Dome, the duo left the building, abandoning the Millennium Experience altogether.

fields.headline: Carjack gangs target Brussels
fields.trailText: Brussels - a city better known for its Eurocrats and long lunches - has been hit by 'le carjacking', the theft of cars at gunpoint.
fields.body:
Brussels - a city better known for its Eurocrats and long lunches - has been hit by 'le carjacking', the theft of cars at gunpoint.

The crimes, now almost a daily event, are driven by an insatiable demand for luxury second-hand cars in the former Soviet Union, eastern Europe and North Africa.

The letters pages of newspapers are filled with horror stories. 'A youth trying to pull open my door and smashing my car window with the butt of his pistol was enough to convince me that I will not drive through Anderlecht [suburb] or the Gare du Midi area [where the Eurostar terminal is located] - day or night - again.'

One man, who saw his BMW 740 being driven off by two masked men carrying pistols, wrote: 'They came out of nowhere when I was parking in front of my own house. I was forced out of the car and thrown to the ground with a gun to my head before they drove off.'

The carjackers are only interested in top-of-the-range Mercedes, BMWs and Porsches with a low mileage and in good condition. They are easier to resell and frequently matched with stolen Belgian registration papers - 21,000 of which were stolen in Brussels in 1998 alone.

'The carjackers often block a car's passage with an older vehicle which they abandon before making off with the victim's car,' a gendarme, who declined to be named, told The Observer .

'The cars are sometimes stripped and their components sold separately. The cars are spirited to Poland, Russia or North Africa. The thieves often target older people who are easier to overpower.'

But carjacking is a dangerous trade. Last week the blood-spattered, naked corpse of Bouchaid Ibork, 29, allegedly one of the most senior figures in the carjacking underworld, was found on an unmade road in the hills surrounding Liege. He had been kidnapped, held to ransom and stabbed three times.

fields.headline: Phantom haunts hero of summit
fields.standfirst: The conquest of Annapurna 50 years ago was France's greatest climbing triumph. Now supporters of two men who got to the top are at war
fields.trailText: A long-forgotten ghost has thrown a chill over the coming celebrations of France's greatest mountaineering triumph, the conquest of Annapurna in June 1950 by a team of alpinists led by Maurice Herzog.
fields.body:
A long-forgotten ghost has thrown a chill over the coming celebrations of France's greatest mountaineering triumph, the conquest of Annapurna in June 1950 by a team of alpinists led by Maurice Herzog.

The courage, sacrifice and companionship needed to surpass 8,000 metres for the first time in climbing history so deeply marked national pride in the drear, postwar years that Herzog's book, Annapurna premier 8000, sold 15 million copies.

But Herzog's classic version of the Himalayan achievement and the four books that followed are at the centre of accusations that the mountaineer - a former Minister and wartime Resistance worker - were monuments to his personal glory that denigrated his companion, Louis Lachenal, who accompanied him to the top.

On 3 June, alpinists will gather in Chamonix under the shadow of Mont Blanc to honour Herzog, now 81, the only surviving member of the six-man Annapurna team.

Whatever praise he receives, there will be no handshake from Lachenal's son, Jean-Claude, who has accused the Himalayan hero of dismissing his father as mentally unstable. 'It is appalling,' he said this weekend. 'My father saved his life and this is how Herzog treats him. In his book, he says my father was a mere ghost who had to be persuaded to climb the last metres.'

Lachenal's memory - he died in an Alpine climbing accident in 1955 - was, according to his family, also seriously diminished by Herzog's censoring of his fellow alpinist's version of the climb published posthumously. Long-simmering resentment came to a head only in 1998 when Herzog published l'Autre Annapurna, apparently to respond to the belated publication of censored passages in Lachenal's autobiography Les Carnets du Vertige .

Since then Lachenal's family has revived grudges that go back half a century when Herzog, carrying a French flag, was photographed alone on the summit of Annapurna. The cover of Paris-Match became an iconic image in French climbing history.

Lachenal, 29 at the time, told another climber, Jean-Pierre Payot, who was with him when he died in the Alps, that he was 'furious' with Herzog and 'fed up with the way he used the Annapurna legend to further his career'.

The reasons became clear with the restored passages of his autobiography in which Lachenal admitted being tempted to renounce the final steps in order to save his frostbitten toes.

'If I continued it was only to save "Mo" [Herzog],' he wrote. 'I was sure that if he went on alone he would never be able to get back.'

The decision cost Lachenal his toes and 16 operations over the next five years, during which he had to learn new climbing techniques. According to Payot, now 71, mountaineering remained his only obsession until he fell into a crevasse on on a glacier above Chamonix during a snowstorm on 25 November 1955.

His son Jean-Claude recalled that after his father's death, he was made Herzog's ward and frequently defended the mountaineer in arguments with Alpine guides who believed Lachenal's claims that the expedition leader had stolen all the glory.

Jean-Claude's bitterness towards the right-wing former Minister of Sports was aroused only when he read this once-censored passage of his father's autobiography in 1998.

'I knew that going to the summit would cost me my frostbitten feet,' Lachenal wrote. 'But if I left my toes on Annapurna, I couldn't care less. I asked Maurice what he would do in my case and he said he would continue. It was for him and him alone that I did not turn back.

'This climb to the the summit was not a question of national prestige. It was 'une affaire de cordée' - a reference to the peculiar bond shared by roped mountaineers on a climb.

That version might have come out earlier if Herzog had not taken possession of Lachenal's diaries after his death, following an agreement with Philippe Cornuau, who had been asked to edit them.

'Two chapters had already been prepared because Lachenal believed his image had been damaged by the Herzog account which makes him out to be a bit of a clown,' Cornuau said. 'The whole point of Lachenal's project was to rectify the Herzog version but chapters criticising the leader were removed.'

Herzog, who annotated the autobiograpy in 1956, wrote at the time that he did not believe Lachenal was ready to sacrifice himself for his leader during the last few metres. A half-century later, he said he was still sure that Lachenal, whom he described as loufoque - nutty -, had been ready to give up.

'I was the leader and he followed,' Herzog said this weekend. 'He was no more than a phantom. That's all there is to it.'

fields.headline: Aborigines plead for white apology
fields.standfirst: Thousands to march on Sydney in last-ditch attempt to force acknowledgment of their 'stolen generation'
fields.trailText: Thousands of Aborigines are expected to march across Sydney's Harbour Bridge today in a mass protest at the continuing divide between black and white Australia.
fields.body:
Thousands of Aborigines are expected to march across Sydney's Harbour Bridge today in a mass protest at the continuing divide between black and white Australia.

The rally, Corroboree 2000, marks the end of a 10-year legislative process to persuade the federal government to ratify a reconciliation acknowledging past human rights abuses and work towards a level playing field for indigenous and non-indigenous Australians.

It also includes the thorny issue of the so called 'stolen generation' - the forced removal of Aboriginal and mixed-blood children from their homes during the twentieth century.

To Aborigines this was ethnic cleansing designed to 'breed out' the blackness from the population. To many whites it was a way of offering Aboriginal children a better chance of getting on in life in white families.

Prime Minister John Howard has steadfastly refused to apologise for previous governments' actions though he says he remains committed to the reconciliation process.

His views have incensed Aboriginal communities and when he gave his Corroboree speech in Sydney yesterday he was booed and heckled by protesters. There have been threats of disruptions to the Olympic Games in September, and some police units will no doubt treat today's rally as a dress rehearsal. Aboriginal leaders have said they plan to set up 'embassies' across Sydney during the Games to inform people of their continuing poor conditions.

Aborigines are expected to come from all over New South Wales and neighbour ing states to protest. In the outback town of Broken Hill, an 18-hour train ride west of Sydney, Auntie Beryl Car-michael fingers her personal invitation from the state Premier, Bob Carr.

Carmichael is an Aboriginal elder and a traditional owner of the Home of the Emu Country, a 1,300-mile spread of land around the town. She is the custodian of her father's stories and culture, the only person to have full spiritual knowledge of this land, and she brings to Sydney the harsh realities of being black in the outback.

'The Government is living in a world of denial. They have even denied the stolen generation happened, but I saw the children taken away from the Menindee Mission where I was born, near Broken Hill,' she said.

'I was 12 and I saw my cousins taken away in the trucks. A lot of children had their names changed so they wouldn't know where they came from. Lots of them were married off to white people to breed the colour out of our people and destroy the Aboriginal gene.'

When Carmichael, now 64, began teaching here in the 1980s racism was entrenched. Broken Hill was still shaking off a tough past, built on the sweat and toil of miners, who hacked the silver, lead and zinc from the hot earth. Many of the white miners, and those working in the service industry that followed on the coat-tails of the opening of the mine, did not mix well with the Aborigines and social unrest followed.

Today things are much improved. However, race relations still have a long way to go here. Carmichael admits resentment is in the air. The State Reconciliation Council that spearheaded the 10-year process sees today's protest as a last chance 'to show the Australian population and parliament what needs to be done and to highlight the federal government's spoiling role in all this'. The council's Sue Lindsay said it would attempt to hand its strategy to Howard in person.

It includes demands for self-determination for indigenous people in conjunction with Aboriginal law and strategies for reconciliation, including a framework through which conditions can improve for Aboriginal people and Torres Strait islanders - the inhabitants of more than 100 islands stretching about 95 miles between the northernmost tip of Australia and the south coast of Papua New Guinea.

'The fight for reconciliation between indigenous and white Australians seems to have the support of a good part of Australia,' said Lindsay. But time is running out and tensions are rising. After 10 years of pressure there is still no apology forthcoming, and the government's stubbornness seems unshiftable.

Carmichael also sees today as a milestone. 'All we want is a fair go, a chance to be equal,' she said as she packed her bags at home in Broken Hill. 'That's all we have ever wanted. Corroboree could be our last chance to get it for Broken Hill and everywhere in Australia.'

fields.headline: From wastrel to wonderboy
fields.standfirst: Steve McManaman's stock has never been higher, but England don't have the options of Real Madrid
fields.trailText: In the context of Real's choosiness McManaman's success in Spain is even more impressive, even if it adds a new twist to the old worry about foreigners in the Premiership.
fields.body:
'Where's that fence, I want to sit on it,' said Steve McManaman after the most important game of his life, demonstrating that his newly acquired powers of anticipation and awareness are not just limited to the football pitch.

Most people's man of the match in the European Cup final had just been asked whether this scintillating Real Madrid side was the best he had ever played in, and though the question did not seem all that searching, McManaman was not sufficiently carried away by personal vindication and the euphoria of the moment to fall into the elephant trap of an unwary answer. 'I've played in several good sides, and I've still got lots of good friends in Liverpool,' he said. 'It's not easy to make direct comparisons, except that I never played in a Champions League match for Liverpool, and obviously I would have liked to.'

The feeling on Merseyside is probably now mutual, for while in the later stages of his Liverpool career McManaman was variously characterised as a slacker, a Spice Boy and a spoilt brat who would surely get his comeuppance on the continent, his magnificent contribution to Real's eighth European Cup raises some uncomfortable questions for Anfield in particular and English football in general. The irony of McManaman's current standing as the most successful ever English export to Europe will not be lost on Liverpool supporters who watched their team miss a Champions League place by losing to Leicester and Bradford. The diplomatic McManaman insists he remains on cordial relations with Gérard Houllier, yet with every elegant surge in Paris he undermined the Frenchman's Anfield revolution, which has basically brought in younger players who are more obviously willing but less enviably gifted.

The immediate Anfield futures of Robbie Fowler and Michael Owen cannot be guaranteed while Liverpool remain outside the Champions League echelon, and there is a limit to the number of post-Bosman foreigners supporters will accept in red shirts at a time when real Scousers are bestriding Europe.

Those seeking to restrict the influx of foreigners should have a close look at the composition of Real's winning team. No fewer than nine of the 14 players used on the night, including seven of the starting line-up, are Spanish, as is the coach. Of the remaining five, three are top-class South Americans - Redondo, Roberto Carlos and Savio - which leaves just McManaman and Nicolas Anelka as the only non-Spanish EU players 'topping up' the squad. Not exactly inundation, and while the odd Bosnian and Yugoslav can be found on Real's books, cut-price Scandinavians and ageing Serie A stars are conspicuous by their absence. Real are an example of why current proposals to limit the number of work permit players clubs can sign from non-EU countries are completely wrong-headed.

The Champions League winners obviously have their voluntary code already. Sign genuine talent from South America, still the most reliable source of exciting young players, and blend it with the best from home. Real do not have a problem with cheap imports, and would be penalised by any reduction in the number of Latin players they could bring over. England, which does have a problem with cheap imports and hardly sources any decent non-EU talent, would be largely unaffected by limitations on work permit players. A cap on non-EU imports is being discussed only because it is workable, whereas restricting movement within the EU is not, but it simply fails to address the problem.

In the context of Real's choosiness McManaman's success in Spain is even more impressive, even if it adds a new twist to the old worry about foreigners in the Premiership. Until recently it had been assumed English football was merely damaging its future by an over-reliance on imports, choking off the opportunities for young players and depriving promising performers of necessary early experience. If we are now losing our best players to Europe at the same time as importing their so-so ones, it begins to look as if we are doubly suffering. It is fair to say that McManaman is something of a one-off, and not every English footballer has the confidence to carve out a new career for himself in Europe, but it is not too difficult to imagine Harry Kewell or Mark Bosnich playing in Italy (no loss to England but a blow to Premiership esteem) or Sol Campbell or Rio Ferdinand finally accepting the lure of a club with real Champions League prospects.

The charge which may be about to be brought against English football - which has just voted a sixth overseas player in a row as Footballer of the Year - is that is does not value its home-grown players highly enough. Consider, as many a young prospect will now be doing, how dramatically McManaman boosted his international stock by joining a continental side. The last England coach to use him with confidence was Terry Venables, before the emergence of David Beckham. Glenn Hoddle regarded McManaman with suspicion, reviling him for pulling out of the friendly competition in France before the last World Cup and only giving him 17 minutes in the competition proper. Kevin Keegan was willing to give him a try, but appeared to have lost patience after a dismal performance in his last international in Poland. All McManaman's faults were on display that day - the head-down dribbling, the running into blind alleys, the tame surrendering of possession or retention of the ball for too long - and if Keegan decided there and then there were better ways to fill an England shirt your correspondent must admit he was entirely in agreement.

McManaman was at Madrid by then but was not regularly making the team and his confidence was low. What changed everything was the arrival of Vicente del Bosque mid-season, who as Manchester United found to their cost, transformed the Champions League campaign by reshuffling the talented players at his disposal and ending up with a Real Madrid who actually played like Real Madrid. Even after his starring role in two quarter-final legs against United, however, McManaman had not heard from Keegan. The week before the final Keegan was enthused enough to talk about bringing him in on the left wing, but one night in Paris apparently convinced the Eng land manager to scrap that tentative plan and rethink his whole formation to accommodate McManaman in midfield.

Meteoric rises are not uncommon in football, but rarely can anyone have gone from pariah to prince, from wastrel to wonderboy, in such a short space of time. As McManaman knows. 'I've had my critics and I'll have them again,' he said. 'It's great when people write nice things about you, but you then have to sustain it. Like over this summer with England.'

Strictly speaking, this is now Keegan's problem, not McManaman's. The player is not going to carry the can if he flops this summer for England, it will be the manager's fault for not using him properly. Keegan, being Keegan, calls this not so much a problem as a fantastic opportunity. Which it is. If McManaman has forced Keegan to re-examine the way England play he is to be applauded, because something needed to. On the other hand, neither Keegan nor the England defence is really convinced by the wing-back system that McManaman and his Spanish team favour, Phil Neville is no Roberto Carlos, Alan Shearer would not get into the Real side and there are now just two games left for try-outs before Euro 2000 gets under way.

There is no ideal solution, and since Paul Scholes is valuable for his goals, Keegan should not be too harshly blamed if he reverts to his original plan of using McManaman broadly on the left. 'It's like a blancmange, you can try different things,' Keegan said in one of his less well-judged soundbites. Pink, wobbly and insubstantial? Surely that was the England (and the McManaman) of six months ago. When the pair are reunited against Ukraine on Wednesday, England expects to see something a little more mature and flavoursome on the menu.

Not exactly inundation, and while the odd Bosnian and Yugoslav can be found on Real's books, cut-price Scandinavians and ageing Serie A stars are conspicuous by their absence. Real are an example of why current proposals to limit the number of work permit players clubs can sign from non-EU countries are completely wrong-headed. The Champions League winners obviously have their voluntary code already. Sign genuine talent from South America, still the most reliable source of exciting young players, and blend it with the best from home. Real do not have a problem with cheap imports, and would be penalised by any reduction in the number of Latin players they could bring over. England, which does have a problem with cheap imports and hardly sources any decent non-EU talent, would be largely unaffected by limitations on work permit players. A cap on non-EU imports is being discussed only because it is workable, whereas restricting movement within the EU is not, but it simply fails to address the problem. In the context of Real's choosiness McManaman's success in Spain is even more impressive, even if it adds a new twist to the old worry about foreigners in the Premiership. Until recently it had been assumed English football was merely damaging its future by an over-reliance on imports, choking off the opportunities for young players and depriving promising performers of necessary early experience. If we are now losing our best players to Europe at the same time as importing their so-so ones, it begins to look as if we are doubly suffering. It is fair to say that McManaman is something of a one-off, and not every English footballer has the confidence to carve out a new career for himself in Europe, but it is not too difficult to imagine Harry Kewell or Mark Bosnich playing in Italy (no loss to England but a blow to Premiership esteem) or Sol Campbell or Rio Ferdinand finally accepting the lure of a club with real Champions League prospects. The charge which may be about to be brought against English football - which has just voted a sixth overseas player in a row as Footballer of the Year - is that is does not value its home-grown players highly enough. Consider, as many a young prospect will now be doing, how dramatically McManaman boosted his international stock by joining a continental side. The last England coach to use him with confidence was Terry Venables, before the emergence of David Beckham. Glenn Hoddle regarded McManaman with suspicion, reviling him for pulling out of the friendly competition in France before the last World Cup and only giving him 17 minutes in the competition proper. Kevin Keegan was willing to give him a try, but appeared to have lost patience after a dismal performance in his last international in Poland. All McManaman's faults were on display that day - the head-down dribbling, the running into blind alleys, the tame surrendering of possession or retention of the ball for too long - and if Keegan decided there and then there were better ways to fill an England shirt your correspondent must admit he was entirely in agreement. McManaman was at Madrid by then but was not regularly making the team and his confidence was low. What changed everything was the arrival of Vicente del Bosque mid-season, who as Manchester United found to their cost, transformed the Champions League campaign by reshuffling the talented players at his disposal and ending up with a Real Madrid who actually played like Real Madrid. Even after his starring role in two quarter-final legs against United, however, McManaman had not heard from Keegan. The week before the final Keegan was enthused enough to talk about bringing him in on the left wing, but one night in Paris apparently convinced the Eng land manager to scrap that tentative plan and rethink his whole formation to accommodate McManaman in midfield. Meteoric rises are not uncommon in football, but rarely can anyone have gone from pariah to prince, from wastrel to wonderboy, in such a short space of time. As McManaman knows. 'I've had my critics and I'll have them again,' he said. 'It's great when people write nice things about you, but you then have to sustain it. Like over this summer with England.' Strictly speaking, this is now Keegan's problem, not McManaman's. The player is not going to carry the can if he flops this summer for England, it will be the manager's fault for not using him properly. Keegan, being Keegan, calls this not so much a problem as a fantastic opportunity. Which it is. If McManaman has forced Keegan to re-examine the way England play he is to be applauded, because something needed to. On the other hand, neither Keegan nor the England defence is really convinced by the wing-back system that McManaman and his Spanish team favour, Phil Neville is no Roberto Carlos, Alan Shearer would not get into the Real side and there are now just two games left for try-outs before Euro 2000 gets under way. There is no ideal solution, and since Paul Scholes is valuable for his goals, Keegan should not be too harshly blamed if he reverts to his original plan of using McManaman broadly on the left. 'It's like a blancmange, you can try different things,' Keegan said in one of his less well-judged soundbites. Pink, wobbly and insubstantial? Surely that was the England (and the McManaman) of six months ago. When the pair are reunited against Ukraine on Wednesday, England expects to see something a little more mature and flavoursome on the menu.

fields.headline: Failing the Test
fields.standfirst: How far can cricket fall?
fields.trailText: Welcome to Eden Gardens, Calcutta. Two hundred thousand people, crammed in, every one using one of those mobile phone thingies. What a racket. Anyway, Wasim Akram comes into bowl. He bowls, and I say, the ball has gone over the slips and into the crowd. Six wides. Quite extraordinary. Fred?' 'In my day...'
fields.body:
Welcome to Eden Gardens, Calcutta. Two hundred thousand people, crammed in, every one using one of those mobile phone thingies. What a racket. Anyway, Wasim Akram comes into bowl. He bowls, and I say, the ball has gone over the slips and into the crowd. Six wides. Quite extraordinary. Fred?' 'In my day...'

'So after this most bizarre start India are six for no wicket. The batsmen are having a conflab in the middle, and... and they're walking off! They are walking towards the pavilion and some of the Pakistani players are trying to stop them. Fred?' 'In my day...'

'My producer tells me that India have declared at six for no wicket after one ball, which has never happened in the history of Test cricket. Fred?'

'What's going on? Where are the players?'

'India have declared, Fred... and now here come the Indian fielders followed by the Pakistani batsmen. And it will be Kapil Dev, who has being called out of retirement for this big game, to open the bowling. He lollops up, rather slowly, and bowls... underarm! And it's a slow, slow full toss and Salim Malik... misses it. And the ball hits the stumps and no-one appeals and Malik is rushing back to the pavilion. Well, well, well. Fred?'
