fields.headline: Practical politics
fields.standfirst: Northern Irish must show willing
fields.trailText: The war is over  for slow learners. That was the message from David Trimble's Ulster Unionist Party yesterday. The narrow but historic vote in favour of re-entering a power-sharing government with their republican enemies shows that unionism is moving slowly towards accepting what the rest of the world already knows - the IRA's futile 30-year old war is finished.
fields.body:
The war is over for slow learners. That was the message from David Trimble's Ulster Unionist Party yesterday. The narrow but historic vote in favour of re-entering a power-sharing government with their republican enemies shows that unionism is moving slowly towards accepting what the rest of the world already knows - the IRA's futile 30-year old war is finished.

Trimble has had to push a reluctant and anachronistic party forward at a snail's pace as he seeks to re-invent unionism for the new century. The vote in favour of his recommendation to restore devolution - 53.2 per cent for, 46.8 per cent against - shows that he stills leads a party that is deeply sceptical about the IRA's intentions. It is now up to everyone else involved in the Northern Ireland peace process, in particular the IRA, to help inject fresh confidence into a troubled and suspicious unionism. They can do this by opening their arms dumps to the independent inspectors and fulfilling their promise to put guns beyond use within a matter of weeks, if not days, and most definitely before Ulster's divisive marching season gets under way. They must also end the barbarous practice of so-called punishment beatings and shootings immediately. The loyalist terrorists must do the same.

However, it is up to those unionists in favour of the Good Friday Agreement not to cause offence to a republican community that has supported the Sinn Fein peace strategy and backed the move from armed struggle to practical politics. Remarks by Trimble that Sinn Fein needs to be 'housetrained in democracy' are unhelpful and only bolster the argument of dissident republicans that unionists are interested in domination rather than co-operation.

webTitle: Greek Church stirs holy war over ID cards

fields.headline: Greek Church stirs holy war over ID cards
fields.standfirst: Socialist leader battles to drag nation into modern world
fields.trailText: For the Greeks it is an identity crisis writ large. The Greek Orthodox Church is calling it a 'wild war', the Greek State a long overdue move to make all Hellenes 'more European'.
fields.body:
For the Greeks it is an identity crisis writ large. The Greek Orthodox Church is calling it a 'wild war', the Greek State a long overdue move to make all Hellenes 'more European'.

On both sides passions have risen - so much so that religious zealots are predicting a 'showdown of biblical scale'. What is certain, say more sober commentators, is that the row over whether to include religious affiliation on state identity cards has become a defining moment.

Does Greece, the EU's only Orthodox nation, belong to the East or the West? And can a Greek be a true citizen if he or she is not officially associated with the Orthodox faith?

Such are the questions that have perplexed Hellenes since Costas Simitis, the determinedly modernist Prime Minister, surprised the nation last week with an announcement that henceforth Greece's cherished tradition of declaring religious beliefs belonged to the past.

'Recording religion on ID cards restricts and insults, either directly or indirectly, the religious freedom of the citizen,' the Socialist leader pronounced in parliament. 'It should neither be compulsory nor optional. It should not exist at all.'

In support of his argument he cited a 1997 privacy protection law abolishing religious data. In private, Simitis has voiced discomfort at the discrimination suffered by Greek Muslims, Catholics and Jews from Greece's long-held habit of stipulating religious beliefs on most public documents. For decades, human rights groups have complained about the noticeable absence of religious minorities from prominent positions in both the State and military.

'The Church should accept [the decision] as a conquest for our civilisation... in the year 2000,' Simitis, a former university professor, said pointedly. 'It should not make a fuss.'

But fomenting a fuss is exactly what the Church intends to do. An overwhelming 98 per cent of Greeks are baptised in the Orthodox Church and it is Greece's biggest landowner. On Friday its governing board, the Holy Synod, warned, after convening in an extraordinary session, that 'the battle will be unyielding'.

Greek identity, it reminded the government in a statement seething with fury, was intrinsically and indivisibly bound up with the Orthodox faith. The Church had acted as the guardian of Hellenism through the four dark centuries of Ottoman rule follow ing the fall of Byzantium. It had united the Greek nation in its hour of need and helped Greeks to maintain their identity when the country entered a European Union defined by homogeny and the dictates of Brussels.

'Our faith is the foundation of our ethnic identity,' snapped Archbishop Christodoulos, the Church's pugnacious leader. The Church, he said, would fight 'with every legal means' to persuade the government that it was wrong. He challenged the government to a referendum on the issue, saying: 'Hellenes should have the optional right to state their faith as Orthodox Christians... to do otherwise would be to deny them their identity.'

More than anything, clerics fear the identity crisis will be the start of a much bigger campaign to separate formally Church and State, as in other EU countries.

As Greece's oldest institution - second only to the government in power - the Church still holds a pre-eminent position in Greek society, even if less than 15 per cent of the population attend Mass regularly. Its public influence - augmented by the vast revenues it gathers from the churches it owns - is such that it recently forced the government to abandon talks on a possible visit by Pope John Paul II, because of the pontiff's belated failure to apologise for the Crusaders' sack of Constantinople.

'Greece is the only country in the West whose constitution is declared in the name of the Holy Trinity rather than the name of the people,' lamented Nikos Dimou, author of The Misfortune To Be Greek . 'You cannot even die in this country without the Church, because there are no civil burials.'

For many the row symbolises Greece's struggle to attain maturity after years of being viewed as a truculent teenager by the rest of the West. For Simitis, it is the last hurdle in a quest to transform the country into a fully fledged modern state.

webTitle: The price of telling the awful truth

fields.headline: The price of telling the awful truth
fields.standfirst: The deaths of two reporters in Sierra Leone are a reminder of the peculiar risks and responsibilities of chronicling atrocities, write Peter Beaumont and John Sweeney
fields.trailText: The French war correspondent Paul Marchard last week divided up the journalists who cover conflict into three headings.
fields.body:
The French war correspondent Paul Marchard last week divided up the journalists who cover conflict into three headings. There were, he said, the Tourists, who popped in for a few days, sniffed round while it was quiet, got their passports stamped and checked out. There were the Mickeys, gizmo fetishists with all the right equipment, yet somehow disengaged. People who allow the idea of themselves as 'war correspondents' to get in the way of the story they are covering. Then there were the Brothers. The Brothers were those who cared and stayed when everyone else was leaving. They were the experts in a world that more than ever eschews expert journalism. They always asked the extra question, went the extra mile to get the story. And they are the moral centre of that vagabond pack that is the international press corps. Of these, he said, Kurt Schork, the veteran Reuters war correspondent who was killed in an ambush in Sierra Leone was Brother Number One.

Marchard, if he had known him, could have included Miguel Gil Moreno, the Spanish cameraman with AP television, who died in the same ambush. For in the morally uncertain world of the war correspondent - lives lived in the accumulation of human misery - these two were among the very best, totemic figures for a generation of reporters who went to the world's most dangerous places.

For although they felt drawn to the most destructive kind of journalism - which maims and kills, wrecks marriages and damages the psyche; which can breed cynicism and contempt - their practice of it transformed it into a redemptive experience. Their epitaph was not only to be found in the grief-stricken articles that were written by their friends and colleagues, but also in flood of appreciations from world leaders, diplomats and - most touchingly - the victims of the wars they covered.

And there is a significance in this: journalism, practised with such consummate skill and courage, demonstrably still matters. For in a profession that is much maligned, journalists can - and do - retain a critical role. Kurt and Miguel - in all their passionate intensity - were cameras to the horror and suffering of the world. For in a post-Cold War landscape where none of the major powers - Britain included - is prepared to lose a single soldier's life in the pursuit of trying to find a settlement to the world's most intractable problems, it has fallen on two groups to put themselves daily on the firing line in pursuit of the ideal of a common humanity.

And the significance of this kind of reporting is in the impact that it has on foreign policy, and on those who would rather turn their eyes away from the horrors of our world. The reporting of journalists such as Kurt Schork, Maggie O'Kane, Ed Vulliamy, Martin Bell and Anthony Loyd of the siege in Sarajevo and the war in Bosnia helped to dramatise a war of aggression and the suffering of a civilian population, stiffening the mettle of an indifferent international community. More recently, the reporting in East Timor and Kosovo was also instrumental - for better or worse - in forcing the world's hand towards belated and clumsy interventions. It is a heavy responsibility. For set against the ever-present personal risk for the journalist is the knowledge that individual correspondents and news organisations can have as powerful a voice as diplomats.

In some respects it has ever been thus. The reporting of the genocide in Armenia and the brutality of King Leopold's Congo created international scandals that tilted government against government. But in the era of CNN and Sky and 24-hour news, foreign correspondents have come to define - by their presence or the lack of it - the stories that we feel we should care about. It is here that the influence of the media becomes insidious, creating a set of value judgments assumed by the viewer or reader, that ranks one place above another in the league of our compassion: the developed world above the developing; white over black or brown or yellow; the haves over the have-nots.

And in these parochial sets of assumptions it is only the agencies, for whom Schork and Gil Moreno worked, who continue with a semblance of a notion of universal coverage, although a universal coverage from which editors can pick and choose.

Back in the early Nineties in Sarajevo Kurt Schork was one of those who was shaking the tree and shouting. He was consumed with righteous anger. He believed that the world was being told a lie: that the UN was doing something for the Bosnian Muslims, when the truth was that it wasn't. Sardonic, wry, sharp, informed with the very latest news, he would rip into the UN spokesmen. Not because he was a cruel man. But because he didn't like the lies, and the appeasement of the bad Serbs, and the inhumanity of the siege. He wanted the truth.

Miguel Gil Moreno, who learned his craft in the same evil cauldron of Sarajevo, was cut from the same cloth. He was quiet and deeply religious. His mother, on hearing of his death, explained that her son believed that he had been 'ordained' to do the work he did, staying on in Kosovo and Chechnya at huge risk because he believed that someone had to chronicle the suffering of the civilians left behind. And in truth what Kurt and Miguel found in Sierra Leone was not that different from Bosnia. The same pious words. The same sickening reality as the West condemned the RUF - the rebels who chop the hands off children - but seemed unwilling to do what is necessary to change its bleak and awful landscape.

The reality is, the RUF sells Sierra Leone's diamonds for guns, a trade in blood the European gem business colludes in. And despite pieties at the press conferences, reassurances that again the world is doing something, when it came to the crunch the undermanned and under-equipped UN handed their guns to the RUF and ran away. Now the Sierra Leone Army hasn't got what it needs to fight the rebels.

But if the deaths of Kurt Schork and Miguel Gil Moreno are emblematic for those who met them, they also remind us of the uncomfortable truth, that we live in a world where journalists and journalism are under constant attack. More foreign correspondents died in Croatia and Bosnia than in Vietnam. And foreign correspondents, despite their high profile, are at the least risk. Most journalists who die are local correspondents, killed by their countrymen, the majority unknown and unmourned in the West.

In Serbia President Milosevic has closed down the independent media. In Zimbabwe and in Iran the independent media is under attack. It is a story that is repeated to a greater or lesser degree across the globe. The enemies of freedom have long recognised that independent journalists - whether local or the visiting reporters of the international press corps - are enemies who must be controlled, destroyed or suppressed.

Schork and Gil Moreno understood this better than anyone else. They understood that the translators and fixers that they worked with - often local journalists - were those who took the greatest risks. And both recognised that there were occasions when a journalist should stop working and try to help. Their are three pictures of Kurt Schork, all taken in Sarajevo. Each shows a version of the same image: a slight American with a wounded civilian in his arms.

But more than anything, Schork understood a fundamental truth. The best stories are those that afflict the comfortable and comfort the afflicted, the ones that the people of power do not want told. If the story-tellers give up, then the bad people too often win. But they don't entirely get away with it. Kurt made sure the UN didn't entirely get away with doing nothing in Bosnia, or the Russians with mass murder in Chechnya, or the RUF and the diamond dealers with savagery in Sierra Leone.

But now they are gone.The final truth is this. The British Army is only in the miserable heat of West Africa because good people like Kurt and Miguel told the world of Sierra Leone's agony. Their deaths are an unutterable loss, but the job they were doing? That goes on.

Most journalists who die are local correspondents, killed by their countrymen, the majority unknown and unmourned in the West. In Serbia President Milosevic has closed down the independent media. In Zimbabwe and in Iran the independent media is under attack. It is a story that is repeated to a greater or lesser degree across the globe. The enemies of freedom have long recognised that independent journalists - whether local or the visiting reporters of the international press corps - are enemies who must be controlled, destroyed or suppressed. Schork and Gil Moreno understood this better than anyone else. They understood that the translators and fixers that they worked with - often local journalists - were those who took the greatest risks. And both recognised that there were occasions when a journalist should stop working and try to help. Their are three pictures of Kurt Schork, all taken in Sarajevo. Each shows a version of the same image: a slight American with a wounded civilian in his arms. But more than anything, Schork understood a fundamental truth. The best stories are those that afflict the comfortable and comfort the afflicted, the ones that the people of power do not want told. If the story-tellers give up, then the bad people too often win. But they don't entirely get away with it. Kurt made sure the UN didn't entirely get away with doing nothing in Bosnia, or the Russians with mass murder in Chechnya, or the RUF and the diamond dealers with savagery in Sierra Leone. But now they are gone.The final truth is this. The British Army is only in the miserable heat of West Africa because good people like Kurt and Miguel told the world of Sierra Leone's agony. Their deaths are an unutterable loss, but the job they were doing? That goes on.

webTitle: The class war that misses the point

fields.headline: The class war that misses the point
fields.standfirst: The system let Laura Spence down
fields.trailText: Populist politics is a dangerous game. It promises short-term public support, but within no overarching political purpose or underpinning intellectual coherence. It always ends in tears.
fields.body:
Populist politics is a dangerous game. It promises short-term public support, but within no overarching political purpose or underpinning intellectual coherence. It always ends in tears.

Yet New Labour last week began its populist counter-offensive to Mr Hague's apparent successes over asylum seeking - however much that threatens to tag the Tories as the racist party. The Chancellor pitched into the controversy over Laura Spence, the gifted Tyneside comprehensive student who was refused a place at Magdalen College, Oxford. 'As with other comprehensive school pupils,' stated the leaked notes explaining her failure, 'she is low in confidence and difficult to draw out of herself despite being manifestly able to think on her feet.' Mr Brown was outraged at this example of the 'old boy network', especially as Miss Spence has gone on to win a place at Harvard.

On the face of it he has a point; 7 per cent of private school pupils win nearly half of Oxbridge's places. Money advantages young men and women not just academically but also in the assurance and self-confidence with which they present themselves to interviewers and employers. Despite their A-level results, comprehensive school children remain under-represented.

But in attacking admissions procedures the Chancellor is highlighting the end of the chain, not the causes. Too many comprehensive school applicants are low in confidence. But why do so many state school children have weaker social and presentational skills?

The answer is brutal. Britain's middle class have fled the underfunded state system for private schools that the state subsidises through their charitable status; there is no parallel in any other industrialised country. It has become difficult for all but a few comprehensive schools to offer a balanced social intake, so the social and presentational skills that middle-class children learn from their parents can be passed on to their working-class peers in comprehensive schools.

If the problem is to be tackled, the charitable status of private schools needs to be withdrawn. State secondary schools spend less than £2,500 per pupil per year, a third and even a quarter of that which the best private schools spend on their pupils. The Government should close the gap - over, say, a 10-year period. And the income inequality that allows so many to pay ever higher private schools fees needs to be lowered. On all three counts New Labour has done nothing.

Mr Brown is right to open this debate, but populism has a habit of rebounding. If the Chancellor is to avoid this fate he should back his words with actions.

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: Freeloaders | Profit loser | Online satire | Offline retailers
fields.body:
Freeloaders

Interesting news coming out of the States. According to a recent survey, music sales near US campuses have dropped for two years running. Why? Experts say it's because now that students can download music for free they are no longer willing to buy CDs. Bad news for the likes of Our Price.

Profit loser

Unfortunate timing, this. An ad in Management Today promotes a 'People and Profits in the New Economy' convention. Sounds interesting. Until you read that a keynote speaker is one Anthony Coleman. Of boo.com.

Online satire

Freeserve has bought the rights to stage online versions of (obligatory words coming up) 'popular satirical TV quiz' Have I Got News For You . Freeserve subscribers will be able to (oh joy) emulate their TV heroes Paul Merton and Ian Hislop by playing online versions of the odd one out and missing word rounds. In the spirt of things, which is the odd one out: a swallow in nosedive, a shooting star, a falling leaf, or boo.com?

Offline retailers

Shocking news from the front line of e-retailing. Four-fifths of online retailers fail to meet basic customer service standards, according to ecommerce firm Trust-On-Line. Big names to get a slap on the wrist include Sainsbury, Lastminute.com, Virgin and Waitrose. Dixons and Toyzone get the big thumbs up.

webTitle: FA fix up friendly against Spain

fields.headline: FA fix up friendly against Spain
fields.trailText: England have fixed up an extra friendly for early next year, when, in line with their new policy of playing friendlies against only top nations, they will take on Spain in February.
fields.body:
England have fixed up an extra friendly for early next year, when, in line with their new policy of playing friendlies against only top nations, they will take on Spain in February.

The game will be in this country at a venue still to be announced, as Wembley will be unavailable. The additional match means that within the first six months of next season England will play France, Italy, Germany and Spain.

Kevin Keegan has denied holding discussions with the FA over an extended contract. It had been reported that the FA were ready to offer him a new six-year deal subject to a successful campaign in Euro 2000, but Keegan dismissed the story as speculation.

England's 22-man squad for the Euro 2000 finals will be announced on Wednesday night, immediately after the friendly against Ukraine. Keegan must cut six players from his initial 28, and he intends to tell each of the unlucky half-dozen in private before the Ukraine match. The following day, the squad of 22 will fly to Malta for a final friendly next Saturday before their Euro 2000 opener against Portugal on 12 June in Eindhoven.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Amsterdam: trial by TV
fields.body:
Amsterdam: trial by TV

Following plans by the Charleroi authorities to lock up Euro 2000 hooligans in fortified garages, Amsterdam police have unveiled their containment policy. According to city mayor Schelto Patijn, troublemakers will be imprisoned for up to 12 hours in a converted hangar and shown continuous football on a big screen to keep them quiet. Final preparations for the tournament also include the release on Tuesday of the final batch of tickets for 17 matches - including England v Romania. Safety, though, says director Alain Courtois,is guaranteed. 'To those who criticise and want to tell us what to do, I tell them "take care of your own fans and we take care of the rest".'

Posh on Becks: can't help herself

Victoria Beckham is taking her vow to stop embarrassing husband David in public rather lightly. Last week The Sun reported how Becks takes Brooklyn to a Tumble Tots activity centre every week and has taught his son to say 'A'ight like Ali G'. Their source for this exclusive? 'He says it with such a smile,' Victoria brazenly told the paper. 'He loves Ali G.' The activity centre, though, seems to be where Becks is really in his element. 'They all sit in a circle and sing Row, row, row the boat and David does it with them,' she told delighted hacks. 'The other week David said, "There never used to be many people there; but now there's loads." I said, "Are you surprised? David Beckham is sitting there going Row, row, row th e boat" .' All in all, another story sure to go down well with Jaap, Roy and the chaps.

Tears as Polster calls it quits

Former Austrian international and bad fashion icon Toni Polster has announced his retirement, just a year after calling himself 'the best active striker in the world'. Polster, 36, made the decision after SV Salzburg lost the Austrian Cup final to Graz AK. 'I didn't want to say anything before the match, but yes, it was my final game,' he told fans afterwards. 'I feel the moment is right to retire.' Polster will now turn his attention full-time to his hugely popular website, where fans can buy from the Polster fashion label - an e-commerce operation on a scale to rival Tomas Brolin's efforts with vacuum cleaners. Polster has tops and trousers for sale, and, being best known for pioneering a perm which, worn with white socks, made Kevin Keegan's best efforts pale into respectability, he's got a look all of his own. More at toni-polster.com.

Win: free England tickets

To start a summer of top Euro 2000 competitions, we're giving away four tickets to see England's warm-up game against Ukraine at Wembley next Wednesday, in association with lastminute.com . To win a pair, answer this: who won Euro 2000 last time Belgium hosted the finals? a) Soviet Union b) West Germany c) France. To enter, email your name, answer and a daytime contact number to observer@lastminute.com - you'll also receive news of lastminute's cable TV-equipped Euro 2000-friendly holidays. Other prizes to come in Said & Done next month: signed England shirts, free £50 bets, computer games and more - watch this space...

webTitle: Arsenal miss out on Sky money

fields.headline: Arsenal miss out on Sky money
fields.trailText: Arsenal may be a little miffed when they discover that their TV money from last season's Premiership is less than the year before, despite the late surge that secured second place in the table and a berth in the 2000-01 European Champions League.
fields.body:
Arsenal may be a little miffed when they discover that their TV money from last season's Premiership is less than the year before, despite the late surge that secured second place in the table and a berth in the 2000-01 European Champions League.

In 1998-99, Arsenal topped the money chart after finishing runners-up to Manchester United in the League, the two clubs becoming the first to break through the £10 million barrier for a single season. But this time, the Gunners will pick up only £9.84 million, less than Leeds and Liverpool who finished behind them in the championship.

Fewer live appearances on Sky and the BBC's Match of the Day was the reason for the club's drop in TV revenue. In 1998-99, Arsenal were on the box 27 times, including 12 live Sky games; last season they were on only 16 times, with their Sky appearances - each worth £311,000 - down to seven.

A Sky spokeswoman said Arsenal had not been shown so often because their European commitments had made it difficult to schedule their matches. 'We have to give six weeks' notice of which London matches we're showing,' she said, 'and in Arsenal's case this caused problems.' With the Premiership clubs discussing the next television contract, which starts in 2001, Arsenal may press for a for mula that rules out a leading team suffering a drop. Last season, the 20 clubs shared £160 million of the £670 million it cost Sky when they regained the live Premiership rights in 1996 for four years (1997-2001). Sky are favourites to keep the rights again, but may have to go as high as £1 billion for the 66 matches per season - six more than before - over a shorter three-year period.

A Spanish TV station with live rights to last Wednesday's European Cup final in Paris came within 90 minutes of not broadcasting the match - but were saved from a major embarrassment by the British broadcaster ONdigital. Via Digital arrived to find they didn't have the right live feed to send home pictures of the all-Spanish final. But just as they were beginning to despair that any of the 50 outside-broadcast trucks at the game could help them out, 021, ONdigital's OB company, came to the rescue.

webTitle: My huge debt to Van Basten

fields.headline: My huge debt to Van Basten
fields.standfirst: England's defensive rock in Euro 2000, a last crack at the World Cup and that meeting with Marco
fields.trailText: Ian Ridley talks to Tony Adams about a last crack at the World Cup and that nmeeting with Marco in 1988.
fields.body:
Tony Adams's football career had hobbled to a crossroads. His ankle had been giving him gyp for so long, draining the desire for the game that had always characterised him, that he was contemplating retirement. Now here he was in the South of France enduring a make-or-break week of injury rehabilitation.

After a punishing day of cycling, running and swimming, he walked wearily one night into a restaurant in Antibes. The figure in the corner looked familiar. It was Marco van Basten, Adams's tormentor at the European Championships of 1988 when a hat-trick from possibly the greatest of all European centre- forwards sent England home in disgrace and fuelled in Holland the confidence to go on and win the tournament.

At the end of his meal, Adams went over to ask Van Basten how he was. 'Fine,' he said, though you sensed he wasn't, his brilliant career not long over, his wrecked ankle ligaments the result of the brutality of the early Nineties that belatedly prompted the outlawing of the tackle from behind. 'I wish I was still playing,' he added wistfully.

I was there as the ghost writer of Adams's autobiography, Addicted. As we left the restaurant, he turned to me. 'It's time to get back playing,' he said. Adams could not have envisaged it in '88 but 10 years later, Van Basten had given him a reason to be grateful, to savour the time he had left in the game. It was a privilege to witness the moment. Within months, Adams had won the Double with Arsenal and proved himself anew at France 98 as one of the world's outstanding defenders.

That had looked an unlikely prospect a decade earlier. It marked the beginning of a rollercoaster relationship with the European Championships over the past 12 years to mirror the nation's as Adams has been variously vilified and left unfulfilled.

Now, four years abstinent from the booze in August - one day at a time, God willing, he will insist on telling you - he also has the chance to turn his and England's European record around.

I haven't had any trouble with my groin.' This time, he senses more public realism than in '88 or '96, probably due to the November defeat by Scotland. 'The fans are waiting for us to fire them,' he says. 'If we don't get out of the group, they will say that it's just the same as the cricket - "Why are England so rubbish?" But I can see them coming round.'

Adams does not see the absence of a specialist left-sided player as a serious deficiency. 'We can compensate. I don't see it as a problem. It can be a positive strength in fact. It depends how you play.' He points out that Steve McManaman enjoyed a good tournament in '96 cutting infield from wide. 'Good players can play anywhere,' says Adams.

The Germany game will most capture the public imagination, but as a player Adams sees it differently. 'Portugal is the biggest game,' he says. 'That first match is so important to set you up. If you beat Portugal, you are maybe looking at getting a point against Germany. But yes, realistically we did play them off the pitch for 75 minutes in '96 and they have not done well since then so they've got good reason to be apprehensive.'

One more score to be settled. Adams will be 34 in October and it will be his last European Championship, though he believes he has one more World Cup in him and is looking forward to being captain again when Alan Shearer retires from the international game after Euro 2000.

And one more footballing step at a time. 'I've pretty much done everything domestically,' he says. 'Internationally it's not happened for numerous reasons. I've not been successful and I would like to be.' In the homeland of Marco Van Basten, it would mean final professional rehabilitation indeed to match the personal.

webTitle: Something is stirring in the Bay of Naples

fields.headline: Something is stirring in the Bay of Naples
fields.trailText: Simon Kuper on the rise, fall and possible resurrection of Napoli, who are on the verge of a return to Serie A.
fields.body:
The other day Napoli received an email from a pensioner living in Brazil. Could he have four tickets for the club's Serie B match against Brescia on Sunday?

He is not alone. Quite a few Neapolitans who emigrated in search of jobs over the past few decades have come home for today's game. A win would return Napoli to Serie A after two years in B .

From there it would be just a hop, skip and a daydream to the Italian title, which the club last won a decade ago thanks to Diego Maradona.

But Napoli have changed a lot since then, and so has the city of Naples. Sixteen years ago, when a helicopter carrying Maradona landed in the San Paolo stadium, he was greeted by tens of thousands of fans who had waited hours to see him. Maradona proved worth it. He holed up in the Hotel Royale with an entourage of relatives, friends and mere acquaintances, and started winning football matches.

It was about time. A club named Naples had been founded by British mechanics in 1904, playing in azure shirts the colour of the Bay of Naples, but in all its incarnations it had disappointed. The day Maradona arrived, the only trophy in the club cabinet was the obscure and defunct Cup of the Alps.

In this regard Napoli resembled Naples, which was also a confirmed loser. Poor, teeming, dangerous and devoid of traffic rules, it was known as the city where Africa began. It was also a city devoted to football. In Naples they used to say that when a man has money, he first buys food, then goes to the football match, then sees if he has anything left to find somewhere to live. When Maradona's transfer from Barcelona looked to be on the rocks, thousands of Neapolitans turned up at local building societies with their savings books to help pay his deposit.

But the bulk of the fee almost certainly came from the Camorra, the Neapolitan mafia, whose members tend to support Napoli. The Giuliano family, a leading Camorra clan, befriended Maradona, inviting him to their parties where they made sure he was photographed.

Nobody seemed to mind much. Maradona led Napoli to Italian titles in 1987 and 1990, and migrant Neapolitans built huge celebrations in cities across Italy. When Maradona was busted for cocaine use in 1991, the club sank.

Napoli turned out to owe £75 million, avoided bankruptcy only because big football clubs don't go bankrupt, and in 1998 were relegated to Serie B.

Meanwhile, the city was undergoing a different sort of change. Magistrates took on the mafia. The Christian Democrats, who for decades had ruled Naples with the Camorra, were cleared out. The G7, the group of industrialised nations, had a summit scheduled for Naples in 1994, and new mayor Antonio Bassolino decided to ensure that no teenager on the back of a scooter would snatch a prime minister's bag on the Piazza San Domenico.

A city clean-up began. Suddenly, from beneath centuries of grime, emerged sculptures, medieval gates and facades of palaces. Traffic policemen began working, instead of just clocking in and going home. You can no longer drive on whichever side of the road you prefer in Naples. Theft began to be regarded as a problem instead of as a leading industry.

Tourists arrived. Naples turned into a European city. It would be wrong to overestimate the degree of change. Naples has not suddenly turned into a Swiss village. It is still poor, still full of Camorristi. But they are no longer omnipotent, and they no longer control the local football club. Several of them have been arrested and become state informers. One, Guglielmo Giuliano, an acquaintance of Maradona, told magistrates this winter that in the Seventies and Eighties his clan knew the results of many football matches before they were played.

He said: 'Many games were fixed thanks to the relationship between our family - and not just our family - and the world of football_ such as that with Mr X, a former Napoli player. While he played for Catanzaro, he was always fixing matches.'

We do not know whether the Giulianos also fixed Napoli games. But it seems that they are not doing so today. The Camorra appears to have lost some of its grip, on the city and on the club. For Napoli too is changing. Corrado Ferlaino, a local bigshot who had run the club for most of the past three decades, has recently sold up to the television magnate Giorgio Corbelli.

Corbelli has a lot of work to do. Few Neapolitans still regard their football club as life's second priority. The San Paolo can accommodate 70,000 people, but by Thursday night only 20,000 tickets had been sold for the game against Brescia, which would still make it one of the largest crowds of the club's two seasons in Serie B.

Yet there is a large slumbering passion for Napoli. More people regularly watch their games on pay-per-view than the number that see all but the biggest Serie A teams. Now the club is talking of signing Roberto Baggio, Gianfranco Zola or Benito Carbone. If Napoli do win promotion, they could be a useful symbol of the city's revival. In jails and in the San Paolo, the Camorristi will be cheering them on.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Vodafone soothes
fields.body:
Vodafone soothes

Watch out for Vodafone Airtouch, which reports annual results on Tuesday. Shares in the the world's biggest mobile phone company have tumbled from their 400p February high, but may be set for a sharp re-rating.

Recent jitters about 'new economy' stocks have, of course, taken their toll. The market also badly misjudged the cost of the new third-generation UK mobile phone licences. Vodafone was forced to shell out £6 billion in the moneyspinning auction, far more than expected.

With other countries set to follow suit, analysts believe Vodafone's total bill could be upwards of £30bn. And, as governments only take readies, the worry has been that Vodafone may take on crippling debt or run out of cash.

This week should soothe those fears. Vodafone's prospects are excellent, its cashflow is healthy and - after the Mannesmann takeover - a £25bn sale of Orange is just round the corner.

Most analysts rate the shares, now at 280p, a buy - including Deutsche Bank, which puts a 444p valuation on Vodafone's head.

High street punt

Fancy a speculative shop on the high street? Check out Actif Group, the clothing wholesaler which is now turning itself into a niche branded retailer. The company has signed two licences to run concessions using the Joe Boxer and Elle brands.

Joe Boxer is an upmarket US underwear and sleepwear brand, and from September Actif will launch concessions in 45 Debenhams stores.

The second brand takes its name from the women's magazine. By the end of July, Actif will have 10 Elle stores up and running around the country at locations such as the Gateshead Metro, Cheshire Oaks and Edinburgh, with concessions in House of Fraser stores and Bentalls at Lakeside, Essex.

At 13.5p Actif is trading on a prospective multiple of 12 times next year's earnings and is a buy, says house broker Seymour Pierce.

Wary of Matalan

At the opposite end of the spectrum, shares in Matalan - the successful discount clothing chain - have recovered from the placing of 12 per cent of shares by the controlling Hargreaves family.

Nonetheless, at 524p, they are still rated at 40 times next year's earnings. Some brokers reckon Matalan has still further to go, with 550p or 600p attainable.

But such a demanding rating assumes years of continuing high growth without a single hiccup. Given the risks inherent in rapid expansion, we prefer other brokers' wariness and advise taking some profits.

Vultures wanted

Where are the value investors or corporate vultures? Failing them, shares in the country's housebuilders are now so lowly rated that the time is surely nigh for managements to look at the option of going private.

Take George Wimpey, for example. At 107p, one of the best known names of all is now trading at a multiple of just 4.4 times prospective earnings. Yet sales are encouraging, profits and margins are improving and net assets per share stand at 158p. Buy for recovery.

Healthy change

Spirent, as the old Bowthorpe electronics business is now known, starts life in rude health after changing its name a fortnight ago.

Current trading is strong, especially in the core telecoms operation, and currencies are now moving in the company's favour.

At 350p, the shares are undervalued and trading may well exceed all expectations for the current year. Broker Salomon Smith Barney has set a conservative 500p target over the next 12 months.

At 350p, the shares are undervalued and trading may well exceed all expectations for the current year. Broker Salomon Smith Barney has set a conservative 500p target over the next 12 months.

webTitle: How UK Inc should spend its windfall

fields.headline: How UK Inc should spend its windfall
fields.standfirst: The Observer debate: Can the pound be brought down? Retired MPC member Charles Goodhart lines up with the interventionists
fields.trailText: The Observer debate: Can the pound be brought down? Retired MPC member Charles Goodhart lines up with the interventionists
fields.body:
The current cash windfall from the auction of the mobile telephone spectrum should involve decisions on optimal public sector asset management. Public sector expenditures are not currently constrained by the availability of cash - and the Chancellor's prudential requirements on debt and deficit ratios are, for the time being at least, more than satisfied.

What determines the chosen path of public expenditures is, in my view, a decision on the optimal shares of consumption and investment, public and private, over the medium term. Whatever path of public expenditures was optimal before the cash windfall from the auction will remain optimal after it, subject only to a few tiny and pedantic qualifications.

If so, the use of the cash windfall has to be seen in the context of how to manage a new portfolio of financial assets to the benefit of UK taxpayers, or of any other focus group - the young, for example, or pensioners.

The two great lessons of finance are that diversification of asset holdings improves risk-adjusted returns, and that risk has to be assessed over the portfolio as a whole, not on individual investments.

Assume that UK taxpayers could hire a fund manager to invest the auction windfall to maximise their risk-adjusted returns. What should they think if she reported back that she was going to invest almost all of it in overpriced British government debt - overpriced because of a shortage of supply exacerbated by an enforced demand from the Minimum Funding Requirement (MFR) of pension funds?

They would, and should, sack that manager, perhaps claiming dereliction of duty. Yet that is exactly the course the Chancellor has, so we are told, set; while simultaneously ordering an enquiry into private sector fund management.

Diversifying part of the windfall into foreign assets would be prudent asset management. In particular, when countries grow relatively more strongly/ weakly, their currencies tend to appreciate/depreciate. Strong/weak growth leads to large/small tax revenues. In other words, whichever of these two paths growth follows, the value of foreign assets would vary inversely with the pressure on domestic taxpayers, making such assets a beneficial hedge.

In any case, expert evidence, for example at a recent Bundesbank workshop, identified the pound as considerably overvalued against all the main foreign currencies - grossly so against the euro. While we cannot forecast short-term movements in nominal exchange rates, history suggests that real exchange rates do return to equilibrium after five to 10 years.

While this could occur through continental European inflation rising faster than the UK's, a more likely medium-term scenario is for the nominal pound/euro exchange rate to reverse recent trends. So a sensible fund manager asked to maximise returns, subject to risk, over a five to 10-year horizon would, in my view, now go overweight on foreign assets, including equities as well as bonds.

One response would be that, if foreign investment is likely to be so profitable in the medium/longer term, the market will already have done it for you. The reason I do not buy this is that there is a dearth of speculators prepared to hold investments for the long term on the basis of a view of the fundamentals. If market momentum is against a position for six months or a year, most speculators will cut their losses, thereby aggravating the misalignments we observe.

Optimal portfolio management to achieve the best risk-adjusted medium-term return for UK Inc. of the auction windfall would include a large (perhaps 50 per cent) purchase of foreign assets and far fewer gilt buy-backs than proposed. But issuing more gilts and instead purchasing foreign assets is identically equivalent to sterilised intervention. Shock! Horror!

My erstwhile colleague Willem Buiter, and Anne Sibert (economics professor at London's Birkbeck College) have argued (The Observer, 23 April) that such sterilised intervention rarely moves the exchange rate in practice, and would therefore be only an empty gesture.

History does indeed suggest that sterilised intervention only rarely has an identifiably successful effect on the exchange rate, but the portfolio management inherent in the exercise is still worth doing for its own sake. If the exchange rate should also decline in the short term, that would be icing on the cake. It would hardly drive the exchange rate in the wrong direction.

Some Eurosceptics may see such intervention as a means of easing the pound into the euro, but it can also be argued that the misalignment provides the best argument for joining a larger, and hence more stable, regional currency.

However, if the pound did not fall, the same critics would attack the short-term losses that might result. Indeed, but, properly assessed, the medium-term overall portfolio risks of concentrating on gilt repurchases are far greater.

Again, opponents of intervention such as Buiter and Sibert assert either that it will have too little effect on asset prices - exchange rates, for example - or too much - on, say, long gilt yields. To quote them: 'Long sterling issues on the scale envisaged would soon raise long-term sterling rates, and further operations would no longer be profitable.'

As a prospective pensioner, I am all in favour of getting rid of the downwards distortion in long gilt yields. Let us get there first, and find out how much new issuance it involved as part of the exercise.

 Professor Charles Goodhart recently retired as a member of the Monetary Policy Committee.

fields.headline: Wall Street's party pooper
fields.standfirst: Celebrity economist Robert Shiller talks to  Faisal  Islam  about his new book on the current age of stock market unreason
fields.trailText: Celebrity economist Robert Shiller talks to Faisal Islam about his new book on the current age of stock market unreason
fields.body:
The dismal science of economics rarely lives up to that monicker so effortlessly. The Nasdaq Index has fallen by 40 per cent since the publication of Irrational Exuberance, a book exploring the economics and psychology of financial market behaviour.

Its author, economist Professor Robert Shiller of Yale University, has 'found himself elevated to the status of a Wall Street guru', says the New York Times.

The book examines the influence of herd mentality, economic triumphalism, sports-style media coverage of stock markets and 'new era' thinking as explanations for a persistent overvaluation of the stock market. It also presents a sobering account of other instances of stock market exuberance from last century and questions the relevance of 'rational expectations'.

A week after the book was published, the markets began their precipitous drop, but Shiller stands by the statistician's maxim that correlation is no indication of causality.

'I predicted it, but I don't take any responsibility for it,' he says.

At his now regular media appearances, Shiller is characterised as a party pooper and a prophet of doom. He is pitted in debate against the authors of a book called Dow 36,000, which contends that the value of the Dow Jones Industrial Average will triple when investors realise the true risk characteristics of shares. A colleague of Shiller from Yale University predicts the Dow will rise by nine times to 100,000 in 20 years.

'Clocks in San Francisco show the temperature, the time, the Dow and the Nasdaq,' says Shiller. 'You can't go down the street without looking at them.'

The stock market and its perceived 'success' over the past decade are ingrained in the American psyche - a symbol of economic virility in exact agreement with ever more tangible advances in technology and communications and financial triumphalism after Cold War victory.

He points to advertisements taken out by US merchant bank Merrill Lynch in March 1999, celebrating the 'human achievement' of the Dow reaching 10,000. 'If this is an achievement worth congratulating, then we should congratulate employees whenever they submit glowing self-evaluation reports.'

Exuberant valuation of shares means that 'as a society we may invest too much in business start-ups and expansions and too little in infrastructure, education and other human capital'.

The basis of Shiller's analysis comes from the emerging field of behavioural finance. It draws on the diverse academic traditions of psychology, sociology and demography as well as financial and mathematical economics. The theory is not new; there are throwbacks to Keynes's 'beauty contest' and George Soros's 'reflexive pricing'.

Essentially, he says, the boom is given its own momentum by a series of feedback mechanisms, some psychological, some cultural and some financial - all underpinned by strong market confidence. At first this may reflect a genuine improvement in underlying productivity and profits, but gradually market valuations are detached from fundamentals.

The title of the book is taken from Alan Greenspan's most famous question. The chairman of the Federal Reserve asked in 1996: 'How do we know when irrational exuberance has unduly escalated asset values?'

'Irrational exuberance just about captures the mindset we have right now,' says Shiller.

Other popular phrases, such as 'speculative orgy', were too strong, he feels, and would possibly attract a different readership. Besides, Greenspan made that remark two days after playing host to Shiller at a Federal Reserve workshop on the stock market.

Shiller's own work centres on financial market volatility and surveys of bankers and large investors since the mid-Eighties.

He asks investors how they would predict the Dow to react the day after a 3 per cent fall. In 1989, 35 per cent of the respondents chose an increase, 34 per cent a further drop, 13 per cent said it would stay the same and 18 per cent had no opinion. By last year, 56 per cent chose a rise, 19 per cent a decrease, 12 per cent said it would stay the same, and 13 per cent were don't knows. The ratio of 'increase' to 'decrease' rose from about evens in 1989 to about 3 to 1 in 1999.

This informs his general scepticism about the current boom.

Shiller's interest in the application of psychology to market behaviour was sparked by his wife, Virginia, a clinical psychologist. Irrational Exuberance is peppered with references to experiments that illustrate the human tendency for overconfidence, the need for psychological anchors and herd behaviour.

But at its base doesn't economics make assumptions about the nature of human psychology that are laughably simple? Aren't people rational egotists, economic agents who seek to maximise happiness subject to a budget constraint?

'I tend to think the rational model is a tool that has proved to be interesting if you want to think about how economies operate ideally,' he says. 'They are use ful but pretty crude approximations because they ignore psychology, and there are times when they don't work at all - like right now.'

Shiller has stronger reservations about the rational expectations revolution. 'It gets tedious when people keep referring to markets as if they magically pooled all information and did everything right. The idea that the unpredictability of returns means that markets are efficient is one of the most remarkable errors in the history of economic thought.'

But if he is aware of the empirical limitations of his academic work and the occasional irrationality of market behaviour, he calls himself a strong free marketeer. 'I'm one of the most extreme zealots for expanding markets.'

Although he says the insights on irrational market behaviour are applicable to international currency and capital markets, he does not see his work as a justification for more protectionism or a 'Tobin' tax on capital flows.

'It seems ironic doesn't it, but what is the alternative to markets?'.

Shiller, a charismatic midwesterner, is enjoying that rarest of luxuries for a professional economist, a wide audience - and he seems to enjoy the attention.

In many ways he's gnawing away at a key part of the American Dream - that any individual can make it by tapping into a wave of national self confidence.

'A lot of the established media are not so comfortable with books that are negative. I get a sense that they'd really rather have someone who is positive. Perhaps they will be vulnerable to possible criticism that they don't want to do anything that shakes the market.

'Success in the stock market has affected people in a deep psychological way. It has gone to their heads. People feel good that they've taken part in this new economy, that they've learnt something, and got new skills.

'If I'm saying it's hot air, some people will feel aggrieved by that. There's also a feeling that it's good for the economy if we're all cheerleaders.

He is aware too that if the market goes down, many individuals are going to suffer. 'I wish I could have prevented it from ever getting so high,' he jokes, 'but I obviously don't control things.'

At the moment he reserves his fire for elements in the US Congress who are lobbying for the national budget surplus to be invested in the stock market. The market mania has even affected his 14-year-old son, who wanted to buy shares in retailer K-mart.

It's often said that Shiller 'walks the walk' by avoiding investment in the new economy. Indeed, he agrees that his investment portfolio is not overladen with stocks of any kind.

But while talking to The Observer, Shiller remembered his founding stake in a real estate information service, Case Shiller Weiss Inc. The company is run by a fellow economist and uses a complex model to give an estimated value for 70 per cent of American homes.

'People think I'm a party pooper, but I've actually got a dotcom company that I'm excited about.'

The interest is not as contradictory as it might seem. The company has patents on pioneering financial securities that will mirror the value of New York property, an attractive option for anyone wanting less exposure to the stock market's irrational herds. And Irrational Exuberance will only increase their number.

 Robert Shiller will deliver a public lecture on his book at the London School of Economics, on Monday 5 June at 6.30pm. Ring 020 7405 7422 for details.

fields.headline: Nabisco bidders take the biscuit
fields.standfirst: The food giants are cannibals, says  Paul Farrelly. Only a few will survive in one piece
fields.trailText: The food giants are cannibals, says Paul Farrelly. Only a few will survive in one piece
fields.body:
There are barbarians at the gate again. Barely a decade after the last great corporate carve-up, some of the most famous names in world food are set to be swallowed up once more.

First Peak Freans' maker Nabisco and French yoghurt giant Danone snacked on our own United Biscuits, with a $2 billion joint bid in February. So McVities, KP Nuts and Hula Hoops joined names like Rowntrees, Terry's and Walkers Crisps in the hands of the global food giants.

And now the goliaths are feasting on themselves. This month, Unilever - producer of everything from Persil to Lipton teas - unveiled a $18bn hostile bid for Bestfoods of the US just days after snapping up Ben & Jerry's ice cream and Slimfast diet foods for $2.6bn in loose change. Bestfoods may hardly be a household name over here, but its brands certainly are. With products such as Bovril, Marmite, Hellmann's Mayonnaise and Knorr soups, the US giant is firmly in the premier league of world food.

Most tantalising of all, however, is the feeding frenzy now engulfing its New Jersey shelf-mate, Nabisco. Twelve years after starring in the biggest buyout ever at the height of Eighties Wall Street greed, the former Shredded Wheat maker finds itself on the menu again. Britain's Cadbury Schweppes is the latest to confirm it was among no fewer than 13 guests invited to the feast in the $20bn auction being conducted by Nabisco's investment banks, Morgan Stanley and Warburg Dillon Read.

The sheer scale of the activity is reminiscent of 1988, the height of the last boom, when within weeks Pillsbury fell to the UK's Grand Metropolitan (now part of Diageo) for $5bn, Kraft Foods to Marlboro-maker Philip Morris for $11bn and finally Nabisco itself to a $20bn junk bond-stuffed deal spearheaded by the barbarians of book and film infamy, US buyout leaders Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, or KKR.

The Wall Street shufflers were instrumental in buying food firms and flogging them off. But against the consumer giants, they are strictly Act I players. 'The last wave of consolidation really happened when the likes of Philip Morris came on the scene,' one senior food executive said. 'Now they've digested those deals, the next wave is under way as the leaders seek to cut costs by swallowing firms that fit well. The new factor, though, is retail mergers. More and more food producers are dealing with retailers with a growing global reach. To keep up, we need to offer better prices and a bigger product range.'

In the new millennium, the industry dynamics may have been changed by growing supermarket power. But at Nabisco, the key player comes straight from barbarian casting. Carl Icahn, the 64-year-old corporate raider who forced Trans World Airlines to its knees, sparked the frenzy with a $5bn offer for a strategic stake in March. But instead of repelling all boarders, the firm opted to put itself and its brands - Ritz crackers, Planters nuts and Lifesavers and Beech-Nut chewing gums among them - up for sale yet again to the highest bidder.

Nabisco's turbulent recent history is a far cry from its homespun roots as a New England cookie maker in 1898. Then, founder Adolphus Green purveyed soda crackers, ginger snaps, wafers and Lorna Doone shortbread to the peckish American public.

By the Eighties, the firm was headed by Ross Johnson, a Canadian adventurer who rescued Nabisco from the price-cutting of the 'cookie wars' waged between American bakers and in 1985 led it into a merger with RJ Reynolds, America's second- biggest cigarette maker. Slated though the deal was, it was hardly the first time food and fags had fancied each other. Marlboro man was already on the prowl. And in the UK, too, United Biscuits took a tilt at Imperial Tobacco only to lose out to Lord Hanson.

In 1988 KKR's strike on Nabisco astonished even Wall Street. At $20bn, it was nearly twice the size of the biggest takeover to date: the $12bn oil bid by Chevron for Gulf. And with the failure of Jimmy Goldsmith's bid for British American Tobacco a year later, it is also still the biggest completed leveraged buyout in history.

And so it might remain, as for KKR it was hardly a success. The bidders paid top dollar and struggled to pay off the debt, especially after Philip Morris plunged the US into a cigarette price war on 'Marlboro Friday' in 1993. Two years later, the Wall Street raiders threw in the towel, selling off their last shares to help prop up Borden, another struggling US food company bought in 1994.

By then, many of Nabisco's top brands had been sold at the bankers' behest. Del Monte fruit went to Polly Peck for nearly $1bn. Shredded Wheat went to Post, part of Philip Morris' Kraft Foods, in 1993. Jacob's Crackers and Smiths Crisps were among European brands which went for $2.5bn to Danone. Now the world's sixth-biggest food producer, the French group was then a middle-ranking biscuit-maker known as BSN; it had bought HP Sauce and Lea & Perrins from Hanson in the late Eighties.

'The leading contenders for Nabisco - Philip Morris and Danone - are those who profited most from Nabisco's break-up,' a City food analyst said.

No sooner had KKR retreated, than Icahn rolled his tanks on to Nabisco's lawn. For four years, the sharp-eyed dealmaker laid siege to the firm, making upwards of $250m from his stake-building. After the group sold off Reynolds' international cigarette operations for $1.9bn to Japan Tobacco and demerged the US Winston and Salem brands last year, Icahn cashed in his chips - only to re-emerge this spring.

The tantalising attraction of Nabisco is the near half- price discount at which it trades on Wall Street for fear of the huge compensation bill it may yet face if tobacco industry prosecutors come gunning for its assets. Icahn is hardly fazed: 'I like to buy things when nobody likes them,' he is prone to say.

The tobacco worries make Marlboro man the analysts' favourite to pick up the whole of Nabisco, as Philip Morris clearly understands the risks. Danone and Cadbury's, meanwhile, who have teamed up, are more interested in cherry-picking the snacks and sweet brands.

The auction is likely to continue for weeks yet, if not months. But, with the new wave of consolidation under way, the industry is already questioning the independent survival chances of all but the very top five in world food.

With products such as Bovril, Marmite, Hellmann's Mayonnaise and Knorr soups, the US giant is firmly in the premier league of world food. Britain's Cadbury Schweppes is the latest to confirm it was among no fewer than 13 guests invited to the feast in the $20bn auction being conducted by Nabisco's investment banks, Morgan Stanley and Warburg Dillon Read. After the group sold off Reynolds' international cigarette operations for $1.9bn to Japan Tobacco and demerged the US Winston and Salem brands last year, Icahn cashed in his chips - only to re-emerge this spring. The tantalising attraction of Nabisco is the near half- price discount at which it trades on Wall Street for fear of the huge compensation bill it may yet face if tobacco industry prosecutors come gunning for its assets. fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Honour-strewn path leads straight to the exit
fields.body:
Honour-strewn path leads straight to the exit

Tales of woe at the Scotsman continue apace. Last week saw a spate of Scottish press awards handed out to journalists who have recently left the organ. One to our own Dean Nelson for Scoop of the Year for his Scottish Lobbygate story, which he broke in The Observer .

This excellent story led to him being headhunted as number three on the Scotsman, but he resigned two months later as Scotsman editor Alan Ruddock was forced out and the paper entered a downward spiral of disaffection and defection. Worse still, joint journalist of the year was Ian Bell - who had tendered his resignation from the Scotsman a full two hours before the awards ceremony.

In the meantime, the Scotsman 's chief competitor, the Herald, has made hay from the misfortunes of its rival. Its latest advertising campaign, an enormous poster featuring Scotsman editor-in-chief Andrew Neil's visage bears the simple legend: 'Buy the Herald '. The latest poster site to be occupied by this cheeky stunt is right outside the Scotsman 's headquarters.

Curse of the celebrity-stalker

Maybe one of the reasons Rebekah Wade (see main piece) has been drafted in to the News of the World is to halt the run of ludicrous 'stories' by its showbiz staff. These included the stunning 'I was in the same room as George Clooney and he spoke to me' shocker.

However, this particular kind of non-event journalism is now infecting the whole of News International, including the Times, whose Times 2 section last Friday featured a frightening photo of a gurning Hillary Clinton standing uneasily alongside a smug Joanna Coles, who looks for all the world like the sort of celebrity-stalker who forces B-list celebs to have their photos taken with her.

Greater horrors await the reader, with a full two-page account of the canapés, floral arrangements and boring cab rides which precede Hillary's eventual appearance at a fundraising benefit - though a picture-editing mistake means that one page appears without a single photo of Joanna herself.

Although Jojo, previously famous for having a baby and being courted by Camille Paglia (the veracity of the latter incident remains unclear - the former is well documented in a book), mithers on at some length about drinking champagne and stuffing her face, it is undetectable from the article whether she actually spoke to Candidate Clinton in person.

To help us out with this there is a lavishly illustrated photo-story of the two sharing a joke captioned: 'So tell me, Hillary, I'm a newcomer to New York, just like you. How do you feel it has changed you?' 'Well, Joanna, I wear a lot of black and talk much faster,' says a tight-lipped Hillary Clinton, wearing a conspicuously turquoise trouser suit.

Cheap at the price

We leaarn that Charles Saatchi has 'splashed' £5,000 on a Freddy Gore painting in the Royal Academy summer exhibition. This particular work is an exact copy of the front page of an edition of the Evening Standard featuring an article about the war in Kosovo.

This breaks even Associated Newspapers' pound-a-word freelance rates. If Mr Saatchi would like to consider an array of old media diaries, the prices are really very reasonable.

webTitle: German-packaged sun will still be cheap and cheeful

fields.headline: German-packaged sun will still be cheap and cheeful
fields.standfirst: Despite upheavals among the tour operators, holidays will remain the same
fields.trailText: Despite upheavals among the tour operators, holidays will remain the same
fields.body:
Don't panic, don't panic. The Germans are about to buy our entire package holiday business - well, almost - but there is no reason for any jokes about beach towels or tin hats.

Not a lot will change under the mass-market sun. Foreign tourists of different nationalities will mix as poorly as they have always done in resorts where they share hotels and sand. And German holidaymakers will still shun the sardine-style charter flights and grotty accommodation that Brits often put up with for the sake of a bargain, as they have always done.

The most important point industry experts were making last week is that they do not expect prices for UK holidaymakers to rise; nor will familiar brand names disappear. Michael East, of industry consultancy Eastcastle, said UK tour operators' programmes were already fixed for next winter and summer. Beyond that, he did not expect the British consumer to notice any difference.

East also argued that the gap between what Germans and Britons pay for their package holidays and the quality of the products they buy are a lot closer that they used to be. Research by Mintel estimates the average price paid in the UK at around £360, compared with a cost of around £400 in Germany, but for the bargain week on the Spanish Costas, the British pay even less.

Klaus Hildebrandt, of German trade newspaper FVW , disagreed: 'The German package is much more a quality holiday. There is a focus on prices but not so much, and we do not have the big discounting on the high street. Travel agents are not allowed to discount holiday prices.

'Germans often go to different resorts and focus on four- or five-star accommodation. And our charter airlines are comparable in quality to the scheduled airlines like Lufthansa; they are better than many national airlines.'

Whatever their disagreement, no one would argue that the events of the past 10 days have been anything other than mindboggling.

Thomson Holidays, which was floated off by its Canadian parent almost two years ago, has agreed to be taken over by Germany's leading leisure firm, Preussag, for £1.8 billion.

There are strong hints that German number two C&N, which had only just persuaded Thomson to the negotiating table when Preussag barged in, will now try to buy Britain's second-placed Airtours as an excellent consolation prize. Airtours itself is close to buying a stake in Germany's third-largest tour operator, LTU. And it does not stop there. Preussag has no chance of its acquisition being approved by the European Commission unless it disposes of its subsidiary - the UK market's number three and the most famous name in travel, Thomas Cook.

Carlson of the US owns 22 per cent of Thomas Cook, and is likely to increase that, but also to bring in a European partner as part-owner in due course. Swiss company Kuoni, which failed to merge with UK number four First Choice last year, is the word on the street, but Thomas Cook is a real prize, and Carlson may consider a variety of offers before it decides on a fellow stakeholder.

And at the same time as Preussag and Thomson dropped their bombshell on the market, First Choice announced it had sold a 20 per cent stake to US cruiseline Royal Caribbean for £200 million. Peter Long, chief executive of First Choice, said last week: 'There are lots of jokes about the Germans taking over the industry. But the UK's Vodafone took over Germany's Mannesman in the mobile phone sector. Business is business.'

Long says prices for UK consumers will not rise. The buying power - in terms of aircraft fuel and hotel beds - of the combined Preussag and Thomson will make the business more efficient and more powerful.

But Long believes competition in the UK industry will remain fierce. 'In our industry, if it ever gets cosy, some company will always break ranks [and slash prices]. The consumer is extremely price-conscious, and there will always be aggressive competition.' First Choice is now looking for its own acquisitions in France, Spain and Italy.

Charles Gurassa, chief executive of Thomson, told the Travel Trade Gazette last week that UK prices would not rise despite the fact that German holidaymakers traditionally pay higher rates for their packages and demand higher quality. He said German consumers preferred to pay extra for four-star accommodation, while the British were happy with two or three star and a lower price.

Industry insiders told The Observer that Gurassa would join the board of directors of Preussag, and the UK operation would be given a great degree of autonomy by its German owners - greater than was the case for Thomas Cook. Preussag chief executive Michael Frenzel is, said by sources to be impressed with Gurassa and to want him to continue implementing the financial recovery strategy that he drew up after taking the post late last year. Another case of change but no change.

And of the holiday market in general, even the Consumers' Association, which has been a fierce critic of the UK package holiday industry during the Nineties, would only cautiously say it was 'anxious' about the future and that prices 'could go either way'.

So should you book that break now? Apparently your guess is as good as anybody's.

fields.headline: Cold comfort merger
fields.standfirst: Heather Connon on a frosty reception for the Iceland/ Booker deal
fields.trailText: There were two indisputable facts in last week's announcement of a merger between Iceland, the frozen food retailer, and cash and carry group Booker. The two companies are complete, according to Iceland chief executive Malcolm Walker, complementary and combined will create a unique business.
fields.body:
There were two indisputable facts in last week's announcement of a merger between Iceland, the frozen food retailer, and cash and carry group Booker. The two companies are complete, according to Iceland chief executive Malcolm Walker, complementary and combined will create a unique business.

The City agreed, but not in quite the way Walker intended. The only reason it will be unique is because no-one else would dream of putting two such businesses together.

The concern is understandable. Iceland has only just started to win over the doubters through a combination of strong growth - sales have risen by 30 per cent in the past three years - savvy marketing over high-profile issues such as genetically modified foods, and some nimble footwork on e-commerce. Its shares have risen almost twice as fast as the market over the past three years, despite the poor retail climate.

Booker, by contrast, has been a disaster. As Walker himself points out, like-for-like sales at its cash-and-carry outlets have been static for five years, while disastrous diversifications and ill-fated acquisitions sent it running to its bankers. Even after Iceland's bid, its shares are still less than a third of their peak.

Two other retailers - Budgens and Somerfield - took a look then walked away, albeit before new chief executive Stuart Rose had taken it in hand. Yet their supermarket businesses have far more overlap with Booker's cash-and-carry range than Iceland does.

Walker dismisses such reservations. Both Booker and Iceland depend on giving customers what they want. Iceland, as its sales record shows, is adept at doing that. It will use those skills to get Booker's sales moving ahead again.

Rose made his reputation by revitalising Dorothy Perkins when many had given it up for dead. He then gave Argos such credibility that Great Universal Stores was forced to pay more than anyone expected to acquire it. If anyone can get Booker's sales moving, surely he can.

'He needs our machine to help him do it,' said Walker. But the benefits that he lists from putting the two companies together sound at best unexciting and at worst unconvincing.

Iceland can use Booker's buying power to source the grocery and household ranges carried in its Iceland Extra chain And it can add Booker's catering products to the frozen foods supplied to the catering trade by its Woodwards business. But Walker admits that the benefit of the former will not be great and, with annual sales from Woodwards just £90 million from last year's total of £1.9 billion, the potential there looks limited too.

In total, Iceland is promising £50m of savings and synergy benefits - just under half from combined buying, £13m from the trading benefits, and the remainder from cutting duplicated costs.

On the Booker side, Iceland's frozen food could help to fill the 25 per cent surplus space in branches. But the key, according to Walker, is winning back customers: half of Britain's 60,000 nursing homes buy from Booker - but they only buy 30 per cent of what they need because it does not stock the other 70 per cent. 'They have lost a lot of customers.'

So have corner shops. According to Verdict Research, the number of corner shops in the country has fallen 15 per cent, to just under 120,000, since 1990. Their sales over that period have risen by just 8 per cent, well behind inflation, while high street and out-of-town stores have grown by 35 per cent and 144 per cent respectively.

Walker denies that this is the key reason for Booker's problems. He blames previous management for neglecting the cash-and-carry business while it invested in activities such as salmon and turkey farming. Management's attention was diverted by difficulties in these businesses, while the acquisition of rival wholesaler Nurdin & Peacock proved a disaster.

Verdict believes that prospects for corner shops, and their cash-and-carry suppliers, are brighter than they have been for years. Shoppers increasingly want good local shops to save them the hassle of driving to the supermarket and standing in the check-out queue. Internet shopping could accelerate that as we move to buying some of shopping online, but use local suppliers for milk, fresh foods and other regular purchases.

But Iceland and Booker say nothing about the health of the corner shop. Nor, indeed, do they make much of the Internet, despite Iceland's status as the leading British e-tailer. This may be a sensible omission. Investors are increasingly sceptical of companies which promise great things from their Internet strategies. Although there does seem to be some scope for Iceland to use Booker's depots for its home shopping service, it would be unwise to place too much emphasis on that until it is clear how the electronic market place is moving.

There was some surprise at the fact that Walker will become non-executive chairman of the combined group next year. Only 54, he is the driving force behind Iceland's success, but says he wants a new challenge and finds the day-to-day running of Iceland 'mundane'. That will leave the field clear for Rose, who will be chief executive of the combined group.

'Iceland is known as a pure, clear focused business which knows what it is doing,' said Walker. 'This takes it into another division. But nothing will change. It will do as well in the future as it has in the past - or better.'

Shareholders who have watched deals such as Somerfield's takeover of Kwik Save or Bookers of Nurdin & Peacock unravel - despite more obvious synergies - are crossing their fingers and hoping this deal will live up to its promise.
