Only 54, he is the driving force behind Iceland's success, but says he wants a new challenge and finds the day-to-day running of Iceland 'mundane'. That will leave the field clear for Rose, who will be chief executive of the combined group. 'Iceland is known as a pure, clear focused business which knows what it is doing,' said Walker. 'This takes it into another division. But nothing will change. It will do as well in the future as it has in the past - or better.' Shareholders who have watched deals such as Somerfield's takeover of Kwik Save or Bookers of Nurdin & Peacock unravel - despite more obvious synergies - are crossing their fingers and hoping this deal will live up to its promise.

fields.headline: Piazza to go - £90m
fields.trailText: Jugglers beware. The Covent Garden Piazza, home to street entertainers and boutiques, has a new landlord.
fields.body:
Jugglers beware. The Covent Garden Piazza, home to street entertainers and boutiques, has a new landlord.

Scottish Widows exchanged contracts last Friday to buy the former central London fruit and vegetable market for £90 million. The deal is part of a deal in which the insurer will snap up offices, industrial estates and shops worth close to £750m from Dutch insurer Aegon.

If the deal is completed, it will be the UK's biggest real estate portfolio swap.

Scottish Widows beat competition from all over the world for the Piazza, a trophy asset. Known rival bidders included the secretive Barclay Brothers and acquisitive property company Marylebone Warwick Balfour, which has just taken over Liberty's.

The site has had many owners in the past 200-years, including the Catholic church, the Duke of Bedford and the Beecham family, founders of what is now GlaxoSmithKline.

It was home to the fruit and vegetable market until the Seventies. After an attempt to turn the Piazza into offices was thwarted, it has flourished as a niche shopping venue. Rents are among the highest in the country.

Scottish Widows, prom-pted by the success of the Covent Garden Soup Company, is expected to capitalise on the Piazza brand and sell goods under that banner.

fields.headline: Appliance of gene science
fields.standfirst: The decoding of DNA will bring better treatments - and altered routes of profit for drugs firms
fields.trailText: The decoding of DNA will bring better treatments - and altered routes of profit for drugs firms
fields.body:
Thalidomide, the drug whose side effects shocked the world in the Sixties, could be about to make a commercial comeback.

The medicine, originally used as a sedative, was withdrawn after it was discovered to cause severe malformations in unborn babies.

In 1998, it was made available for the treatment of leprosy. But soon its use could expand as an effective and potentially lucrative treatment for cancer. This time it will be safe.

The re-emergence of Thalidomide is perhaps the most emotive example of a trend set to soar in coming years - re-evaluating previously harmful or ineffective drugs and reapplying them.

The drugs could be used for different purposes from those originally intended - and all at low cost to pharmaceuticals companies with large 'back-catalogues'.

The process will be made possible by pharmacogenetics - applying the fast-evolving knowledge of genetic processes in drug development to the understanding of the human genome.

But the possibilities are more wide-ranging than re-introducing old treatments. Scientists are pointing to a future where the discovery of new genetic targets for drugs, and their effectiveness rates and side effects, can be understood more precisely than hitherto imaginable.

In a few weeks' time the entire human genome - constructed of two coded spirals of DNA made up of 3 billion pairs of characters, or 'bases' - will be decoded and placed in the public domain.

Biotechnology companies are already working to identify which clusters along the genome form genes. The genes create proteins which instruct cells to carry out functions in our bodies.

For biotech and pharmaceuticals companies, the key is identifying the genes that cause disease and determine our response to medicines.

More than 99 per cent of the genome is identical from one human to another. But glitches in our genetic codes will stand out. These are made up of single base pairs called single nucleotide polymorphisms, or 'snips'.

Some snips cause disease and some determine our reaction to medicines. These can be identified and become 'targets' for drug treatments.

This could have a radical impact on the time and cost of bringing new drugs to market. In 1998 the period between pre-clinical trials and launch was estimated as nine years - by 2008 it could be six years. This would have huge implications for the research and development operations of drugs giants such as Glaxo Wellcome, which spends £1.3 billion a year on R&D.

Drugs trials go through four stages. They are initially tested on animals; then a three-phase 'clinical' process begins. In Phase I they are tested for safety on healthy people. In Phase II they are tested for safety and efficacy on a wider group of patients. In Phase III they are tested for safety and efficacy on a group of thousands of patients.

As Professor Richard Weinshilboum of the US Mayo Clinic, who has done pioneering genetic work into childhood leukaemia, says: 'There is a simple paradigm in all drug development. At one end of the spectrum you want to minimise toxicity. At the other end you want to maximise efficacy.' Thalidomide, for example, failed because while it may have been effective, it was toxic.

Drugs companies claim pharmacogenetics will enable them to identify this balance more efficiently in future, while slashing time and costs.

Dr Ian Purvis of Glaxo Wellcome says: 'Identification of targets, and side effects of treatments, are fundamental parts of the research process. The impact of genetics is incredibly important.'

This case was put by a Glaxo Wellcome scientist, Professor Allen Roses, in medical journal the Lancet last month. He explained that drugs used to be developed by identifying physical signs of disease - phenotypes - and working backwards to produce a treatment. This was then trialled among patients with that phenotype. Now, he says, 'snip maps' have been developed, charting the hundreds of thousands of snips which have so far been discovered, and their meaning. A patient's genetic information can be scanned for snips, and their response to a drug predicted.

This has big implications for R&D. The cost and size of Phase III trials can be reduced because companies could identify which patients responded in earlier phases, screen their genotypes and recruit only those patients with appropriate similar profiles. The same applies for testing for side effects.

The vision of tailoring drugs individually is beguiling. However, there are several hurdles. First, genetics will make drug discovery more complicated; this impacts on cost, and the timescale in which they can be delivered is unclear.

For example, says Weinshilboum, ethnic groups with different genotypes may respond differently to drugs.

At one level these are fairly crude distinctions. While researching drugs for leukaemia, he found that polymorphisms in Asian people made them less able to metabolise the drug, so they required higher doses. But the dosage for Asians would be harmful or fatal to a European, who would metabolise the drug more quickly.

Some biotechnology companies are sceptical about the impact of pharmacogenetics on trials. Its most useful application will be, they argue, in the initial discovery of drugs. Biotechnology companies may have a vested interest here - drug discovery is where they focus their energies.

Dr Raj Parekh of biotech company Oxford Glycosciences believes this is only the tip of the iceberg. The complexity will increase all the time, he says. 'We know that different racial groups have different genotypes. But in Europe and America there has been such interbreeding that the genetic complexity will threaten the economics of trialling.'

Parakh points out that if, in a trial, five polymorphisms underlying a disease were identified, that would increase the sample from, say, 1,000 patients to 120,000.

This leads to another problem - the fragmentation of diseases and patient populations. Nick Edwards, a partner at Andersen Consulting, says these dynamics could change our entire concept of disease. Some diseases have simple genetic causes. For example, haemophilia is identified with a single polymorphism. At the other extreme, schizophrenia could have more than 20 - indicating a class of conditions with different causes.

The promise of genetics is to increase the current 400 disease targets which make up the pharmacopoeia - or body of medicine for which treatments have been developed - to some 10,000.

But many conditions within this 10,000 will be sub-divisions of conditions we now believe to be one disease. These subsets will have smaller patient groups. So the question becomes: how many of the new targets will have genetic causes simple enough to make it worth the drugs companies' while investing in them?

The economies of scale which underpin development of blockbuster drugs such as Zantac or Losec which treat seemingly homogenous conditions will alter. Edwards believes the way forward will be to identify the conditions which can be worked on, and discard those that are not cost-effective.

But pharmaceuticals companies point out that while there may be a fragmentation in markets, the value of the products will increase because genetic development will make them highly effective for those they are developed to treat.

'We may lose market share, but we will be able to charge premium prices for treatments which are far more effective than medicines have been in the past,' says one senior R&D scientist.

One example of this, as ABN Amro biotechnology analyst Nick Woolfe points out, is a breast cancer treatment called Herceptin, developed by US biotech company Genentech and Roche.

The drug is aimed at women whose cancer is caused by their gene HER2 being overactive. However, only 35 per cent of women with breast cancer have this problem. Herceptin can therefore only be marketed at a third of the breast cancer population.

Herceptin is estimated to have been prescribed to 15 per cent of those women with breast cancer caused by the HER2 gene - a high penetration rate compared with the 5 per cent sale achieved by non genetically targeted drugs. Nevertheless, Herceptin has annual sales of around $200m, making it a blockbuster seller, albeit by a different route.

So, although the revenues from drug development are likely to be more narrowly based than in the past, companies can offset high-cost development with high prices. Conversely, they can find new applications, and new patient populations for old drugs at negligible cost.

webTitle: The loafer's guide to popular culture

fields.headline: The loafer's guide to popular culture
fields.standfirst: This week: Lars von Trier
fields.trailText:
Who is he?
Denmark's nuttiest filmmaker. Oh, and Palme d'Or winner at this year's Cannes.
fields.body:
Who is he?
Denmark's nuttiest filmmaker. Oh, and Palme d'Or winner at this year's Cannes.

For what?
Dancer in the Dark, a bizarre musical starring Best Actress winner Björk as a blind Czech immigrant to the US, who goes to the gallows for a crime she didn't commit, but not before indulging in some Busby Berkeley-style song-and-dance routines.

Universally hailed as a work of genius, etc?
Not quite. While the jury obviously loved it, the critics were poleaxed, one calling it 'less Pennies From Heaven than Springtime for Hitler', while others bandied about words like 'ridiculous', 'terrible' and 'lamentable'. Meanwhile, von Trier accused Björk of being 'a mad woman' and eating her costume in a fit of rage before storming off the set. Not to be outdone, Björk summarily announced that the experience had been 'so intense' that she'd never make another film again.

Jeepers! Is this the first time old Lars has courted controversy?
Far from it. Pretty much all of von Trier's movies have trod the genius/ shite thin line: take Breaking the Waves, in which Emily Watson's simpleton prostituted herself in the belief - justified, as it turned out - that it would cure her crippled husband; The Idiots, made under the no-frills Dogme rules, which von Trier drew up (and promptly renounced by using 100 digital cameras for Dancer), in which a wacky commune faked mental illness in order to live a purer life, and indulged in real-time orgies and penetration scenes to boot; and his TV hospital soap The Kingdom, sort of ER meets Twin Peaks, in which spirits of dead girls haunted the lifts, and interns gave birth to devil-children.

So, like a former prince of Denmark, he likes to put an antic disposition on?
Something like that. He's known to get naked himself when filming nude scenes, believed when young that if household objects weren't placed in certain places there would be a nuclear holocaust, and countered a pathological fear of flying by driving down to Cannes in his VW camper van.

And for his next trick?
He's planning a 'full-on porn movie' with his Dancer in the Dark co-star Catherine Deneuve; sensibly, she's 'rewriting a few scenes before I commit'.

fields.headline: Revolt at £30bn Orange sale
fields.standfirst: Top managers threaten to quit if French win bidding  Dutch and Japanese waiting in wings
fields.trailText: Orange's senior management threatened last night to quit if, as expected, France Telecom buys the UK's third-largest mobile operator.
fields.body:
Orange's senior management threatened last night to quit if, as expected, France Telecom buys the UK's third-largest mobile operator.

Vodafone Airtouch is set to announce the disposal of Britain's third largest mobile phone operator on Tuesday in a £30 billion deal.

However, Hans Snook, Orange's chief executive - who is largely credited with building the brand - has told his French counterparts that he and his senior management will remain only if the new parent company agrees to float off its combined mobile operations and keep him at its head.

Vodafone AirTouch has been forced by the European Commission to sell Orange following its merger with Germany's Mannesmann. France Telecom was beaten by the Germans in last year's bidding for Orange.

It now leads this race against the Dutch operator KPN and MCI WorldCom of the US because it can offer Vodafone much-needed cash.

The Commission ruled that Vodafone must not interfere with Orange while it still owns the company, making it powerless to prevent Snook delivering his ultimatum and conducting his own negotiations.

But the Commission could question whether Vodafone has allowed Orange to operate independently if Snook and his team were to walk away when a sale was agreed. 'There would be a suspicion that this deal was too cosily arranged,' one City analyst said.

Late last night all three telecoms firms were attempting to iron out the legal complexities through a series of parallel negotiations. According to bankers, France Telecom chairman Michel Bon has also talked to Orange directly behind the scenes.

'Make no mistake this is not yet a done deal,' one source said.

'It is a question of whether what is written down on paper can be made to stick. Without the backing of the Orange management there will be no deal,' a banking adviser said.

Vodafone is keen to announce the sale of Orange before it unveils full year results on Tuesday. The company has lost a third of its value in recent weeks as the City worries about the high costs it will have to pay for the new third generation of mobile licences.

France Telecom is desper ate to secure Orange so it can compete with Vodafone. It is the leading mobile operator in France with 10 million subscribers, against Orange's 5.5 million in the UK. French mobile joint ventures have 4 million more in the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark, Portugal, Greece, Eastern Europe and South America.

The French have been given a period of exclusivity, which expires tonight.

This weekend, KPN and its Japanese ally NTT DoCoMo - which owns 15 per cent of the Dutch operator - were also locked in talks with bankers. 'KPN is still interested in Orange with DoCoMo as its partner,' one adviser said. 'The Japanese are huge. They have the money and they need a European footprint.'

NTT DoCoMo has 30 million mobile customers in Japan alone. It is owned by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the world's biggest phone company, and made profits last year of £2.7bn - more than Vodafone's - on turnover of £19bn.

fields.headline: Dancer's safety net
fields.trailText: deborahbull Extracted: 21:12 Status: NONE
fields.body:
deborahbull Extracted: 21:12 Status: NONE

Dancer's safety net DEBORAH Bull, principal dancer with the Royal Ballet, knew what she wanted at the age of 11. Some may call her dedicated, others ambitious; she claims she is now merely 'focused'. Surely someone with such rigid discipline is equally severe with her finances? 'I'm not actually.' She laughs and positions her legs in a way that only someone with 25 years of training and extreme agility is able to. 'I'm organised about lots of things in my life but I have a bit of a blind spot about money. I don't really check bank statements. It's partly being busy, but it's also not really wanting to know. I could not tell you what I've got in my bank account and I don't want to know. I always expect that it's going to be a dire story, so I don't look.' It's a hangover from being young and in debt, she explains. It is a myth, though, that dancers don't eat because they have no money. According to Deborah, dancers who survive on lettuce leaves do it to 'stay thin'. Not this dancer. Deborah's idea of a treat is to 'go round the corner and have a cappuccino with cake or a bagel and then look at clothes and shoe shops. Regular girly things. I love clothes.' The bank manager is unlikely to be worrying her too much at the moment. Apart from a punishing dancing schedule of principal roles, Deborah is an active member of the Arts Council and sits on boards including the South Bank Centre. She also writes and makes television and radio appearances. Deborah recognises that she has to be highly organised to hold so many positions. 'I am organised - it's down to a puritanical upbringing, I suppose. I don't like to let people down.' But, she claims, these organisational skills really do not run to personal finance, so she has an accountant. 'He invests in things for me and I'm very grateful. It has become a bit of a game in itself. You know, how much can I put in the pot? Because otherwise I would just spend it.' The puritanical upbringing she refers to was 'middle-England working class', as one of four daughters. 'The women have always managed the budget. The men would bring the money home on Fridays and give it to the wife. My mum has never been overdrawn in her life and never borrowed money. When she brought us up, what you had in your purse was what you spent.' Deborah admits that frugality has skipped a generation. 'I don't like overdrafts, but I'm perfectly happy to borrow on credit cards even when I've got the money.' She adds: 'I like to have the rainy day bit. For me, the bleakest feeling is not having something to fall back on.' The duration of a dancer's working life is bound to be uncertain. According to Deborah: 'You become less flexible, have to work harder to maintain fitness, and your injuries repair more slowly. Your attention shifts too. You become a woman in a big world, not a kid who's focused exclusively on dance. And then there's the competition. There are dancers joining the company who are 20 years younger than me. If you think how much faster sprinters are than 20 years ago, think how much higher ballet dancers jump these days. You rely on experience which they don't have yet, and that's all.' Next week: crime writer Val McDermid

Some may call her dedicated, others ambitious; she claims she is now merely 'focused'. Surely someone with such rigid discipline is equally severe with her finances? 'I'm not actually.' She laughs and positions her legs in a way that only someone with 25 years of training and extreme agility is able to. 'I'm organised about lots of things in my life but I have a bit of a blind spot about money. I don't really check bank statements. It's partly being busy, but it's also not really wanting to know. I could not tell you what I've got in my bank account and I don't want to know. I always expect that it's going to be a dire story, so I don't look.' It's a hangover from being young and in debt, she explains. It is a myth, though, that dancers don't eat because they have no money. According to Deborah, dancers who survive on lettuce leaves do it to 'stay thin'. Not this dancer. Deborah's idea of a treat is to 'go round the corner and have a cappuccino with cake or a bagel and then look at clothes and shoe shops. Regular girly things. I love clothes.' The bank manager is unlikely to be worrying her too much at the moment. Apart from a punishing dancing schedule of principal roles, Deborah is an active member of the Arts Council and sits on boards including the South Bank Centre. She also writes and makes television and radio appearances. Deborah recognises that she has to be highly organised to hold so many positions. 'I am organised - it's down to a puritanical upbringing, I suppose. I don't like to let people down.' But, she claims, these organisational skills really do not run to personal finance, so she has an accountant. 'He invests in things for me and I'm very grateful. It has become a bit of a game in itself. You know, how much can I put in the pot? Because otherwise I would just spend it.' The puritanical upbringing she refers to was 'middle-England working class', as one of four daughters. 'The women have always managed the budget. The men would bring the money home on Fridays and give it to the wife. My mum has never been overdrawn in her life and never borrowed money. When she brought us up, what you had in your purse was what you spent.' Deborah admits that frugality has skipped a generation. 'I don't like overdrafts, but I'm perfectly happy to borrow on credit cards even when I've got the money.' She adds: 'I like to have the rainy day bit. For me, the bleakest feeling is not having something to fall back on.' The duration of a dancer's working life is bound to be uncertain. According to Deborah: 'You become less flexible, have to work harder to maintain fitness, and your injuries repair more slowly. Your attention shifts too. You become a woman in a big world, not a kid who's focused exclusively on dance. And then there's the competition. There are dancers joining the company who are 20 years younger than me. If you think how much faster sprinters are than 20 years ago, think how much higher ballet dancers jump these days. You rely on experience which they don't have yet, and that's all.' Next week: crime writer Val McDermid

fields.headline: ...a drug habit
fields.trailText: A dictionary definition of a habit is something 'acquired by frequent repetition of the same act until it is almost involuntary'. One of the most cost-effective habits, on a pounds versus damage-to-health basis, is smoking. Once you are in the vice-like grip of nicotine addiction, you will be spending just £4.20 a day for 20 gaspers. It might warm your heart further to know that 80 per cent of your money will go to the Treasury, and 5 per cent of that directly to the NHS. So, when they switch on the respirator at the side of your bed, you will have paid for it yourself.
fields.body:
A dictionary definition of a habit is something 'acquired by frequent repetition of the same act until it is almost involuntary'. One of the most cost-effective habits, on a pounds versus damage-to-health basis, is smoking. Once you are in the vice-like grip of nicotine addiction, you will be spending just £4.20 a day for 20 gaspers. It might warm your heart further to know that 80 per cent of your money will go to the Treasury, and 5 per cent of that directly to the NHS. So, when they switch on the respirator at the side of your bed, you will have paid for it yourself.

Illegal drugs are not necessarily more habit-forming. Cocaine is psychologically addictive, but has few withdrawal symptoms. A gram costs £50 and a committed user might snort more than one per day. Crack is chronically addictive, but the difference is that addicts will smoke as many rocks (at £20 each) as they can buy.

However, the defining habit-forming drug is heroin. Such habits need to be fed by smoking or injecting the drug. Chasing the dragon may not cost much at first (kitchen foil, £1.50; lighter, £1; £20 bag of heroin per week), but the law of diminishing returns is harshly applied.

Heroin is cheaper in cities such as London and Liverpool, where £5 bags are available. Prices depend on supply, so they may fluctuate, but trends suggest that heroin is becoming ever cheaper: in the 50s, William Burroughs would pay $2 for a grain containing two hits ($14, or £9 in today's money). A full-blown intravenous habit can cost in the region of £20,000 annually.

The cost of a habit can become a life-or-death equation. In 1997, there were 255 heroin-related deaths - but of Britain's one in four smoking adults, 120,000 will die of a smoking-related disease every year.

If you wish to straighten yourself out, there are three options. Go it alone, go to a private clinic, or get on to a detox scheme. The first requires a will of iron, the second £2,000 per week, while your fellow taxpayers chip in for the third. However, as Charlie Parker noted: 'They can take it out of your body, but they can't take it out of your mind.'

Annual cost of a drug habit
Nicotine £1,500
(£1,200 of which goes to the government)
Cocaine £18,000
Crack no upper limit Heroin £1,000 to £20,000
Rehab up to £30,000

fields.headline: Net phone, net profit
fields.standfirst: You need never miss a deal because you're away from base.  David Prosser on the wonder of Wap phones
fields.trailText: The problem with online share dealing is that you need to be at your personal computer to trade. If you're away from base, you will often miss out on worthwhile sales and purchases.
fields.body:
The problem with online share dealing is that you need to be at your personal computer to trade. If you're away from base, you will often miss out on worthwhile sales and purchases.

Soon that problem will be solved, and we will be able to deal from sun-drenched holiday beaches, from parked cars or restaurants using a new mobile phone system linked to the Internet.

An online stockbroker, mybroker, launched the UK's first mobile phone share-dealing service last month, and its rivals are planning to follow suit soon. Mybroker's new wireless application protocol, or Wap-based, phone service offers share price information and trading facilities.

What is Wap?

For the uninitiated, Wap is a technical standard which allows users of devices such as mobile phones, personal organisers and pagers to view Internet content on the screens of their handsets, and to send data.

Mybroker's James Bateman says: 'If you're trading from home and spend half the day out, you'll still be able to deal.'

The firm has priced its Wap share-dealing services on the same basis as its online broking. Investors will pay a flat £25 fee on each trade. The mobile phone facility is, however, an adjunct to mybroker's Internet offering, not an alternative. You must have an online account in order to use its Wap service.

Effectively, a Wap-equipped phone is just another way to access mybroker's online service.

In addition to share trading, mybroker is also offering real-time share price information to Wap-equipped customers. Investors can choose up to 100 stocks on which to receive live prices by phone, though the selection has to be made through your PC.

Wap customers will also have access to price information on all other London-quoted shares, with time delays of up to 10 minutes. Both services are free, although mybroker levies an inactivity fee of £10 on customers who haven't placed a trade for more than a month.

At first sight, this pricing looks good value, but investors who like the idea of mobile phone-based dealing should remember that there will be other costs. First, to use Wap-based services, you need a Wap-equipped hand set. So far, there are only two models on the market, from Nokia and Motorola, both costing more than £100. But Ericsson is due to launch its Wap phones soon, and, as other providers follow later this year, prices should come down.

Users will also need a Wap service provider. BT Cellnet, Vodafone and Orange all now offer their network users connection to the Internet, though the mybroker service is available only to BT Cellnet customers. Its line rental starts at £17.50 a month.

Then there's the cost of calls. All the time you're online through your phone, you're stacking up charges of 5p a minute on BT Cellnet and Orange, and the standard mobile rates on Vodafone.

Price competition on Wap charges is hotting up. BT Cellnet is in the process of launching cheaper tariffs, but users will have to pay for airtime when they're actually only waiting for data to download.

All these costs will mount up quickly, and potential mybroker Wap customers will need to ask themselves if they are worthwhile.

No need to feel insecure

Dealing through your mobile phone will take some getting used to.

For a start, tapping instructions into your phone is bound to take more time than trading through a computer. Bateman admits: 'You will find it a little bit more fiddly,' though he adds: 'It's not that tricky.'

On the other hand, he says, investors need not worry about another potential concern; the security aspects of Wap-based trading. They are just as secure as PC-based online services, he insists. 'Investors need a user name and password to access their accounts, and only users will know these.'

That aside though, experienced Internet users will almost certainly find Wap services, including the mybroker offering, disappointing. The Internet content is stripped down to basic text before it is transmitted to your mobile, so don't expect anything jazzy. This is done so that data loads onto your phone more quickly, but even so, the process can be frustratingly slow.

Mybroker's site will take a few minutes to download to your phone, during which time you're paying call charges, even though it should only take 10 seconds or so to place a trade.

The good news is that changes to battery and screen technology are near, which should improve the quality of these services.

And the UK's system of mobile phone networks is due to be upgraded in 2002, when the industry will switch to the universal mobile telephone system.

This should make the access to data hundreds of times quicker than with the current system, allowing mobile phone users to reach content that resembles much more closely the Internet as we are now used to seeing it.

In the meantime, mybroker is plotting to upgrade its Wap-based service. The company is a subsidiary of Options Direct, a stockbroker which specialises in giv ing private investors access to the derivatives market, and traded option dealing should be available by mobile phone soon.

Look out, too, for improved company research facilities. Several firms already offer excellent research and data to Wap- users. Digitallook.com carries almost as much detail as is available from the respected Hemmington Scott Internet-based service. Rival TD Waterhouse also offers a useful Wap information service.

This article is from the June issue of Money Observer, which is on sale at newsagents, price £3.50. For 12 issues at £31.97, a saving of £10, call 0870 870 1324 and quote reference MYFG001.

fields.headline: Even Buffett can't second-guess hi-techs
fields.trailText: When a crop of new technology companies burst into the Ftse 100 index in March, there were fears that they would distort the index and make it too volatile to be useful as a benchmark for the market's performance.
fields.body:
When a crop of new technology companies burst into the Ftse 100 index in March, there were fears that they would distort the index and make it too volatile to be useful as a benchmark for the market's performance.

Some Ftse constituents are certainly very volatile. Around a dozen have dropped by 30 per cent or more in the past three months, including new entrants such as Baltimore Technologies, Psion and Kingston Communications - the last two face expulsion next month. But a similar number have risen by 30 per cent or more over the same period, including such stalwarts as Kingfisher, Abbey National and GlaxoWellcome. The Ftse 100 Index, however, has fallen just 1 per cent over that period.

Despite complaints, the index reflects what is happening in the market. Investors have not stopped buying shares; they're simply buying different ones. Next month's changes are likely to show that investors are thinking again about new- and old-economy values.

There has been a dramatic shift in sentiment against technology stocks. The Techmark index has halved from its March peak and is now around the level of last November. Baltimore, Bookham and the rest are unlikely to make profits for some years yet: the challenge is assessing how much, they will be making in 10 years' time. Even Warren Buffett, dubbed the world's most successful investor, baulks at this.

Savvas Savouri, equity strategist at Commerzbank, is no braver, but thinks it helps to split technology stocks into four categories. First come the consumer websites - and the troubles of boo.com, lastminute and theStreet show how hard it is to be successful in this area. Then there are hardware suppliers such as Compel, Logica and London Bridge. Business flows here will be unpredictable, as the Millennium bug showed. Third come the software experts, such as Baltimore, ARM and Psion. Here you are buying into the expertise of a small team, hoping they can thwart the competition, and that the market will not change direction. Even the experts find that difficult.

Savouri's final category is suppliers of telecoms services and equipment, where competition is fierce but the market is growing fast enough to compensate for pricing pressure. No one knows how long that will continue. More seriously, the sell-off in technology stocks now seems to have gained a momentum of its own. It would be rash to buy until there is evidence that the floor has been reached.

In the old economy, there are at least profits against which share prices can be assessed. Some of these prices do look low. But in some traditional areas - retailing, food manufacturing, water and electricity, for example - many established players are battling against overcapacity and falling prices. Look for companies with a competitive advantage, sound management and a clear strategy. It is no coincidence that Boots, Shell and Abbey National have all performed well recently.

fields.headline: web watch
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson has tried planes and trains; now he is turning his attention to automobiles, with the launch of a new sales website, www.virgin.com/cars .
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson has tried planes and trains; now he is turning his attention to automobiles, with the launch of a new sales website, www.virgin.com/cars .

Branson and the site's other co-founders, Ian Lancaster and Quentin Wilson (of BBC's Top Gear) claim the company will revolutionise car buying, making it clear, straightforward and even fun. By offering an average discount of 17 per cent off UK prices, and a servicing and warranty repair service that is particularly likely to appeal to women, Virgincars aims to become the UK's biggest car retailer, with 24,000 sales in the first year.

It is already possible to buy cars at massive discounts to the recommended UK prices through the Which? website www.carbusters.com, and www.oneswoop.com. So how do the sites compare? It is difficult to compare on a like-for-like basis (prices are shown in the table below), because each site obtains cars from different outlets in different countries, and may not be able to provide the precise model you are looking for.

Also, Virgin includes all 'on the road' costs, including registration, road tax, delivery, and even a tank of petrol. Carbusters includes 'on the road' costs, but excludes a £200 admin fee.

Oneswoop does not include any 'on the road' costs in its initial indicative price, and therefore looks much cheaper. Even its indicative 'on the road' price (described on the site as the Oneswoop guideline price) is an average of prices charged by different sources around Europe for cars closest to your specification. To get a final 'on the road' quote for the car you want to buy from Oneswoop or Carbusters, you pay a £10 fee. Virgin charges nothing. And while Oneswoop requires payment in euros, Virgin and Carbusters take sterling.

Each site offers different ranges and models. Virgin currently offers cars from 14 manufacturers, and lists most ranges and models, although many were not available on the days we visited the site. Oneswoop misses out on stalwarts like Renault, Toyota and Fiat but did offer a lot of ranges and models for the 10 makers that it does sell. Carbusters was probably the most disappointing. Although it offers 13 marques, its choice of ranges is limited. Its Ford offering, for example, is limited to Focus, Puma and Fiesta.

However, Virgin's extra services are likely to be the biggest winning factor. All cars sold by Virgin Cars are covered for three years by its servicing offer - Virgin Cars @ Your Service. Owners simply call the service with their registration number, and Virgin will identify which service the car needs and transfer the owner to the Virgin Cars Service Centre to fix a price for the work and arrange a date for the car to be picked up.

James Pillar, a spokesman for Virgin Cars, says a bulk servicing deal will result in prices 15 per cent lower than standard garage charges.

But the deciding factor could be Virgin's offer to buy your existing car, provided it is less than five years old and has less than 60,000 miles on the clock. The site includes a 'used price indicator', and Virgin will ask you to pay for an AA check costing £59 if you decide to go ahead.

The only way a traditional dealer can tempt you across his threshold now is with the offer of a test drive, but Pillar says Virgin Cars even plans to spoil that ploy. 'We hope to offer a range of the most popular cars in the next few months so that people can test drive through Virgin as well.'

fields.headline: Pig's ear of camper claim
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Last September our camper van was broken into and thousands of pounds worth of walking and climbing equipment was stolen. Our insurance with Direct Insurance Centre covered the contents of the van up to a limit of £2,000, so we claimed for this. The insurers sent a sympathetic assessor, who agreed that the value of equipment stolen exceeded £2,000, and submitted his report to the insurer.
fields.body:
Last September our camper van was broken into and thousands of pounds worth of walking and climbing equipment was stolen. Our insurance with Direct Insurance Centre covered the contents of the van up to a limit of £2,000, so we claimed for this. The insurers sent a sympathetic assessor, who agreed that the value of equipment stolen exceeded £2,000, and submitted his report to the insurer.

In January the insurer finally offered us £1,960, minus an excess of £100. I accepted the settlement but objected to the excess, since we had already paid a £50 excess to have the windows of the camper van repaired, and my reading of the policy was that the excess should be £100 in total.

The insurers agreed and asked for proof of payment of the excess, which I sent last February. I have heard nothing since. Is there anything I can do about this? I feel I ought to be able to charge interest on the amount offered in January.

PR
Buxton

Direct Insurance Centre admits that there has been a breakdown in communication between itself and the loss adjuster.

The settlement cheque was originally raised in February, but held up because the insurer says it thought it ought to be paying you £50 more. Instead of coming back corrected, the cheque went into limbo. Your complaints to the loss adjuster were not passed on to the insurance company, which says it is disappointed it was not given the opportunity to sort this out sooner.

Direct Insurance Centre admits to making a pig's ear of your claim, and to causing unnecessary delays. It has confirmed your claim for the contents of the caravan at £1,983, deducted the correct excess of £50 and sent you a cheque for £1,933. On further thought, the company agreed to waive this half of the excess and forwarded another cheque for £50.

Term insurance: Can we opt out?

We are in our third year of a fixed-term mortgage with Nationwide Building Society. As part of the agreement, we were obliged to take buildings and contents insurance with the company. We believed this was for the first year only. This year's quote looked expensive. We found an alternative which was £10 a month cheaper. Nationwide said we had to accept their quote while we were under the fixed term.

I was told there was no independent ombudsman to whom we could write; we could only appeal to Nationwide. Does this mean Nationwide can charge whatever it likes for insurance for three years?

GH-R

The mortgage agreement you signed said you were committed to Nationwide's house insurance for the full five-year fixed term, with no mention of any limits on how premiums might rise. But you do have the right to take your complaint to the Building Societies Ombudsman (even though the issue is house insurance, the policy was sold by a building society). Telephone: 0207 931 0044.

Isas after death: probate rules

My wife and I each have cash Isas and we are both over 80. If I die before her, will my wife need probate to withdraw my Isa?

DL
Harrogate

It depends how much is in the account when you die. Isa providers set their own limits - around £15,000 - below which you do not need probate for a cash Isa; you just complete a statutory declaration form. To access the money, she will have to close the Isa and transfer the proceeds to her name, unless she uses the money to pay for funeral expenses, probate fees or inheritance tax, which can be paid direct.

It is different if the Isa contained shares. Then probate is required if the person's whole estate, including savings, life insurance and assets, totals more than £5,000.

webTitle: We can pay the bills and eat - that's it

fields.headline: We can pay the bills and eat - that's it
fields.standfirst: Mounting debts, three children and a mortgage make this family fearful about the future. What can be done, they ask  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText:
Vital statistics
Caroline Hooley
fields.body:
Vital statistics
Caroline Hooley

AGE: 41

LIVES IN: Winchester

OCCUPATION: Casework supervisor

EARNS: £15,000

MORTGAGE: £52,000

DEBTS: Overdraft and student loan

INVESTMENTS: None

PENSIONS: None

AIMS: To plan for the future while surviving now

Caroline Hooley and Robert Larter have no credit cards, no store cards and not even a cheque guarantee card. They do not dare because, with the expense of three children - Joe, aged 14, Charlotte, 13, and William, 9 - they find it difficult keeping track of where their money is going.

Their overdraft has soared from £500 to £2,000 in the past few months - mainly because their car needed repairs to get through its MoT test - and the debt is getting larger. 'Every month we fall further behind,' says Caroline. They have even cashed in two endowment policies 'to keep the wolf from the door when we were desperate'.

Their bank has offered them a loan to replace their overdraft at a lower rate of interest but Caroline regards this as expensive because they would have to repay a higher amount each month.

A few years ago, they seemed to be getting straight. 'A small inheritance in 1998 enabled us to clear 10 years' accumulated debts as well as make some improvements to the house.'

But their income dropped last year when Robert, a printer, went part-time so that he could take a two-year pre-university course. He now earns £10,000 working three days a week and, when the course ends, would like to go to university, perhaps part-time. By then he will be 45, and Caroline is worried about how they would cope. 'The change to our finances has already been a big shock.'

Caroline started a post-graduate teaching course but changed her mind, and kept her £3,000 student loan to bail them out of a crisis. 'I have no regrets about starting the course, or stopping it - only the loan,' she says. The first repayment, about £40 a month, is due now, but she is not sure whether the money has left her current account.

Debt problems are usual among their friends. 'Many have between £15,000 and £20,000 in credit card debt and keep remortgaging to pay it off.' The couple started an endowment mortgage in 1991, and their house is now worth about £120,000, but Caroline is worried in case they have to increase their endowment payments if, when the policy pays out, the sum is too small to settle what they owe.

'There is nothing to spare,' she says. 'We can pay the bills and eat, and that is about it.'

Robert was sold a pension by a salesman from Confederation Life, now Sun Life of Canada, but Caroline admits: 'We are very ignorant about it. Both he and his boss were paying in £25 a month when he worked full time, but I assume there is less going in now.'

She finds it hard to worry about pensions. 'I don't pay into the local government scheme because I don't see how we could afford it now.'

But she wants to put their finances on a firmer footing: 'Our financial ignorance has limited our choices, and we have been at the mercy of salespeople who did not have our financial best interests at heart,' she adds.

Adviser 1: Sophie Brookes

The debts faced by Caroline and Robert are minimal, but they do need to start tracking their money properly and decide their priorities.

First, they must produce a household budget so that they can work out where their money is going, and check if they have made adjustments since Robert cut his working hours.

Caroline should defer repayments on her student loan - I am sure her salary is low enough for her to qualify for this.

The couple must find out why they are overdrawn. If it is because they are living beyond their means, they need to look for cuts in spending. If it is because, for example, the mortgage payments go out the day before they get paid, they can change their standing order. Whatever the answer, they need to start reducing the overdraft.

The bank loan will cost more each month, which increases their outgoings, so they should discuss with the bank how they can reduce the overdraft, perhaps making repayments at a level they can afford. If their approaches to the bank fail, they may need to open an instant access account elsewhere to take their wages, and then negotiate with the bank, safely knowing they have control of their salaries.

They should look at saving with a credit union for the cash they need for emergencies and Christmas spending, so that they do not miss the overdraft so much. Realistically, it is going to be difficult for Robert to go into full-time education. Apart from the extra loans they would have to pay back, their household income would fall.

They may not want to hear this, but it may be that they need to increase their income. Perhaps Robert will have to look at working full-time again. One possibility would be to get a lodger. Caroline refers to friends who keep remortgaging and paying off their debts: this does not mean that it is a good idea.

Sophie Brookes is development officer with National Debtline, run by the Birmingham Settlement.

Adviser 2: Ian Millward

Pensions should be an absolute priority at their ages, so they should at least think about when and how they can contribute.

As a minimum they should contact Sun Life of Canada to confirm that Robert's contribution is still £25 a month; get a current valuation; and check which fund he is paying in to. When he has more money, he could either top up his monthly payments or consider another firm.

A perk of local government work is the quality of the pension scheme, so Caroline ignores that at her peril. Perhaps they should release some equity from their home to help while Robert is studying.

Ian Millward works for Bath-based financial adviser Chase de Vere.

webTitle: Shell out - or be cast adrift

fields.headline: Shell out - or be cast adrift
fields.standfirst: Beach huts are in high demand along the British coastline.  Jill Insley tells how how to find your own
fields.trailText: If you think buying a beach hut is a cheap alternative to carting your family abroad for their summer holiday, prepare for a shock.
fields.body:
If you think buying a beach hut is a cheap alternative to carting your family abroad for their summer holiday, prepare for a shock.

A shortage of beach huts coming onto the market has caused prices to spiral over the past few years, and in some areas, a well appointed wooden shelter with a good view of the sea can cost as much as £30,000.

Southwold in Suffolk is possibly the most expensive place to buy at the moment. Sonia Moore of Southwold estate agent H A Adnams says huts on the town's North Beach cost about £6,000, but if you prefer Centre Cliff or East Cliff you will have to pay £12,000 to £15,000. And a hut on the more prestigious Gun Hill or Constitution Hill will set you back up to £30,000.

'They come with calor gas stoves, items of crockery and cutlery,' she says 'but you are not allowed to sleep in them and there's no running water - just standpipes within easy reach.'

Elsewhere on the coast, the average price is about £6,000, while a 5' by 5' hut on Bournemouth's seven-mile stretch of golden sand is likely to cost less than £1,000. However, unless you strike lucky in finding a hut owner who is prepared to sell directly to you, you could be in for a long wait. Most local councils have lists for people interested in buying a beach hut, and Dave Reed, seafront operations manager for Bournemouth Council, says thousands of people are now on the list he manages: 'If you put your name down now, we may be giving you a call in about eight years' time.'

The annual running costs can also be quite steep. Most huts are built on council-owned land, and are therefore subject to annual licences, site rent or council tax if the property is more substantial. Site licences in Lyme Regis cost from £200 to £1,000 a year, depending on the position and size of the beach hut, while in Bournemouth you will pay £420, discounted to £395 for early settlement. And even if you paint or woodstain your hut every year, the ravages of sea and salt air mean you will probably have to replace bits of your hut from time to time.

Sheila Brackley, a pensioner who has owned a beach hut at Hunstanton on the North Norfolk Coast for 36 years, says: 'We've virtually replaced the whole hut because we've owned it since the kids were small. But it's been very good value. My children loved it when they were small, and their children, too.'

Bournemouth

The council runs a slick operation with 1,343 huts, CCTV to prevent vandalism, four barbecue sites and a train service which runs along the length of the prom. However, you can't shirk on your beach hut upkeep - huts are inspected every year and you'll get a letter requesting repairs when necessary. The huts are likely to cost about £1,000 to buy, £900 to rent on an annual basis, £119 to rent from April 1 to June 10, £190 from September 9-23, and from £40 a week in between. Call 01202 451 763.

Frinton, Essex

This is the creme de la creme of the Essex coast and beach huts change hands for anything from £3,000 toward the northern end of the prom to £10,000 in the more swanky Walings. Local estate agent Gordon Suckling (01255 851 185), which handles sales and rental, has a hut for sale at £3,000. Huts cost £60 a week to rent in the peak season - some are still available.

Langland Bay, Swansea

About 70 beach huts are all owned by Swansea Council. Most are rented on an alternate three-monthly basis (April, June, August for £190, or May, July, September for £160) to locals whose names are picked out of a draw, but the council retains a few to rent to visitors on a weekly (£50) or daily basis (£18). Call 01792 363105 to book.

Lyme Regis

Chalets at the top end of the market are more like wooden beach bungalows, complete with bathrooms, bedrooms, kitchens and hot and cold water. They sell for about £37,000. Bog standard huts go for about £6,000. The council owns 25 huts that it rents out for £29.96 per week or £4.70 a day in May, June and September, and £38.78 a week or £17.70 a day in July and August. Call 01297 445175.

Abersoch, North Wales

The huts are situated on Abersoch's main beach, which has two slipways and is popular for watersports. The huts are mostly wooden, but a few brick-built ones have gone up in the past few years. From £6,000 for a leasehold to £15,000 for a freehold. Call local estate agent Beresford Adams on 01758 712016.

Southwold, Suffolk

Prices range from £6,000 to £35,000, and a waiting list is run by estate agent H A Adnams (01502 723 292), which also handles rentals. Expect to pay £65 a week through the agency, or up to £100 if arranged privately.

Wells-next-the-Sea, Norfolk

Traditional beach huts on stilts are managed by Viscount Coke's estate. Huts sell for £5,000 to £6,000, but there is a waiting list of 160 at the moment. A few can be rented out by the day or week, costing from £7.50 to £13.50 a day. Call 01485 532439.

webTitle: Why business is the new sex

fields.headline: Why business is the new sex
fields.trailText: You may have flicked casually through a magazine of late and come across one of a plethora of adverts featuring a young, attractive individual, either elegantly tailored by Savile Row or lounging in a warm cashmere sweater, flogging some new business product. They look as focused and smart as the slogan beneath them. But these ads don't just represent a fad in advertising. Behind them lies a quiet revolution that has consolidated itself over the past few years of economic stability. Business has gotten all sexy on us.
fields.body:
You may have flicked casually through a magazine of late and come across one of a plethora of adverts featuring a young, attractive individual, either elegantly tailored by Savile Row or lounging in a warm cashmere sweater, flogging some new business product. They look as focused and smart as the slogan beneath them. But these ads don't just represent a fad in advertising. Behind them lies a quiet revolution that has consolidated itself over the past few years of economic stability. Business has gotten all sexy on us.

One advert for Minolta Office Systems - a company offering printers, copiers and IT services - might serve as an example. Picture a beautiful, besuited woman, standing still on a railway concourse as the world rushes by her. She has a warm but wary countenance, a briefcase and some jargon. It reads: 'If not you, who' - and at this point each clause becomes a new line - 'will write a presentation that grows business, will share a thought that transforms your company, will help another person succeed, will crack a joke in a meeting that desperately needs one, will stop a mistake from happening, will uncover a new and important way.'

It's quite a mouthful, as jargon goes. But more curious still is the amalgamation of ideas and qualities now associated with routine business practice. Here they promote innovation, charity, humour, care and the ability to find a new, third way: the übermensch who can do sums, success and sideswipes in the same boardroom. This kind of ad - coupled with this mentality - is everywhere.

Meet the besweatered man at a PC, his arms raised like a jubilant athlete because Credit Suisse Boston has provided 'sound financing and advisory solutions in today's turbulent financial markets'; the catwalk face used to embody the business acumen that made Nextel 'one of six who started a $520m software company'. It's as though we've re-written the rules as to what business is, and irreversibly blurred the lines between work and play. The dull act of registering a company is now seen as youthful, dynamic and sexy.

Welcome to the new economy, to buzzword compliance, lift interface opportunities and eight hours' sleep minimum. By now you should be used to DD, B2B, RSI, DNR, GV and the monopoly of the ABC1. What a mess. But it's not simply an acronym-heavy return to the vulgar affluence of the 80s. Nigel Lawson's yuppies always faced a body of public opinion that considered them vile, but since socialism slipped into a coma on 1 May 1997, there have been few voices left to question the merits of untold business success. It's fine, it's great, it's young dot.commers transforming the economy for the benefit of us all. Be young, be beautiful, be rich, and don't expected to be regaled (that much). The explosion of the internet has brought the same feeling of universal expectation that the Gold Rush brought to California in 1848. Everyone can supposedly get a piece of the action, which makes the action all the more attractive.

Martha Lane Fox is clever, quite successful and probably quite rich, but didn't start selling holidays just to make the world a better place. But newspapers and the media have turned her - a businesswoman - into a cultural icon, and people have bought shares in that idea faster than the company could dish them out. The new economy has resulted in a marriage between youth and affluence that has managed to keep up the appearance of being based on innocence and innovation, despite being founded on old-fashioned, 80s-style greed. And the kids in particular love it. Considering the current state of youth culture in the West - where Britney's statements about chastity or rapper Eminem's marathon stint on MTV are the closest we get to subversion - the best shot a teenager has of knocking a hole in the establishment is to start a dot.com and put them out of business. There are teenagers in Silicon Valley keener to have their first incorporated company than their first hands-free first orgasm. Sex has always had an affiliation with decadence and bohemia, neither of which effectively exists any more. Instead, in business our libidos trust.

fields.bodyText: You may have flicked casually through a magazine of late and come across one of a plethora of adverts featuring a young, attractive individual, either elegantly tailored by Savile Row or lounging in a warm cashmere sweater, flogging some new business product. They look as focused and smart as the slogan beneath them. But these ads don't just represent a fad in advertising. Behind them lies a quiet revolution that has consolidated itself over the past few years of economic stability. Business has gotten all sexy on us. One advert for Minolta Office Systems - a company offering printers, copiers and IT services - might serve as an example. Picture a beautiful, besuited woman, standing still on a railway concourse as the world rushes by her. She has a warm but wary countenance, a briefcase and some jargon. It reads: 'If not you, who' - and at this point each clause becomes a new line - 'will write a presentation that grows business, will share a thought that transforms your company, will help another person succeed, will crack a joke in a meeting that desperately needs one, will stop a mistake from happening, will uncover a new and important way.' It's quite a mouthful, as jargon goes. But more curious still is the amalgamation of ideas and qualities now associated with routine business practice. Here they promote innovation, charity, humour, care and the ability to find a new, third way: the übermensch who can do sums, success and sideswipes in the same boardroom. This kind of ad - coupled with this mentality - is everywhere. Meet the besweatered man at a PC, his arms raised like a jubilant athlete because Credit Suisse Boston has provided 'sound financing and advisory solutions in today's turbulent financial markets'; the catwalk face used to embody the business acumen that made Nextel 'one of six who started a $520m software company'. It's as though we've re-written the rules as to what business is, and irreversibly blurred the lines between work and play. The dull act of registering a company is now seen as youthful, dynamic and sexy. Welcome to the new economy, to buzzword compliance, lift interface opportunities and eight hours' sleep minimum. By now you should be used to DD, B2B, RSI, DNR, GV and the monopoly of the ABC1. What a mess. But it's not simply an acronym-heavy return to the vulgar affluence of the 80s. Nigel Lawson's yuppies always faced a body of public opinion that considered them vile, but since socialism slipped into a coma on 1 May 1997, there have been few voices left to question the merits of untold business success. It's fine, it's great, it's young dot.commers transforming the economy for the benefit of us all. Be young, be beautiful, be rich, and don't expected to be regaled (that much). The explosion of the internet has brought the same feeling of universal expectation that the Gold Rush brought to California in 1848. Everyone can supposedly get a piece of the action, which makes the action all the more attractive. Martha Lane Fox is clever, quite successful and probably quite rich, but didn't start selling holidays just to make the world a better place. But newspapers and the media have turned her - a businesswoman - into a cultural icon, and people have bought shares in that idea faster than the company could dish them out. The new economy has resulted in a marriage between youth and affluence that has managed to keep up the appearance of being based on innocence and innovation, despite being founded on old-fashioned, 80s-style greed. And the kids in particular love it. Considering the current state of youth culture in the West - where Britney's statements about chastity or rapper Eminem's marathon stint on MTV are the closest we get to subversion - the best shot a teenager has of knocking a hole in the establishment is to start a dot.com and put them out of business. fields.headline: A Dame of two halves
fields.standfirst: She's treated like a royal but doesn't act like one. She's a star, but she can't act. What is the point of Liz Taylor?
fields.trailText: She's treated like a royal but doesn't act like one. She's a star, but she can't act. What is the point of Liz Taylor?
fields.body:
Elizabeth C4

Elizabeth Taylor - England's Other Elizabeth BBC1

Reputations: Liberace BBC2

By the time she had reached her sixties, 'Elizabeth had ceased to be a mere queen,' said Dr David Starkey in the final part of his excellent, illuminating dramatised documentary, Elizabeth on Channel 4. By now, in the autumn of her reign, Liz One was simply known as the pop-starry Gloriana, 'England's national icon'.

Predictably, Channel 4's Gloriana was embodied by an enigmatically pale, pointy-faced, bewigged thespiana, ruffed and ready to perform the dumbshow Elizabeth we all recognise as the greatest, most abiding cliché of royalty: a woman sat stock-still and staring on a big posh chair, silent, shimmeringly bejewelled and super-haughty. Given that even the most resourceful actor lacks the opportunity to get hands-on experience as a monarch, this must necessarily pass for method-regal. But the whole effect was camped up even more by having Elizabeth played by Karen Archer glowering against a backdrop of 100 or so guttering candles, thus making her look like a bedraggled Sting in the video for 'Every Breath You Take'. Altogether 'very Eighties', if not entirely 1580s.

Growing up in the latter part of the twentieth century as a Karen isn't likely to give you airs and graces, but perhaps to be christened Elizabeth automatically brings with it pretensions to grandeur - inside every petit bourgeois Liz from the 'burbs, is there a great big grand old Queen bursting to get out? Either way, in a week when the woman BBC1's Omnibus Special had dubbed England's Other Elizabeth was being quite successfully upstaged all over the media by Elizabeth Hurley (England's understudy 'Other Elizabeth'?), Elizabeth Taylor, from Hampstead via Beverly Hills, demonstrated her right-on royal attitude by keeping the slavering celebrity hordes waiting at a BFI dinner in her honour. Except that royalty wouldn't dream of ever keeping anybody waiting.

Funnily enough - and it came to me in a blinding flash - on Omnibus, the tireless, tearful, charity-working power-victim heroine-turned Dame looked like precisely what Diana might have grown into. Though brunette and bloated, there were moments in Friday's soft focus interview that were pure Panorama -era Diana - less a flesh-and-blood human being than an immaculate celebrity conception. And while she must surely have an interior life of some sort, there was little evidence of it here, not even when, voice quavering, eyes brimming, she sobbed over the death of Mike Todd.

Compare and contrast Liz's 'we said goodbye five times. He'd go downstairs and come back up again... the following morning my secretary and my doctor walked into the room... he was dead ' with Diana's famous 'yes, I loved him...' speech. These were both first-rate poor-me oratories from women who were perhaps too busy performing love ever to really feel it.

But while I remain wholly fascinated by Diana, it is probably treason to admit to never having been remotely captivated by even the idea of Elizabeth Taylor and much less the reality. I'm tired of the tyranny of her received 'beauty' - that spooky, preternatural prettiness (the 'mind of a child inside the body of a woman') that had long since evolved into a blowsy, weak-chinned, Rank starlet cuteness by the time she was in her twenties.

And I never cared a fig for the interminable Richard Burton shenanigans in which a pair of talent-squandering narcissists demonstrated nothing much more than a very great love of each other's fame. And who ever cared about the vulgar (though admittedly quite impressively Elizabethan) diamond love-tokens? Or the accumulated dullness of all those other tawdry husbands? And the sense that her extraordinary range of illnesses seem like a subconscious effort to ensure she remains both uninsurable and unemployable. After all, it's easy enough to overlook her many shortcomings as an actress when other distractions include not only a handspan waist, heaving embonpoint and flashing lilac eyes, but Paul Newman, Monty Clift and James Dean too. This is one smart Dame: no acting, no bad reviews! A clip from an old guest appearance on the US soap General Hospital saw her fluffing her lines and apologising to a plainly awestruck cast and crew with the words 'Shit. I'm sorry. I'm not used to acting'.

So it was a shame that this Omnibus concentrated on the acting when Liz surely received what she recently referred to as her 'dameship' for sterling work with the American Foundation for Aids research ('we've raised about $160 million...'), not for her acting or her nuptial profligacy. But perhaps she could only be persuaded to speak, ever-vacillating between faltering and feisty, with eyes locked-on to camera like violet missiles, by concentrating mostly on the scripted dramas. None the less, the only people drummed up to sing her praises in this department were Burton (on Parkinson, in 1974), Angela Lansbury (who worked with her on National Velvet ), an academic from the Film Studies Program at Wesleyan University and old mucker Shirley MacLaine.

There was much nonsense about 'instinctive acting' and the observations (though not from Liz) that 'if you really surrender and get out of your own way, particularly in a close-up, then an audience will see your soul...' But all I could see was Academy Award-winning lighting highlighting the Lux creaminess of skin and glycerine-dewiness of eye. The best bit came when MacLaine hinted at a project currently evolving somewhere way beyond Planet Camp. Entitled These Old Broads and written by Carrie Fisher (for MacLaine and 'Debbie [Reynolds], Betty Bacall, Julie Andrews and Elizabeth...'), Shirley observed drily that Liz would only have to 'play the part in bed, so I think she's insurable'. After the inevitable celestial celebrity showdown, where she'll get to meet Diana ('hey! you, get off of my cloud'), what's the betting that Elizabeth is remembered (by my generation at least) chiefly for her friendship with another inhabitant of celebrity Never-Neverland, Michael Jackson. And though this is the one relationship of hers that really does intrigue me, unfortunately Jacko remained off-limits on Omnibus .

In the same way that so much of Liz's life is such familiar viewing, you probably think you've seen most of Michael's, too. But though we're au courant with 'Ben' and Thriller and the Brits appearance, I had never before seen the slightly surreal film footage of a teenage Jackson visiting Lord Montagu's famous car museum at Beaulieu. Here he was captured enjoying a vintage set of wheels alongside the marabou and rhinestone-wearing, candelabra-loving, not-awfully-heterosexual pop-classic pianist, Liberace, plus Liberace's live-in lover-cum-chauffeur whose face had been remodelled to resemble the pianist's own gurning, twinklingly-youthful visage. And all this quite by chance! It is surely safe to say that Beaulieu will not have seen anything like the same level of sniggering, snuggling, scent-impregnated quiveringly fruit-flavoured high-voltage preeningly-queeny celebrityhood either before or since.

Interestingly, just as during England's Other Elizabeth, I wanted to know a great deal less about the subject's work and much more about her fame, so with Reputations , I wanted somebody who really knew to tell me how good a pianist Liberace was, or might have been, and why he failed to follow a career which saw him appear as guest soloist with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra at the age of 21. Instead we got a dismissive 'talented, but not brilliant' from unlikely narrator Denis Lawson, far too much footage of his mother and way too little of his murky éminence grise and brother, George, who had first encouraged him to play ragtime in Wisconsin nightclubs.

Anyway, by the end we were shown pictures of Freddie Mercury, Elton and - blimey! - Michael Jackson and told by biographer Ray Mungo that Liberace's legacy had been to make it 'all right to be a screaming queen onstage'. Which doesn't seem like much of a legacy, frankly, for a man with a museum and, just like Liz, a foundation of his own. Having watched the programme on tape, afterwards I hopped through the channels and found the charmingly warm, genial host of the daytime quiz Supermarket Sweep asking his contestants to identify 'scrag, linzertorte and farl'. I don't suppose Dale Winton has ever remembered Liberace in his prayers, but I bet he just adores that darling Dame.

fields.headline: Perfectly supernatural
fields.standfirst: Stir of Echoes is surprising and scary - and Kevin Bacon isn't the only one hypnotised
fields.trailText: Occasionally good films come from out of the blue or, to use a livelier American term, from left field. Such a picture is David Koepp's uninvitingly titled Stir of Echoes.
fields.body:
Stir of Echoes (99 mins, 15) Directed by David Koepp; starring Kevin Bacon, Kathryn Erbe, Illeana Douglas, Kevin Dunn

Occasionally good films come from out of the blue or, to use a livelier American term, from left field. Such a picture is David Koepp's uninvitingly titled Stir of Echoes. Koepp scripted Jurassic Park and Mission: Impossible; his 1996 directorial debut, Trigger Effect, went straight to video here without creating a ripple; and all I'd heard of his second feature film was that it resembled The Sixth Sense. Well, it is a little like The Sixth Sense, and also a little like The Shining. But it's based on a novel by Richard Matheson, published in the Fifties when Stephen King was still in primary school and years before M. Night Shyamalan was born. A specialist in horror, SF and the occult, Matheson wrote the best of Roger Corman's Poe movies, contributed to Twilight Zone and Star Trek, and turned his own books into such classics as The Incredible Shrinking Man (the paperback of which a babysitter reads in Stir of Echoes) and Spielberg's Duel .

The movie takes place in a working-class Polish-American suburb of Chicago where electricity repairman Tom Witzky (Kevin Bacon) and his wife Maggie (Kathryn Erbe) live in a rented house with Jake (Zachary David Cope), their five-year-old son. Jake talks to what initially seems to be an imaginary friend called Samantha, but it transpires that he's a 'receiver', a person with X-ray vision in touch with strange forces. His father develops similar, though more intermittent, powers when at the end of a party he drunkenly agrees to be hypnotised by his aggressive sister-in-law Lisa (Illeana Douglas), partly as a way of showing up her New Age mysticism. In this bravura sequence we are grasped with a steely grip that doesn't let up for the next 90 minutes. Lisa tells Tom to shut his eyes and imagine he's in an old picture palace. It's painted black. He's on his own. His seat starts floating towards the screen that has one word on it that he can't make out - until he's almost up against it. The word is SLEEP. This is our own dream experience of being at the movies.

Under hypnosis, Tom sees strange, violent images concerning a woman and his house, and when he awakes he continues to be haunted, first seeing a ghost, then experiencing premonitions. Is he in touch with something in his past, or have he and his son been brought into dangerous communion with a recent local tragedy? I will say no more. This is a constantly surprising and frightening picture. But what makes it a little special is the way Koepp roots the story in a convincingly etched blue-collar community and has the protagonist and his wife engaged in a real marriage. Unlike the family in The Shining, this couple really care for each other and their child, and unlike Nicholson's madness in Kubrick's picture, Bacon's is induced by a sense of unidentifiable moral responsibility. When her husband becomes steadily unhinged, we understand Maggie's pain and sense of helplessness. All the performances are of a high order, and only very occasionally does Koepp strike a false note.

webTitle: Vanessa Paradis gets pelted with knives, All Saints die

fields.headline: Vanessa Paradis gets pelted with knives, All Saints die
fields.trailText: The Girl on the Bridge | Honest | Simon Magus | The City | A Monkey's Tale
fields.body:
The Girl on the Bridge (92 mins, 15) Directed by Patrice Leconte; starring Daniel Auteuil, Vanessa Paradis

Honest (105 mins, 18) Directed by David A. Stewart; starring Nicole Appleton, Natalie Appleton, Melanie Blatt, Peter Facinelli

Simon Magus (105 mins, PG) Directed by Ben Hopkins; starring Noah Taylor, Embeth Davidtz, Rutger Hauer, Ian Holm, Sean McGinley

The City (88 mins, 15) Directed by David Riker; with Anthony Rivera, Jose Rabelo

A Monkey's Tale (76 mins, PG) Directed by Jean-François Laguionie; featuring the voices of John Hurt, Michael Gambon, Michael York, Rik Mayall

Like Jacques Doillon, Alain Corneau, André Téchiné and half a dozen other French directors in their forties and fifties, Patrice Leconte has managed to sustain a career making personal, middle-of-the-road movies of a sort unthinkable in Britain since the Sixties. In such films as Monsieur Hire, The Hairdresser's Husband, Tandem and Ridicule, his unhappy male protagonists are outsiders, drawn to women who mystify and disturb them. His characters are, in the words of Claude Beylie and Jacques Pinturault in their invaluable Les Matres du Cinéma Français, 'fragile and vulnerable, immured in their solitude'.

His latest picture, The Girl on the Bridge , is a bittersweet romantic comedy shot on location in Paris, Monte Carlo, San Remo, Athens and Istanbul in shimmering, high-contrast black-and-white. It begins on a bridge over the Seine where Gabor (Daniel Auteuil), a professional knife thrower, goes to recruit suicidal assistants for his act. He rescues the beautiful, promiscuous Adèle (Vanessa Paradis) from the icy river and they bring each other luck as they perform increasingly dangerous acts in nightclubs around the Mediterranean and she follows his advice at the roulette table. They break up, go to pieces and inevitably meet again. It's a wispy affair, an extended anecdote that recalls La Baie des Anges , Jacques Demy's New Wave tale of amour fou between two gamblers on the Cte d'Azur, back in 1962. Auteuil and Paradis are an engaging pair and the knife-throwing scenes have a bizarre erotic power, as Leconte intends them to.

You can hardly see the coffin of the current British cinema for the nails that have recently been driven into it, the latest of which is Honest , a comedy thriller set in 1968 London. It's directed by David A. Stewart of the Eurythmics, and stars Nicole Appleton, Natalie Appleton and Melanie Blatt, three quarters of the group All Saints. The girls play working-class East End sisters who support their crippled dad (James Cosmo) and get up gang boss Corin Redgrave's flaring nostrils by committing armed robberies dressed in identical grey suits, black ties and false moustaches - reservoir bitches, as it were. One of the girls hides stolen diamonds in a lava lamp belonging to an American Rhodes scholar (Peter Facinelli) who writes for Zero, a counter-cultural newspaper and has taken a fancy to her. There's a fashion photographer got up like David Hemmings in Blow-Up, a druggy midnight plunge into a Trafalgar Square fountain à la Dolce Vita, and a climactic chase during a private view at a Mayfair art gallery of the sort featured in every Swinging London movie. This is a witless, half-baked enterprise, soulless and inert. Its spirit is perhaps summed up in the American's line: 'It's just a £2 cab fare from Carnaby Street to Bethnal Green, but it's another world.'

A good deal better is the FilmFour production Simon Magus , a first feature by writer-director Ben Hopkins, shot in Wales and set in mid- nineteenth century Poland. This is sub-Isaac Bashevis Singer stuff about a young Talmudic scholar (David Townsend) who seeks to preserve his remote Jewish community by acquiring land from the local German squire (Rutger Hauer) to build a station on the recently laid railway line. Unfortunately, a wealthy anti-Semitic entrepreneur (Sean McGinley) has similar ideas and conflict results. Standing between the Jewish and Gentile communities is Simon (Noah Taylor), a holy fool driven hither and yon by Satan (Ian Holm), but eventually using his magical powers and guile to help his fellow Jews and effect reconciliation.
