In the third, a man with TB living rough can't provide the proof of residence that will get his little daughter into a school. In the fourth, a sad seamstress in a sweatshop tries to raise money for her child's operation in Mexico. It's an uncompromising, heartbreaking picture about soluble problems.

However, by the time you read this, I will have skipped off, bucket and spade in one hand, typewriter in the other, and that delightfully lapidary sentence 'Philip French is on holiday' will be appearing at the foot of this column for the next month.
fields.bodyText: The Girl on the Bridge (92 mins, 15) Directed by Patrice Leconte; starring Daniel Auteuil, Vanessa Paradis Honest (105 mins, 18) Directed by David A. Stewart; starring Nicole Appleton, Natalie Appleton, Melanie Blatt, Peter Facinelli Simon Magus (105 mins, PG) Directed by Ben Hopkins; starring Noah Taylor, Embeth Davidtz, Rutger Hauer, Ian Holm, Sean McGinley The City (88 mins, 15) Directed by David Riker; with Anthony Rivera, Jose Rabelo A Monkey's Tale (76 mins, PG) Directed by Jean-François Laguionie; featuring the voices of John Hurt, Michael Gambon, Michael York, Rik Mayall Like Jacques Doillon, Alain Corneau, André Téchiné and half a dozen other French directors in their forties and fifties, Patrice Leconte has managed to sustain a career making personal, middle-of-the-road movies of a sort unthinkable in Britain since the Sixties. In such films as Monsieur Hire, The Hairdresser's Husband, Tandem and Ridicule, his unhappy male protagonists are outsiders, drawn to women who mystify and disturb them. His characters are, in the words of Claude Beylie and Jacques Pinturault in their invaluable Les Matres du Cinéma Français, 'fragile and vulnerable, immured in their solitude'. His latest picture, The Girl on the Bridge , is a bittersweet romantic comedy shot on location in Paris, Monte Carlo, San Remo, Athens and Istanbul in shimmering, high-contrast black-and-white. It begins on a bridge over the Seine where Gabor (Daniel Auteuil), a professional knife thrower, goes to recruit suicidal assistants for his act. He rescues the beautiful, promiscuous Adèle (Vanessa Paradis) from the icy river and they bring each other luck as they perform increasingly dangerous acts in nightclubs around the Mediterranean and she follows his advice at the roulette table. They break up, go to pieces and inevitably meet again. It's a wispy affair, an extended anecdote that recalls La Baie des Anges , Jacques Demy's New Wave tale of amour fou between two gamblers on the Cte d'Azur, back in 1962. webTitle: Big fish, big chair, big ideas

fields.headline: Big fish, big chair, big ideas
fields.standfirst: Laurie Anderson's imaginative take on Moby Dick dwarfs David Edgar's problem play about Albert Speer
fields.trailText: Albert Speer | Songs and Stories from Moby Dick | Notre Dame de Paris
fields.body:
Albert Speer Lyttelton, London SE1

Songs and Stories from Moby Dick Barbican, London EC2

Notre Dame de Paris Dominion, London W1

What has gone wrong at the National? Albert Speer could hardly have a stronger collection of talents. The play is based on Gitta Sereny's penetrating study of the man who was first Hitler's architect, and later his Minister for Armaments. It is written by David Edgar, skilled and subtle as a dramatist and an adapter: it was he who gave us Nicholas Nickleby . It is directed by the master of the panoramic sweep and the telling detail, Trevor Nunn. Despite all this, the piece delivers no news. It is sometimes pedestrian, sometimes spectacular: it is not incisive or illuminating.

In pursuit of the truth about the man who declared ignorance of Hitler's systematic genocide of the Jews and who nevertheless proclaimed his own feelings of guilt - 'I should have known. I could have known. I didn't know,' - Speer divides into two. First the protagonist gives an account of his life: father-fixated, flattered by Hitler's attention, rising rapidly and anxious. In the second half - almost a separate play - his life after imprisonment in Spandau is examined by others. In a lurid afterpiece, he is judged guilty.

This twofold structure may be an attempt to suggest ambivalence. But it looks like a mistake: like doing everything at too great length. And the method of conveying information, in which first Speer and then his associates address the audience directly with their explanations of the action, is finger-waggingly obtrusive. The wish to instruct and a desire to display are at odds throughout.

Some elements come across forcefully. At the play's centre are two tremendous performances. Roger Allam - a transforming and undersung actor - is a perfectly judged Hitler, a man who presents himself as more house-painter than hell-raiser, and who moves from sinister emollience and ingratiating chirpiness to a stooped and cranky figure, one palsied hand clenched trembling behind his back. Alex Jennings, the most effortlessly melodious actor since Gielgud, works on a knife edge between chilly composure and urbane charm. When either character bursts out - into anger or remorse - the effect is galvanic.

There are arresting, sometimes revealing images. Against Ian MacNeill's effective cavern of a set, Speer's architectural creations are shown with the allure they must have held for a hungry crowd. Plumes of light shoot into the sky like fountains; his model of a rebuilt Berlin glows like a lunar landscape: Hitler and his entourage stumble through it with the blundering confidence of boy scouts.

There are moments when Edgar's wit and Nunn's direction combine to acute effect. The meal at which Speer, fresh from Spandau, announces to his family that he is going to grant them a miserable future by dredging up the past in his memoirs, is staged like the Last Supper, with Speer's betrayal the more devastating because it is executed with a sort of innocence. He is seen - not for the first time - as having no sense of the effect of his actions.

But magnetic staging does not amount to insight. And insight, analysis and revelation are the only reasons for staging a piece about Speer. We know the Nazis could project visual allure; we know Speer was a difficult case. And we know that while families were being wiped out, the men who gave the orders were stumbling about looking normal. In a banal illustration of the point, film from the concentration camps is from time to time played behind the action. It dwarfs everything.

Suddenly the Barbican is being besieged by invention. Songs and Stories from Moby Dick is a vaulting multimedia show by the multi-talented American performer Laurie Anderson. It is nothing so daft as a musical staging of Melville's novel about whales and God and revenge: rather, it is a tribute to his imagination, and an evocation of the great associative roll of his writing. Anderson is like a spiky-haired, red-booted Prospero. She is a conjuror of seas and spirits and memories. She even carries her own version of Prospero's staff, an instrument called a 'talking stick' which she has designed herself: a digital turntable shaped like a wand, which looks like a harpoon and performs like a wireless.

The early scenes of the show are dominated by a thrumming, buzzing noise, like the sound of a giant wasp, and by a huge grey and white back-projection of the ocean. Then come the wail of bagpipes and an eerie blue light; later, giant pages from the book appear on the screen turning over each other like waves; golden letters tumble off the text and fly like spray in all directions; as the entire stage becomes mottled black and white, as if it were a marble hall, you read words about the marbled appearance of the sea. There are graphic illustrations of passages and characters from the novel. Captain Ahab capers around in a stovepipe hat like a demented Rumplestiltskin. Pip the cabin boy is given his own song, rendered by Anderson in a piping voice, and is swallowed up by an ocean in which the fat mouths of fishes open like flowers.

There are also moments which are pure Anderson. Some of these are hippie dreams; some of them are sharp. She says she thinks that Moby Dick is about Big Heads - humans have them and so do whales. She unnerves you with switches of perspective - perching in a huge armchair, lolling on a tiny one. She brings you the creaks and clanks of a ship and the clicking sounds of whales; she shows you how a pillow can look like the face of a rock.

Richard Cocciante has supplied a girningly memorable melody - 'Live for the One I love' - for Notre Dame de Paris . Apart from that, there are only two glimmers of hope in this assault on the ears and on Victor Hugo. First, when Esmeralda advances towards a huge bed: for a second you expect 'The Song of the Hump'. Second, when villainous Frollo ('I'm a priest,' he sings) is pursued by two untethered pillars which, gliding pointlessly around the stage, approach him in a pincer movement.

Luc Plamondon's story is impossibly jumbled; his words (English versions by Will Jennings) are mostly indistinct. A madly vigorous choreography - with characters abseiling up walls, somersaulting onto mattresses, cavorting in swimming trunks - adds to the air of desperation. Two particularly nasty moments feature a chant of asylum seekers, pretty in pastel rags, and a dance with a troupe of men waving in unison the corpses of their girlfriends.

fields.headline: California preening
fields.standfirst: Don Henley doesn't like rap, Jerry Springer or the rest of the Eagles. So what's left?
fields.trailText: Don Henley is wearing a gold necklace and playing with a toy sampler. As the former Eagles singer and drummer raps the lyrics to one of the band's old hits, 'Life in the Fast Lane', the sampler provides a scratched version of the song's original guitar riff.
fields.body:
Don Henley is wearing a gold necklace and playing with a toy sampler. As the former Eagles singer and drummer raps the lyrics to one of the band's old hits, 'Life in the Fast Lane', the sampler provides a scratched version of the song's original guitar riff. Another switch blurts out the chorus, which Henley deliberately nips into short stabs of individual words while striking exaggerated rap poses and high-fiving his audience. Don Henley is 52, a mature, successful artist: why on earth, at this showcase LA gig to promote his new album Inside Job, is he indulging in clumsy parodies of electronic music?

Well, it's not a whim, that's for sure. In the US, the promotional material for Inside Job, a bewitching mix of ballads and social commentary, describes it as a 'Return to Real Music': suburban America's latest stand against the black rappers. Later that evening, Henley fails to appear at a post-gig barbecue. Over ribs and banana pudding flown up Texas, Hans, a German critic, collars me. 'You think he was great, yes?' he asks. 'Makes you wish you were born in California. The Eagles are so rock'n'roll.' I start to wonder: what right does Henley have to deify blue-collar rock'n'roll as a pure art form, given its plagiarism from the blues and R&B?

For most of the Seventies, The Eagles were America's biggest rock group; their worldwide sales of 100 million set a new benchmark. The group split in 1980, briefly reuniting in 1994 for a money-spinning tour and the album Hell Freezes Over (which is when, back in 1980, they had said they would reform). Henley has made four solo albums and his 1984 song 'The Boys Of Summer', a cornerstone of rock radio, was one of the finest US singles in an otherwise forgettable musical decade. As a lyricist, he is still capable of being the most dynamic writer of the West Coast jet-set, out-performing the likes of Randy Newman and Jackson Browne. His rustic vocal roar seems to have been burned off for FM radio.

This year, in a considerable boost to his ego, The Eagles - Their Greatest Hits (1971-75) was certified the bestselling album ever in the US, its 26 million sales surpassing even Michael Jack son's Thriller. Yet all those sales have exacted a price. Henley has been known to march journalists to the door when bored or insulted. He has launched broadsides against the record industry and his bandmates from The Eagles ('Joe Walsh? He was raised partly in California, mainly in Mars').

The interview takes place the morning after the barbecue. Henley, in jeans and a loose workshirt, sits on a small sofa, pouring a Diet Coke as he waits. Starchy-faced, his only motion comes from his tongue, darting over his teeth, pushing his top lip outwards. He looks like an old man playing with his dentures. 'I was trying to make fun of the original,' says Henley crisply, still probing his teeth, when I mention 'Life In The Fast Lane'. 'At least it didn't sound like most of what makes the charts these days. Rock'n'roll doesn't mean anything,' he grumbles. 'I didn't even like grunge - all that unfocused anger was just a waste. Rap music doesn't make any sense. The Nation of Islam? What kind of a message is that? And all these pop groups are just clever marketing. Money! That's the bottom line in America these days.' He pauses, exhausted from his rant. 'I guess that's what I was trying to say yesterday.'

The anti-corporate ideology has been a constant feature of his songwriting, paradoxically, given The Eagles' money-making power. Later he will vilify his record company. 'They're all bean counters,' he snaps. 'They call my music product: it's art. They call me a rock star when I'd rather be described as a musician. Or better, a recording artist.' He continues: 'It's a symptom of the disease in this country - the commercialisation of everything. You have people selling their private lives on Jerry Springer - these are not the ideals my generation fought for. At my age, how can you not expect to feel disillusioned about America?'

Throughout the interview, Henley barely cracks a smile. With his clipped speech, he makes for polite, but rather humourless company. He still believes - despite the platinum discs for the Eagles and Grammy awards for his solo albums, even despite a track from his new CD being used to play out next week's episode of ER on Channel 4 - that he is still not given the respect he is due. 'I was never allowed to make all the final decisions in The Eagles,' he admits. 'We had strong personalities in that group - all driven by various ambitions.'

Henley makes his way towards a TV crew making a a documentary for a US network's British subsidiary. 'Is it as vapid as the US version?' he wonders, before sauntering away. No one replies. 'Only marginally less so, then,' he says dryly. I watch as the man who co-wrote 'Tequila Sunrise' and 'Desperado' saunters off, still muttering to himself, and I wonder what stripped away all that West Coast idealism.

Inside Job is released tomorrow on Warners

webTitle: Here's one we made earlier... out of ashtrays

fields.headline: Here's one we made earlier... out of ashtrays
fields.standfirst: Hanover's Expo 2000 offers acres of kitsch and flashes of genius that put the Dome in the shade (again)
fields.trailText: Hanover's Expo, which opens this week, is what the Dome would have been if the Millennium Commission hadn't insisted on pouring hundreds of millions into the toxic waste dumps of Greenwich, and had opted instead for Birmingham's bid to celebrate 2000 at the National Exhibition Centre.
fields.body:
Expo 2000 Hanover

Hanover's Expo, which opens this week, is what the Dome would have been if the Millennium Commission hadn't insisted on pouring hundreds of millions into the toxic waste dumps of Greenwich, and had opted instead for Birmingham's bid to celebrate 2000 at the National Exhibition Centre.

It is a makeover of a collection of glum concrete sheds in the middle of nowhere - normally used to show off machine tools and construction equipment - plus a job lot of specially constructed new pavilions of variable quality, rather than a brand new project. On the face of it, the Expo should be staring at catastrophe on an even more gigantic scale than the Dome.

At £1 billion, it has cost considerably more than the Dome, and by predicting visits by 40 million people in six months, it has a target that the Millennium Commission never dreamed of, even in its most optimistic moments. And yet Hanover might just work, not because it is doing anything new, but because it is sticking to the traditional formula of the Expo: acres of brilliantly crafted junk, with the occasional flash of genius.

We remember successful Expos for the innovation of their architecture and engineering. Crystal Palace was filled with replicas of the Venus de Milo carved in butter. And the same 1889 Paris Expo that built the Eiffel Tower also boasted a replica of the Bastille, stormed every hour on the hour by a troupe of actors got up as sans-culottes .

The Dome is neither one thing nor another, not bad enough, but not good enough either. It's too polite to follow in the full-blooded tradition of the great Expos, and its exhibits are too bland to have the redeeming architectural brilliance of the Crystal Palace.

But despite all the morally-improving rhetoric about sustainability and new technology, Hanover has a series of pavilions of such baroque kitschness that it's impossible not to warm to them. They at least have the courage of their convictions in a way that very little at the Dome does.

You can find a desert fortress straight out of Beau Geste built by the United Arab Emirates, complete with cannon at the main gate, and an Airbus load of authentic desert sand. It's sandwiched between the ski-lift that swings right across the site, and the Ferris wheel. There is a traditional village from Bhutan embellished with 800 specially commissioned carvings. Croatia's sky-blue box allows you to walk over a glass-covered beach strewn with archaeological fragments. Monte Carlo has constructed a pavilion that celebrates tax exile, a dazzling white apartment block with a millionaire's yacht float ing in its own tank of water.

The Poles couldn't make up their mind whether to go for cutting-edge architectural modernity like their Baltic neighbours, or opt for the ethnic end of the market, exploring the same territory as the Emirates. In the event, they have tried to have it both ways, building a plate-glass box, into which they have inserted a collection of thatched cottages, an effect much like putting a ship in a bottle.

But alongside all this, Hanover also has a beautifully chaste pavilion designed by Alvaro Siza for Portugal, as good in its way as any of his permanent buildings. There is an extraordinary Japanese structure built by Shigeru Ban using only paper, and at least one work of real architectural brilliance - the Dutch pavilion designed by the architectural group MVRDV. It will go down as one of the few truly great pieces of Expo architecture, alongside Mies van der Rohe's Barcelona pavilion and Moshe Safdie's Habitat flats at the Montreal Expo.

And the German pavilions, while none of them are particularly distinguished pieces of architecture, manage to be genuinely engaging. One pavilion the size of a football stadium has nothing in it except a flock of 72 self-propelled robots as big as elephants silently circling the giant, darkened interior in an unforgettable piece of theatre. Another has Bach's piano; the first car ever built by Benz; a slice of Berlin Wall; and the actual peace treaty Germany signed with France in 1956 to settle the future of Alsace.

Hanover also provides depressing evidence that none of the lessons of the Dome have been learned by the Foreign Office and the Department of Trade and Industry, the two ministries responsible for commissioning the British pavilion.

Rather than build a pavilion, as even the Hungarians, and the Yemenis have managed, Britain has rented an off-the-peg industrial shed from the organisers, customising it with red, white and blue stickers on the exterior. Britain's pavilion purports to celebrate the quality of Britain's architects and designers, but it has employed none of them, selecting instead HP:ICM, to design it, a previously obscure firm that can hardly be said to have covered itself in glory on the Body Zone at the Dome. On the inside you find a curious hymn to Blairism, subtitled: 'Diversity, It's in Our Nature'.

You enter through a mock-up of the front door of 10 Downing Street, of a crudeness which would make it look uncomfortable in a moderately well-equipped branch of B&Q, and which distracts you from the fact that the organisers have managed to borrow the original door and thrown its impact away by hanging it up out of reach. The sum of Britain's contemporary achievements in design is represented by ashtrays from assorted Conran restaurants, alongside the Dyson vacuum cleaner and a wind-up radio, and the somewhat presumptuous suggestion that, based on the birthplace of its designer, the iBook for Apple is in some mysterious way an example of British design.

It sits in the shadow of the Dutch pavilion which is everything that Britain's is not. In the flat and featureless landscape of Hanover, it stands out with the force of a skyscraper in the prairie. It takes the form of a layer cake that symbolises the Dutch landscape. There are no exhibits as such, but the architecture is integrated with content. One floor is a greenhouse growing a meadow of daisies under artificial sunlight. Piled on top of that is a forest of oak trees. From the ground you can look up and see the surreal spectacle of the trees sitting on the neon strip-lit ceiling below. The top slice of the cake is a clutch of wind-powered generators and an artificial turf mound.

The whole thing has a jangling tension between the natural and the manmade, which is what Holland is all about. It also suggests a national culture with the self-confidence to take a chance on an extremely risky piece of design. Britain's pavilion reflects exactly the opposite,with a condescending ineptness that comes across just as clearly as the bravery of the Dutch.

fields.headline: So that's where the pin went...
fields.standfirst: In Glyndebourne's witty new Nozze di Figaro, for once you can see Cherubino hiding. Only one thing is missing
fields.trailText: Once invited to Glyndebourne to see Le Nozze di Figaro, the Queen famously commented: 'That's the one with the pin, isn't it? I have seen that.' To reduce one of the greatest works in the repertoire, a comedy of manners of the highest intricacy and elegance, to a mere pin might be said to be missing the point. Yet one sympathises
fields.body:
Le Nozze di Figaro Glyndebourne, East Sussex

Andras Schiff Royal Festival Hall, London SE1

Once invited to Glyndebourne to see Le Nozze di Figaro, the Queen famously commented: 'That's the one with the pin, isn't it? I have seen that.' To reduce one of the greatest works in the repertoire, a comedy of manners of the highest intricacy and elegance, to a mere pin might be said to be missing the point. Yet one sympathises. In the fourth act, without warning, the lost pin in question suddenly becomes the focus of the opera. It heralds a long and confused unravelling of mixed identities, leading eventually to happy reconciliation (that bit, at least, is clear). Even long-standing devotees of the work take a certain pride in having not the faintest idea of what's going on in the last act of their favourite opera.

Graham Vick, in his new production for Glyndebourne, didn't entirely shed light on the matter. Since few, if any, directors have, it may be wiser to concentrate instead on the many strengths of the illuminating first three acts. Never have the ironies or undertones been laid so bare. With his designer Richard Hudson, Vick has continued the visual theme and aesthetic spirit of his Cosi fan Tutte of two years ago. (His third Mozart/da Ponte opera, Don Giovanni, follows later in the season.) Here the empty rehearsal room has become a magic theatre in which ever-changing screens and gauzes both clarify and cloud the action. Characters begin in shirts and jeans, scene by scene donning wigs and frock coats until the transition from life to art is complete. This neatly reverses the political action of the opera since all are now equal (physically) at the start rather than merely edging towards parity at the end.

Beautifully lit by Jennifer Tipton, the designs use every shade of ivory from creamy satin to humdrum calico to buff cardboard, these quiet contrasts matching the text's subtleties to perfection. By creating a false 'off-stage', all is visible in the act two farce of entrances and exits. For once we can see Cherubino hiding nervously in the closet, Susanna eavesdropping, the Count arriving at his wife's chamber. The effect, unexpectedly, is to darken the comedy and heighten the tension, exactly as the score's insistent string line and short, repeated motifs demands.

Peter Mattei, a virile and savvy Figaro, dominated a sympathetic but not wholly well-matched cast. Christiane Oelze's Susanna, though charming, was often too quiet and Maria Costanza Nocentini as the Countess lacked strong vocal or dramatic impact. But Marina Comparato's Cherubino was engaging, and Mariusz Kwiecien had admirable vocal flexibility as the stiff, buttoned-up, bullying Count. In the troublesome garden scene, the screens are moved aside and the characters move around the empty stage as if playing blind-man's buff. If Vick can adjust this final act, Glyndebourne will have a handsome, perceptive Figaro on its hands. As it is, three quarters of it is riveting. The London Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Andrew Davis, provided loving and refined support, never forcing the tone or tempo.

How much can a player reasonably demand of the audience he is there (and paid) to entertain? Anyone would draw a line at, say, firing water pistols at the stage or heckling. Earlier this month in Germany, Anne-Sofie Mutter walked off stage mid-piece, with her conductor Kurt Masur, because the audience was fidgeting too much. The modern work was difficult and not quite what they were expecting. When the performers returned, everyone sat in silence, no doubt terrified, and the work was completed. Last Sunday afternoon, a keen audience packed the Festival Hall for a recital by Andras Schiff . To hear Schiff play Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier (Book II), which he distils to a bare, brilliant essence, is always an event.

The hall was conspicuous for the presence of several distinguished musicians and attentive students, many following scores. No one in search of light entertainment would willingly give up their afternoon to hear one chap commune with Bach for two and a half hours. Yet 10 minutes into his performance, while playing the long left-hand opening statement of a fugue, he waved his free arm angrily at the audience unmistakably telling us, by his gesture, to 'Shut up'. The problem was that a few members of this committed bunch were a touch bronchial, still adjusting to the switch from damp, cold outside to dry, warm hall. One thing about the Festival Hall is that it's good for coughs. From a sniff to a snort to a full-blown chesty convulsion, the acoustic tosses each round the auditorium like renaissance polyphony around a cathedral.

Everyone, well-drilled in concert etiquette, struggled to keep their explosions to the natural pause between one pair of preludes and fugues and the start of the next. But Schiff didn't want any natural pauses and held his hands over the keyboard to show the inherent link between each piece. After the interval, a lady was sent on stage to explain his sense of the work 'as an uninterrupted arc', by which time, like naughty children in school assembly, we had certainly got the point ('Would he rather we just died quietly?' muttered a peeved American). He may have achieved the concentration he quite properly required but he certainly didn't help ours. For much of the second half you could scarcely hear his unquestionably dazzling playing for the clatter of large, courtesy cough sweets against several hundred pairs of teeth.

Probability Theory no doubt could give a better equation, but even common sense tells us that if an (optimistic) five per cent of the audience have a cold and each of them coughs randomly three times in a long evening with precious few opportunities to clear the tubes, we'll be running at two coughs a minute. Mr Schiff ought to cancel any February engagements.

fields.headline: Behind the Aryan curtain...
fields.standfirst: German symbolism deserves to be reclaimed from the Nazis
fields.trailText: No artist has ever suffered a plunge in reputation quite so sudden or so steep as the Swiss-born symbolist Arnold Böcklin, the leading painter of his adoptive Germany in the late-nineteenth century. He was as famous as those who acclaimed him - Nietzsche, Brahms, Schopenhauer and Munch, who called him 'the sacred flame' of German art
fields.body:
Kingdom of the Soul: Symbolist Art in Germany 1870-1920

Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery, until 30 July

No artist has ever suffered a plunge in reputation quite so sudden or so steep as the Swiss-born symbolist Arnold Böcklin, the leading painter of his adoptive Germany in the late-nineteenth century. He was as famous as those who acclaimed him - Nietzsche, Brahms, Schopenhauer and Munch, who called him 'the sacred flame' of German art. Every self-respecting burgher owned a copy of his masterwork, Island of Death, in which a white-robed priest ferries a corpse over Stygian waters to a mausoleum raked by moonlight. In its day, the picture was as familiar as the opening chords of Beethoven's Fifth; it was the Mona Lisa of German painting.

When Böcklin died in 1901, Richard Strauss wrote the funeral hymn and the world's press rushed to eulogise 'the founder of a new yearned-for art'. One year later, however, the artist was disparaged as a pedlar of kitsch; two years later he was vilified in a book, The Böcklin Case, as the witting stooge of a chauvinist state. It didn't help that his main champions were nationalists. The sacred flame waned fast. Apart from a stint in the Thirties, Böcklin's work was rarely seen in European museums until his rehabilitation in the late Seventies.

So what did for Böcklin? The Nazis, of course, who commandeered Böcklin and many of his peers for the Führer's pantheon of approved artists. But even before this posthumous patronage contaminated his career, there was another force which effectively deleted German symbolism from the history of art. This was the overwhelming tendency of the world's museums, even before impressionism set the seal, to favour French over German painting. A symbolist, according to this bias, was a nervy Parisian dreamer; not some coarse provincial labouring in a Bavarian forest.

Kingdom of the Soul is the first show of German symbolism ever to be staged in Britain - or indeed Germany, where its European tour began. Given the circumstances, it could hardly fail to surprise: from Böcklin's alarming melodramas to Klinger's phantasmagoria and Zwintscher's eerie nightscapes, there are almost 200 works by 60 artists, most of them unknown in this country. Seen together, they amount to a visual opera performed at full-volume blast.

Symbolism, a vague term in itself, is all about the gradual evocation of mood as opposed to the clear description of fact. In France, this produced an effete iconography of wilting flowers, floating wraiths, unicorns and the jewel-dripping fantasies of Gustav Moreau. In Germany, it meant everything from golden lads and lasses enjoying a Bavarian Eden to ravens, monsters and haunted chapels, Olympian gods, fallen mortals and shattering visions of the afterlife. Above all - and you see this throughout the show - it meant lonely figures silhouetted on a shore, looking out to sea, yearning for some unattainable land beyond.

The unattainable can often be identified with some precision as Italy, Goethe's 'land where the lemon flowers'. More than half of these artists went to Italy and came back infatuated with classical culture. A typical symbolist landscape, as painted by Ferdinand Knab, shows a Roman temple against a heavy northern sky scattered with cawing harbingers. A typical symbolist myth, as painted by Anselm Feuerbach, shows Diana bathing - or it would, if you could make her out in the inky gloom of Feuerbach's Black Forest.

In short, the landscape of German symbolism is profoundly Teutonic. The warm South, with its oranges and lemons, becomes the romantic North. Even Hans Thoma's Eden, a paradise of date-palms and parrots, is stricken with a cataract straight out of Caspar David Friedrich. In this context, it's horribly easy to see how symbolism's classical athletes could look to later eyes like Hitler Youth practising eurythmics for the Fatherland.

Yet the mood evoked by this art - with some appalling exceptions of Aryan kitsch - is anything but triumphalist. Böcklin's shark-finned Tritan, copulating with a red-eyed Nereid in a dark convulsive sea, still seems frightening. Max Klinger's etchings of the afterlife - as a black canyon into which we are hurled by death - send shivers of foreboding across the mind.

Klinger, who is very much the star of this show, painted a Crucifixion in which the figure of Christ is entirely, distressingly naked. It caused a sensation in 1870 and it still seems properly shocking today. But it turns out to be consistent with so much of this art, which never shies from full-on male nudity, female eroticism and all-out release of the irrational, emotional psyche.

German symbolism is routinely diagnosed as a reaction to Bismarck's modernised, materialist state. But that doesn't begin to explain the astonishing variety of this show, which runs all the way from Klinger's magnificent bust of the glowering Nietzsche to Richard Muller's jackbooted skeletons and Franz Von Stuck's soft-porn tat. This variety even devolves to the micro-level of a single career. Von Stuck, for example, can surprise you with a single, incisive etching. Böcklin veers from the late romanticism of his Self-Portrait with Death to the Hammer-horror schlock of his ruined chapel.

It may be that there is no clear definition of symbolist art, nothing to connect the flimsy fantasies of Moreau with the durable power of Klinger's etchings. But Böcklin seems to have identified some of the characteristics of German symbolism, wittingly or not, when he said that art should tell a story, as much as literature, and that it should aim for the resonance of music.

Island of Death inspired Rachmaninov, Strindberg, Dali and Hesse. De Chirico acknowledged a lifelong debt to Böcklin. Look at Zwintscher's painted paradoxes and you see the makings of Magritte; look at Liepold's Gateway to the Cosmos and you see the graphic art of the Seventies prefigured. As this enthralling, if long-delayed show reveals, German symbolism is a crucial missing chapter in the story of art.

Seen together, they amount to a visual opera performed at full-volume blast. Symbolism, a vague term in itself, is all about the gradual evocation of mood as opposed to the clear description of fact. In France, this produced an effete iconography of wilting flowers, floating wraiths, unicorns and the jewel-dripping fantasies of Gustav Moreau. In Germany, it meant everything from golden lads and lasses enjoying a Bavarian Eden to ravens, monsters and haunted chapels, Olympian gods, fallen mortals and shattering visions of the afterlife. Above all - and you see this throughout the show - it meant lonely figures silhouetted on a shore, looking out to sea, yearning for some unattainable land beyond. The unattainable can often be identified with some precision as Italy, Goethe's 'land where the lemon flowers'. More than half of these artists went to Italy and came back infatuated with classical culture. A typical symbolist landscape, as painted by Ferdinand Knab, shows a Roman temple against a heavy northern sky scattered with cawing harbingers. A typical symbolist myth, as painted by Anselm Feuerbach, shows Diana bathing - or it would, if you could make her out in the inky gloom of Feuerbach's Black Forest. In short, the landscape of German symbolism is profoundly Teutonic. The warm South, with its oranges and lemons, becomes the romantic North. Even Hans Thoma's Eden, a paradise of date-palms and parrots, is stricken with a cataract straight out of Caspar David Friedrich. In this context, it's horribly easy to see how symbolism's classical athletes could look to later eyes like Hitler Youth practising eurythmics for the Fatherland. Yet the mood evoked by this art - with some appalling exceptions of Aryan kitsch - is anything but triumphalist. Böcklin's shark-finned Tritan, copulating with a red-eyed Nereid in a dark convulsive sea, still seems frightening. Max Klinger's etchings of the afterlife - as a black canyon into which we are hurled by death - send shivers of foreboding across the mind. Klinger, who is very much the star of this show, painted a Crucifixion in which the figure of Christ is entirely, distressingly naked. It caused a sensation in 1870 and it still seems properly shocking today. But it turns out to be consistent with so much of this art, which never shies from full-on male nudity, female eroticism and all-out release of the irrational, emotional psyche. German symbolism is routinely diagnosed as a reaction to Bismarck's modernised, materialist state. But that doesn't begin to explain the astonishing variety of this show, which runs all the way from Klinger's magnificent bust of the glowering Nietzsche to Richard Muller's jackbooted skeletons and Franz Von Stuck's soft-porn tat. This variety even devolves to the micro-level of a single career. Von Stuck, for example, can surprise you with a single, incisive etching. Böcklin veers from the late romanticism of his Self-Portrait with Death to the Hammer-horror schlock of his ruined chapel. It may be that there is no clear definition of symbolist art, nothing to connect the flimsy fantasies of Moreau with the durable power of Klinger's etchings. But Böcklin seems to have identified some of the characteristics of German symbolism, wittingly or not, when he said that art should tell a story, as much as literature, and that it should aim for the resonance of music. Island of Death inspired Rachmaninov, Strindberg, Dali and Hesse. De Chirico acknowledged a lifelong debt to Böcklin. Look at Zwintscher's painted paradoxes and you see the makings of Magritte; look at Liepold's Gateway to the Cosmos and you see the graphic art of the Seventies prefigured. As this enthralling, if long-delayed show reveals, German symbolism is a crucial missing chapter in the story of art.

fields.headline: Grease monkeys are the word
fields.standfirst: In Matthew Bourne's version of Carmen, mechanics replace the cigarette girls
fields.trailText: Matthew Bourne's new show for Adventures in Motion Pictures opens with a billboard bidding us welcome to Harmony (population 375). It's one of those godforsaken Midwestern towns not a hundred miles from Pleasantville and other ironically named American movie locations.
fields.body:
Car Man Lyceum, Sheffield; Nottingham Theatre Royal 5-10 June, and touring until 29 July

Matthew Bourne's new show for Adventures in Motion Pictures opens with a billboard bidding us welcome to Harmony (population 375). It's one of those godforsaken Midwestern towns not a hundred miles from Pleasantville and other ironically named American movie locations. A sign outside the local car repair shop announces 'Man Wanted' - a double entendre on a par with Car Man 's subtitle, 'an auto-erotic thriller'.

The music is Bizet's Carmen - or rather, Rodion Schedrin's ballet suite version of the opera, interspersed with new music by Terry Davies. As in Bourne's hugely popular Swan Lake, gender expectations have been reversed. Instead of smouldering cigarette girls, male garage hands clock off, hose themselves down and join the female half of the tiny population outside Dino's Diner.

Dino is a slob, lecherously played by Scott Ambler. Lana, Dino's Italian-American wife, is the Anna Magnani of this hick town. Her role as Carmen is shared with Luca the drifter, biceps bulging beneath his tight, white T-shirt. He is the irresistible force who takes over the Man Wanted post, Dino's wife and the diner. While he's about it, Luca also seduces Angelo, the uptight Don Jose figure whose life is about to fall apart.

So far, so good. By the end of Act I, the screw has tightened nicely in this well-assembled set of boxes within boxes. Bourne is playing with several conventions: Hollywood film noir, Italian low-life realism, melodramatic opera and stylised dance. Lez Brotherston's versatile bi-level set allows the action to move freely; Chris Davey's lighting tells us where and how to look. Scenes are transformed from lurid technicolour to black-and-white.

All the characters are strongly established, their body language needing no words to spell out their motives. There are going to be at least three casts on tour, with some of the principals alternating roles. Burly, Brando-ish Ewan Wardrop, whom I saw as the dark angel, Luca, will also be fragile, febrile Angelo; Will Kemp will toughen himself from wimp to seducer. The women's roles, at present, are underwritten, though Michela Meazza as Lana flaunted her sexuality with a vengeance.

Bourne's choreography moves from naturalism to elaborate routines. The corps of floozies and grease monkeys can be as stylised as Roland Petit's tarts and toreadors in his 1949 Carmen . Then at times they mirror the coupling of the principals, as though the whole town was in rut. The pas de deux for the central characters, however, are the weakest element in the show. Brief, underdeveloped, they convey only one overriding emotion - lust, anguish or animosity.

The realisation of how much is missing from these encounters comes when they cross into ballet territory: Angelo and his girlfriend appalled and mesmerised by a gun, for example, in echoes of a Mayerling pas de deux. Bourne cannot find imagery beyond the literal, so the grappling becomes banal. Angelo is seriously deranged in the second half of show, which starts to go to pieces even before he does. Too many screws have been driven into too many planks for the structure to hold steady. Yet more film genres are added to the mix: schlock horror, penitentiary drama, revenge thriller. A cabaret opens Act II, with a Martha Graham parody, a modern dance play within a play. The reference is one to earlier AMP numbers. Bourne may not have calculated, how ever, how compelling Car Man 's story has become by the interval. Audiences want to know what happens next. The clever stuff and the laughs belonged to Act I. Now the inevitable has to happen, without distractions.

The point of taking the show on the road is to discover what kind of vehicle it is. AMP has the chance to streamline its chassis (and substitute Chevvies for the Morris Minors which have no place in Harmony, USA) before its London season at the Old Vic in September.

webTitle: 'I tell my wife I love her. But the truth is, I don't'

fields.headline: 'I tell my wife I love her. But the truth is, I don't'
fields.trailText: 'Do you love me?' In moments of intimacy, my wife will often ask me this question, her large brown eyes staring up into mine earnestly but pitifully, rather like a labrador puppy begging for a biscuit. (It's a flippant and cruel comparison, but indicative of the heartless bastard I can feel myself becoming.)
fields.body:
'Do you love me?' In moments of intimacy, my wife will often ask me this question, her large brown eyes staring up into mine earnestly but pitifully, rather like a labrador puppy begging for a biscuit. (It's a flippant and cruel comparison, but indicative of the heartless bastard I can feel myself becoming.)

I always reply in the affirmative, of course, but I find it hard to meet her gaze as I do so. The truth is, I don't think I do love her any more, certainly not in the way I used to.

But then it's often the same with relationships. Initial attraction develops into curiosity, which segues into blazing passion. Once you've got past that stage you become companions - soulmates - familiar with each other's idiosyncracies and content.

But then their foibles become irritating; every word and action sets your teeth on edge and you become almost incapable of having a rational conversation without turning into some sarcastic, acid-tongued monster.

Thankfully, my wife and I are not at that stage and probably never will be. Neither of us is equipped with the ruthless temperament necessary for that kind of confrontation, and I do still care for her, not in a sensual, passionate way, but I don't want to see her hurt.

No, it's worse than that - worse than all-out domestic/emotional warfare, which would at least add some fire and passion to our relationship. Instead, we've encountered boredom. Or at least I have. I think she takes my occasional dark moods as a sign of stress, tiredness or overwork, rather than a symptom of boredom and disillusionment.

The worst part of it is, I can't tell her. She's faithful, trusting and naive, and she loves me deeply. Any sign of grevious domestic disharmony, and talk of failure in our relationship, any hint that I no longer love her, would destroy her. Cowardice keeps me silent.

Add to this the X-factor: our three-year-old daughter, blonde and beautiful, with huge brown eyes that radiate happiness and intelligence. I love her with an intensity that I wouldn't have thought possible a few years ago, and I wouldn't do anything to harm her or damage her trust. The thought of what would happen to her if her parents split up fills me with dread. The emotional upheaval for all of us, the weekend-only access, the thought of never being allowed to get as close to her as I am now. I can't think of anything more horrible.

So I soldier on, for her sake, and for the sake of not wanting to hurt my wife. I tolerate the tedium of a stalled relationship. We have always been different - different interests, different personalities. Opposites attract, but now we just kind of cancel each other out. I can see it, she can't. So I continue to fake it. When she needs my affection, I respond dutifully. My mouth smiles, but my eyes don't. I feel trapped and I can't tell her. The boredom, I can deal with; but the deceit... There are times when, in the heat of an argument, I've almost blurted out the truth - told her how I really feel. But then I think of the consequences, and I bite my tongue.

The truth is, we rarely argue. I've always felt that blazing rows can be a good thing in a relationship, clearing the air and bringing about a state of calm, like a fierce electrical storm on a muggy summer's day. Perhaps the fact that we don't argue any more is just another symptom of a dying relationship, where the partners can no longer be bothered to make an effort - though my wife would no doubt see this domestic equilibrium as a good thing.

Ostensibly, we carry on as normal - whatever that is. I continue to live a lie, and my lack of courage, my inability to bring about change, frustrate me. But when I look around and see the physical and emotional wreckage of lives shattered by divorce and separation, I ask myself if it was all worth it. Days of domestic boredom I can cope with, especially if the alternative means being a part-time parent, which would, for me, be the worst thing imaginable.

I often dream of freedom, of running away from it all and starting again, but they're just dreams. I know it's something I'll never be able to do. I'm too terrified of the consequences. So things remain as they are.

'Do you love me?' my wife asks.

'Yes' I reply. And my heart shrivels a little more.

The author's name has been changed

fields.headline: Knights of the lunch table
fields.standfirst: To mark Sir John Gielgud's death last week, we reprint his classic 1975 lunchtime encounter with Sir Ralph Richardson, witnessed by John Heilpern and Jane Bown
fields.trailText: To mark Sir John Gielgud's death last week, we reprint his classic 1975 lunchtime encounter with Sir Ralph Richardson, witnessed by John Heilpern and Jane Bown
fields.body:
Sir John Gielgud and Sir Ralph Richardson, starring in Harold Pinter's No Man's Land, meet for lunch in a West End restaurant at the request of a newspaper.

The setting is discreet and grand.

There, the two actors are to be specially photographed for The Observer .

Outside the restaurant, the roar of a motorbike is heard.

Enter SIR RALPH RICHARDSON.

He is dressed in a smart brown suit and an enormous cyclist's helmet, like a visor. He offers the helmet to the head waiter with the aplomb of an English gentleman handing over his bowler hat. Then he sits at a corner table and orders a vodka martini.

Enter SIR JOHN GIELGUD.

He is tall and elegant, pink and sunny, immaculately dressed. An acquaintance spots him and greets him warmly: 'Wish you were lunching with us, Johnny!'

The two actors meet and sit together. Both are very relaxed in each other's company, and fun. Words tumble out of Sir John, whereas Sir Ralph measures them carefully, as if squeezing out every syllable.

SIR JOHN: Come on the motorbike?

SIR RALPH: Best...way.

JG: The last time you took me pillion I practically had a fit. I was a stretcher case.

RR: I have been killed several times myself.

JG: Shall we have oysters?

RR: Good idea! And to follow? Fish and game go rather nicely together.

JG: I shall have roast grouse because I love it. I love roast grouse more than anything.

RR: Roast grouse is awfully good.

JG: I remember being taken to the Naval and Military Club as a very young man and being given oysters and grouse for the first time. I thought I really was living it up.

RR: Shall we live it up now?

JG: Certainly!

RR: You're looking very well, by the way.

JG: Thank you.

RR: I haven't seen much of you lately.

JG: We meet in costume.

RR: We meet as other people.

A waiter hovers.

RR: We're having oysters followed by grouse.

JG: You are, too? Oh, good.

RR: Wine?

JG: You're very good on the wine, Ralph.

RR: Let's have a small carafe of white wine with the fish and a small carafe of red with the game. I would like to have more, but dare not.

JG: We're all much more abstemious with drink than we used to be.

RR: I'm less abstemious. When I was young, I never drank during the run of a show, except on Saturday nights.

JG: Oh, I used to drink away like anything. On the first night of Much Ado , Peggy Ashcroft and I drank a bottle of champagne before going on and we never played so well in our lives.

RR: It would have terrified me. The spring wouldn't be there. Lowers the energy.

JG: But just think of all those brilliant people who couldn't function without a drink. I'm sure Barrymore couldn't have done it.

RR: Kean was the greatest drinker of them all, of course. Hot brandy. When he was playing Othello, he invented a false exit for himself so he could nip off for a brandy and come on again, fortified as it were.

JG: Do you think opera singers have a drop or two between their arias?

A waiter serves oysters. A waiter serves wine.

RR: A toast! To The Observer !

JG: May its building never be streaked.

RR: Did you see the charming Russian painting in the Times? Looked like a Nicholson.

JG: With the spires?

RR: Curious that Russia has never really produced a great painter.

JG: Diaghilev had some very talented people, but they were more designers.

RR: I wonder how painting could have escaped a nation like Russia.

JG: Very baffling country, Russia.

RR: And Leningrad?

JG: Very bleak.

RR: How are your oysters?

JG: Marvellous!

RR: The strangest thing happened to me when I was coming out of the theatre last night. I was walking down St Martin's Lane when a man suddenly shouted: 'Look! It's Sir John Gielgud!'

JG: But in America they always call me Sir Ralph Richardson. Perhaps it's because we've acted together over the years. We're almost like the broker's men in Cinderella .

RR: But would you say we look alike, Johnny? I was in France some time ago. Very peculiar. It was dark and my wife had gone down a little alley. I said: 'Mu, it's this way.' And a Frenchman appeared in the half light and cried: 'Mon Dieu! It's John Gielgud!'

JG: I've been stopped twice in London for Kenneth Clark.

RR: I should be most flattered to be mistaken for him.

They finish the oysters. Grouse is served.

JG: I was so angry with myself at the Garrick the other day. I just couldn't remember the name of an actor I knew. I haven't even remembered it now. Someone like Sybil Thorndike never forgets anybody.

RR: Never.

JG: She even remembers people she met in Australia.

RR: She remembers everyone.

JG: I have to look up the names of actors in Spotlight . Emlyn Williams used to turn over all the pages and whenever he saw a photograph of an actor wearing a hat he'd shout: 'BALD.' Emlyn could spot them.

RR: Pass the Paul Robeson.

Gielgud passes over a large pepper mill.

JG: A Russian came to see me after the show last night.

RR: A Russian! What did he want?

JG: He spoke terribly good English for a Russian. He said he was so glad he'd seen the performance because he felt he understood Harold Pinter at last. He said that No Man's Land is just a wonderful black comedy. It was such a relief to me. People get rather desperate about what the play means. I'm not sure I know either. Yet here was the Russian who accepted it simply as a black comedy instead of searching for endless symbolism and implications of every kind. I mean, I'm sure Harold's plays always have implications, but I don't think his intention is for the audience to spend the entire evening trying to solve them. I'm sure he's quite pleased if people go away and discuss the possibilities.

RR : Did you see that man walk out of the performance last night?

JG : The only time it's happened.

RR : Perhaps he was offended by the language.

JG : Yet it's very interesting how the elderly public remains so calm at all the expletives flowing from us on stage.

RR : Common parlance.

JG : I remember saying to my mother when I was a boy: 'Couldn't we go and see Uncle Fred in the Scarlet Pimp ?' And my mother replied:'If you ever use such language again I'll turn you out of the house!'

RR : There were times when it used to be thought that the legs of furniture were risqué. They used to put little crinolines round piano legs.

JG : Like a lady never revealing her ankles. How times have changed! I've never had anyone interrupt a play because of the bad language, except in Brighton, of course. When I was in Veterans whole rows got up and stormed out. 'Don't use THAT WORD in front of my wife.'

JG : Curious, isn't it? Brighton was always the best audience outside London. Very..._dangerous now.

Suddenly Sir Ralph jumps, pointing to his plate dramatically. Waiters surround him.

RR : What is THAT?

JG : I think it's a bit of liver, Ralph.

RR : Never touch it! Take the liver away. Otherwise, perfect. Bear the offending liver away...

JG : I hear Peter Brook's coming over from Paris with a new production.

RR : Ah, Brook.

JG : You've never worked with him, Ralph. But I've done four or five productions and I'm devoted to him. Sometimes I wish he wasn't quite so eclectic.

RR : Eclectic? What does the word mean?

JG : What does it mean? Special, I think.

RR : Sounds Greek to me. Greekish sounding word..

JG : I suppose it must be Greek. But the only man I've known who had the same quality as Brook was Komisarjevsky. He was an architect, a designer, a painter, a director. Enormous talent and knowledge. I think Lindsay Anderson is so brilliant, but he hasn't got the charisma of Brook. Peter's a sort of world figure. I often long for Lindsay to have the same appeal and success. I think he would do marvellous work if he had a little more appreciation.

RR : What was that terrible production Brook did? Of course, he's done such amazing stuff. Parts of A Midsummer Night's Dream were among the most brilliant theatre of our time. But that ghastly thing. You were in it.

JG : Oedipus ?

RR : That's it! Awful.

JG : Oh, I thought it was extraordinary. I'll never regret doing it. I wasn't very good in it. I didn't know how to do what he wanted. But you know, there were terrible rows between Brook and Olivier. When Olivier saw this great phallus on the stage of the Old Vic he thought the theatre would be closed down by the police. Brook wouldn't give in, though. They were arguing in the dressing room. So I left them to fight it out between them. When I came back a huge mirror had a crack right through it. It was like the Lady of Shalott. I long to know which one of them did it.

RR : When I went to see the production, somehow I hadn't got a programme. So I said to Mu: 'Leave it to me.' And I went down the aisle up to a chap, but he was lashed to a pillar. I didn't know what was going on. It turned out he was in the show. I think he was in the chorus. But the show hadn't started yet. Mu said: 'Did you get a programme?' And I had to say it wasn't possible because all the programme sellers were lashed to the dress circle. Very strange.

JG : Oh, dear! It's like the old lady who went to Wesker's Roots and they cooked a meal on stage during the first act. Onions and a frightful stew. The lady went up to a programme seller and said: 'Isn't there a rather curious smell in this theatre?' And the programme seller replied: 'It's the play, madam.' But what did the poor actor who was lashed to the pillar say to you?

RR : Well, of course, when I asked him for a programme all I got were these strangled sounds. He was gagged you see. The whole experience upset me very much. I'm a very square man.

JG : Yes, you are. But you're also very clever, Ralph. You can be very suspicious, but once you overcome it you're enormously interested and warm. Unlike me, you're cautious. Which is quite right.

RR : Very, very cautious.

Enter Miss Jane Bown, the photographer from The Observer. The two actors greet her most courteously.

RR : It must be so difficult being a photographer. It's a hobby of mine! But whenever I try to photograph anyone they always look as if they've been hit over the head with a meat axe.

JG : I think I'd rather be photographed than drawn. David Hockney did a drawing of me when I was 70 and I thought if I really look like that I must kill myself tomorrow.

RR : It wasn't too bad, Johnny.

JG : It's awfully difficult to reconcile yourself with your image at any age, I think. I couldn't get over Garbo being 70 the other day. Did you see that photo of her? It really shocked me. Photography is rather a terrifying medium. Look at Richard Avedon's pictures. Merciless! He photographed me once and asked me to cry for him. So I thought of everyone I loved and the tears flowed like mad. But he never published the picture anywhere. Two hours of crying for nothing. I was very cross.

RR : The trouble is I can never remember who I am whenever I'm photographed. Who am I? I find I'm no one in particular and it tends to emerge in the photos. Is the light all right, Miss Bown?

JG : It's strange. I never feel secure whenever I'm photographed in costume at dress rehearsals. You're not yet the character that's being photographed. When you've been playing a part for a little while you get the right face for it. You can see it.

You can feel secure in your feet. The role comes gradually with various parts of the body. It doesn't fill the anatomy at once. Sometimes the voice is behind. Other times, I feel very secure in my ... eyes.

JG : Marvellous grouse!

RR : Absolutely wonderful! I went to a restaurant in Hollywood once and had the most frightful lunch. When they asked me to pay I made the only joke I've ever cracked in my life. I said: 'The only thing you've cooked is the bill.'

Short pause.

RR : Aren't you nice, John? The way you laughed at my only joke. Jolly nice of you!

JG : Have you ever had a really marvellous Indian curry?

RR : Nothing like it!

JG : I had one in Ceylon. I went to Government House and we had an all-curry lunch. Had to rest for three hours afterwards. It was unbelievable!

RR : I know! I once had a curry in Bombay. There's a millionairess there who lives in a fantastic palace. Talk about food of paradise! Afterwards I said to her: 'It must be marvellous to be a millionairess, as you undoubtedly are. And this superb curry! How could you possibly find a chef to make it?' And she replied: 'There's only one chef in this palace and that chef is me.' Imagine it! The Indian millionairess had gone to market at five o'clock that very morning to select the ingredients herself. Probably bearers to carry her back.

JG : How splendid! Have you been reading Ackerley's Hindoo Holiday ?

RR : Wonderful! I'm so glad you gave it to me.

JG : Don't you think it's clever?

RR : I savour it sip by sip. What a writer!

JG : Don't you find Indians are so extraordinary? When I was in Bombay at the end of the war I was lying naked in my hotel room when the telephone rang. A voice said there was a lady to see me. Well, I'd been flying all week and was too tired to see anyone. But five minutes later the door burst open and an enormous Indian lady in a green sari looked at me trying desperately to cover myself with a tiny towel and announced: 'My name is Mrs Sabawala. My house is music in stone. Will you come to lunch tomorrow?' It turned out she had played Madame Arcati in Blithe Spirit with the local amateurs. Her house had a huge gate with a cardboard crescent moon pinned to it. Nothing to drink.

RR : Nothing to drink!

JG : And terrible chairs. As you sat down your back was lacerated by the teak. You had to practically go down on your hands and knees to look out of the windows. The whole thing was absolutely mad! There was a tiny poet in a white suit who read a long poem he'd written in my honour. It once happened with Alan Ginsberg in New York too. I seem to inspire poetry in strange people. But I was so startled by the Indian poet that I stepped back in alarm and fell in a pool covered in lilies.

RR : My God, what you suffer! Not that you care, Johnny.

JG : Couldn't have happened in England, Ralph.

The two famous actors laugh and finish their lunch.

John Heilpern is theatre critic for the New York Observer and is the official biographer of John Osborne

fields.bodyText: Sir John Gielgud and Sir Ralph Richardson, starring in Harold Pinter's No Man's Land, meet for lunch in a West End restaurant at the request of a newspaper. The setting is discreet and grand. There, the two actors are to be specially photographed for The Observer . Outside the restaurant, the roar of a motorbike is heard. Enter SIR RALPH RICHARDSON. He is dressed in a smart brown suit and an enormous cyclist's helmet, like a visor. He offers the helmet to the head waiter with the aplomb of an English gentleman handing over his bowler hat. Then he sits at a corner table and orders a vodka martini. Enter SIR JOHN GIELGUD. He is tall and elegant, pink and sunny, immaculately dressed. An acquaintance spots him and greets him warmly: 'Wish you were lunching with us, Johnny!' The two actors meet and sit together. Both are very relaxed in each other's company, and fun. JG: The last time you took me pillion I practically had a fit. I was a stretcher case. RR: I have been killed several times myself. JG: Shall we have oysters? RR: Good idea! And to follow? Fish and game go rather nicely together. JG: I shall have roast grouse because I love it. I love roast grouse more than anything. RR: Roast grouse is awfully good. JG: I remember being taken to the Naval and Military Club as a very young man and being given oysters and grouse for the first time. I thought I really was living it up. RR: Shall we live it up now? JG: Certainly! RR: You're looking very well, by the way. JG: Thank you. RR: I haven't seen much of you lately. JG: We meet in costume. RR: We meet as other people. A waiter hovers. RR: We're having oysters followed by grouse. JG: You are, too? Oh, good. RR: Wine? JG: You're very good on the wine, Ralph. RR: Let's have a small carafe of white wine with the fish and a small carafe of red with the game. I would like to have more, but dare not. JG: We're all much more abstemious with drink than we used to be. RR: I'm less abstemious. When I was young, I never drank during the run of a show, except on Saturday nights. JG: Oh, I used to drink away like anything. On the first night of Much Ado , Peggy Ashcroft and I drank a bottle of champagne before going on and we never played so well in our lives. RR: It would have terrified me. The spring wouldn't be there. Lowers the energy. JG: But just think of all those brilliant people who couldn't function without a drink. I'm sure Barrymore couldn't have done it. RR: Kean was the greatest drinker of them all, of course. Hot brandy. When he was playing Othello, he invented a false exit for himself so he could nip off for a brandy and come on again, fortified as it were. JG: Do you think opera singers have a drop or two between their arias? A waiter serves oysters. A waiter serves wine. RR: A toast! To The Observer ! JG: May its building never be streaked. RR: Did you see the charming Russian painting in the Times? Looked like a Nicholson. JG: With the spires? RR: Curious that Russia has never really produced a great painter. JG: Diaghilev had some very talented people, but they were more designers. RR: I wonder how painting could have escaped a nation like Russia. JG: Very baffling country, Russia. RR: And Leningrad? JG: Very bleak. RR: How are your oysters? JG: Marvellous! RR: The strangest thing happened to me when I was coming out of the theatre last night. It was dark and my wife had gone down a little alley. I said: 'Mu, it's this way.' And a Frenchman appeared in the half light and cried: 'Mon Dieu! It's John Gielgud!' JG: I've been stopped twice in London for Kenneth Clark. RR: I should be most flattered to be mistaken for him. They finish the oysters. Grouse is served. JG: I was so angry with myself at the Garrick the other day. I just couldn't remember the name of an actor I knew. I haven't even remembered it now. Emlyn Williams used to turn over all the pages and whenever he saw a photograph of an actor wearing a hat he'd shout: 'BALD.' Emlyn could spot them. RR: Pass the Paul Robeson. People get rather desperate about what the play means. I'm not sure I know either. Yet here was the Russian who accepted it simply as a black comedy instead of searching for endless symbolism and implications of every kind. I mean, I'm sure Harold's plays always have implications, but I don't think his intention is for the audience to spend the entire evening trying to solve them. I'm sure he's quite pleased if people go away and discuss the possibilities. RR : Did you see that man walk out of the performance last night? JG : The only time it's happened. RR : Perhaps he was offended by the language. JG : Yet it's very interesting how the elderly public remains so calm at all the expletives flowing from us on stage. RR : Common parlance. JG : I remember saying to my mother when I was a boy: 'Couldn't we go and see Uncle Fred in the Scarlet Pimp ?' Of course, he's done such amazing stuff. Parts of A Midsummer Night's Dream were among the most brilliant theatre of our time. But that ghastly thing. You were in it. JG : Oedipus ? RR : That's it! Awful. JG : Oh, I thought it was extraordinary. I'll never regret doing it. I wasn't very good in it. I didn't know how to do what he wanted. Brook wouldn't give in, though. They were arguing in the dressing room. So I left them to fight it out between them. When I came back a huge mirror had a crack right through it.
