webTitle: Don't take the fun out of being a parent

fields.headline: Don't take the fun out of being a parent
fields.trailText: The mother, the father, and the Baby Blair. They make a perfect picture, don't they? As icons, they stand for everything a family ought to be. But how close can the rest of us hope to get to this ideal?
fields.body:
The mother, the father, and the Baby Blair. They make a perfect picture, don't they? As icons, they stand for everything a family ought to be. But how close can the rest of us hope to get to this ideal?

Look beyond the picture frame, look at any tabloid any day of the week, and the picture of British family life looks like something out of Hades. As a nation we have become obsessed with fears about damaged children and endangered childhood.

These stories come and go very fast. We are up in arms about them one day, and then, a few days later, not thinking about them at all. So it is hard to see what effect they have on our thinking in the long term. But if you put all the stories of the past 10 years back to back, you see our traditional understanding of parenthood being eroded almost daily by the dreadful tales of deranged baby snatchers and killer babysitters, mothers who leave their children home alone and go off for a fortnight in Benidorm, and mothers who stay at home while their boyfriends beat their children to death.

Everywhere we look we see paedophiles. Some run children's homes, others run scout clubs, or masquerade as teachers, priests, doctors, nursery aids, and counsellors. Many are stepfathers. Biological fathers have a record that is only slightly cleaner, and, while most mothers continue to be above suspicion, the scandals featuring abusive and murderous ones are slowly undermining our complacency.

Faced with this endless procession of disgraced, failed, and criminal parents, it is easy to forget that the vast majority of parents do not murder their children. It is hard even to think about procreation as a basic human right. In fact, it is a human right (enshrined in British law since 1998). But every time we read of a child who has been hurt or abandoned, abused or killed, we cannot help but ask, how did we let this happen? Why were these parents entrusted with this fragile, innocent life? The idea that parents need to be improved morally, and held to strict public standards, is one that is gaining support right across the political spectrum. Thus, we have think-tanks publishing report after report on the endangered family, the inadequate parent, and the lawless child. We have the Government attributing an ever-expanding range of social ills on parental neglect, abuse, or 'lack of preparedness'. There is wide debate about the damage done to children by parents who divorce, by parents who spend too little time at home because they work too hard, and by parents who ought to have realised they were too poor, or immature, and irresponsible to give their children that all-important good start. There is a growing consensus that something must be done to tell these parents what their responsibilities are.

If I am objecting to this consensus, am I saying that parents should be allowed to do whatever they want, no matter what effect this has on their children? That they need not take responsibility for their mistakes? No, of course I'm not. I think it is essential for parents to take responsibility for their children, and for the way they bring them up. There may be a limit to what individual parents can do for their children, but (in my view) all parents owe it to their children to work with what they have. Even when their lives are constrained and their choices severely limited, they still have a great deal of power over their children, and their children depend on them to use that power wisely.

My problem with the 'new morality' I have seen developing, scandal by scandal, over the past two decades, is its ambivalence about parents having any power at all. Traditional morality divided parents along gender lines, giving ultimate authority to the male head of household. The new morality sets out to be gender-blind, but it still divides parents into two groups, and only sees one group as capable of exercising parental power and authority. It would like to demote the other, less 'responsible' parents to the status of children, or should I say, to the status formerly accorded to women before we got the vote.

However, treating parents like children does not make them into better parents. No mother can hope to care for her children in a humane way if she is perfectly content to let others set the rules by which they live.

For example, I cannot claim to be doing the best for my children if the first thing I do is defer in all matters to a higher authority. I am not going to be able to do much for them if I agree to stay at home and cultivate my own parent trap. My children don't just need me at home: they need me to defend their interests outside it. Not just their present interests, but their future interests. And not just their personal interests, but the interests of their generation. But I can't do that unless I have the right to do so. If I say parents need to have rights, the first response is often a shudder, followed by a reminder about the legions of parents who don't deserve them.

But imagine if you applied that argument to other areas of life. Imagine if you said that adults couldn't use banks any more, because some of them were embezzlers. Imagine if you banned all drivers, because some drove when over the limit and ignored traffic lights. No one draws up a bill of rights using as their model a bank robber or a drunk driver. The model is always an ideal type, and the degree to which a human being can enjoy those rights depends on how hard he or she tries to live by the ideal. You can take rights away from people who act criminally or irresponsibly, but unless you give them rights, they cannot act at all. Michael Freeman, the children's rights advocate, says that possessing rights 'is necessary to constitute personality. Those who lack rights are like slaves, means to another's ends, and never their own sovereigns'. While it's true that adults do have rights as individuals, their rights as representatives of their families or their children are being fast eroded. This has happened as a direct consequence of the many media-led panics about parenting, which have given rise to a growing consensus that parents have children for suspect reasons, and use them as extensions of their egos or for their private pleasure. And while many people believe that curtailing parents' rights is wise, and state intervention in families necessary to keep parents from using their power over their children badly, it also means that parents have less and less power to change their children's lives for the better.

Nowhere is this more apparent than in 'Supporting Families', the consultation document in which the Government sets out its radical new framework for family policy. Many of the measures in this document - such as parenting orders - are coming into place right now. As government documents go, it could not be more family-friendly. In addition to an ambitious national childcare strategy and financial aid for families in greatest need, it also proposes a new sort of partnership between parents and the state. The Government offers to become almost the third parent of every British child, a sort of Holy Ghost of family life, offering help, advice, and guidance from cradle to grave.

But look closer. The language in this document is rather worrying. Children are measured and judged primarily by their behaviour and performance. When the word happiness' appears, it is paired with the word 'success'. When the word 'loving' appears, it is to modify the word 'firmness'. Bringing up children is not a joy or a revelation, but a service. Children are not little people with their own personalities that transform the way you look at the world. They feature instead as challenging and problematic objects that must be monitored, corralled, tamed and improved. While this may be an accurate description of some aspects of child-rearing, as an overview it is narrow and blinkered and does not come close to describing what it means to me, or, I suspect, to anyone who has ever looked after children, Tony and Cherie included.

The document's use of the blanket term 'parent' is similarly worrying. At first it looks nice, modern, inclusive. But replace the word 'parent' with 'line manager', and you quickly see that it treats parents as if they were public employees. Go back to those same statements and replace the word 'parent' with 'woman' and you pick up on the paternalistic tone. You begin to understand how business is being done. It's: 'We've thought this out very carefully, darling, and I know it sounds awfully complicated, but honestly, it's for your own good.' As opposed to: 'We need to think this over and here are my ideas. As a parent of 21 years' standing, what do you have to add?'

Well, Jack Straw, here's what I have to add. I can't claim to be the sort of parent you might want as a role model. I'm divorced. I am not always good at loving firmness. My study is a tip, as is my bedroom. According to my partner, the towels in the dryer are still damp. Last night, I made myself a Lemsip and then forgot to put the mug in the sink. Once, about 10 or 11 years ago, I forgot all about supper and when my children began to complain at 11 in the evening, I found out that all I had to give them was ice cream.

In spite of all this, I really do try very hard, at least most of the time, to be a good example to my children, and think very hard about how I bring them up. I've agonised as any parent about whether or not I have brought them up to have the right kind of manners, and the right set of values and the right attitude to work, life and other people. I entertain the usual vain hope that they will all turn into thoughtful, talented, happy, dependable, neat adults. I indulge in as many impossible fantasies as any parent about the amazing things they might do for mankind one day, thus proving to the world that I was a much better parent than they ever imagined.

But there is one ambition I am pretty sure I never had. I don't think I ever sat down with their fathers and said: 'Here's an idea. Let's spend the next 20 years or so raising children according to government standards. Let's become a building block of society, and turn out a host of responsible citizens. Let's make sure they grow up knowing that really good citizens should always do what the state tells them to do, and never question it.'

No two of my children have ever held a cup in the same way, or had the same way of walking, or had the same voice, or the same way of singing, thinking, laughing, or seeing the world. Bringing them up has mostly meant watching them become themselves. It's a terrible mistake to think that parents are the wise ones, and children their blank slates. If I had to say what I've treasured most about the times I've had with all four of my children, it's been the things they surprised me with, the things they did or said or thought up or discovered by themselves. When my eldest daughter woke up early one morning when she was five (or it was six), took my cheque book out of my handbag and wrote me a cheque for a million pounds. When she wrapped up all my jewellery in the pages of a typescript I was printing out and gave it back to me. When my two little daughters decorated my bedroom with 200 plastic animals, and positioned them in such a way that they were all facing the television set. When they learnt to count to 10 in Turkish. When they tried and failed to teach me sign language. When I took them to a village in Spain, and they kept themselves amused by counting the things they saw and couldn't understand. I've learnt as much about life from watching my children grow as they've ever learnt from watching me.

It would be too much to expect any government to see children the way parents do, just as it would be too much to hope that, when children and young people don't behave in a way that is convenient for them, governments will not immediately see this behaviour as anti-social.

The problems begin when there is no one out there to challenge this view of things, or to suggest that it is not the only valid interpretation of events. The worst thing about the current media panic surrounding parents and parenthood, is that it makes state intervention seem necessary. We're failing our children, and our families are disintegrating, so someone must step in and restore the moral order. What's broken must be fixed.

But there always have been parents who fail their children, and there always will be. So long as most parents operate in conditions as appalling as some of those that exist today, we can be pretty sure there will continue to be many, many parents who fail their children. Efforts to police and lecture them, shame and name them, may make those parents feel bad, and the rest of us feel superior, but they won't solve the problems that pushed them over the edge.

This is not to say that turning parents into scapegoats is something of which only the authorities are guilty. It has become ingrained in our culture, something we all seem to take great pleasure in. It's a way of confirming to ourselves that actually, despite all the changes we've gone through over the past decades, most of us still have the same values, or at least a shared understand ing of what it is we've almost lost. It is a form of moral shorthand. Look at them, we say. Is this what the world is coming to? Maybe it won't be if we punish them for their sins. To imply that a parent fails because of lapsed morals, is to imply that there's an easy solution. You don't have to solve poverty, or redesign your employment policy, or try to figure out how you factor in unpaid work when planning a market economy. All you have to do is give people lessons, and then more lessons. If they still don't learn, all they deserve is a lecture and a stiff fine.

I can see the attraction of this argument. What I can't understand is how anybody could seriously believe it. You have only to use your eyes and think for a moment to see that there is always more to it than that. This brings me to the one thing I really do hope I have taught my children: that believing in fairy-stories just because they're comforting can be a dangerous enterprise.

I hope I've taught them that while it is sometimes inconvenient to stop and think, and ask awkward questions, it is also what makes a democracy stay democratic, a society ethical, and a conscience clear. I hope I've taught them that, for no other reason than that it was from them I rediscovered the importance of inconvenient questions - as those are the kind that children ask.

They stubbornly insist on seeing life as a mystery to explore instead of a grim plan they must honour. They revel in the little things that adults forget to notice. They show their emotions, even to the point of being pleased when they see themselves in the mirror. They look forward to their birthdays. Even when they refuse to eat their vegetables, they grow. They ask 'why?'. These are just a few of the miracles they perform for their parents, and that is why even today, with things so grim and getting daily grimmer, parents still talk about life with children as a joy.

I hope my children will be able to know this joy themselves when they grow up, and that then as now they will keep on stopping and looking and asking those inconvenient questions.

A BILL OF RIGHTS FOR PARENTS

1 The right to bear children

2 The right to raise children

3 The right to create a home

4 The right to informality

5 The right to determine your own marital status

6 The right to plan, choose, share and define care

7 The right to define support

8 The right to receive support

9 The right to challenge intervention

10 The right to be consulted

11 The right to have an independent life

12 The right to represent your children's interests

13 The right to define the place of parents in society

14 The right to represent the larger interests of parents and other carers, and explore the ethical and political dilemmas of domestic life in the political arena
fields.bodyText: The mother, the father, and the Baby Blair. They make a perfect picture, don't they? As icons, they stand for everything a family ought to be. But how close can the rest of us hope to get to this ideal? Look beyond the picture frame, look at any tabloid any day of the week, and the picture of British family life looks like something out of Hades. As a nation we have become obsessed with fears about damaged children and endangered childhood. These stories come and go very fast. We are up in arms about them one day, and then, a few days later, not thinking about them at all. So it is hard to see what effect they have on our thinking in the long term. But if you put all the stories of the past 10 years back to back, you see our traditional understanding of parenthood being eroded almost daily by the dreadful tales of deranged baby snatchers and killer babysitters, mothers who leave their children home alone and go off for a fortnight in Benidorm, and mothers who stay at home while their boyfriends beat their children to death. Everywhere we look we see paedophiles. Some run children's homes, others run scout clubs, or masquerade as teachers, priests, doctors, nursery aids, and counsellors. Many are stepfathers. Biological fathers have a record that is only slightly cleaner, and, while most mothers continue to be above suspicion, the scandals featuring abusive and murderous ones are slowly undermining our complacency. Faced with this endless procession of disgraced, failed, and criminal parents, it is easy to forget that the vast majority of parents do not murder their children. It is hard even to think about procreation as a basic human right. In fact, it is a human right (enshrined in British law since 1998). But every time we read of a child who has been hurt or abandoned, abused or killed, we cannot help but ask, how did we let this happen? Why were these parents entrusted with this fragile, innocent life? The idea that parents need to be improved morally, and held to strict public standards, is one that is gaining support right across the political spectrum. Thus, we have think-tanks publishing report after report on the endangered family, the inadequate parent, and the lawless child. We have the Government attributing an ever-expanding range of social ills on parental neglect, abuse, or 'lack of preparedness'. There is wide debate about the damage done to children by parents who divorce, by parents who spend too little time at home because they work too hard, and by parents who ought to have realised they were too poor, or immature, and irresponsible to give their children that all-important good start. There is a growing consensus that something must be done to tell these parents what their responsibilities are. If I am objecting to this consensus, am I saying that parents should be allowed to do whatever they want, no matter what effect this has on their children? That they need not take responsibility for their mistakes? No, of course I'm not. I think it is essential for parents to take responsibility for their children, and for the way they bring them up. There may be a limit to what individual parents can do for their children, but (in my view) all parents owe it to their children to work with what they have. Even when their lives are constrained and their choices severely limited, they still have a great deal of power over their children, and their children depend on them to use that power wisely. My problem with the 'new morality' I have seen developing, scandal by scandal, over the past two decades, is its ambivalence about parents having any power at all. Traditional morality divided parents along gender lines, giving ultimate authority to the male head of household. The new morality sets out to be gender-blind, but it still divides parents into two groups, and only sees one group as capable of exercising parental power and authority. It would like to demote the other, less 'responsible' parents to the status of children, or should I say, to the status formerly accorded to women before we got the vote. However, treating parents like children does not make them into better parents. No mother can hope to care for her children in a humane way if she is perfectly content to let others set the rules by which they live. For example, I cannot claim to be doing the best for my children if the first thing I do is defer in all matters to a higher authority. I am not going to be able to do much for them if I agree to stay at home and cultivate my own parent trap. My children don't just need me at home: they need me to defend their interests outside it. Not just their present interests, but their future interests. And not just their personal interests, but the interests of their generation. But I can't do that unless I have the right to do so. If I say parents need to have rights, the first response is often a shudder, followed by a reminder about the legions of parents who don't deserve them. But imagine if you applied that argument to other areas of life. Imagine if you said that adults couldn't use banks any more, because some of them were embezzlers. Imagine if you banned all drivers, because some drove when over the limit and ignored traffic lights. No one draws up a bill of rights using as their model a bank robber or a drunk driver. The model is always an ideal type, and the degree to which a human being can enjoy those rights depends on how hard he or she tries to live by the ideal. You can take rights away from people who act criminally or irresponsibly, but unless you give them rights, they cannot act at all. Michael Freeman, the children's rights advocate, says that possessing rights 'is necessary to constitute personality. Those who lack rights are like slaves, means to another's ends, and never their own sovereigns'. While it's true that adults do have rights as individuals, their rights as representatives of their families or their children are being fast eroded. This has happened as a direct consequence of the many media-led panics about parenting, which have given rise to a growing consensus that parents have children for suspect reasons, and use them as extensions of their egos or for their private pleasure. And while many people believe that curtailing parents' rights is wise, and state intervention in families necessary to keep parents from using their power over their children badly, it also means that parents have less and less power to change their children's lives for the better. Nowhere is this more apparent than in 'Supporting Families', the consultation document in which the Government sets out its radical new framework for family policy. Many of the measures in this document - such as parenting orders - are coming into place right now. As government documents go, it could not be more family-friendly. In addition to an ambitious national childcare strategy and financial aid for families in greatest need, it also proposes a new sort of partnership between parents and the state. The Government offers to become almost the third parent of every British child, a sort of Holy Ghost of family life, offering help, advice, and guidance from cradle to grave. But look closer. The language in this document is rather worrying. Children are measured and judged primarily by their behaviour and performance. When the word happiness' appears, it is paired with the word 'success'. When the word 'loving' appears, it is to modify the word 'firmness'. Bringing up children is not a joy or a revelation, but a service. Children are not little people with their own personalities that transform the way you look at the world. They feature instead as challenging and problematic objects that must be monitored, corralled, tamed and improved. While this may be an accurate description of some aspects of child-rearing, as an overview it is narrow and blinkered and does not come close to describing what it means to me, or, I suspect, to anyone who has ever looked after children, Tony and Cherie included. The document's use of the blanket term 'parent' is similarly worrying. At first it looks nice, modern, inclusive. But replace the word 'parent' with 'line manager', and you quickly see that it treats parents as if they were public employees. Go back to those same statements and replace the word 'parent' with 'woman' and you pick up on the paternalistic tone. You begin to understand how business is being done. It's: 'We've thought this out very carefully, darling, and I know it sounds awfully complicated, but honestly, it's for your own good.' As opposed to: 'We need to think this over and here are my ideas. As a parent of 21 years' standing, what do you have to add?' Well, Jack Straw, here's what I have to add. I can't claim to be the sort of parent you might want as a role model. I'm divorced. I am not always good at loving firmness. My study is a tip, as is my bedroom. According to my partner, the towels in the dryer are still damp. Last night, I made myself a Lemsip and then forgot to put the mug in the sink. Once, about 10 or 11 years ago, I forgot all about supper and when my children began to complain at 11 in the evening, I found out that all I had to give them was ice cream. In spite of all this, I really do try very hard, at least most of the time, to be a good example to my children, and think very hard about how I bring them up. I've agonised as any parent about whether or not I have brought them up to have the right kind of manners, and the right set of values and the right attitude to work, life and other people. I entertain the usual vain hope that they will all turn into thoughtful, talented, happy, dependable, neat adults. I indulge in as many impossible fantasies as any parent about the amazing things they might do for mankind one day, thus proving to the world that I was a much better parent than they ever imagined. But there is one ambition I am pretty sure I never had. I don't think I ever sat down with their fathers and said: 'Here's an idea. Let's spend the next 20 years or so raising children according to government standards. Let's become a building block of society, and turn out a host of responsible citizens. Let's make sure they grow up knowing that really good citizens should always do what the state tells them to do, and never question it.' No two of my children have ever held a cup in the same way, or had the same way of walking, or had the same voice, or the same way of singing, thinking, laughing, or seeing the world. Bringing them up has mostly meant watching them become themselves. It's a terrible mistake to think that parents are the wise ones, and children their blank slates. If I had to say what I've treasured most about the times I've had with all four of my children, it's been the things they surprised me with, the things they did or said or thought up or discovered by themselves. When my eldest daughter woke up early one morning when she was five (or it was six), took my cheque book out of my handbag and wrote me a cheque for a million pounds. When she wrapped up all my jewellery in the pages of a typescript I was printing out and gave it back to me. When my two little daughters decorated my bedroom with 200 plastic animals, and positioned them in such a way that they were all facing the television set. When they learnt to count to 10 in Turkish. When they tried and failed to teach me sign language. When I took them to a village in Spain, and they kept themselves amused by counting the things they saw and couldn't understand. I've learnt as much about life from watching my children grow as they've ever learnt from watching me. It would be too much to expect any government to see children the way parents do, just as it would be too much to hope that, when children and young people don't behave in a way that is convenient for them, governments will not immediately see this behaviour as anti-social. The problems begin when there is no one out there to challenge this view of things, or to suggest that it is not the only valid interpretation of events. The worst thing about the current media panic surrounding parents and parenthood, is that it makes state intervention seem necessary. We're failing our children, and our families are disintegrating, so someone must step in and restore the moral order. What's broken must be fixed. But there always have been parents who fail their children, and there always will be. So long as most parents operate in conditions as appalling as some of those that exist today, we can be pretty sure there will continue to be many, many parents who fail their children. Efforts to police and lecture them, shame and name them, may make those parents feel bad, and the rest of us feel superior, but they won't solve the problems that pushed them over the edge. This is not to say that turning parents into scapegoats is something of which only the authorities are guilty. It has become ingrained in our culture, something we all seem to take great pleasure in. It's a way of confirming to ourselves that actually, despite all the changes we've gone through over the past decades, most of us still have the same values, or at least a shared understand ing of what it is we've almost lost. fields.headline: Laurence of suburbia
fields.trailText: You can barely switch on your television without being told how to turn your kitchen into a Moroccan souk, or your utility cupboard into a fantasy on a theme of the Palace of Versailles. And the man who is chiefly responsible for all of this is Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, camp-as-you-like star of the makeover interiors show Changing Rooms .
fields.body:
This weekend around 26 million people will be dabbling in DIY. Not so long ago, bank holidays were spent scrapping on the seafront; nowadays, we pick fights in B&Q, battling over the last remaining pot of lavender Dulux. Five years ago, there were only four interiors magazines; you can currently pick from 25. You can barely switch on your television without being told how to turn your kitchen into a Moroccan souk, or your utility cupboard into a fantasy on a theme of the Palace of Versailles. And the man who is chiefly responsible for all of this is Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, camp-as-you-like star of the makeover interiors show Changing Rooms .

It was he, for instance, who magicked up a plum-coloured Queen Anne-style dining room with a fake fireplace for the Dukes family in Hull, and looked a little bit perplexed when Mrs Dukes promptly burst into tears. Certainly, his outlandish, jackdaw tastes mean that he acts as a Plimsoll line for DIYers. The comment 'That looks a bit Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen', often heard in home-improvement emporiums, is in fact a coded command meaning: 'Put that tester pot right back where you found it or there will be hell to pay.' He himself points out that as far as the viewing public is concerned, he is 'the fifth horseman of the Apocalypse, who rapes your room and then laughs in your face'.

I have been invited to meet Laurence at his house, The Nook, which does not disappoint. It's a classic 'Changing Rooms' project, since it is one thing on the outside (a squat Twenties bungalow with fussy stained-glass windows windows overlooking a busy south London road) and something else entirely within. Pia, his assistant, lets me into the turquoise hall, where recesses in the wall accommodate Nefertiti heads and pink-and-gold teacups, and shows me into the lilac sitting room, which is tiny - only marginally larger than a ping-pong table, so that you can pull the curtains, switch on the telly and shut the door without stirring from the sofa. Crammed with pink roses in distressed china jugs, and timber-sized candles, and biographies of Purcell and Cecil Beaton, with Satie's Gymnopédies tinkling restfully out of the CD player, it evokes the cabin of a romantic novelist who is going on a very long Cunard voyage. There isn't really room for me on the sofa, what with all the fawn velvet cushions, but I jemmy myself in as best I can. You simply can't imagine a family of four - Laurence, 34, has a wife, Jackie, and two little daughters called Cecile and Hermione - gathering in here to play Monopoly.

Laurence himself is in the garden shed that serves as his office, where he toils on his cutlery lines, and his wallpaper lines, and his tassel lines, as well as the telly stuff. He no longer does private commissions. ('It's an awful thing to say, but doing stuff for private clients is very bad business, when I look at how much I can charge for opening a supermarket.') When he enters - ever the camp, full-throttle dandy-highwayman in a William Hunt suit and an op-art tie-and-shirt combo that makes my eyes water - vapour trails of aftershave and cigarette smoke curl in his wake. He is making the most of Marlboro Lights, having decided to give them up last New Year's Eve. Or rather, last New Year's Eve, he decided he would give them up on June 24. 'You need a big date to work towards. Giving up on New Year's Day is pants because you've got to get through January,' he says. 'Whereas if you give up in the middle of summer, there are more distractions. I keep doing aversion therapy and thinking, "How disgusting!" In fact, I've got to have another cigarette now. I love smoking. I'm so good at it.'

The decision to give up smoking is but one plank in the all-new LLB philosophy. The others are to a) move the business out of the garden shed and into proper premises and b) to move house. Without any prompting, Laurence tells me that they bought The Nook for £125,000 four years ago, and now it's under offer at £375,000. 'Some of the estate agents were saying, "You can stack on an extra 70 grand because it's your place." But we decided we weren't going to be cheeky. I've made a quarter of a million on it - to ask for more than that just because I'm "me" sounds a bit... you know... downmarket.' He and Jackie, who married in 1989, are currently in a 'very tight biddingy-war thingy' on the next place, a house a few streets away which is a fine example of Adelaidian architecture.

'When you get to William IV, it's not William-ian, it's Adelaidian after Queen Adelaide, because she was a great arbiter of taste.'

The prospect of moving has allowed Laurence to show his true colours, which are not quite as bright as you'd expect. 'For four years I've been battling against a really rather ugly hunchback bungalow, so you need to paint it rather scary colours to take your eyes away from the fact that there's no architectural detail. I have quite enjoyed the democracy of that: there's nothing in this place that I haven't done for someone else on Changing Rooms. My MDF has exactly the same problems as their MDF. But this new place is so frighteningly posh that there's no question of me being democratic any more. I'm not going to contrive it. No colour boards.'

Laurence has several sociological theories about the DIY boom. He points out that 'a big Changing Rooms archive' has been assembled at the Victoria and Albert Museum: 'The V&A really feels that interior design has become a democratic preoccupation in a way that it never has been before. It's all about encouraging people to take control of their own environment. I do honestly believe there is something very important about this interiors obsession. Say on Monday morning you've got some thing really shitty to do: on Sunday night you do the weirdest things, like tidying up the linen cupboard, or sorting the cutlery drawer so all the forks are in the right place. If you take a little bit of control, it makes dealing with the big things easier.'

Gravel crunches in the drive, and then Jackie, strapping and jolly-looking, appears in the doorway. 'I have just signed on the dotted lines for our new offices!' she announces triumphantly. 'This is a mega day for us. The first time the company has actually taken proper premises. And d'you know, the great thing is that Laurence hasn't even seen it. I'm afraid I just got on with it - if you wait, you wait forever. So I've got some cold champagne to celebrate.'

'Is it decent?' asks Laurence, provocatively. He has already told me that they argue 'like Taylor and Burton'.

The gravel announces another arrival. Jehovah's Witnesses. Laurence says: 'Well, they might want to buy the house, so let's be nice.' He opens the door. There are astonished sounds of recognition. 'Good morning!' sings Laurence, switching to full-beam. 'You're reaching into your bag... are you bringing out a standard lamp, like Mary Poppins? Oh, how kind of you! I'm in the middle of an interview at the moment, but you can leave it with me - I'll give it a go. Are there puzzles in it? Do you do horoscopes? Restaurant reviews?' Fifteen seconds after he opened the door, he's closing it, leaving the Witnesses roaring with laughter on the other side.

Laurence grew up in Streatham, developing an early pash on aristocratic dynasties such as the Mitfords and the Sitwells to relieve the tedium of suburbia. His father, a surgeon, died of leukaemia when Laurence was nine, so he and his younger brother and sister were raised singlehandedly by their mother, increasingly affected by multiple sclerosis. The only time Laurence underplays anything is when talking about his childhood, which he calls 'very happy' and 'very comfortable and straightforward'.

Taste hit him between the eyeballs when he was 11, and touring two local schools which had offered him a place. 'We drove up to Dulwich College in the car, just to have a look around, and I had a meltdown. "I can't go to this school! It's vastly scary!" And then we drove up to Alleyn's, and it was lovely: a redbrick country house. I placed Dulwich College as being Crippensville, and Alleyn's as being lovely, with dried flowers and Agas.' After O-levels, he went to Camberwell Art School, and from there, into a rubber-flooring company where he worked in marketing.

When pushed, he admits his father's death probably had something to do with the pace of his teenage years.

'I don't think it's a conscious decision, but there is this motivation to get on and do. You do suddenly understand that things can come to an end very suddenly and it's as well to get doing very quickly.' When he came over a bit creative, the only thing he could do was change the way he looked. 'I got to the stage where I was feeling a bit frustrated. So I thought: right, I'm going to grow my hair again. And I bought my first frock coat.' When the company was sold, he made the decision to try his hand at interior design, and worked on the Richmond and Criterion theatres.

It was Jackie, then doing stints on Richard and Judy's sofa as the editor of Debrett's Wedding Guide, who mentioned to a producer friend that Laurence might be right for an interiors pilot. One of his colleagues on the first series was Liz Wagstaff, who became Hermione's godmother, and who was jailed last week for defrauding colleagues out of £54,000, having claimed that she had cancer and needed the money for treatment. Jackie had given Wagstaff £2,000. Can we talk about that? 'We can't, unfortunately, because Jackie's trying to broker a deal at the moment with I don't know which paper, to get some money back for people, the researchers and the runners who gave her £500.'

While Gary takes his picture, Laurence directs me to items of interest elsewhere. 'Have you noticed the wallpaper? It's mine, £9.99 a roll from Homebase. Please notice the photograph of me and Jackie with Prince Andrew. I'm not entirely sure of my motives in putting it out, but it was a lovely evening.' I get down on my hands and knees to inspect Cecile's doll's house. Clearly, she is her father's daughter: there is a bath in the sitting room, and one inhabitant is wedged into the fireplace. 'There's something so incredibly downmarket about being famous,' sighs Laurence happily, as one pose succeeds another.

Later, I ring the Royal Institute of British Architects and the Georgian Group to check how to spell 'Adelaidian', but they've never heard the term before. I call the V &A to find out more about the Changing Rooms archive but I can't find anyone there who is able to say whether it exists. 'I've been asking around, and nobody has heard of such an archive, so to say we have one is probably untrue,' says a spokesperson. Never mind. Laurence understands the importance of trompe l'oeil .

I've made a quarter of a million on it - to ask for more than that just because I'm "me" sounds a bit... you know... downmarket.' He and Jackie, who married in 1989, are currently in a 'very tight biddingy-war thingy' on the next place, a house a few streets away which is a fine example of Adelaidian architecture. 'When you get to William IV, it's not William-ian, it's Adelaidian after Queen Adelaide, because she was a great arbiter of taste.' The prospect of moving has allowed Laurence to show his true colours, which are not quite as bright as you'd expect. 'For four years I've been battling against a really rather ugly hunchback bungalow, so you need to paint it rather scary colours to take your eyes away from the fact that there's no architectural detail. I have quite enjoyed the democracy of that: there's nothing in this place that I haven't done for someone else on Changing Rooms. My MDF has exactly the same problems as their MDF. But this new place is so frighteningly posh that there's no question of me being democratic any more. I'm not going to contrive it. No colour boards.' Laurence has several sociological theories about the DIY boom. He points out that 'a big Changing Rooms archive' has been assembled at the Victoria and Albert Museum: 'The V&A really feels that interior design has become a democratic preoccupation in a way that it never has been before. It's all about encouraging people to take control of their own environment. I do honestly believe there is something very important about this interiors obsession. Say on Monday morning you've got some thing really shitty to do: on Sunday night you do the weirdest things, like tidying up the linen cupboard, or sorting the cutlery drawer so all the forks are in the right place. If you take a little bit of control, it makes dealing with the big things easier.' Gravel crunches in the drive, and then Jackie, strapping and jolly-looking, appears in the doorway. 'I have just signed on the dotted lines for our new offices!' she announces triumphantly. 'This is a mega day for us. The first time the company has actually taken proper premises. And d'you know, the great thing is that Laurence hasn't even seen it. I'm afraid I just got on with it - if you wait, you wait forever. So I've got some cold champagne to celebrate.' 'Is it decent?' asks Laurence, provocatively. He has already told me that they argue 'like Taylor and Burton'. The gravel announces another arrival. Jehovah's Witnesses. Laurence says: 'Well, they might want to buy the house, so let's be nice.' He opens the door. There are astonished sounds of recognition. 'Good morning!' sings Laurence, switching to full-beam. 'You're reaching into your bag... are you bringing out a standard lamp, like Mary Poppins? Oh, how kind of you! I'm in the middle of an interview at the moment, but you can leave it with me - I'll give it a go. Are there puzzles in it? Do you do horoscopes? Restaurant reviews?' Fifteen seconds after he opened the door, he's closing it, leaving the Witnesses roaring with laughter on the other side. Laurence grew up in Streatham, developing an early pash on aristocratic dynasties such as the Mitfords and the Sitwells to relieve the tedium of suburbia. His father, a surgeon, died of leukaemia when Laurence was nine, so he and his younger brother and sister were raised singlehandedly by their mother, increasingly affected by multiple sclerosis. The only time Laurence underplays anything is when talking about his childhood, which he calls 'very happy' and 'very comfortable and straightforward'. Taste hit him between the eyeballs when he was 11, and touring two local schools which had offered him a place. 'We drove up to Dulwich College in the car, just to have a look around, and I had a meltdown. "I can't go to this school! It's vastly scary!" And then we drove up to Alleyn's, and it was lovely: a redbrick country house. I placed Dulwich College as being Crippensville, and Alleyn's as being lovely, with dried flowers and Agas.' After O-levels, he went to Camberwell Art School, and from there, into a rubber-flooring company where he worked in marketing. When pushed, he admits his father's death probably had something to do with the pace of his teenage years. 'I don't think it's a conscious decision, but there is this motivation to get on and do. You do suddenly understand that things can come to an end very suddenly and it's as well to get doing very quickly.' When he came over a bit creative, the only thing he could do was change the way he looked. 'I got to the stage where I was feeling a bit frustrated. So I thought: right, I'm going to grow my hair again. And I bought my first frock coat.' When the company was sold, he made the decision to try his hand at interior design, and worked on the Richmond and Criterion theatres. It was Jackie, then doing stints on Richard and Judy's sofa as the editor of Debrett's Wedding Guide, who mentioned to a producer friend that Laurence might be right for an interiors pilot. One of his colleagues on the first series was Liz Wagstaff, who became Hermione's godmother, and who was jailed last week for defrauding colleagues out of £54,000, having claimed that she had cancer and needed the money for treatment. Jackie had given Wagstaff £2,000. Can we talk about that? 'We can't, unfortunately, because Jackie's trying to broker a deal at the moment with I don't know which paper, to get some money back for people, the researchers and the runners who gave her £500.' While Gary takes his picture, Laurence directs me to items of interest elsewhere. 'Have you noticed the wallpaper? It's mine, £9.99 a roll from Homebase. Please notice the photograph of me and Jackie with Prince Andrew. I'm not entirely sure of my motives in putting it out, but it was a lovely evening.' I get down on my hands and knees to inspect Cecile's doll's house. Clearly, she is her father's daughter: there is a bath in the sitting room, and one inhabitant is wedged into the fireplace. 'There's something so incredibly downmarket about being famous,' sighs Laurence happily, as one pose succeeds another. Later, I ring the Royal Institute of British Architects and the Georgian Group to check how to spell 'Adelaidian', but they've never heard the term before. I call the V &A to find out more about the Changing Rooms archive but I can't find anyone there who is able to say whether it exists. 'I've been asking around, and nobody has heard of such an archive, so to say we have one is probably untrue,' says a spokesperson. Never mind. Laurence understands the importance of trompe l'oeil .

webTitle: I'm 24 years younger than my husband -  and I want to leave him for a man at the office

fields.headline: I'm 24 years younger than my husband -  and I want to leave him for a man at the office
fields.standfirst: Moral Muse
fields.trailText: Moral Muse
fields.body:
When I first met and fell in love with my husband, I was 20 and he was 44, married and the father of two grown-up daughters, 19 and 21. It was a very difficult situation but we were very much in love and married three years later.

Eleven years on, we're still together and have a beautiful nine-year-old son whom we both adore. I still love my husband, but I'm no longer happy. We have grown apart and want different things from life, particularly after he had a minor heart attack five years ago. He recovered well, but it changed him.

I feel very attracted to a man I have met at work. He's single, about my age and also attracted to me. I'm very tempted to have an affair, even leave my husband and start a new life with my son.

However, I can't forget what my husband gave up for me. His daughters haven't spoken to him since he left their mother for me. We know through other people that both girls are married and have children, but all my husband's attempts at a reconciliation have been rejected. When his former wife remarried four years ago we hoped that they would relent. But it didn't happen.

How can I leave and still be able to live with myself? Sometimes I wonder whether they would acknowledge him again if I was out of the picture. Some people would say that I brought my problems upon myself. Nevertheless I would welcome your advice.

M.C. of London

You have mapped out your plans for the future with your own happiness in mind, and all that is left is the inconvenience of a smarting conscience, which you hope will be resolved by an approval, or at least justification, in this column. Well I don't think you can have that luxury.

I sometimes think that morality - which forms no part whatsoever of our inheritance - has been invented by humans to disguise their invariably selfish motives.

Place yourself in your husband's shoes; take the immense leap across the gender and generation gaps and see how he has been led by the pricking of his gonads and his vanity into a relationship that has served him ill. It seems there was little true rapport to supplement your passion. Once the novelty and the frisson of attracting a younger woman had dwindled and the ravages of age and stress began to make their mark on him, there was no long-term companion with whom love and friendship had been forged by a shared youth, history and the successful raising of a family. Someone who would not pull out when the hard times came. He probably blames himself as much as you for his instinctive folly, which has deprived him of the gentle delight of growing old in tandem with a soul-mate, and all his hopes for the future happily extending and expanding around him.

His previous wife is totally out of his reach, his daughters unbending in their rejection. The loss of his children and grandchildren must be a bitter blow, and though he has irretrievably lost time and trust with them, he should continue his efforts to gain forgiveness.

In this tale of destruction and rejection there is not a lot you can do to improve matters. I would doubt your motivation to continue in a lacklustre marriage, but you do have your son to consider. He would be better off with two parents than one, and it is undoubtedly in a child's interest to remain with his natural parents if he can.

You speak of a new potential mate, but maybe this man at work is looking for a light-hearted affair rather than wife and ready-made son. Would you be as eager to discard your present marriage if there were no male arms waiting to receive you?

Your husband would be better off without you; as you observe, there is a measure of hope for rehabilitation with his first family especially if he is prepared to eat humble pie with them. But he must not lose his son in addition; that would be too cruel. Whatever you do must include a plan to keep them together; you could even consider giving him custody of the boy.

READERS' REPLIES

'Don't even think about it' is my instant advice. Strange perhaps coming from a man who left his wife four years ago with children at a similar age to M.C.'s lover at the time he left.

Believe me, happiness is so elusive when you elect to take the unconventional course of action.

You say you love your husband and no doubt your son even more. I see little hope of happiness in pursuing any form of liaison with the man at the office. No doubt you had critics at the time of your marriage, they will have a field day if you have another affair.

A.S. of Surrey

So you fell in love with and married a man much older than yourself, who was married to someone else when you met him and left his first wife and family to marry you and give you your 'beautiful' nine-year-old son.

Since his heart attack he has 'changed' and you've found someone younger and more attractive.

You are right not to forget what he gave up for you and wrong to think that whisking yourself and his son out of his life could make things easier for him with his former family. Imagine for a moment that it had been the other way round. That you had had the life-threatening illness and he had decided he'd be better off taking your son away to live with someone more attractive and healthy. How would you have felt?

If you really did still love your husband you could not consider the action you propose. If you really have to get out of the relationship for your own sake, you still don't have the right to take your son away from him. I assume this boy loves his father. If you take him away to live with this younger lover, what is he going to think of you?

T. of Nottingham

NEXT WEEK'S DILEMMA IS

FROM A.S. OF SOUTH LONDON

At the ripe old age of 42, I find myself pregnant again. My husband is 45 and we already have two children: a 16-year-old girl and a 14-year-old boy. After the initial shock we became used to the idea and are looking forward to the birth. Our daughter is delighted and has been very supportive but our son is very 'cross' with us.

He has let us know that he thinks 'it is disgusting' to have a baby 'at our age' and has been generally sulky and uncooperative. We have tried to reassure him that the new baby won't change the way we feel about him and his sister.

I am now four-and-a-half months pregnant and his attitude is starting to upset me. Is his reaction normal? And what can we do to help him to accept and love his new brother or sister?

Write to Observer Review or e-mail margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on next week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.

fields.headline: Italian stallion
fields.standfirst: The Modena 360 is the best Ferrari yet.
fields.trailText: Ferrari. And before another word is said, a cacophonous mechanical kingdom is conjured in the mind's eye, and mind's ear. Of sensuous, blood-red machines, improbably powerful engines that howl with vulpine intensity. Of breathtaking speed. Of Manchester United's training ground at Carrington crowded with the road-going symbols of success of Beckham, Butt, Sheringham, Yorke and co. Of Formula One and racing legends. Of smooth, middle-aged gits balding around Surrey golf lands with leggy tots admiring the cut of their driver's credit card. A string of automotive clichés, in fact, before you've had the privilege of sliding down into the leather-sheathed driving seat of the latest Ferrari 360 Modena.
fields.body:
Ferrari. And before another word is said, a cacophonous mechanical kingdom is conjured in the mind's eye, and mind's ear. Of sensuous, blood-red machines, improbably powerful engines that howl with vulpine intensity. Of breathtaking speed. Of Manchester United's training ground at Carrington crowded with the road-going symbols of success of Beckham, Butt, Sheringham, Yorke and co. Of Formula One and racing legends. Of smooth, middle-aged gits balding around Surrey golf lands with leggy tots admiring the cut of their driver's credit card. A string of automotive clichés, in fact, before you've had the privilege of sliding down into the leather-sheathed driving seat of the latest Ferrari 360 Modena.

Turn the key, blip the drilled aluminium, racing-style throttle, and catapult yourself along Surrey Tarmac away from Maranello Concessionaries, Ferrari's UK HQ, and away into a magic mystery tour of the fastest A roads and B roads you've ever encountered. Faster than fairies, faster than witches, this silver-grey road-racer beguiles like no other car you'll meet in a year of Sundays. The 360 Modena is quite simply one of the finest cars I've driven, and this includes many older Ferraris, Lamborghinis, Maseratis and De Tomasos. And Jaguars, Porsches and Moss knows what.

What this car does so well is prove that a car that would not disgrace itself on a race track can be used as everyday transport, if you're rich and sybaritic enough in spirit and wallet. Not that the 360 is a gas guzzler. It isn't. It's simply beautifully made, mostly of aluminium and thus very light, and for an Italian supercar extraordinary in that it looks and feels as well put together as a Porsche, and that's saying something. A Porsche is one of the most beautifully made machines you can buy with your own money.

Not only does the car feel all of a piece, but it's a doddle to drive. No, seriously. Sure, if you're used to Mondeos and Meganes, you might find the stupendous power a little unsettling and the width of the car disturbing (at 6ft 4in, it's among the very widest), but you would soon delight in the way you can overtake everyone in sight at will and in any gear, the way in which the car zips around any corner at virtually any speed you choose with almost no body roll, the hugely powerful brakes, the go-kart steering and the blissful comfort of the seats. Beyond this, the interior is wonderfully moulded and stitched together, the exquisite testa rossa (red-headed) V8 engine visible behind the driver's head, and the air-con works a treat.

You really can potter through town in this supremely potent car, sit in jams without fear of the 400bhp engine overheating, and cope easily with a clutch that is neither heavy nor sudden. Is this too much of a good thing? Shouldn't a Ferrari be a snarling, flame-haired bitch of a car, a popping, spitting machine that is only rightly happy at grossly illegal speeds screaming like a banshee up and down twisting mountain roads as if the devil (or the polizia) was on its tail-pipes? Yes and no. While it will lug around town in top gear, the 360 will, should you want it to, move with a speed and dexterity that will delight aficionados and quietly terrify those who might find it hard to believe that a car really can be so quick through corners, up hills and over humpbacks. Unlike other very fast cars, its tyres do not 'tramtrack' on rough roads, nor under heavy braking. It has no Jekyll-and-Hyde character whatsoever. It simply does faster and faster without ever losing its composure (as long as you don't lose yours).

There is, though, a 'traction control' system that ensures every driver should manage their first fast turn in this car without embarrassing or frightening themselves. When you switch this safety device off, the car can be chucked around, despite its physical bulk, as if it was a Caterham 7. Only its width means that Britain's automotive terrier could get away from the Ferrari on B-roads. There are, dammit, times when discretion gives way to valour and, also because this £103,000 car isn't mine (sadly) and must be returned to its owners without so much as a thumbprint showing on its gleaming Pinifarina-designed bodywork.

And, no, this is not a car you will feel embarrassed to drive. It has no fins or spoilers. Aerodynamic testing nurtured a body shape that needs nothing to hold it down. Instead, like a Formula One racer, the 360 hunches down automatically the faster you push it. It never feels as if it is about to take off as E-Types and Lamborghini Miuras have done, in my experience, as they enter two-mile-a-minute territory. I know you're not meant to drive cars this fast and yes, of course, it's all very boyish and so on, but I bet you would want to go very fast indeed, too, if I were able to give you the key to the 360 Modena. For one thing, the sound of the 40-valve engine - titanium con rods, forged aluminium pistons, four camshafts, hydraulic tappets_ phwoarr_ is as compelling as any fast movement from the great Ludwig Van. Sorry, I'm getting a bit carried away, but you try and curb your passion when let loose in what must be, by most standards, one of the finest and fastest road cars ever built.

There are, however, several snags with the 360. The price, for one, unless you're a dot.com teenage trillionaire in which case you can afford to buy Fiat which own Ferrari several times over and have change to buy Porsche, too. Then there's the parking. You need a lot of space and bottle to park a Ferrari in the street. Do you dare to? Naturally, every Modena sold features a hidden global satellite tracking devise. If stolen, the car can be found anywhere in the world. It works, as several lucky Ferrari owners know to their advantage. The other snag is the waiting list: two-and-half-years. Still, by that time I might have decided to grow a goatee, talk mockney, wear combat trousers, design a web-site and, hey presto, have made a trillion pounds. Or, perhaps not. Whatever. The 360 Modena is a superb machine, a mechanical jewel and proof that the car as we've known it pretty much for a century has plenty of life in it yet.

It must seem decadent to have driven to Liverpool in a Ferrari to give a talk in a parish church (my journey from London took six hours, though I did go via Oxford, Broadway, the Elan Valley, Welshpool, Chester, Birkenhead and the wonderful Mersey Tunnel rather than taking the M1/M6), but this magnificent car makes motoring as much fun as it was when I first got my licence. It just happens to cost about 2,000 times what I paid for my first car. Certain pleasures get much more expensive as the miles reel by.

If stolen, the car can be found anywhere in the world. It works, as several lucky Ferrari owners know to their advantage. The other snag is the waiting list: two-and-half-years. Still, by that time I might have decided to grow a goatee, talk mockney, wear combat trousers, design a web-site and, hey presto, have made a trillion pounds. Or, perhaps not. Whatever. The 360 Modena is a superb machine, a mechanical jewel and proof that the car as we've known it pretty much for a century has plenty of life in it yet. It must seem decadent to have driven to Liverpool in a Ferrari to give a talk in a parish church (my journey from London took six hours, though I did go via Oxford, Broadway, the Elan Valley, Welshpool, Chester, Birkenhead and the wonderful Mersey Tunnel rather than taking the M1/M6), but this magnificent car makes motoring as much fun as it was when I first got my licence. It just happens to cost about 2,000 times what I paid for my first car. Certain pleasures get much more expensive as the miles reel by.

fields.headline: Building society
fields.standfirst: If you're planning to pick up a friendly architect, then this week's Mode exhibition is the place.
fields.trailText: 'People are scared of architects,' says Mike Tonkin. 'They think we're like the police.' However, Tonkin could not be further from the archetypal image of the cold, cerebral, scary architect. He is an unassuming character, dressed in a funny padded jacket (a touch Star Trek ) and trousers with little zips. But he is also remarkably straightforward and (most untypical, this) warm and human. This week, he and his associates will be manning the stand at the RIBA Lounge at the homes and interiors show, Mode, at north London's Business Design Centre. It is the show's second year. And a good thing, too, not least because it is one of the few places that the public can go in search of advice - or a whole new way of living - from a host of architects.
fields.body:
'People are scared of architects,' says Mike Tonkin. 'They think we're like the police.' However, Tonkin could not be further from the archetypal image of the cold, cerebral, scary architect. He is an unassuming character, dressed in a funny padded jacket (a touch Star Trek ) and trousers with little zips. But he is also remarkably straightforward and (most untypical, this) warm and human. This week, he and his associates will be manning the stand at the RIBA Lounge at the homes and interiors show, Mode, at north London's Business Design Centre. It is the show's second year. And a good thing, too, not least because it is one of the few places that the public can go in search of advice - or a whole new way of living - from a host of architects.

Last year, the RIBA Lounge attracted a good deal of press attention and was one of the busiest sections of the show. For most of those queuing up, it was their first encounter with an architect. According to Tonkin, 'if you don't happen to know an architect, it is very difficult to know how to get in touch with one.' Tonkin, who is based in an endangered building at the back of King's Cross Station, next to the area's famous huge old oil tanks, has a very user-friendly approach to his work: asking, looking, playing and making. He spent the mid-90s in the Far East, doing just that, and creating an impressive body of work, which ranges from a Hong Kong hairdressing salon that looks like something from outer space, to the interior of the Lane Crawford department store, and a series of cinemas, all painted blood red inside to reflect Tonkin's theory that most films are about murder. The heat of the red just added to the thrill.

While in Hong Kong, Tonkin met up with a nightclub owner, Christian Rhomberg. As well as designing various nightclubs for him, including the renowned Cube, and another club in Innsbruck, Austria, he designed his own home - a futuristic, organic space filled with colourful, glowing light. Pictures of the Rhomberg House caught the eye of 30-year-old Cassian Young, who attended Mode last year in search of an architect to transform his three-storey bachelor pad in a London mews. 'The ground floor was useless as it was,' he says. But his brief to Tonkin was quite vague: he was interested in light, and liked the work of the artist James Turrell. His only reference point was Turrell's 1993 piece, Air Mass . It featured a flat, rectangular glow of white light suspended in a sea of red. His budget was £75,000. This is the sort of client most architects dream of.

Twelve months later, the plans are finished, the 3-D model is made, and the work for the house is out to tender. Cassian's new home will be ingenious, with his sleeping quarters, kitchen, living and entertaining area divided between the floors. The house gets lighter and airier the higher you go, helped by four towers that bring light into the space from above. One tower is a shower unit, stretching the entire three storeys, another a light chamber taking natural light to the lower floor. There is also a stair/storage tower with his music system on top, and a shorter tower for the kitchen made out of planks of board. As in the Rhomberg House, everything will either glow or appear to float, just as in a James Turrell installation.

Tonkin won a second commission at Mode: to rework a family house in Essex. It helped that Tonkin liked the house, a 60s dream home built by an American in the style of the Californian modernists. It featured an extraordinary red- and blue-tiled kitchen which won the Daily Mail Award for Ideal Kitchen in 1975. While the architect has tried to persuade the clients to keep as much of the original interior as possible, including wooden panelling, and some wild wallpaper, the main structural change to the house has been the installation of a 3m by 2.5m skylight in the living-room ceiling. Directly under the skylight, Tonkin has built a 'conversation pit' - a sunken area, padded and upholstered in the same dark fabric as the skylight. The idea is that the clients will be able to lie under the light and look up at the sky above; the glass will also be fitted with neon light, designed to light up rivers of water when it rains.

The project is typical of Tonkin, who has treated the existing house sympathetically rather than going at it with a sledgehammer. Tonkin likes to analyse his clients a bit, to find out odd details about their lives and what they want from their home. 'Play the role of the man on the street,' he says. 'Play the feng-shui master, search for freaks, assume nothing.' He treats each job as a story, and the clients as characters within it.

If you have a story to tell Mike Tonkin and his small team, or a problem that needs the help of an architect, the RIBA Lounge at this year's Mode is the easiest place to find one. Representatives from 30 practices will be available to discuss your dreams and needs, from your planned attic conversion to a vague idea of revamping your basement. And if you're really serious, it might be the start of your very own ideal home.

fields.headline: Cooped up and contented
fields.standfirst: Morph animator Peter Lord thought he was the best in the business until Nick Park of Wallace & Gromit came along. Now they've combined forces and have been cooped up for years thinking about nothing but chickens
fields.trailText:
Nick Park
I was doing the animation course at the National Film and TV School, and there was some money available for students to approach people we admired and invite them to come and spend the day lecturing. My first choice was Pete and his partner Dave Sproxton from Aardman. I'd grown up with Morph and Vision On, so they'd been a great inspiration to me. I used to watch their things on TV, then go up to the attic and make my own stuff.
fields.body:
Nick Park
I was doing the animation course at the National Film and TV School, and there was some money available for students to approach people we admired and invite them to come and spend the day lecturing. My first choice was Pete and his partner Dave Sproxton from Aardman. I'd grown up with Morph and Vision On, so they'd been a great inspiration to me. I used to watch their things on TV, then go up to the attic and make my own stuff.

I was very nervous about showing them my work because what they were doing seemed so smooth and sophisticated. Also, my graduation film, A Grand Day Out, was still in its very early stages, so I didn't feel very confident about showing it to anyone. I remember being terribly flattered by Pete saying there was a good sense of direction to what I was doing. It was exactly what I wanted to hear because I didn't want to just make puppets do funny things. It made me think we had common aims.

A few months later, I got a phone call from Aardman asking if I'd like to work there for a month in the summer break. It was a dream come true. I stayed with Pete's family when I first arrived in Bristol. I've always looked up to him as a very mature person. He's one of those people who makes you feel he's the one who is learning. He makes you feel better about yourself, which is a real gift.

We're both observers. We like to be quiet and contemplative, but there is also an expansive, extrovert side to Pete which is reflected in the company. He is very good at encouraging new talent. He has no hesitation in telling people what they're doing is worth something.

Before we started working on Chicken Run, our first feature film, we had a year sitting around laughing, walking in the woods, coming up with ideas. It was the first time we'd spent much of time together, and we talked about a lot of other things besides the film, like our shared love of nature. At first we were very polite to each other because we didn't want to step on each other's toes. But on a film of this scale, people need decisions quickly, so we had to become a lot more decisive.

I relied a lot on Pete's confidence. He's much better with grown-ups than I am. He can get up and make speeches, and he'd challenge the writers and composers to give more. I just felt so scared of everyone at first. We had to pitch the idea for Chicken Run at a dinner with Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg - it was a chicken dinner. We just had a simple line: it's an escape movie with chickens. Luckily, Steven said that The Great Escape was one of his favourite films. I've learned a lot from Pete about listening to people's ideas and evaluating them in a way that allows people to feel they're contributing something. He is a good person to throw ideas at because he's so honest, without ever being harsh. He doesn't laugh at things unless they're funny. I tend to use my instincts as to what's funny and what isn't. I think his knowledge of English literature enables him to look at the overall picture, not to get bogged down with the details, as I do.

Part of me longs to get back to Wallace and Gromit, because I feel more confident with them, but Chicken Run has stretched me in a good way, and it's been a genuine pleasure working with Pete. I think I would have cracked up if I'd tried to do it alone. Making a big film like this is creativity with a gun at your head. Neither of us could stand the pressure, but it was a comfort to know there was someone to share the load.

Peter Lord
I first met Nick at the National Film Theatre when he was a student and I'd already made quite a few films. Then we met up again at the National Film and TV School, where I'd gone with Dave Sproxton, my partner at Aardman, to talk to the students. It was Nick's idea for us to go. He showed us the storyboards for A Grand Day Out which were incredibly ambitious. He was very shy and quietly spoken, but it was immediately obvious he was highly talented. I was impressed that he was doing the whole thing himself.

At the time, Aardman was just two blokes, Dave and me, but we had aspirations to become a proper studio. After the Channel 4 series, Conversation Pieces, we found ourselves flavour of the month and we were able to start thinking in terms of expansion. Nick was the obvious choice to join the team. We worked together on the Peter Gabriel video, Sledgehammer. Quite early on I was aware of his genius. He had a precision that was really striking. He certainly didn't need any help from me. I remember thinking, 'I could never do that!'

Until then, I'd thought I was the best at what I was doing, then along came someone who was better. I didn't resent it but I'd be pretty unnatural if I hadn't felt jealous at times. But it's impossible to dislike Nick; he's so nice about his success.

And I wasn't alone. I think every other animator in Britain felt as I did. I was very proud for him when he won the Oscars for Wallace & Gromit. I don't take any credit for his talent - he came to us fully fledged - but I do take credit for giving him the environment to make it happen.

On a simple level, we're surprisingly alike. We both love to be alone, both love the country. We exchange wildlife stories after little country forays, but we don't really discuss aesthetic or intellectual things that much. Nick isn't a great one for books. We find the same things funny, both in terms of sight gags and more subtle, observational things. We've been allies against the world during the making of Chicken Run .

When we started on the film I was effectively creative director of Aardman, which was a full-time job, so it was a big decision to give that up to concentrate full-time on Chicken Run . I thought, 'If I don't do this now, it'll be a long time before another opportunity like this comes along.'

We'd never worked together much because Nick had always been so self-sufficient. Considering we've been closeted together for four and a half years, it's amazing we've never had an argument. We've disagreed on a few things, but I very seldom argue with anyone. The big problem has been the regime we've had to work under. We never really got on top of it. Despite being the directors, we've been slaves to the production.

It was nice to be able to retreat to our office together and have a moan. The dread of it not being successful was always a fear. What if everyone compared it to the Wallace & Gromit s and found it lacking? I could see the headlines: 'Nick Park teams up with Peter Lord to create turkey'.

Chicken Run opens on 30 June
