fields.headline: Candid camera
fields.standfirst: Richard Billingham's searing family snaps divided the critics.So what will they make of his drab urban landscapes? Lynn Barber talks about painting, Proust and binmen with KwikSave's most famous shelf-stacker.
fields.trailText: I would have thought no one could possibly dislike Richard Billingham's work, but I was wrong. When I blithely told an art-critic friend that I was writing about Richard Billingham, he exploded, 'His work isn't ART!' Oh really, what is it then? Are we back to saying that photography can't be art? Unfortunately my friend was too incoherent with rage to make much sense, but the word naive came up a lot, and so did sensationalist. Since we were talking about the Sensation exhibition at the time, the latter accusation seemed particularly bizarre - I would say that Billingham's photographs were far less sensationalist than most of the stuff in the exhibition - if they provoked a shock among RA visitors, it was only because RA visitors tend to lead sheltered lives.
fields.body:
I would have thought no one could possibly dislike Richard Billingham's work, but I was wrong. When I blithely told an art-critic friend that I was writing about Richard Billingham, he exploded, 'His work isn't ART!' Oh really, what is it then? Are we back to saying that photography can't be art? Unfortunately my friend was too incoherent with rage to make much sense, but the word naive came up a lot, and so did sensationalist. Since we were talking about the Sensation exhibition at the time, the latter accusation seemed particularly bizarre - I would say that Billingham's photographs were far less sensationalist than most of the stuff in the exhibition - if they provoked a shock among RA visitors, it was only because RA visitors tend to lead sheltered lives.

But naive is more problematic, and this is perhaps why Billingham has never been wholly accepted into the Britart fold. Obviously we know - because his photographs tell us so -that he comes from a deprived, dysfunctional family in a Birmingham towerblock. But does that make him a naive artist? I mean, it's not as if he's some illiterate aboriginal found wandering in the desert with a paintstick in his hands. He went to art school, he has a degree in fine arts. He knows exactly what he is doing in his work - in fact, according to Jonathan Watkins, director of the Ikon Gallery in Birmingham, he is exceptionally decisive and particular about the details of hanging and installation and catalogue design.

And yet, as a person, he seems_ naive is not quite the word, but innocent maybe or unworldly, a sort of Candide or Forrest Gump who hasn't yet got used to the fancy ways of the big bad world. He is 29, but I can hear myself on the tape sometimes addressing him like a child, 'Do you know what you want to eat, Richard? Shall I order something for you from the menu?' We were in Birmingham's Café Rouge and he seemed never to have seen a menu before - but then he quite deftly ordered two bottles of wine and drank most of them, as well as smoking all my cigarettes.

Sometimes he seems to play up his naivety, saying he never knew what an art dealer was till he signed with one, or that he never knew foreign galleries would pay for you to fly out to hang exhibitions and put you up in hotels. He had never stayed in a hotel before, and says he still hasn't seen inside a middle-class home. But then he walks around the Ikon Gallery as if he owns it, and mentions that he enjoyed the Tate opening and a recent trip to Paris to design a book with agnès b. This switch from naivety to sophistication, insecurity to authority, goes on constantly and is always catching me on the wrong foot. When I wittered on about his childhood poverty, he snapped, 'I think of poverty as being people from Ethiopia not having nothing to eat - That's poverty.' The class gulf yawned.

He wouldn't take me to see his parents - he said they were off limits to journalists because 'You can't parade them around like poodles!' - but he did take our photographer, Neil Drabble. Neil said the flat was quite ordinary, but Billingham's parents were good fun, and there was lots of laughter - as indeed there is in Billingham's photographs. But Billingham wouldn't take either Neil or me to his own home in nearby Stourbridge, which makes one wonder what terrible secrets it contains. Knicker blinds? Mug trees? He describes it as 'a bit bland, actually'.

Anyway, however naive he might or might not be as a person, that doesn't mean he's a naive artist. But that seems to be the suspicion among some critics - that he's someone who just got lucky by pointing his camera at a God-given subject, his own family. And of course his family, first shown in his book, Ray's a Laugh, and then in the Sensation exhibition, is enthralling - poor drunken Ray with his eternal bottles of home-brew, fleshy Liz with her rotting teeth and lavish tattoos, Jason the teenager, the cats, the dogs, the hamster, the serried ranks of knick-knacks on the sideboards, the miniature Venetian masks on the wall, the jigsaws, the telly, the squalor in the kitchen. All such a refreshing change from the normal grainy photojournalistic representation of towerblock life which invariably features someone sitting on the edge of an unmade bed looking doleful to camera, with the implicit message: 'This is meant to shock you out of your complacency. Don't you care ?' Nah, I always think, flicking the page, don't care for toffee - but I care passionately about the Billinghams, precisely because they are not presented as social problems but as riotously colourful individuals.

Still, the critics ask: can Billingham do any more than that? Is he just a one-hit wonder, or can he be equally interesting when photographing something other than his family? Actually, I think even this question is unfair. We don't ask whether Rachel Whiteread can do more than make casts of things, or whether Jenny Saville can paint more than big nudes. We normally accept that artists have a chosen subject area and technique, but somehow Billingham has to 'prove himself' by doing something completely different. I don't see why, frankly - but Billingham does. He explains: 'When I first showed my family pictures, I realised that a lot of people liked them just because they saw the surface, and they didn't see the beauty underneath. And as soon I started showing the family photographs, I stopped taking them, because it was sort of over. If I was to start taking them with a view to exhibiting them, then that wouldn't be a good motive because I wouldn't be doing it out of curiosity any more. And I thought if I could strip all the subject away, and just photograph nothing - so they're not an index of the subject matter but just of how they were taken - then that would show that they are good photographs, and people would like them for the right reasons.'

Hence his new show at the Ikon Gallery. It wasn't installed when I met him, but he showed me the videos and photographs that will make up the exhibition. The videos were shot in 1998 and 1999 and still relate to his family - there is one of his mother smoking, one of his father lying in bed, one of a friend smoking a cigarette 'backwards' and a very disturbing one called Playstation , of fingers frantically tapping at a computer console. 'It's my brother coming down off speed and playing the PlayStation madly - he'll do this for something like 30 hours nonstop. Originally I was going to film his face and the computer screen, but all the expression was in the fingers.' It is a far more frightening picture of addiction than his father with his home-brew.

The exhibition also includes some of the first photographs he ever took - black-and-white portraits of his uncles and his father. These are easy to like. But then there are his urban landscapes, which are much more difficult. He says he took literally thousands of them, between 1992 and 1997, and has chosen just 15 for the show. They are dull-coloured photographs of drab urban spaces, patches of wasteland, corners of towerblocks, all taken round Cradley Heath, where he grew up. There are no people in them, and no obvious points of interest. The Ikon catalogue talks about a Proustian search for lost time, but Billingham says only: 'My friend described them as the sort of photographs you would take when you were starting a roll of film, and I thought that was a good description.' I must admit, I find them baffling. Obviously these places mean something to him , but what?

Billingham says, 'Well, it's like something is about to happen. It's like a stage set for something about to happen.' To me, they all seem laden with menace, the sort of places that scream 'mugger lurking', or 'paedophile about to pounce', but perhaps that says more about me than it does about Billingham. He says they're just places he used to pass on the way to school or to his grandparents', but he didn't want to make them look nostalgic. 'Maybe they're about picture-making more than anything else.'

Maybe they are - but they're still terribly unsettling. So is Billingham himself - I've never felt so completely unhinged by an interviewee. He is perfectly friendly, eager to talk, but it is as if we are both equipped with foreign phrasebooks where the questions and answers don't match up. I think a possible explanation is that he is quite new to this communicating lark - he was a loner for much of his childhood and didn't really feel that he fitted in anywhere till he arrived in the art world. And, he explains, 'I am quite self-contained. I do feel a lot, but I don't show a lot. I suppose when I was growing up and being a bit more neglected than the other kids socially - well, you can see how it is - so you learn not to show it so much. But I'm not, like, walled up or anything.'

He says his upbringing was not that bad - 'The thing is, I was never encouraged, but I was never dis couraged either, so I was left to my own devices.' He thinks he was 'normal' when he was small but then somehow retreated into himself when he was about 11. He didn't make any friends at school and was always the last to be chosen when they were picking sides for football. Nor did he have any success with girls - he didn't have a girlfriend till he was 22. 'Because I was so into my books and into my artwork, maybe I was n't interested. And I think when I was living on the estate, when I was a teenager, maybe I was quite angry or something, and there was nobody on the estate that I would like.'

Obviously, he was neglected as a child, and his younger brother Jason was taken into care at the age of 10. But Richard by then was 17 and the social worker who came round decided that he was alright - his room was well lit and full of books. And he was alright in a way - he was getting on with his art. He was always 'the best drawer' at school and managed to get himself on to an art foundation course at the local Bourneville College. But while he was there, his mother left home and went to live in a neighbouring towerblock and his father just drank himself into a stupor. 'I think my dad drank a lot in the hope that she would see him in such a state that she would feel sorry and come back. But it didn't work!' This was the period commemorated in one of his most haunting photographs of his father getting up from bed staring at a pile of sliced bread on the bedside table. It was one of the first colour photographs Richard took and is still one of his favourites.

For 18 months, his father 'just stopped in his room and drank and didn't eat nothing, so I just left this bread in there, but he still didn't eat it.' Every day, when he came home from college, he wondered whether he'd find his father dead or alive. I said, conventionally, that that must have been a terrible period, but Billingham said, 'Well, when I think back, I've only got happy memories of it, to be honest. Because I was free and doing my work, and in myself I was happy.' Since his mother was away, his brother in care, and his father never emerged from his room, Billingham had the flat pretty much to himself. Then he went off to university and soon afterwards his parents got together again.

He went to the University of Sunderland but not by choice - all of the six art schools he chose rejected him - and he talks of it disdainfully as 'a drop-out course'. But he worked hard and remained very focused. At this stage, he still thought of himself as a painter who was only taking photographs as source material to use for paintings. That is why he never cared about his equipment - he used an ordinary instamatic with built-in flash, or even a disposable camera, and sometimes bought film past its sell by date. But one day it dawned on him that his photographs had more life than his paintings. 'When I started, I was just doing photographs to paint from, and that's why they look so set up. But occasionally I'd do a photograph that wasn't set up, and when I would see it back from the chemist it would be a bit more of a shock or something - I could see my dad in a different light. And then I started taking the photographs more and more, just out of my own curiosity.'

His parents got so used to him taking photographs they didn't even notice, which is why they are so un-selfconscious. He would just be sitting round the flat and then something would happen - his father would fall over or send the cat flying through the air - and he would snap it. He says, 'The best photographs are the ones where I just lift the camera and snap - the less I think about it, the more spontaneous it is.' Interestingly, he says that the worst photograph is one of his parents both eating in front of the telly, because 'it looks like any hack photographer could have come in and taken this photograph - it doesn't show you anything about the relationship I have with them. I wish I'd never put it in the book. But it's so well known now I just have to live with it.'

Eventually, Billingham started showing the photographs to friends and tutors at the University of Sunderland. He didn't say at first that they were of his own family, though later he did. While he was still a student, in 1994, some of his photographs were included in an exhibition at the Barbican called Who's Looking at The Family? And he was invited to the opening, but it was not a happy experience. 'I was introduced to other photographers, but they weren't artists. And I was new to all this, so when I was introduced to people and they said, "What do you do?", I said, "There's some of my work over there, do you want to have a look at it?" - and they'd sort of edge away. It was so rude, but I was very young then; I wasn't dressed right or anything. But I wish people weren't like that - they should just accept you, you know. I mean, they saw the work, but nobody cared about it because I wasn't anybody at the time.'

Then he finished university and came back to Birmingham and worked as a shelf-stacker in KwikSave. He was a hard worker and very fit, so he was always being offered places on management-trainee schemes, but he preferred to keep stacking because it left his mind free to think about art. He never called himself an artist because 'I would have thought it pretentious, if I wasn't having shows. I thought of myself as one, but on the estate, if I'd called myself an artist, they would have thought I was mad. Now I can call myself an artist because that's how I make my living.'

For two years after university, he stacked shelves and got on with his own work. Then one of his Sunderland tutors suggested he should do a book, and got a publisher to commission it. This was Ray's a Laugh , the collection of his family photographs, published by Scalo of Zurich in April 1996. For once, the expression 'overnight success' seems accurate. One day he was a shelf-stacker in KwikSave, the next he was being signed up by art dealer Anthony Reynolds and wooed by art galleries all round the world. He was shown in MOMA in New York and had one-man shows in Los Angeles, Paris, Milan, Frankfurt, Brussels and Rome; Charles Saatchi bought his work and included it in Sensation; Artangel commissioned him to make a film, Fishtank , which was shown on BBC2, and in 1997 he won the Citibank Photography Prize.

It was a novel experience for him to find himself in demand everywhere, to have people falling over themselves to meet him. Up till then he'd passed through life almost unnoticed. 'I was very introverted, you see, and I have to admit I didn't let on things. I was self-contained, a lot more so than now. But when I did the book, this was the first time other people could see what was inside me and all of a sudden they wanted to get to know more, and want my opinion. It was funny - like, I had no attention before and now I've got a lot of attention.'

His life now is a strange mixture of the gritty and the glitzy. He bought himself a £77,000 house in Stourbridge, one of the Black Country suburbs of Birmingham, a few years ago and has spent some time doing it up, but now he wants to rent a studio so he can go out to work in the morning and come back at night, more like a real job. He makes about £40,000 to £50,000 a year, which he says is 'enough to live on, but not enough to travel about and stay in hotels. But I feel I'm rich because I don't have to work for a living.'

He wants to stay in Birmingham because he finds it easier to work there, and also, of course, cheaper. But he loves coming to London for the day, for a quick fix of the art world. 'People talk about the art world being shallow and everything, but I really like it.' What he misses in Birmingham is the company of other artists. He has one good local friend who was a fellow student at Sunderland, whom he sees about once a week, and he goes to London one day a week. 'These things are just enough to keep me not being lonely, but I do still feel alienated because there's no one I can talk to.'

He lives a few miles from his parents and visits them often. He took them to one of his first shows, in Bradford in 1996, and they were quite intrigued to see pictures of themselves on the walls, 'but they were more interested in staying in the hotel and getting free meals, to be honest'. He says it's diffi cult to take them anywhere because 'they're not very good at balance and walking', but he did take them to Brighton a couple of times. Mainly, though, they just sit at home and smoke and watch telly - he says the flat has bookshelves all round like a library, but they're full of videos, not books. Ray has cut down on his drinking, simply because he falls over if he drinks too much. Richard has managed to get them increased benefits and disability allowance, and he has bought them a microwave and a washing machine, but he says there's no point in giving them cash because they'd just leave the money lying around till someone nicked it.

I asked whether he'd tried to 'save' his brother Jason, and he seemed offended by the question, but then said yes, actually he had - he tried to get him to do A levels and persuaded him to move back from his foster parents, but it didn't work out: 'He had had no freedom [in care] and then he had all this freedom which he couldn't handle and he got involved with the kids on the estate and the first thing he did was get a girl pregnant!'

Billingham will not make the same mistake. He values his hard-earned freedom, and plans to keep it. He had a girlfriend, a social worker in Brighton, but she wanted to settle down and have a family and he felt he was too young. 'It's only in the last three years I've had my freedom to do my work properly, and there are still things I want to do.' But he says he will have a family one day - 'I wouldn't want to argue, though. People say in arguments truths come out, which is correct, but you don't have to communicate by arguing, do you? I'm scared of arguing!'

So what will he do next? The Ikon exhibition is a good roundup of all his work so far, but it doesn't really offer any clues or pointers to the future. However, Billingham says he has been doing lots of sketches and drawings, which he hopes to use as the basis for paintings when he has more time. 'I try to work every day but it's difficult to, because there's so many other things, but Francis Bacon said what seems like inspiration comes from regular work - and I'm much better if I can work regularly. But I don't always get the chance - I mean, there's a meeting about catalogue design, or putting the rubbish out for the binmen.' It is typical of him to give binmen and catalogues the same importance. Perhaps this is what people mean by his 'naivety' - his attachment to the real world, which counts as oddity in the art world. It's a very valuable oddity, I believe.

But naive is more problematic, and this is perhaps why Billingham has never been wholly accepted into the Britart fold. Obviously we know - because his photographs tell us so -that he comes from a deprived, dysfunctional family in a Birmingham towerblock. But does that make him a naive artist? I mean, it's not as if he's some illiterate aboriginal found wandering in the desert with a paintstick in his hands. He went to art school, he has a degree in fine arts. He knows exactly what he is doing in his work - in fact, according to Jonathan Watkins, director of the Ikon Gallery in Birmingham, he is exceptionally decisive and particular about the details of hanging and installation and catalogue design. And yet, as a person, he seems_ naive is not quite the word, but innocent maybe or unworldly, a sort of Candide or Forrest Gump who hasn't yet got used to the fancy ways of the big bad world. He is 29, but I can hear myself on the tape sometimes addressing him like a child, 'Do you know what you want to eat, Richard? Shall I order something for you from the menu?' We were in Birmingham's Café Rouge and he seemed never to have seen a menu before - but then he quite deftly ordered two bottles of wine and drank most of them, as well as smoking all my cigarettes. Sometimes he seems to play up his naivety, saying he never knew what an art dealer was till he signed with one, or that he never knew foreign galleries would pay for you to fly out to hang exhibitions and put you up in hotels. He had never stayed in a hotel before, and says he still hasn't seen inside a middle-class home. But then he walks around the Ikon Gallery as if he owns it, and mentions that he enjoyed the Tate opening and a recent trip to Paris to design a book with agnès b. This switch from naivety to sophistication, insecurity to authority, goes on constantly and is always catching me on the wrong foot. When I wittered on about his childhood poverty, he snapped, 'I think of poverty as being people from Ethiopia not having nothing to eat - That's poverty.' The class gulf yawned. He wouldn't take me to see his parents - he said they were off limits to journalists because 'You can't parade them around like poodles!' - but he did take our photographer, Neil Drabble. Neil said the flat was quite ordinary, but Billingham's parents were good fun, and there was lots of laughter - as indeed there is in Billingham's photographs. But Billingham wouldn't take either Neil or me to his own home in nearby Stourbridge, which makes one wonder what terrible secrets it contains. Knicker blinds? Mug trees? He describes it as 'a bit bland, actually'. Anyway, however naive he might or might not be as a person, that doesn't mean he's a naive artist. But that seems to be the suspicion among some critics - that he's someone who just got lucky by pointing his camera at a God-given subject, his own family. And of course his family, first shown in his book, Ray's a Laugh, and then in the Sensation exhibition, is enthralling - poor drunken Ray with his eternal bottles of home-brew, fleshy Liz with her rotting teeth and lavish tattoos, Jason the teenager, the cats, the dogs, the hamster, the serried ranks of knick-knacks on the sideboards, the miniature Venetian masks on the wall, the jigsaws, the telly, the squalor in the kitchen. All such a refreshing change from the normal grainy photojournalistic representation of towerblock life which invariably features someone sitting on the edge of an unmade bed looking doleful to camera, with the implicit message: 'This is meant to shock you out of your complacency. Don't you care ?' Nah, I always think, flicking the page, don't care for toffee - but I care passionately about the Billinghams, precisely because they are not presented as social problems but as riotously colourful individuals. Still, the critics ask: can Billingham do any more than that? Is he just a one-hit wonder, or can he be equally interesting when photographing something other than his family? Actually, I think even this question is unfair. We don't ask whether Rachel Whiteread can do more than make casts of things, or whether Jenny Saville can paint more than big nudes. We normally accept that artists have a chosen subject area and technique, but somehow Billingham has to 'prove himself' by doing something completely different. I don't see why, frankly - but Billingham does. He explains: 'When I first showed my family pictures, I realised that a lot of people liked them just because they saw the surface, and they didn't see the beauty underneath. And as soon I started showing the family photographs, I stopped taking them, because it was sort of over. If I was to start taking them with a view to exhibiting them, then that wouldn't be a good motive because I wouldn't be doing it out of curiosity any more. And I thought if I could strip all the subject away, and just photograph nothing - so they're not an index of the subject matter but just of how they were taken - then that would show that they are good photographs, and people would like them for the right reasons.' Hence his new show at the Ikon Gallery. It wasn't installed when I met him, but he showed me the videos and photographs that will make up the exhibition. The videos were shot in 1998 and 1999 and still relate to his family - there is one of his mother smoking, one of his father lying in bed, one of a friend smoking a cigarette 'backwards' and a very disturbing one called Playstation , of fingers frantically tapping at a computer console. 'It's my brother coming down off speed and playing the PlayStation madly - he'll do this for something like 30 hours nonstop. Originally I was going to film his face and the computer screen, but all the expression was in the fingers.' It is a far more frightening picture of addiction than his father with his home-brew. The exhibition also includes some of the first photographs he ever took - black-and-white portraits of his uncles and his father. These are easy to like. But then there are his urban landscapes, which are much more difficult. He says he took literally thousands of them, between 1992 and 1997, and has chosen just 15 for the show. They are dull-coloured photographs of drab urban spaces, patches of wasteland, corners of towerblocks, all taken round Cradley Heath, where he grew up. There are no people in them, and no obvious points of interest. The Ikon catalogue talks about a Proustian search for lost time, but Billingham says only: 'My friend described them as the sort of photographs you would take when you were starting a roll of film, and I thought that was a good description.' I must admit, I find them baffling. Obviously these places mean something to him , but what? Billingham says, 'Well, it's like something is about to happen. It's like a stage set for something about to happen.' To me, they all seem laden with menace, the sort of places that scream 'mugger lurking', or 'paedophile about to pounce', but perhaps that says more about me than it does about Billingham. He says they're just places he used to pass on the way to school or to his grandparents', but he didn't want to make them look nostalgic. 'Maybe they're about picture-making more than anything else.' Maybe they are - but they're still terribly unsettling. So is Billingham himself - I've never felt so completely unhinged by an interviewee. He is perfectly friendly, eager to talk, but it is as if we are both equipped with foreign phrasebooks where the questions and answers don't match up. I think a possible explanation is that he is quite new to this communicating lark - he was a loner for much of his childhood and didn't really feel that he fitted in anywhere till he arrived in the art world. And, he explains, 'I am quite self-contained. I do feel a lot, but I don't show a lot. I suppose when I was growing up and being a bit more neglected than the other kids socially - well, you can see how it is - so you learn not to show it so much. But I'm not, like, walled up or anything.' He says his upbringing was not that bad - 'The thing is, I was never encouraged, but I was never dis couraged either, so I was left to my own devices.' He thinks he was 'normal' when he was small but then somehow retreated into himself when he was about 11. He didn't make any friends at school and was always the last to be chosen when they were picking sides for football. Nor did he have any success with girls - he didn't have a girlfriend till he was 22. 'Because I was so into my books and into my artwork, maybe I was n't interested. And I think when I was living on the estate, when I was a teenager, maybe I was quite angry or something, and there was nobody on the estate that I would like.' Obviously, he was neglected as a child, and his younger brother Jason was taken into care at the age of 10. But Richard by then was 17 and the social worker who came round decided that he was alright - his room was well lit and full of books. And he was alright in a way - he was getting on with his art. He was always 'the best drawer' at school and managed to get himself on to an art foundation course at the local Bourneville College. But while he was there, his mother left home and went to live in a neighbouring towerblock and his father just drank himself into a stupor. 'I think my dad drank a lot in the hope that she would see him in such a state that she would feel sorry and come back. But it didn't work!' This was the period commemorated in one of his most haunting photographs of his father getting up from bed staring at a pile of sliced bread on the bedside table. It was one of the first colour photographs Richard took and is still one of his favourites. For 18 months, his father 'just stopped in his room and drank and didn't eat nothing, so I just left this bread in there, but he still didn't eat it.' Every day, when he came home from college, he wondered whether he'd find his father dead or alive. I said, conventionally, that that must have been a terrible period, but Billingham said, 'Well, when I think back, I've only got happy memories of it, to be honest. Because I was free and doing my work, and in myself I was happy.' Since his mother was away, his brother in care, and his father never emerged from his room, Billingham had the flat pretty much to himself. Then he went off to university and soon afterwards his parents got together again. He went to the University of Sunderland but not by choice - all of the six art schools he chose rejected him - and he talks of it disdainfully as 'a drop-out course'. But he worked hard and remained very focused. At this stage, he still thought of himself as a painter who was only taking photographs as source material to use for paintings. That is why he never cared about his equipment - he used an ordinary instamatic with built-in flash, or even a disposable camera, and sometimes bought film past its sell by date. But one day it dawned on him that his photographs had more life than his paintings. 'When I started, I was just doing photographs to paint from, and that's why they look so set up. But occasionally I'd do a photograph that wasn't set up, and when I would see it back from the chemist it would be a bit more of a shock or something - I could see my dad in a different light. And then I started taking the photographs more and more, just out of my own curiosity.' His parents got so used to him taking photographs they didn't even notice, which is why they are so un-selfconscious. He would just be sitting round the flat and then something would happen - his father would fall over or send the cat flying through the air - and he would snap it. He says, 'The best photographs are the ones where I just lift the camera and snap - the less I think about it, the more spontaneous it is.' Interestingly, he says that the worst photograph is one of his parents both eating in front of the telly, because 'it looks like any hack photographer could have come in and taken this photograph - it doesn't show you anything about the relationship I have with them. I wish I'd never put it in the book. But it's so well known now I just have to live with it.' Eventually, Billingham started showing the photographs to friends and tutors at the University of Sunderland. He didn't say at first that they were of his own family, though later he did. While he was still a student, in 1994, some of his photographs were included in an exhibition at the Barbican called Who's Looking at The Family? And he was invited to the opening, but it was not a happy experience. 'I was introduced to other photographers, but they weren't artists. And I was new to all this, so when I was introduced to people and they said, "What do you do?", I said, "There's some of my work over there, do you want to have a look at it?" - and they'd sort of edge away. It was so rude, but I was very young then; I wasn't dressed right or anything. But I wish people weren't like that - they should just accept you, you know. I mean, they saw the work, but nobody cared about it because I wasn't anybody at the time.' Then he finished university and came back to Birmingham and worked as a shelf-stacker in KwikSave. He was a hard worker and very fit, so he was always being offered places on management-trainee schemes, but he preferred to keep stacking because it left his mind free to think about art. He never called himself an artist because 'I would have thought it pretentious, if I wasn't having shows. I thought of myself as one, but on the estate, if I'd called myself an artist, they would have thought I was mad. Now I can call myself an artist because that's how I make my living.' For two years after university, he stacked shelves and got on with his own work. Then one of his Sunderland tutors suggested he should do a book, and got a publisher to commission it. This was Ray's a Laugh , the collection of his family photographs, published by Scalo of Zurich in April 1996. For once, the expression 'overnight success' seems accurate. One day he was a shelf-stacker in KwikSave, the next he was being signed up by art dealer Anthony Reynolds and wooed by art galleries all round the world. He was shown in MOMA in New York and had one-man shows in Los Angeles, Paris, Milan, Frankfurt, Brussels and Rome; Charles Saatchi bought his work and included it in Sensation; Artangel commissioned him to make a film, Fishtank , which was shown on BBC2, and in 1997 he won the Citibank Photography Prize. It was a novel experience for him to find himself in demand everywhere, to have people falling over themselves to meet him. Up till then he'd passed through life almost unnoticed. 'I was very introverted, you see, and I have to admit I didn't let on things. I was self-contained, a lot more so than now. But when I did the book, this was the first time other people could see what was inside me and all of a sudden they wanted to get to know more, and want my opinion. It was funny - like, I had no attention before and now I've got a lot of attention.' His life now is a strange mixture of the gritty and the glitzy. He bought himself a £77,000 house in Stourbridge, one of the Black Country suburbs of Birmingham, a few years ago and has spent some time doing it up, but now he wants to rent a studio so he can go out to work in the morning and come back at night, more like a real job. He makes about £40,000 to £50,000 a year, which he says is 'enough to live on, but not enough to travel about and stay in hotels. But I feel I'm rich because I don't have to work for a living.' He wants to stay in Birmingham because he finds it easier to work there, and also, of course, cheaper. But he loves coming to London for the day, for a quick fix of the art world. 'People talk about the art world being shallow and everything, but I really like it.' What he misses in Birmingham is the company of other artists. He has one good local friend who was a fellow student at Sunderland, whom he sees about once a week, and he goes to London one day a week. 'These things are just enough to keep me not being lonely, but I do still feel alienated because there's no one I can talk to.' He lives a few miles from his parents and visits them often. He took them to one of his first shows, in Bradford in 1996, and they were quite intrigued to see pictures of themselves on the walls, 'but they were more interested in staying in the hotel and getting free meals, to be honest'. He says it's diffi cult to take them anywhere because 'they're not very good at balance and walking', but he did take them to Brighton a couple of times. Mainly, though, they just sit at home and smoke and watch telly - he says the flat has bookshelves all round like a library, but they're full of videos, not books. Ray has cut down on his drinking, simply because he falls over if he drinks too much. Richard has managed to get them increased benefits and disability allowance, and he has bought them a microwave and a washing machine, but he says there's no point in giving them cash because they'd just leave the money lying around till someone nicked it. I asked whether he'd tried to 'save' his brother Jason, and he seemed offended by the question, but then said yes, actually he had - he tried to get him to do A levels and persuaded him to move back from his foster parents, but it didn't work out: 'He had had no freedom [in care] and then he had all this freedom which he couldn't handle and he got involved with the kids on the estate and the first thing he did was get a girl pregnant!' Billingham will not make the same mistake. He values his hard-earned freedom, and plans to keep it. He had a girlfriend, a social worker in Brighton, but she wanted to settle down and have a family and he felt he was too young. 'It's only in the last three years I've had my freedom to do my work properly, and there are still things I want to do.' But he says he will have a family one day - 'I wouldn't want to argue, though. People say in arguments truths come out, which is correct, but you don't have to communicate by arguing, do you? I'm scared of arguing!' So what will he do next? The Ikon exhibition is a good roundup of all his work so far, but it doesn't really offer any clues or pointers to the future. However, Billingham says he has been doing lots of sketches and drawings, which he hopes to use as the basis for paintings when he has more time. 'I try to work every day but it's difficult to, because there's so many other things, but Francis Bacon said what seems like inspiration comes from regular work - and I'm much better if I can work regularly. But I don't always get the chance - I mean, there's a meeting about catalogue design, or putting the rubbish out for the binmen.' It is typical of him to give binmen and catalogues the same importance. Perhaps this is what people mean by his 'naivety' - his attachment to the real world, which counts as oddity in the art world. It's a very valuable oddity, I believe.

fields.headline: It's a jungle out there
fields.trailText: I am not in the coolest of humours following this week's adventures with our excellent fridge, which is one of those models that have been pre-programmed by the factory to break down the minute ambient temperatures reach the point where you've just got back fully loaded from Tesco in the sweltering furnace of your ridiculously ill-ventilated Fiat Ulysse, which explains why we are enjoying a Saturday buffet breakfast of shepherd's pie, yogurt and thawed cod steaks, though, oddly, not why the repairman couldn't find our house yesterday even though he must have scoured the village for literally a minute before roaring off home in his fully equipped white van to relax on the patio with a chilled Carlsberg and a copy of this month's Bollocks to the Customer. Still, I'm sure he'll call back some time next November.
fields.body:
I am not in the coolest of humours following this week's adventures with our excellent fridge, which is one of those models that have been pre-programmed by the factory to break down the minute ambient temperatures reach the point where you've just got back fully loaded from Tesco in the sweltering furnace of your ridiculously ill-ventilated Fiat Ulysse, which explains why we are enjoying a Saturday buffet breakfast of shepherd's pie, yogurt and thawed cod steaks, though, oddly, not why the repairman couldn't find our house yesterday even though he must have scoured the village for literally a minute before roaring off home in his fully equipped white van to relax on the patio with a chilled Carlsberg and a copy of this month's Bollocks to the Customer. Still, I'm sure he'll call back some time next November.

My wife tries to cheer me up by suggesting that I pop down to her allotment in the blistering heat and cut the 8ft grass, which obviously she would do herself but unfortunately has some urgent sitting around chatting with other mums to do at the local swimming pool while the six-year-old wins a certificate for hopping across the shallow end on one foot unaided. 'It's getting to be a bit of an eyesore down there,' she says, mistaking me for someone who has shown the vaguest interest in growing our own food while supermarkets are still happy to take credit cards. 'Look, Tim has lent us some shears,' she says, handing me a pair of bonsai topiary nail-scissors.

I'm not even going to mention my back. Needless to say, the allotment has turned into an Ecuadorian rainforest after the recent monsoon and sub-Saharan sunny patches cycle that is now officially British weather. Luckily, I have enlisted the help of our eldest, who drags a rake around for five minutes before being called upon to chase a butterfly across the farmer's field, and of course he now needs a drink. So off he saunters back to base camp, leaving me to work up an unattractive sweat as I hack my way through the undergrowth until I find the path to my wife's spring onions, though not until I've discovered the legendary lost Mayan temple of Xtahudxhuan and two Japanese soldiers who don't know the war has ended. Half an hour later, the boy turns up carrying half a plastic beaker of warm tap water. 'You haven't got very far, Dad,' he very accurately observes.

My wife arrives home with the news that we are supposed to be going to Natalie's garden party this afternoon. 'I did tell you,' she says, though, as it turns out, not the requisite 14 times with the TV turned off. Still, it means I get to discuss current thinking on spinal trauma with Natalie's husband Colin, who is an orthopaedic surgeon specialising in gardening injuries. We arrive after a hot detour to Waitrose to buy a bottle of non-screwtop wine and stick our boiled heads in the freezer. Natalie's garden is quite massive and looking very nice, as well it might - a man has been paid to cut the grass (!) and Natalie has had some flowers planted for the occasion. How civilised and relaxing. We laze about in the sun, until the inevitable intervention of the eldest, who has been doing somersaults off the bouncy castle and managed to take a bite out of his own knee. 'Why didn't you have a sandwich like everybody else?' I joke. He scowls at me before limping off with a square of kitchen roll stuck to his leg. Five minutes later he has embedded his teeth in someone's head while still trying to perfect the same trick. But just when you think he might monopolise the Bank Holiday casualty figures, a girl completely unrelated to our family falls out of the tree house. Luckily, most of the guests happen to be doctors and the poor child is soon surrounded by anaesthetists and paediatric consultants sipping glasses of wine and agreeing that she probably just hurt herself landing on the ground.

'Shouldn't you be over there?' I ask Natalie, who is a GP.

'Not really my field,' she says. 'Though if anyone needs a cervical smear...'

We stand for a moment watching the eldest, who is now throwing a live chicken in the air to see if it will fly, which can be quite dangerous for a boy likely to follow it up by eating trifle with his fingers. Luckily, Colin arrives with a cold beer. 'You look like you're ready for another,' he says.

Now that's what I call a diagnosis.

phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: That C word again...commitment
fields.trailText: It seems to be the fate of some women to become relationship universities. What usually happens in these cases is that the woman in question is involved with a man for many, many years. They grow and learn together. Often they will cohabit, and buy lots of 'stuff!' to cement their union - houses, cushions, smoke alarms, dishwashers. Very commonly, they will discuss marriage. Or should I say, she will discuss marriage. He will become quieter and quieter as the years pass, staring into space as she, at first gaily, then with increasing hysteria, lists the pros and cons of matrimony.
fields.body:
It seems to be the fate of some women to become relationship universities. What usually happens in these cases is that the woman in question is involved with a man for many, many years. They grow and learn together. Often they will cohabit, and buy lots of 'stuff!' to cement their union - houses, cushions, smoke alarms, dishwashers. Very commonly, they will discuss marriage. Or should I say, she will discuss marriage. He will become quieter and quieter as the years pass, staring into space as she, at first gaily, then with increasing hysteria, lists the pros and cons of matrimony.

'I just don't want to get married,' he might say. 'Why spoil what we have?' What he means is: 'Why spoil what I have?' Sooner or later, the couple's little splash-pool of contentment becomes a poisoned stream. They continue to grow together, to mould each other's destinies, but there's an edge. The woman reads certain news reports, like how the old maid, the parish spinster, is dying off, and thinks bitterly: 'Not around here, she isn't.' When they eventually split, he admits: 'I've learned so much from you.' He can afford to be gracious - he just graduated from relationship university, where he learned from the best how to be that exquisite combination of lover and friend. Now all he has to do is get out of there, and share it all with the next lucky blonde.

Couples like this are legion - their stories unfold with such dreadful predictability that if they were a movie, you'd walk out. Whereas the traditional Old Maid tended to have one special gentleman slip away, the current breed of New Maids seems to spend their entire lives dropping the ball. It's like terminal relationship butterfingers, and it would almost be funny if their pain wasn't so terrible. I've lost count of the times I've sat and listened to tales of woe about how such and such a guy left after aeons of cohabiting, only to marry another woman within the space of a year.

What seems to upset the women left behind the most is the time and effort they've squandered. All that wasted energy - thumbing through The Rules, taking notes in front of Sex and The City - loosening the top of the jar, only to watch somebody else waltz away with the jam.

I've seen such tragic cases that I'm starting to believe that stringing a woman along for years without marrying her should be classified as a form of domestic abuse. There should be fines and prison sentences. 'What are you in for?' 'Refusing to wear the morning suit.' 'Me too - she built her entire case on some crap about me coming from Mars, and her coming from Venus.' At this stage, maybe I should admit that, for a brief period when I was pregnant, I thought getting married was a 'really good idea'. Then again, around the same time, I also thought that eating pickled onion sandwiches and crying because my socks didn't match were 'really good ideas'. So it is that, these days, I automatically associate wanting to get married with feeling insecure, trapped, desperate, and downright crazy. Oh how I long for Mr Right to come along and make me feel that way again.

While some couples obviously belong together, others seem to get married purely to give their co-dependency credibility. Moreover, while it may be true that certain women use sex as a weapon, where marriage is concerned, men seem to have all the bullets. Women end up chasing men, spoiling them rotten, giving them egos the size of barns, and condemning themselves to an eternity of self-hatred, and for what? A dress? A ring? A future? A past? There was a frightening article recently about a group of women who admitted that it didn't matter that they were divorced because at least they'd proved to the world - and their sad spinster mates - that somebody had once wanted them 'that much'. Digesting this garbage, you couldn't help but think: did Emmeline Pankhurst get trampled under the King's horse for this?

Of course it's difficult for a woman to see her friends getting married, and feeling that she's strapped on to the back of a rocket heading in the wrong direction. Difficult but not impossible. When people say, as they are wont to: 'With those attitudes, you will end up alone, with only cats and books for company', why not reply with feeling: 'Yeah, on the other hand, it could all go horribly wrong.' fields.bodyText: It seems to be the fate of some women to become relationship universities. What usually happens in these cases is that the woman in question is involved with a man for many, many years. They grow and learn together. Often they will cohabit, and buy lots of 'stuff!' to cement their union - houses, cushions, smoke alarms, dishwashers. Very commonly, they will discuss marriage. Or should I say, she will discuss marriage. He will become quieter and quieter as the years pass, staring into space as she, at first gaily, then with increasing hysteria, lists the pros and cons of matrimony. 'I just don't want to get married,' he might say. 'Why spoil what we have?' What he means is: 'Why spoil what I have?' Sooner or later, the couple's little splash-pool of contentment becomes a poisoned stream. They continue to grow together, to mould each other's destinies, but there's an edge. The woman reads certain news reports, like how the old maid, the parish spinster, is dying off, and thinks bitterly: 'Not around here, she isn't.' When they eventually split, he admits: 'I've learned so much from you.' He can afford to be gracious - he just graduated from relationship university, where he learned from the best how to be that exquisite combination of lover and friend. Now all he has to do is get out of there, and share it all with the next lucky blonde. Couples like this are legion - their stories unfold with such dreadful predictability that if they were a movie, you'd walk out. Whereas the traditional Old Maid tended to have one special gentleman slip away, the current breed of New Maids seems to spend their entire lives dropping the ball. It's like terminal relationship butterfingers, and it would almost be funny if their pain wasn't so terrible. I've lost count of the times I've sat and listened to tales of woe about how such and such a guy left after aeons of cohabiting, only to marry another woman within the space of a year. What seems to upset the women left behind the most is the time and effort they've squandered. All that wasted energy - thumbing through The Rules, taking notes in front of Sex and The City - loosening the top of the jar, only to watch somebody else waltz away with the jam. I've seen such tragic cases that I'm starting to believe that stringing a woman along for years without marrying her should be classified as a form of domestic abuse. fields.headline: Rough cut
fields.standfirst: What do you do when your doctor tells you your son should be circumcised? Sophie Radice agonises over the choices
fields.trailText: One terrible evening last year, my eight-year-old son's foreskin got stuck back at bathtime
fields.body:
One terrible evening last year, my eight-year-old son's foreskin got stuck back at bathtime when he was routinely cleaning himself. Within minutes, it had alarmingly ballooned behind a tight red ring of swollen skin and he was screaming with pain. My husband was still at work and I suddenly felt desperately inadequate. What should I do? Perhaps there was a knack to this? Was this something that happened to boys that I didn't know about?

I phoned my GP, who told me that this was an emergency and to get to hospital immediately. My son then had to endure an hour of agony which overcame his extreme embarrassment at having to hold an ice-pack on his genitals while dozens of medical staff came in to our cubicle and gave their opinion. When that failed to bring down the swelling, he was given morphine, followed by gas and air, while a consultant tried to manipulate his foreskin back into its usual position. Despite being told that we were very lucky that the 'foreskin expert' just happened to be in the hospital and this consultant had 'never encountered one that he could not get back', in the end my son was put under general anaesthetic to drain the fluid by a small incision. I was told that he had a bad attack of balanitis - inflammation of the foreskin - which is why he was complaining of having a sore willy. When he tried to clean it in the bath by pulling back his foreskin, paraphimosis occurred. This is when the retracted circle of foreskin becomes tight and swollen, and then fluid builds up behind the tight ring of skin.

Before he went into the operating theatre I was told that 'he would certainly have to be circumcised at some point and did I want it done now so he would not need another operation?' Even though I was warned that the swelling would make it slightly more tricky, my immediate response was: 'Yes, of course.' I should explain that there is a history of tight foreskins in my family, with one case of circumcision in late childhood. More importantly, I never wanted my son to have to endure this kind of agony again. The consultant added, 'If you had seen as many old men with their foreskins stuck back, as I have, then you'd have no doubts.'

Before signing the consent form, I hesitated just for a moment, however. My son had already gone under the anaesthetic, and standing next to his unconscious form, I suddenly felt that it would be terribly wrong to make this decision on his behalf. I needed to discuss it with him, my husband, my son's father, my doctor and, as it turned out, anyone who could give me an opinion, be it cultural, emotional, sexual or medical.

In the months that followed, I tried to get as much information as possible by raising what I discovered was the highly emotional and pun-ridden ('Let's get straight to the point,' said the urologist; and 'You must read this seminal work') subject of circumcision as often as I could. Both my uncircumcised husband and ex-husband were horrified that I had even considered agreeing to the operation. Meanwhile, my doctor prescribed an antibiotic cream to apply at the slightest sign of swelling and told us to take our time making up our minds.

Jewish friends and a Muslim relative felt that my son's medical problems added weight to the cultural reasons for having their sons circumcised as babies. Religious circumcision may have its origins in ancient Egypt of 3000 BC. It was adopted by the Jews and later the Muslims, possibly as a hygienic measure in a hot and sandy climate. It then became a ritual of religious observance.

Dr Schamroth of the Association of Progressive Mohalim, who performs circumcision on both Jewish and Muslim babies, says that 'it is not a nice thing to have to do to a newborn. As a doctor, I feel that there are no medical disadvantages in later life, though I don't feel there is overwhelming evidence of advantages either. My concern is to make it as untraumatic as possible, with local anaesthetic.'

Talking to friends in mixed marriages with sons was also helpful because of the lengthy debates they had inevitably had during pregnancy. Sandra Rose is married to Paul, with a son aged three and a two-month-old daughter. He is Jewish and she was brought up in a non-religious family of Christian origin. 'The thought of any kind of operation removing healthy tissue was extremely difficult to get my head around,' she said. 'When Daniel was born, we spent three days arguing about it, and in the end I found my husband's religious and emotional reasons - he wanted a son that resembled him and his forefathers - more compelling than my squeamishness. In the event, the circumcision, when Daniel was eight days old, was a deeply moving family event, and Daniel didn't even cry.'

The circumcision debate is not only between non-Jews and Jews and Muslims but international, intergenerational and in the case of my bother-in-law from Guyana - where only men of certain ancestry use circumcision as a mark - intertribal. British men of my grandfather's and father's generation were routinely circumcised at only a few days old. It is likely that circumcision was introduced in this country by doctors who felt that it would discourage masturbation, which was considered to be the cause of a number of illnesses, including epilepsy and blindness. This attitude prevailed until 1935, when the aptly named Dr Cockshut wrote in the British Medical Journal : 'I am convinced that masturbation is much less common in the circumcised - with these considerations in view, it does not seem apt to argue that "God knows best how to make little boys".' Circumcision later came to be considered more 'civilised' in that it was a sign of a hospital birth, and possibly because during both World Wars and the era of National Service, circumcised conscripts suffered from fewer infections if hygiene was poor.

In America, there is now a radical anti-circumcision movement in response to a 60 per cent circumcision rate, which has gone down from nearly 90 per cent. There is also a small movement of American men who attempt to 'grow back' their foreskin by means of bands and weights. In the UK, there is little call for extreme pro- or anti-circumcision groups because a number of factors brought down the rate of circumcision to today's 10 per cent. A highly influential paper, 'The Fate of the Foreskin', was written in 1949 by a Dr Gairder, stating that most boys' foreskins retract naturally by the age of four or five and the rest by adolescence. Also, mothers started to question the practice at the same time as the NHS (where money was always tight) was born and sexual attitudes (masturbation no longer being considered the root of all evil) became more relaxed.

At its most atavistic level, the debate can get nasty. Uncircumcised and circumcised men defend their own penile state. The circumcised are confident that they are smegma free, more aesthetically pleasing, free from cancer of the penis, urinary tract infections, premature ejaculation (I have even heard a circumcised man say that he has a bigger erection because there is no skin holding him back) and are better lovers. The uncircumcised feel they are more sensitive because the foreskin protects the glans, that women find them easier to 'handle' without lubrication. They, too, consider themselves to be better lovers.

Mr Cuckow, consultant paediatrician urologist at London's Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital, says that 'men can be far too concerned with either wanting a circumcision, or regretting one, or in the defending of non-circumcision in the context of the sexual performance. There is such a wide spectrum of normality when it comes to the penis, and sex involves such a huge range of stimuli and sensation, which are not all centred on the tip of the penis.'

Although an important consideration, my son's future sex life is not the only thing I have to think about here. Above all, I don't want him to have to endure repeated discomfort or emergency dashes to the hospital. Cuckow is reassuring. 'At the end of the day, the foreskin is a normal piece of tissue which is not pathological, but like any part of the body, it does need some looking after. Be vigilant about gentle washing and tell your son to retract his foreskin a little when he does a pee.'

In a quiet moment, I gently told my son some of the things I had learned and asked what he thought. I was surprised to hear that although he wasn't that keen on the operation, he would have it done if he could go back to the same hospital - 'because they had the best Nintendo 64 game console that I have ever seen. That's a good enough reason, isn't it?' The decision is on hold.

Circumcision: the facts

The foreskin In most boys, the foreskin (also called a prepuce) is attached to the head of the penis at birth. It keeps the glans soft, moist and sensitive and protects it from exposure and chaffing. During growth and development, the foreskin gradually separates from the head of the penis or glans and it is extremely inadvisable to pull it back forcibly, as unenlightened paediatricians used to do. Consultant Mr Wilcox of the paediatric urology department of Guy's hospital says that this 'may cause tears and scar tissue, which will mean problems in retracting the foreskin later on'.

Problems These three conditions are the most common reasons for medical circumcision but many doctors, urologists and paediatricians would now consider other treatments such as antibiotic and steroid creams as well as gentle and extremely gradual stretching exercises.

 Phimosis, or tight foreskin: a condition in which the foreskin cannot be drawn back. It may cause the foreskin to balloon out on urination, which may in turn cause urinary tract complications.

 Paraphimosis: a condition in which the foreskin, having been retracted, is too tight to re-cover the glans. The trapped foreskin then causes the glans to swell and fill with fluid.

 Balanitis: inflammation of the foreskin or glans. It may be caused by irritants such as soap, a build-up of smegma (natural waxy cream-coloured substance under the foreskin), or friction.

Hygiene One of the reasons many paediatric urologists think that boys have problems with their foreskins is that parents, and particularly mothers, are unwilling or embarrassed to teach boys how to properly clean themselves. In the bath, boys from the age of four or five should be taught to very gently pull back the foreskin a small way and clean as much of the glans and foreskin as they can. As they get older, they will be able to pull the foreskin back further so they can wash away urine and smegma. If the foreskin does get stuck back, then try to firmly pull it back into its normal position as soon as possible because any delay increases the chance of swelling. If this is impossible, then get to hospital as quickly as you can.

Circumcision Circumcision is the surgical removal of the sleeve of skin and mucosal tissue that normally covers the head of the penis. In very repeated cases of infection, medical circumcision may be seriously considered. It is worthwhile getting a second or third opinion from other urologists. In most medical circumcisions, which commonly occur in mid- to late childhood, a general anaesthetic is used, but with infants, a local anaesthetic cream or injection can provide a penile nerve block. Some doctors and all Orthodox Jewish mohels (the men who perform the task) prefer to avoid the small risks posed by anaesthetic agents. There is a good deal of controversy about how much the baby is traumatised by circumcision.

Timing If your child must be circumcised, think carefully about the timing. Penelope Leach recommends that parents wait until the boy is more than six: 'The younger they are, the more difficult it is for them to understand that removing the foreskin will not damage the organ.' If the boy is prepubescent or adolescent and self-conscious, he may find the whole process deeply embarrassing and humiliating. Circumcision is a minor operation, but it can be extremely upsetting.

Recovery Older boys may find the few days after circumcision extremely painful. There are many ways to help keep the pressure off, such as using a sports box or sitting on a beanbag.

www.cirp.org" American, highly researched website with anti-circumcision leanings.
